column8: The game is relaxing and enjoyable, perfect for those who love interior design and decorating.
column9: The snapping and placement mechanics are frustrating and inaccurate.

column8: The game has a lot of potential and is expected to improve with future updates.
column9: The game has numerous bugs and crashes frequently.

column8: There are some bugs and optimization issues, but they are manageable and expected in early access.
column9: The game is not optimized well, leading to performance issues.

column8: The game offers a variety of customization options for furniture and room design.
column9: There is a lack of customization options for furniture and room dimensions.

column8: The story mode includes interesting puzzles and tasks that keep the gameplay fresh.
column9: The controls and user interface are not intuitive or user-friendly.

column8: The sandbox mode allows for creative freedom and extensive customization.
column9: The game feels incomplete and lacks content.

column8: The graphics and lighting are aesthetically pleasing and add to the overall experience.
column9: The story mode and mini-games are not engaging or fun.

column8: The game is compared favorably to other interior design games like The Sims and House Flipper.
column9: The game is not suitable for realistic room planning due to restrictive mechanics.

column8: Players appreciate the ability to mod and the potential for future content through updates.
column9: The graphics and visual design are not appealing to many players.

column8: Some players have experienced issues with controls and UI, but overall find the game intuitive and fun.
column9: The game has potential but needs significant updates and improvements.

column8:
Your enjoyment will depend entirely on what you‚Äôre coming in to this looking for.

If you‚Äôre wanting an RPG experience that captures the player agency and character building that resembles the original game, you‚Äôre not going to get that here. There are no stats and very few differences between the clans outside of narrative flavor.

What it does do well is act as a well written and engaging visual novel. Multiple playthroughs do reward you with more content and context for the characters and I think aid in fleshing out the narrative overall. 

The art style is also fantastic and combined with the music there is a lot of effort put in to immersing you in the story. 

It‚Äôs not for everyone and it‚Äôs not amazing but on sale I do think it‚Äôs worth a look.

column8:
First of all this is not a game, it's a book, or really a short story, and it's mostly pretty underwhelming. It does an okay job introducing you to the setting, but only okay. If you're a fan already, it's kinda an interesting story, but only kinda. Some of the characters and subplots are mildly interesting, but only mildly. You make very few "choices", as far as I could tell, none of them have any impact at all, you rarely use your powers or do anything that feels very vampirey and when you do, that's underwhelming as well. There's even a few points where you'll have the option to do something normal or with a power, and then the text will say, actually it was super easy, didn't even need your powers, just to drive home that your input doesn't matter. An odd choice from the writers.

I bought this on a deep sale and if you want to get it the same way, it's okay. But at full price, there's no way this is worth the money.

I feel like this game can be a good start for anyone that never touched the World of Darkness series, especially the Vampire the Masquerade setting. Because it do give you some basics and a nice starting point to jump into the roleplaying in the later setting. Even for veterans it could be a nice "snack" to play through, but the game is so short that I would recommend to buy it on a sale, because otherwise it is just too much for that full price.

column8:
Es la primera vez que he jugado a un juego de WoD. Llevo unos a√±os queriendo conocer el mundo porque tiene muchos elementos que me pueden atraer. Algunas rese√±as en ingl√©s que indican que esta novela gr√°fica puede servir de introducci√≥n a novatos me ha hecho dar el paso. Como algunos imaginar√°n, parte del impulso para entrar en World of Darkness se debe al pr√≥ximo estreno de Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines 2. Si eres un novato como yo, recomiendo empezar por este juego para ir haci√©ndose una idea de Vampiro. Mi intenci√≥n era jugar a algo breve que me explicara peque√±os detalles de manera org√°nica en lugar de entrar de cabeza en algo que asuma conocimientos previos de la ambientaci√≥n por parte de los jugadores.

Ahora s√≠, hablemos del juego: 
-Es breve (unas nueve horas en mi primera vuelta). Esto es interesante si buscas algo introductorio a lo que dedicar uno o dos d√≠as. La parte mala es, como han indicado algunos jugadores, que acaba de forma abrupta. Aunque entiendo la idea siento que me han lanzado una jarra de agua fr√≠a con hielos al verme plantada frente a ese final. Tengo muchas preguntas que no han quedado resueltas porque hay un contrarreloj que no me ha permitido explorar todas las misiones secundarias y eso puede resultar frustrante para jugadores a los que les gusta conocer todos los detalles posibles sobre los personajes involucrados. Entiendo la decisi√≥n porque la temporalidad del juego no permite que profundices lo suficiente, algo que sucede en el mundo real tambi√©n. 
-Los personajes son interesantes y vemos algunas pinceladas de la vida de cada uno. Lo que no se nos cuenta de forma expl√≠cita se puede deducir, imaginar o ampliar (asumo) en las siguientes entregas. En general me han gustado, incluso reconozco la profundidad a aquellos que no terminan de convencerme. 
-Hay opciones de di√°logo que merece la pena explorar. Es un juego peque√±o, una aventura que podr√≠a durar un par de sesiones (en t√©rminos roleros) y el estudio tengo entendido que era peque√±ito, as√≠ que comprendo que muchas decisiones lleven a la misma conclusi√≥n o l√≠neas de di√°logo muy similares. El final es el que es, he jugado con los tres personajes forzando situaciones distintas, pero en principio solo parece que todo acaba de la misma forma (para m√≠ no es algo negativo, pero puede que algunos jugadores lo vean como tal). 
-La m√∫sica es muy buena, acompa√±a muy bien a las ilustraciones que van a poner color a las partes m√°s decadentes de la ciudad. Es muy acertada. 

Ahora toca hablar de las peores partes del juego:
-Destaco que, a diferencia de juegos del estilo, no se pueden seleccionar cap√≠tulos una vez has terminado el juego. 
-Algo que va de la mano con el punto anterior es que el juego tiene recursos muy buenos para los novatos en vampiro como el diccionario de t√©rminos empleados habitualmente en la ambientaci√≥n‚Ä¶ una idea maravillosa que se derrocha porque cuando tu personaje muere o acabas la partida NO PUEDES VOLVER A TU √öLTIMO GUARDADO. La partida simplemente hace *puff* y se desvive. Tu partida se borra por completo. Me apena terriblemente porque soy una de esas jugadoras pesadas a las que les gusta leer todos los di√°logos y alternativas (algo que hac√≠a mucho en BG3, Dragon Age o Pentiment). Supongo que este punto negativo tendr√≠a sentido para relacionarlo con el realismo de jugar en mesa en el que si tu personaje pasa a mejor vida pues la campa√±a ha terminado para ti, pero no estoy de acuerdo con esta decisi√≥n porque estamos jugando a un videojuego, al fin y al cabo, cada medio tiene sus puntos positivos y sus puntos negativos. 
-Otra parte terrible es la traducci√≥n al espa√±ol. Gracias por traducirlo, supongo, pero creo que han hecho uso de alg√∫n traductor autom√°tico porque muchas partes no ten√≠an sentido (a veces no se tiene en cuenta el g√©nero del personaje al que se est√°n dirigiendo, usan calcos del ingl√©s que no tienen sentido en espa√±ol y cosas del estilo). 

Como conclusi√≥n me gustar√≠a animar a quienes tienen curiosidad por estos juegos que den un paso adelante. Estoy de acuerdo con las notas de 7 √≥ 6, a m√≠ no me gusta calificar una obra en t√©rminos num√©ricos porque suena muy fr√≠o, descontextualizado. Me he divertido jugando y explorando en las distintas vueltas que he dado al juego.

Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York √® una storia interattiva basata sul Mondo di Tenebra in cui √® ambientato il gioco di ruolo Vampiri: La Masquerade. In termini prettamente di gioco, si gioca poco, trattandosi di un racconto interattivo, per cui l'imput del giocatore √® limitato alla scelta del personaggio da interpretare, tra i tre disponibili (Toreador, Ventrue e Brujah) e alla scelta delle opzioni di dialogo e di interazione (comprende l'occasionale utilizzo di poteri vampirici, definiti Discipline). A livello artistico,  ho trovato il gioco molto gradevole, sia nel design dei personaggi, che in quello degli sfondi.
In termini di narrativa, il gioco sa essere molto avvincente. Mi ha coinvolto molto, spingendomi a vedere come finiva, anche se ho qualche riserva sul finale. Per quanto riguarda la rigiocabilit√†, essa dipende pi√π dal fatto che non si possono portare a termine tutte le missioni in una sola partita (il gioco si svolge in un lasso temporale di una quindicina di notti), ma per quello che ho notato, a parte qualche caso specifico, il testo √® pressappoco uguale per tutti e tre i personaggi.
In definitiva, il gioco mi √® piaciuto molto, consiglierei di darci un'occhiata, magari in un periodo in cui √® in sconto.
Reads like leftwing tumbler fan-fiction. Instead of vampire poltics, it's on-the-nose political pandering.
column9: Reads like leftwing tumbler fan-fiction. Instead of vampire poltics, it's on-the-nose political pandering.

column8: a nice little text based game with a lot of reading,the mechanics are not particularly flash out but not shown to be particularly useful either,worth it on sale if you know already the vampire the masquerade franchise for one more taste of it

column8: A New York entry point to VtM. There is no combat or puzzles, so it may not click if you are not into text-driven play, yet the short-story format delivers dense, briskly paced writing.
column9: A New York entry point to VtM. There is no combat or puzzles, so it may not click if you are not into text-driven play, yet the short-story format delivers dense, briskly paced writing.

column8: A fun but short narrative adventure where side quests along the way feel more impactful than they end up. 100% worth it if you buy it on sale. Has atmospheric music, relationships, intrigue, action, cool characters. Railroaded at the end. 4/5

The story is interesting and embodies the vampire masquerade RPG. Interesting character design, you had the option of three clans and run the different missions.
Only thing is you cannot recruit all four for your coterie.

column8:
So below this you will find a spoiler... if you do not know about this spoiler... what happens is so infuriating it makes me want to give this game a negative review.  But if you do know about it and can avoid this disastrous design flaw... I think the game is worth playing.

[spoiler] Don't start the quest to investigate the snooping reporter until you are ready to end the game.  Avoid this quest whenever you have the option while you have other things you want to do.  When you complete this quest, it ends the game abruptly no matter if you have quests to complete (quests that seem really important for the story) or not.

However, it will also make every other quest you did seem pointless and  I am not sure any choices you make affect the outcome of the story. [/spoiler]

column8:
I like this game! It has some deep flaws (the ending comes out of nowhere! it sucks!!) but... the side quests were enchanting. Despite its flaws, I had a LOT of fun playing this.

My recommendation: once you pick a sidequest, follow it all the way through. The game doesn't give enough time to finish them all, so don't leave any half-done!

column8: Jeu chill, narratif, qui permet de d√©couvrir l'univers de vampire la mascarade. La musique est super, l'histoire intrigante...

Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Coteries of New York is a narrative-driven visual novel developed by Draw Distance and set in the rich and complex universe of Vampire: The Masquerade, part of the larger World of Darkness franchise. Released on Steam in 2019, the game offers a more accessible entry point into the gothic-punk world of vampiric politics, morality, and survival, standing apart from the more action-oriented or open-ended Bloodlines title. While much smaller in scope, Coteries of New York delivers a focused, intimate story steeped in atmosphere and character-driven drama, making it an intriguing, if not flawless, addition to the franchise.

You begin the game by choosing one of three vampire characters, each from a different clan‚ÄîVentrue, Toreador, or Brujah. This choice not only determines your character‚Äôs personality and abilities but also subtly influences how the narrative unfolds. The main storyline revolves around your recent Embrace (transformation into a vampire) and your struggle to find a place in the dangerous and often treacherous world of Kindred society. Set in a contemporary, stylized version of New York City, the story takes place in the midst of a growing power struggle between the Camarilla‚Äîthe rigid, authoritarian vampire sect that enforces the Masquerade‚Äîand various other forces threatening its dominance.

The writing is the heart and soul of Coteries of New York, and it largely succeeds in immersing players in the emotional and philosophical weight of vampiric existence. Themes of loss, identity, power, and loyalty are explored through well-crafted dialogue and branching story paths. While the game lacks traditional gameplay mechanics, it excels in choice-driven storytelling. Decisions matter‚Äîsometimes immediately, sometimes subtly across the story‚Äôs duration‚Äîand the game encourages role-playing that reflects your chosen character‚Äôs background and disposition. The interactions with potential coterie members (vampires who may join your group) are particularly compelling, each offering their own backstories, agendas, and moral gray areas. The coterie characters‚Äîsuch as the haunted Nosferatu Hope or the stoic Gangrel Tamika‚Äîare written with nuance and depth, and your evolving relationships with them form the emotional core of the game.

Structurally, the game is relatively linear, though it offers enough branching paths and alternate scenes to encourage multiple playthroughs. The narrative is divided into nights, during which you can choose how to spend your limited time: deepening relationships, investigating key plot threads, or dealing with existential crises. There's an ever-present sense of tension, both from the countdown to a potentially deadly political showdown and from the constant need to balance your hunger for blood with the fragile Masquerade‚Äîthe rule that vampires must keep their existence hidden from humanity. This mechanic is more thematic than gameplay-based, but it adds a layer of psychological weight to your choices. Feeding too often or in reckless ways may lead to consequences, though these are more narratively implied than systemically enforced.

Visually, Coteries of New York employs a mix of still illustrations and ambient effects to create a moody, stylish presentation. The art is evocative, capturing the urban decay and supernatural tension of the World of Darkness. Characters are presented through detailed portraits, each with distinctive visual flair that aligns with their clan and personality. The music and ambient sounds do an excellent job of setting the tone, using dark synths and environmental noises to complement the noir-inspired storytelling. While the visual presentation is limited compared to fully animated games, it succeeds within the visual novel format, evoking a strong sense of place and mood without overstaying its welcome.

One area where Coteries of New York shows its limitations is in its brevity. A single playthrough can be completed in 4‚Äì6 hours, and while multiple endings and character choices offer some replay value, the core plot remains relatively compact. Additionally, players looking for mechanical complexity‚Äîsuch as combat, character builds, or strategic resource management‚Äîmay find the experience too passive. This is a game for readers, for those who enjoy story above all else. There are occasional moments where dialogue branches feel inconsequential or converge too quickly, lessening the impact of some decisions. Moreover, the central plot sometimes takes a backseat to side character development, which, while enriching the world, can leave the main narrative arc feeling underdeveloped by the end.

Despite these shortcomings, Coteries of New York excels at what it sets out to do: telling a grounded, emotionally resonant story in the Vampire: The Masquerade universe. It captures the existential horror, political tension, and moral ambiguity that define the setting, all while being more approachable for newcomers than many previous titles. It doesn‚Äôt try to be an epic or an RPG in the traditional sense‚Äîinstead, it offers a focused, character-driven journey that rewards thoughtful choices and narrative engagement. For fans of visual novels, urban fantasy, or the World of Darkness as a whole, this is a short but memorable experience that offers a taste of the complex underworld lurking beneath modern civilization.

Rating: 7/10
column9:

There's an ever-present sense of tension, both from the countdown to a potentially deadly political showdown and from the constant need to balance your hunger for blood with the fragile Masquerade‚Äîthe rule that vampires must keep their existence hidden from humanity. This mechanic is more thematic than gameplay-based, but it adds a layer of psychological weight to your choices. Feeding too often or in reckless ways may lead to consequences, though these are more narratively implied than systemically enforced.

Visually, Coteries of New York employs a mix of still illustrations and ambient effects to create a moody, stylish presentation. The art is evocative, capturing the urban decay and supernatural tension of the World of Darkness. Characters are presented through detailed portraits, each with distinctive visual flair that aligns with their clan and personality. The music and ambient sounds do an excellent job of setting the tone, using dark synths and environmental noises to complement the noir-inspired storytelling. While the visual presentation is limited compared to fully animated games, it succeeds within the visual novel format, evoking a strong sense of place and mood without overstaying its welcome.

One area where Coteries of New York shows its limitations is in its brevity. A single playthrough can be completed in 4‚Äì6 hours, and while multiple endings and character choices offer some replay value, the core plot remains relatively compact. Additionally, players looking for mechanical complexity‚Äîsuch as combat, character builds, or strategic resource management‚Äîmay find the experience too passive. This is a game for readers, for those who enjoy story above all else. There are occasional moments where dialogue branches feel inconsequential or converge too quickly, lessening the impact of some decisions. Moreover, the central plot sometimes takes a backseat to side character development, which, while enriching the world, can leave the main narrative arc feeling underdeveloped by the end.

Despite these shortcomings, Coteries of New York excels at what it sets out to do: telling a grounded, emotionally resonant story in the Vampire: The Masquerade universe. It captures the existential horror, political tension, and moral ambiguity that define the setting, all while being more approachable for newcomers than many previous titles. It doesn‚Äôt try to be an epic or an RPG in the traditional sense‚Äîinstead, it offers a focused, character-driven journey that rewards thoughtful choices and narrative engagement. For fans of visual novels, urban fantasy, or the World of Darkness as a whole, this is a short but memorable experience that offers a taste of the complex underworld lurking beneath modern civilization.

Rating: 7/10

column8:
I would not recommend to buy this and I'll explain why.

At the beginning it feels like a promising and fleshed out game however you won't be able/allowed to do most of the content because the game forces the story to move on without you as the player being able to do anything about it. Events are hardcoded in to happen no matter what. the mainstory don't even match up with what you've been doing at  all prior to these "main events" happening.

This game is a waste of your time, do not buy it!

column9: love to watch the draculas drink the blood

column8:
Okay, first let's get this out of the way: I was misschieved by the game. They made me think my decisions would have a genuine impact on the ending. Spoiler: The ending is unvariable no matter which character you start with, no matter which companions you get, and no matter if you manage well your Hunger or not. So be aware of this before you give it a go.

Now, there is one thing that you can control: the companions you get and the side-quest you take. You may not choose the ending of the story, but you can choose the road you take to get there. The stories are okay. They do not blow my mind, but they are good enough to be enjoyed. 

The game can be completed in one evening and that gives it a plus with the little time I have to play now a days.

Coming from a background of playing a lot (and I mean, A LOT) of VTM, the tabletop roleplaying game (V20, Dark Ages, and V5) and after reading a lot of the source material, I can say that the game is a great introduction to the narrative you can expect from this setting. This is a world of fishes trying to eat eachother outside of your Neonate's hands. Not only the side-stories reflect this very well, but the ending is a prime example of it.

And, writting this having played the second one (Shadows), I can say that having played this game before allowed me to get more hints about the situation and really helped to improve the experience.

So,  if you are planning on getting the full pack (the complete trilogy), this game is, in my opinion, a must play. As I said, it is not a long game and, even if the ending does not really change, it is well enough sewn that you really do not notice until you give it a second playtrough.

And, please, play Shadows. It is the better version of the game.

Not very long to play through and while the choices decide some of the scenes you go through and people you befriend/recruit they don't feel like they have much impact on any of the important parts of the story. And for the small choices, what to say and how to deal with a situation, they most often felt pointless.

This is terrible. The ending just felt so rushed. I had created the habit of playing one in-game night per day right before I sleep, and I confess in the beginning it was really good, I was hyped all through to the end. 

Then the end came, and that's what ruined the game completely. It just came out of nowhere, I'm not sure what triggers the end game events but then each night the game takes control from your choices and pushes you towards these events, I couldn't complete the other missions I planned on doing for the other characters, missed a tonne of gameplay.

Played entirely on Steam Deck: compatibility mode > Proton Experimental is needed otherwise sounds will be disabled.

column8: This isn't really worth the money or time put into it. It plays like a "choice of games" interactive novel, but with a visual novel interface, and less overall quality.

column8:
Probably one of my favourite games ever. I have been tiptoeing around the World of Darkness for half my life and this was an amazing introduction. I played as Toreador and it felt like coming home. The fact that you can't go back in the story made me really think through my decisions, which I quite enjoyed. The art style, plot(s) and characters are just amazing. 

There's a lot of "lore dump", so if you're already a VTM expert this may feel a bit tedious. For newbies it may also be a bit much. But I personally enjoyed it as a kind of VTM tutorial. 

The end came a bit fast but it's also fun to replay so you can finish the other quest lines. 

The second game is a bit different and you can't import your character sadly. So this works as a standalone story just as well.

Outside of the excellent art style, sound/music design, and general WoD vibes, the story is...okay-ish at best and disappointing at worst. While playing, you feel like multiple plotlines are being set up and leading up to something interesting and cool, only to find out this is not the case. I will not spoil anything, but keep your expectations low when it comes to the overall story. I would say that the game would not be worth more than 5 euros, so instead of buying it for 20, wait for a discount to buy it instead of full price.

column8:
I would recommend this ONLY if you are interested in Vampire: The Masquerade and want to delve into its lore a bit from a neonate's point of view. For a first taste of the RPG, it's fine. I love the whole urban horror and World of Darkness vibe, and it's somewhat satiated my appetite. Plus the fact that it comes with a dictionary for the terminology is great for someone new.

BUT. If you're looking for a game/visual novel where your decisions carry weight and there's replayability, turn around; you won't find it here. There are three clans to choose from, and the only thing that changes is the slight flavor of some dialogue at certain points. The rest, once seen for the first time, can be skipped with the CTRL key at maximum speed; it's irrelevant. The only reason to replay it would be to see the end of some sidequests or completing the storyline of one of the 4 companions available to unlock, and even then this barely has any impact on the end of the game in the slightest except for some flavor again.

So, that's it, a good start for a newbie to Vampire The Masquerade, a relatively interesting story that more or less shows us how Kindred society works, but it feels more like a book accompanied by art (beautiful, it must be said), with 0 replayability or variations based on decisions.

column8:
Even though the game is far from perfect, I really enjoy it. I've already played all three characters on my PS and decided to refresh my memory, and the second playthrough was as enjoyable. Somehow the writing feels so nice, as well as the atmosphere and the characters around the protagonists. They are all really well-written and are the main reason why I enjoy the game so much. And of course the artwork. The artists did a great job, backgrounds and character sprites feel incredible - I absolutely adore this semi-sketchy, painterly style. Amazing, a joy for the eye.
However it leaves on a very unsatisfying note and the ending feels rushed, so it is a rather bittersweet experience. Awesone game, but the finale sucks

I've been fond of the lore of The Masquerade since playing Bloodlines over 20 years ago. Coteries of New York has the same commitment to world-building and vibes in a smaller package, but no less robust, and the text-based gameplay arguably allows this game to focus on what this series can do best.

Coteries of New York has the same commitment to world-building and vibes in a smaller package, but no less robust, and the text-based gameplay arguably allows this game to focus on what this series can do best.

[/] it's a visual novel
[x] doesn't take too long to complete a run, even if you do zone out occasionally and listen to stuff
----
[x] new york, new york it's a hell of a town
[x] doesn't require you to know the whole corebook
[x] a bunch of memorable characters
[x] good soundtrack, couple of standouts here
[x] multiple clan pathways, some replayablility
[ ] some sequences are more scripted than others, even with the visual novel stuff
[ ] a "dramatis personae" character list alongside the dictionary could have been handy
[ ] an eventual [sans undertale talking noises] exposition dump regarding your vulnerabilities
----

A surprisingly good intro to vampire the masquerade.  Concepts are explained as the game goes on, and there's always a dictionary if you forget what a term is.  There are a number of storylines that you can't complete all of them, which gives space for replayability.  The game also doesn't pull any Main Character punches - you will eventually run into characters that are far more powerful and important than you and you will have to eat any insults thrown your way - or be shown your place if you decide to play up.  

My only real criticisms are that I wouldn't mind a list of characters alongside the dictionary.  I forgot a character's name and lucked my way through a conversation option to get information I wanted to progress the story - or at least, I [i]thought[/i] I lucked my way through. The story ends pretty much the same way each run, so conversation options don't [i]really[/i] matter too much when you're going to eventually end up in the same spot.  

Worth getting on sale, a good distraction for a few hours

column8: Um bom jogo para quem gosta do g√™nero. √â um romance contado e jog√°vel. Suas escolhas durante os di√°logos ditam os pr√≥ximos fatos da novela. A ambienta√ß√£o Vampiro a Mascara 5¬™ edi√ß√£o em Nova York √© perfeita.

I got this at 85% discount and I'm still pissed off. Had I paid full prize, I would consider this one of the biggest ripoffs of my life.

Where to start?
Well, first of all, it took me less than 10 hours to complete all three storylines with almost all achievements. And this is because the "three" storylines share about 90% of the content. The only reason to play this more than once is to finish all the quests, and to do so, in the second/third playtrhough you can just keep clicking whatever.

Careful: MILD SPOLIERS

And you can do that because the weight of your decissions is almost zero. Yeah, you can "lose" the sidequests, but I was as least expecting some different endings. Not here. If the game wanted to make you feel that as a neonate your doings mean nothing... well, accomplished. 

The story is not good enough to compensate this. Once you assume that you have bought 'a book', you at least expect to be a good one. And again, no. Mediocre at best. There are a couple of characters that are interesting, but that is all.

Special mention to the part where the game tells yoy that you need to feed but gives you no chance. You just stumble into it.

The art is cool, but if you only are using background images, at least do not recycle them. Am I too exigent expecting that the alley near X house uses a different scenary from the alley behind Y park?

Overall, this would be a game you buy for 2‚Ç¨ to kill an afternoon to play tag-along and get someone introduced to the 'Vampire the Masquerade' world. But that is all, and I'm sad about it. 

Aw, Christof Romuald... I miss you so bad.

I expected this to have more RPG elements to it, but a choose your own adventure story placed in this setting is just fine. I liked the music and the minimalist animation to the background images. It set the scenes well.

The standard price is absurdly high for this. Get it on deep sale.

If you are into interactive vampire novels, look no further! Very well written, very engaging, the characters are excellent. A great yet different kind of game.
It is an interactive novel based in the Vampire the Masquerade universe.
I think the writers did a great job at setting the mood and create interesting characters for the different clans.
I enjoyed my time playing this game and as long as you now what you are getting into it is definately worth the price.

An interesting visual novel from a World of Darkness universe - that I really enjoy. As a visual novel, its quite niche and something I do not generally play. 

Still, it kept me hooked and interested in the story to finish the game and feel like it wasn't a waste of time. Especially at the start of the game when you were forced to role-play as someone who doesn't know what is happening. 

The dialogues were not a masterpiece, but they did deliver. The music was fine and art as well, at least as much as you can expect from very simple visual novel game. 

The gameplay... well‚Ä¶ you are just reading... mostly. Occasionally deciding, whether to drink from someone or not, or use one of your powers or not. Very simple promise, that drove me crazy. Why? The indication how much I can use my powers wasn't clear at all, I never knew when I would have another opportunity to drink, so most of the time I was just worrying and saving my powers and therefore basically role-played a human. Someone might say, its a me problem, but I would say: [i]"No. Its game design issue. The game should let me know what I can and can't do and control, without having to play the whole game first. If I can just lean, as the game progresses its fine to have some learning curve. But here I just had no idea for the entirety of the game. The blood indicator on the screen was definitely not enough for me."[/i]

Fortunately, even though it bothered me, it didn't take away from story too much and I generally enjoyed it reading and experiencing. It wasn't anything groundbreaking, but it delivered the enjoyment that I was satisfied with, even though it fell short near the climax. 
Its a shame though that you couldn't finish all side stories, as there is a limit of how many turns you can play the game. That sucked, because I started with stories of characters that I had least interest in, thinking that I will just finish those first before I get to the good ones. However, I hit the limit and then I was stuck with what I had done and no way to go back unless I want to start the game from scratch. That really sucked, but fortunately, those side stories that I chose to finish first weren't all that bad and in the end, I think I enjoyed them. But it still pisses me off.

In the end, the game was fine. The most telling statement from my review, that reflects what I think, is [b]"feel like it [the game] wasn't a waste of time"[/b]. Take it a as a recommendation or not, but it generally more for World of Darkness fans then anyone else.

Tolle Visual Novel. Und Vampire The Masquerade ist sowieso ein toller Teil des World of Darkness Universums

Writing a review after I've played all three games of this VN series. 

Coteries is my favorite from the series. Compelling story, intriguing art and characters, the mood is immersive. None of the other two VNs could achieve that, especially not Reckoning.  

I started playing not knowing anything about the World of Darkness series, and this was a pleasant surprise. The game has some choices, but no different endings, and the outcome does not seem to play a big part in the following stories. It leaves a lot of open story threads behind, but the mystery is appealing, and you don't expect all your questions to be answered.

I think this game is ok. If I could rate it "meh" between yes and no for reccomending it, I would. Like, if you like VNs, you could like it. But it has very limited agency in terms of choices, as well as routes. There is only 1 main ending excluding 2 extra endings you can get at the start for dying early. While events can be interesting and varied, only few end up influencing the ending - even then, only in bits and pieces.

The music and art direction is gorgeous so that is a feast for the eyes and ears, imo. Unfortunately the story feels really lacking towards the end - it has a nice crescendo, up until it straight up screeches to a halt where everything happens all at once, making everything feel unsatisfactory and rushed. The ending for me also felt very "welcome to the game 2" style. Lots of words only for the whole thing to end with a sudden transition into credits...

Now I have to at least try and get into the next two games just to know wtf happens with Qamar. Damn you lol

This is a borderline thumbs up from me. As someone that's associated with VTM for a very long time, there were parts of the atmosphere that I felt were quite fitting, and there were some characterizations that I enjoyed. From a VN perspective I think that the backgrounds and settings were nice and had some dynamics which was appreciated compared to many VNs using static backgrounds and the like, but the overall writing and plot left something to be desired. It wasn't bad for a single playthrough though and I don't feel like I wasted my time, which is why it gets a thumbs up, but would be a 6/10 for a score.

- it is barely half a game, ending abruptly midway of story

- devs are lying (insert your favorite adjective here) that promised translation of game and didnt delivered, ignoring many players that ask about this

column8:
Great game if you're looking for a good read. 

Went into it wanting to survive and do some whacky stuff but was pleasantly surprised by the well written scenes, the prose and by extension, the artwork. Switched to playing with the purpose of emulating how I believed the character I was using would respond to certain situations and it was a blast. 

Would have preferred features like lone feeding spots, a Beast meter, randomised events (SI attacks, unpredictable NPC run-ins, hidden companions in insignificant side quests) and a levelling system with clan-specific ability trees. 

Other than that, knocked out the park. Hits different with dimmed lights and bitter coffee. My tongue hates me but I like what I see, so my eyes don't.

8/10. Pain-staking for some vampires, but we're masquerading with this one.

column8:
Pretty good as virtual novels go. If you like VNs, Vampire: the Masquerade, or both, I recommend you get the game.

Positives:
A colorful cast of characters representing the complexities of Camarilla and Anarch politics. 
Enough side quests that the world feels lived in, and a good enough pay off at the end to make it feel like those side quests are meaningful. 
Additional positive - the payoff I mentioned gives good replayability.

Negatives:
There are almost always only three options, including at character creation. Out of the thirteen+ clans in VTM, only Ventrue, Brujah, and Toreador are represented; given the roleplay-heavy nature of visual novels, I would have liked a Malkavian option.
No Sabbat. For all the vampire politicking, there was no Lasombra and/or Tzimisce archbishop around, or at least, none I encountered on my first run.
Additional negative - there's no way, as far as I can tell, for a Brujah to defect to the Anarchs. Come on devs, that's the most obvious reason to play a Brujah!

column8:
Just played through the whole of this game.

Was captivated the whole time. Loved the different narrative threads. Great use of a few hours of you want a great story of a vampire thrown into a well-written universe.

Was disappointed however to find out via other reviews that, despite being a narrative driven game, [spoiler]your actions have very little impact on the outcome of the story. I was quite prepared to replay the game to see different characters and outcomes but after seeing that I am much less inclined, which is disappointing as I would have liked to do that whilst collecting achievements.[/spoiler] I have just purchased one of the sequels that was on sale. But the reviews for that seem to state the same issue. I will still play it but it is very disheartening as someone that very much enjoys those kind of story games and was willing to invest a lot of time into the game and it's sequels.

column8: Buena trama

i was really enjoying this visual novel and then it cut me off midway through exploring everything and jumped me to the end of the story in what felt like an incredibly odd and disjointed way! i would've loved to be able to dive into all of the storylines with one character as i'm not someone who often replays games but, instead, i find myself feeling majorly disappointed with the direction this game went. there were so many interesting plotlines that i wanted to explore!! but the game said no!!! what the fuck!

i adore the VtM universe and was really enjoying the game's writing and then I got to a certain point and the game decided my playthrough was over. major enjoyment killer. the characters feel interesting and very VtM, i wasn't expecting the twist at the end at all in that it came out of nowhere and had (from my perception) barely hinted at anything that was "revealed" in the final scenes. started so strong and good but holy fuck i hate when games do this.

i can't in good conscience recommend this game without giving a heavy warning beforehand, the abruptness of the ending left me with an incredibly bad taste in my mouth despite how strongly the game started.

achievements gotten:
The Managerial Call
A Walk in the Park
Good Job, Mods
Sweet Smell of Success
Consider This My Resignation Letter
Enchanted To Meet You
Get Out Of Here, Stalker
Wild at Heart
Beast Mode
Hope is a Dangerous Thing...
...Damned If You Do

column8:
O jogo n√£o √© nada impressionante e n√£o faz jus a toda a gl√≥ria e reputa√ß√£o de Vampiro: A Mascara.
Mesmo assim o jogo √© muito interessante especialmente para jogadores e narradores de Vampiro. Um ponto em que sem d√∫vida alguma o jogo acerta √© em trabalhar bem a imers√£o do que √© ser um vampiro no World of Darkness, atrav√©s de uma narrativa um pouco mais detalhado voc√™ consegue ter acesso ao que um vampire sente no seu dia a dia. E isso faz do jogo uma boa forte de inspira√ß√£o para narradores de RPG.

Interesting characters, choices & story. I almost wanted to replay it right away to get to know different characters and see how it plays out, but I need to clear my backlog and I already installed the sequel.

Es el primer juego de Vampire que he jugado y ten√≠a muchas ganas. La historia es buena, los personajes interesantes, los dibujos son preciosos, lo malo es que la traducci√≥n en castellano es regular. Mi personaje es una joven vampira pero cuando interact√∫a con otros personajes hablan como si fuera un tio, y eso para la inmersi√≥n en la ambientaci√≥n y atmosfera es algo HORRIBLE.

A good introduction into the world of Vampire the Masquerade. I enjoyed the overall story, the visuals and the narration. Also, the music, even though the end credit song could have been more meaningfull. The game gave me a good impression of a life as a new born vampire - and I liked that. Even though I've had my share with this world (through pen & paper games and good old bloodlines) I learned some new things and never got bored. 

Nevertheless I think, especially for a visual novel like this, there are things that could be better. For example.. choices. 
Only one true ending, really? That feels poor, really. But it feels wrong since the game continually stresses the importance of being careful.  The game gives me the impression that the life as a newly embraced vampire is difficult. But there‚Äôs no mechanics that would support it, so it makes me feel like I‚Äôve been promised things and then didn't get them.

There were also moments that broke the realism of the game: After the tutorial, at one point the game acts as if I had made a bad decision. It simply assumes that I was rude - but I wasn't! This seems really poorly written to me and shouldn't be in a game like this. 

I would also have liked the option to play as another female person - if I want to be Brujah or Tremere I have to be a guy.  
The main character feels okay-ish, but at some point I (playing as Ventrue) could drink up any blood which seemed strange to me, since I yet learned in the tutorial that my protagonist was very specific about the blood type. 
The pacing of the story feels a little bit off, too: The desciption in steam sounds like it is all about a fight between the Camarilla and the Anarchs, yet the game pushes to the ending once you've been introduced to some people of the Anarch. I've found this to be very sad, since I actually liked the Anarchs! Well.. at least some of them.

I would have also enjoyed some more expressions of my main character of choice.. she always looks the same, however I play her. 

For a visual novel that lacks game choices that make a replay fun, Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York is nice. Wouldn't recommend it outside of a sale - buy it if you'd like some nice texts about vampires and a story that is compelling but not too deep.

El arte est√° chulo, la m√∫sica est√° chula y la historia promete. Los detalles acerca del Ansia y la Humanidad est√°n bien (aunque ¬øalguien entiende c√≥mo funciona lo de usar los poderes y sufrir Ansia? ¬øPor qu√© tengo Ansia cuando bebo? ¬°Deber√≠a ser al rev√©s!). No est√° exento de alg√∫n bug extra√±o, pero bueno.

El problema es que la trama es un mierdote. Pasas las noches enfrascado en miniquests para conseguir amigos y nada de eso importa porque al final que pim que pam y zas, y si te has quedado igual que antes pues mala suerte. Si juegas con otro personaje igual con un poco de suerte entiendes qu√© ha pasado algo mejor.

La verdad es que no puedo recomendarlo aunque algunas cosas me hayan gustado. Sencillamente no funciona como juego ni como novela visual.

A beautiful execution of one's introduction into the World of Darkness. Coteries of New York makes every choice feel different enough (once getting past night 1) that you'll find yourself starting anew to try out the other routes this game offers. If virtual novels are your thing consider giving this rendition of VTM a shot.

column8:
Visual novel breve ambientata nell'universo Vampire The Masquerade.

La storia si svolge a New York in modo lineare dal punto di vista di tre personaggi appartenenti a tre linee di sangue diverse: Toreador (Artista), Ventrue (Dirigente), Bruja (Testa calda) 

In base alle scelte del giocatore cambieranno alcune route e interazioni dei personaggi ma la dirittura di arrivo √® sempre la stessa. Non aspettatevi finali alternativi.

Nel nome del gioco viene messo in risalto anche il concetto di "Coterie", ovvero un gruppo di vampiri unito da uno scopo comune. L'obiettivo √® dunque ovviamente quello di farsi alleati. Ci sono vari personaggi con cui interagire ma gli alleati principali con le loro storie da seguire e completare sono 4: 

Un Ventrue (Stregone del sangue), Un Nosferatu (Deforme investigatore), una Malcavian (Geniale lunatica) e una Gangrel (Selvaggia misteriosa). 

Nel complesso √® un bel gioco. In saldo costa appena due caff√®, offre una storia interessante, le grafiche sono basilari ma carine e sopratutto c'√® una sezione glossario comoda per familiarizzare con i termini di VTM. 

Consigliato.

ùôëùòºùôàùôãùôÑùôçùôÄ ùôèùôÉùôÄ ùôàùòºùôéùôåùôêùôÄùôçùòºùòøùôÄ - ùòæùô§ùô©ùôöùôßùôûùôöùô® ùô§ùôõ ùôâùôöùô¨ ùôîùô§ùôßùô† 
[ MINOR SPOILERS ]

Non so neanche come cominciare. Se √® un bene? Relativamente. 
Questa visual novel mi ha veramente lasciato l'amaro in bocca, stupendomi proprio all'ultimo minuto. Sono una persona che apprezza sempre ogni tipo di finale, non pretendendo di rimanere chiss√† quanto colpita se la storia in s√® non mi ha suscitato granch√®. Ma qui, quando per tutto il gioco credevo di non essermi affezionata chiss√† quanto a un personaggio in particolare, all'ultimo mi sono dovuta ricredere. Il gioco, illudendoti di poter fare qualcosa per evitare che accada quell'evento, ti lascia di stucco. Ormai abituata ai soliti clich√®, mentirei se dicessi che mi aspettavo il solito good ending. Eppure non riesco a smettere di pensare a quanto mi abbia colpita la fine di Coteries of New York. Certo, √® un finale pressoch√® mediocre, perch√® a dirla tutta la trama non ha mai spiccato di originalit√†, infatti non mi riferisco a quell'aspetto, bens√¨, a ci√≤ che mi ha impattato emotivamente. Ma ora, passiamo all'analisi vera e propria.
Ho iniziato questa vn all'incirca un anno fa, aspettandomi tanto ma rimanendo annoiata dalla prima parte di gioco. Ci ho messo 10 mesi (?) a convincermi di continuarla, per poi effettivamente finirla in soli 2 giorni. 
L'incontro col principe, secondo il mio umile parere, √® stato davvero una rottura di cojoni. MA! Perch√® c'√® un "ma"; tutto questo √® ovviamente fondamentale per dare delle basi semi-solide al resto del gameplay. 
Specifico di aver giocato nei panni della Ventrue, perci√≤ l'inizio non √® stato minimamente movimentato, anzi. La storia comincia a diventare interessante dopo che la bellissima Sophie ci prende sotto la sua ala, dandoci la libert√† di muoverci per la citt√† liberamente, a partire dalla 5/6 notte. Ed √® l√¨, che per me √® scattata la scintilla. Mi sono mangiata il resto di Coteries in men che non si dica, appassionandomi sempre pi√π al personaggio che impersonavo, sentendomi effettivamente all'interno di New York nei panni di un vampiro. Le opzioni di dialogo sono la mia parte preferita, siccome si discostano dai soliti discorsi politically correct che potresti trovare in altre vn a scelte. Certo, vista la vasta gamma di dialoghi, la personalizzazione del personaggio sarebbe stata grandiosa, ma con un po' di fantasia puoi accontentarti. 
Non mi va comunque gi√π, sia chiaro. 
Ma allora, avendo tutte queste opzioni di dialogo, perch√® non creare finali diversi? Voglio dire, i vari bad ending durante il gioco non mancano, ma √® molto diffcile ottenerli siccome sembra sempre di essere protetti da una rete di salvataggio che scatta nel momento in cui il nostro protagonista √® in pericolo.
Nonostante questo, ho apprezzato molto l'insieme totale del gioco, lasciandomi soddisfatta dell'esperienza totale. Lo consiglierei? S√¨, ma solo se si √® qualcuno con molta pazienza e uno spirito creativo che pu√≤ apprezzare le piccolezze quali le personalit√† discostanti dei personaggi, i quali sembrano quasi vivi. Hope ne √® l'esempio per eccellenza! 
Oh, un'ultima pecca. Le descrizioni chilometriche. Non fraintendetemi, amo immedesimarmi il pi√π possibile, perci√≤ credo siano fondamentali per un'esperienza di gioco pi√π completa! Ma dio, non ho bisogno di leggere 20 paragrafi di descrizione del vicolo che ho appena imboccato.

Decent as a book, not so much as a game

Bit too linear, some responses change nothing, outside of... needing to click in different place, three different clans do give you different choices and slightly changed course of actions... but it all comes down to the same "use power to win or not to see someone do the work for you". I get that it needs you to progress and abandons the standard aproach of VNs to just save and replay after every fail or change to the story, but it doesn't really let you fail outside of prologue and you can forget branching in this narrow walled off experience.

Outside of few cringe texts it wasn't a bad experience and again, as a book it wasn't, so for someone who doesn't care about all the choices and simply likes to read it will be fine, especially with the bonus lore from journal that expand on rather vague dialogues and explanations of the world by characters themselves

Animated backgrounds and overall style of drawings are great, but characters could use few more poses and emotions, not to mention some more sound effects at least after player actions

As a game 5/10, as a book 7/10 cos I like the world of darkness

column8:
It's.....fine? For 2 bucks (super sale) it's great but for 19, it's a waste, imo.

It's a visual novel where your choices, ultimately, don't matter. The flavor of the scenes change a bit depending on choices you make, but the ending stays the same, no matter what. That annoys me.

Characters are interesting and the graphics are cool.

Nice expression of WoD. Far more complex than the first opus (still enjoyable but quite short)

I usually am not a fan of V5 in general, but as soon as you take that aside, Coteries is a really fun VTM novel. Definitely better than whatever else (*empty desert wind SFX*) they're making for the IP nowadays. (Though the text CYOAs were good)

Bis jetzt gef√§llt mir das spiel, sehr gut ist. Wer auf Vampir Storys steht, wird hier bestens bedient. Das Game ist auch deutlich umfangreicher als gedacht. Sch√∂n finde ich es das es eine Deutsche √úbersetzung gibt, ist hoffe das diese bei den anderen auch nachgereicht wird.

I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs a good or a bad thing that I played the Shadows before this game. Maybe if I didn‚Äôt, I had lower expectations and enjoyed it more. Or maybe, I decided not to touch the Shadows at all.

Can‚Äôt say this is a bad read but it‚Äôs sure disappointing. The lack of meaningful choices is always sad in a game when those are literally the only gameplay. I understand why there is only one true ending, on a meta-level ‚Äî [spoiler] a young vampire can‚Äôt hope to win in a game of Elder, Jyhad, yada yada. For the purpose of introduction into the VTM setting it works. I get the message. And look, I love a good tragedy, I have no the problem with the MC ending up in a bad place in the end.[/spoiler] I do think that the message would work better if you could actually mess up along the way.

The game stresses out since the begging the importance of feeding ‚Äî but it doesn't matter, even if the MC does ended up starving themselves and killing a rando near their heaven, there would be no consequences. Insult every single important Kindred you meet, brake the Masquerade as many times as you want, fail to recruit anyone into your Coterie ‚Äî it doesn't matter, you'll get to the end regardless. And it‚Äôs sad. I think it would me much more interesting if it was possible to fail. Actually get executed for breaching the Masquerade, [spoiler] taken by the SI [/spoiler] if you fail to build the Coterie, piss off enough important people to [spoiler] not impress Arturo in the end so he wouldn‚Äôt even bother to offer you his blood. [/spoiler] Anything, just one of this things would make the difference for me. And it would better suited the idea I think: [spoiler] no matter how much you succeed, in the end you‚Äôre just an Elder‚Äôs pawn. [/spoiler] You struggle, you finally get to the end and you get‚Ä¶ well, you know what.

I was disappointed that if I wanted to play a female character, I only could choose Ventrue. But then I thought, okay, maybe the game will do something interesting with the MC‚Äôs special drinking preferences and it‚Äôll be fun. And it was, in the beginning. There was even the scene when Ventrue‚Äôs Compulsion took over the MC and I loved it. But after the ‚Äútutorial‚Äù part with Sophie was over, the story immediately forgot about all that and the MC could drink from anyone without any problem.

The game makes it sound like being a newly embraced vampire is difficult. But there‚Äôs no mechanics that would support it, so it makes me feel like I‚Äôve been promised things and then didn't get them.

Plus, the MC overall feels like the weakest point in the whole writing. They are too developed to be an empty slate, so I can‚Äôt roleplay them as I want (I know how my Ventrue used to spent her free time until the promotion, how she feels about the company she‚Äôs working on, when was her last one night stand etc ect), but not developed enough for it to feel like a personal story (like it is with Julia in the Shadows). So I stuck in this weird, unsatisfying middle ground.

Also, if you believe the Steam description, the story is supposed to be about the struggle between the Camarilla and the Anarchs. But almost all the time you play you are with the Camarilla, and when you finally get to hang out with the Anarchs, the game pushes you to the ending like two night later. But with everything above, it‚Äôs a minor complaint.

On the bright side, the character art is noticeably better done in the Coteries than in the Shadows (aside from a few exceptions, like the Ventrue MC). Different artists, as I found out. Shame they didn‚Äôt improve it in the future.
column9:

Actually get executed for breaching the Masquerade, [spoiler] taken by the SI [/spoiler] if you fail to build the Coterie, piss off enough important people to [spoiler] not impress Arturo in the end so he wouldn‚Äôt even bother to offer you his blood. [/spoiler] Anything, just one of this things would make the difference for me. And it would better suited the idea I think: [spoiler] no matter how much you succeed, in the end you‚Äôre just an Elder‚Äôs pawn. [/spoiler] You struggle, you finally get to the end and you get‚Ä¶ well, you know what.

I was disappointed that if I wanted to play a female character, I only could choose Ventrue. But then I thought, okay, maybe the game will do something interesting with the MC‚Äôs special drinking preferences and it‚Äôll be fun. And it was, in the beginning. There was even the scene when Ventrue‚Äôs Compulsion took over the MC and I loved it. But after the ‚Äútutorial‚Äù part with Sophie was over, the story immediately forgot about all that and the MC could drink from anyone without any problem.

The game makes it sound like being a newly embraced vampire is difficult. But there‚Äôs no mechanics that would support it, so it makes me feel like I‚Äôve been promised things and then didn't get them.

Plus, the MC overall feels like the weakest point in the whole writing. They are too developed to be an empty slate, so I can‚Äôt roleplay them as I want (I know how my Ventrue used to spent her free time until the promotion, how she feels about the company she‚Äôs working on, when was her last one night stand etc ect), but not developed enough for it to feel like a personal story (like it is with Julia in the Shadows). So I stuck in this weird, unsatisfying middle ground.

Also, if you believe the Steam description, the story is supposed to be about the struggle between the Camarilla and the Anarchs. But almost all the time you play you are with the Camarilla, and when you finally get to hang out with the Anarchs, the game pushes you to the ending like two night later. But with everything above, it‚Äôs a minor complaint.

On the bright side, the character art is noticeably better done in the Coteries than in the Shadows (aside from a few exceptions, like the Ventrue MC). Different artists, as I found out. Shame they didn‚Äôt improve it in the future.

column8: Pretty fun visual novel. Really short, and the choices like, almost entirely don't matter, despite the game presenting them as if they do, but there's a lot to love. The characters are unique and likeable, the artstyle fits the universe perfectly, and I just think it's neat.

column8: Bom novel

My first-time experience playing a visual novel. Second-time experience in Vampire: The Masquerade's rich universe.

First things first, I am impressed by the fullness of the universe. The player gets everything explained by a built-in vocabulary. Vampire rules, hierarchy, clans, abilities ‚Äî I find each part amazing. I was fully involved in the process.

The visual style is outstanding. Backgrounds are slightly animated, with shifting clouds, silhouettes, and some excellent lightwork bringing a ton of atmosphere to a setting that demands it. Music and sounds are pretty okay. Characters and their storylines are well-written.

What is questionable:
- Sometimes felt a lack of choices for a reply.
- I didn't have an opportunity to feed for a few days, thought it was leading to 'Game Over,' but... it actually didn't affect anything?
- For second and more playthroughs, there should be skips for known dialogs.

P. S. And every time I see Sophie stick her finger through her lower lip (where her tongue is), I can't unsee it.

column8:
Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York est une exp√©rience narrative se d√©roulant dans le riche univers des Vampires. En bref, elle met en sc√®ne la lutte de pouvoir entre deux factions de vampires ‚Äì la Camarilla et les Anarch ‚Äì le tout baignant dans les feux nocturnes. C'est un bon Visuel Novel. Y a-t-il beaucoup de fins et de choix diff√©rents √† faire ? Non. L'histoire qui est racont√©e est-elle bonne ? Oui.

En gros, c'est une histoire int√©ressante et captivante. L'ouverture est par contre tr√®s longue. Le reste a des personnages tr√®s cr√©dibles et un flux tr√®s agr√©able. La bande sonore est tout simplement sid√©rale et quelques pistes ont fait leur entr√©e dans la playlist de fond moody, c'est obscur et tr√®s atmosph√©rique.

Le travail artistique est incroyablement bien fait. Pour la plupart, ils ne sont jamais r√©utilis√©s au point de devenir ennuyeux, √† l'exception du d√©cor de la ruelle sombre.

L'histoire est tr√®s solide. Elle a ses moments creux o√π elle se tra√Æne un peu, mais dans l'ensemble, il n'y a pratiquement pas de remplissage inutile et c'est un bon passage.

Vous recevrez 4 cartes sur 8 et 28 succ√®s facilement. Je recommande ce Visual Novel qui exploite parfaitement les th√®mes matures du Monde des T√©n√®bres pour le plaisir d'une bonne lecture.

Amicalement,
Le pasteur
.

column8:
Very frustrating at times, great at other times. I'd give it a neutral review. Scratches the itch, but is also quite frustrating at times. It has serious problems with BOTH of its core mechanics: choices and hunger.

An interesting book with good pictures and atmospheric background sound, but it's not a game where you choose your journey. Your choices in many cases are made for you regardless which options you actually select. Quite frustrating.

1. CHOICES. You are given choices of how you behave, then the game reports on your choices, but after that the story moves like you didn't act that way, but instead as if you've acted the way the story expected you to. Super confusing.

2. HUNGER. Your hunger level is ABSOLUTELY unclear. At some points you see the blood on the left side of your screen (the cue you are told in tutorial which indicates you are hungry) and then it disappears without you feeding. At other times you don't see the blood on the side of your screen and the beast takes over. VERY confusing. Even though I feed at every single opportunity the game presents to me. Feels like there is no point in trying to control your hunger and the beast events are just scripted to happen. I just killed a person in beast mode right outside my home. The next evening the sheriff turns up and completely ignores that fact. Just goes on where the story is intended to go next. 

This makes the story very disjointed. Feels completely streamlined. Pretends to be a game of choices, where in reality your choices are ignored and replaced by game developers choices. Maybe they need to use AI to make the game actually as flexible as they market it to be.

An example: SPOILER ALERT
During my initial encounter with sheriff I don't cause any trouble. And the sheriff says so during the trial when he recounts our interaction. The the Prince returns with the verdict and states that I did cause trouble... Seems like the planned narrative was that I did cause trouble and sheriff was rude/violent with me.

The second time we meet I actually choose to try to help sheriff and we also talk normally.

The third time we meet the game pretends that interaction during the second meeting (which was my choice) never happened and I'm super afraid of the sheriff due to our first interaction.

Before our fourth meeting the beast suddenly took over and I killed a person close to my home. The next evening the sheriff turns up and completely ignores that fact....

This make a VERY disjointed story,

A good introductory game to people who are curious about the Vampire the Masquerade setting. And quite fun, even if the amount of choice you have as a player is slightly limited (or so it feels, as of time of writing).

Edit: Having now completed a playthrough I find myself disappointed. It might be a World of Darkness, but at a bare minimum it a game should give you a sense of fulfilment after having completed it. However, as I sit in the credits I feel like nothing I did mattered. No part of the story was influenced in the slightest by my actions, or decisions. I am left with the feeling that I was an audience to a play laid before me, told that my choices mattered, and at the end told that the script had been written ahead of time and nothing changed with anything I did. 

I wanted to like this game, but with the way it ends, I just feel disappointed. Five interesting hours, spoiled by the last 50 minutes.

column8:
Basically I enjoyed it because I am interested in Vampire: The Masquerade. I would recommend waiting for a sale. Beat in 4 hours. Does have some replayability but it is no Night Road. Not a lot of real choices.

I do really like the artwork and the characters and most of the writing. I think it also explores some interesting aspects of Kindred society that I had not really thought about, especially their relation to Christianity and God I really enjoyed.

The ending kinda felt like it came out of nowhere and was a bit confusing but I think it is fitting for this universe. I do wish it gave more nights to get to know the other characters better but I enjoyed my time with it.

column8:
It a good visual novel. are there many ending and different choices to be had? no. its the story that's being told good? yes.

basically its a fun and engaging story. The opening is on the other hand very long. so if I could change one thing about the game its opening. 
the rest has very believable characters and a very nice flow. the soundtrack is just stellar and a couple of tracks have made it in to moody background playlist. it's dark and very atmospheric.
the art work is amazingly done. some background sets are reused in the game (looking at you dark alley set...). for the most part it never gets reused to en extend that it becomes annoying except for dark alley set.
The story is noting groundbreaking but very solid. It has its low moment were it feels a bit dragging but overall there is practically any pointless filler and a good passing. 

Do I recommend this game? yes if your in to 'Vampire the Masquerade' or visual novels. It your not, maybe get it on a sale or something. You might find you, like it.

Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York √© um visual novel que oferece uma entrada acess√≠vel e envolvente para quem deseja explorar o universo sombrio e fascinante de Vampire: The Masquerade. Com uma narrativa rica e personagens bem constru√≠dos, o jogo √© relativamente curto, o que o torna ideal para novos jogadores que querem conhecer esse mundo sem mergulhar em algo muito complexo. A trama √© repleta de escolhas, permitindo que o jogador explore diferentes perspectivas, e a ambienta√ß√£o do jogo cativa com sua atmosfera sombria e elegante.

Outro ponto positivo √© a leveza do jogo em termos de desempenho. √â poss√≠vel rod√°-lo at√© em uma batata com fios, o que facilita o acesso ao universo de Vampire: The Masquerade at√© para quem n√£o tem uma m√°quina potente.

Ainda assim, o jogo tem suas limita√ß√µes. Embora o enredo progrida bem, o final deixa um pouco a desejar, parecendo apressado e encerrando de forma abrupta. Al√©m disso, as escolhas feitas ao longo do jogo t√™m pouco impacto real na hist√≥ria, servindo mais como um caminho para conseguir conquistas do que como decis√µes que moldam a narrativa de forma significativa. A variedade limitada de cl√£s jog√°veis tamb√©m √© um ponto fraco; s√≥ √© poss√≠vel explorar tr√™s dos muitos cl√£s do universo de Vampire: The Masquerade, o que reduz a possibilidade de experimentar o jogo sob diferentes vis√µes e habilidades vamp√≠ricas.

Em resumo, Coteries of New York √© um √≥timo passatempo e uma introdu√ß√£o s√≥lida ao universo Vampire: The Masquerade, especialmente para iniciantes. Para quem quer se aprofundar mais e ter mais op√ß√µes de escolha e personaliza√ß√£o, √© interessante explorar outros jogos da franquia, como Bloodlines ou Swansong.

column8: I enjoyed the story and the visuals, artstyle and especially the sound effects -- they are very fitting and on point. At first plot seemed simple enough, but it still sucked me right into. column8:
Just played through this and while the game does a great job of introducing the Vampire: the Masquerade setting (as well as the World of Darkness), hoo boy was that a bag of mixed shit altogether if I ever saw one!

I really like the core setup and visuals and there's some great characters to interact with. Being familiar with the old New York by Night module it was even nice to be reacquainted with some old NPC characters and see what roles they had in the setting now. The characters and side missions are fun, and it offers a lot of replayability as you'll never have time to explore all possible threads thrown at you in one playthrough.

But the plot, oh lord, where should I begin? The plot was awful and the ending a complete nonsensical cliffhanger of the worst kind. It's just pure gibberish and makes me wonder if who ever wrote it was suffering from an aneurysm at the time. And none of the choices made or paths chosen through the game have any effect whatsoever on the ending. The exact opposite of what this type of game should be.

2 out of 5 broken fangs. But that's just because I'm nice. In short, it's shite. Polished shite but still shite. Some good intentions and I like the style of the game. But good intentions paved the path to... well you know where.

I really like the core setup and visuals and there's some great characters to interact with. Being familiar with the old New York by Night module it was even nice to be reacquainted with some old NPC characters and see what roles they had in the setting now. The characters and side missions are fun, and it offers a lot of replayability as you'll never have time to explore all possible threads thrown at you in one playthrough.

But the plot, oh lord, where should I begin? The plot was awful and the ending a complete nonsensical cliffhanger of the worst kind. It's just pure gibberish and makes me wonder if who ever wrote it was suffering from an aneurysm at the time. And none of the choices made or paths chosen through the game have any effect whatsoever on the ending. The exact opposite of what this type of game should be.

2 out of 5 broken fangs. But that's just because I'm nice. In short, it's shite. Polished shite but still shite. Some good intentions and I like the style of the game. But good intentions paved the path to... well you know where.

column8: Only thing i wish this had would be proper voice acting. Otherwise it is an amazing experience.
column9: Only thing i wish this had would be proper voice acting. Otherwise it is an amazing experience.

column8: A solid 7/10 in vampire vibes.
column9: A solid 7/10 in vampire vibes.

column8: Game play is mostly just left mouse clicking and reading. You can't change the key bindings nor use auto play. If you want to try out something stupid that will result in a Game Over, just for fun, it erases your save, forcing you to start at the beginning. Maybe if it was voice acted with auto-play, this would be good. As it is, there's not enough to justify a $20 price tag. I got it 90% off ($2) and still I don't think I can recommend it because it doesn't seem to respect your time.

column8: I played the sequel first, but was even more disappointed with CONY. They managed to make a interesting game and great set up, but it feels massively unfinished. Its hard to go into details without spoilers but as far as visual novels go its just not got the variety and meaning to choices and dialog that you get from most other VNs. Its a massive shame as it feels like it wouldnt have been difficult to fix the lack of choices mattering, and adding some variations.

column8:
This is my first visual novel, but I'm a major fan of Vampire: the Masquerade (VtM), which is set in the table-top RPG The World of Darkness. I have played both the PC games VtM - Bloodlines (2004) and later on VtM - Redemption (2000). I've also read several novels from that universe, but even a fledgling, a complete noob to VtM will enjoy this game. As you play it, specific terms are put in a dictionary you can access at any time and characters or bits of narrative text also explain various basic things. People who are fans of VtM will undoubtedly get more out of it, though. There were several times when I went "this must be a reference to that". Despite expecting to know just about everything mentioned there, I still learned some new things, but maybe that says more about me than the vastness and ever expanding lore and canon events of this world.

When it comes to the genre, it was pretty much what I expected. You click on the icon that produces new text boxes and sometimes you get to make a choice, either a dialogue choice or an action. That's pretty much it. There is no voice acting, no stats or leveling or anything, just one text box after another. There is background music, which is nice and I like the way it sets the mood without being distracting. The character portraits and sceneries are very well-made and detailed, but where this game and the World of Darkness really shines is in the writing, story and characters.

There were many memorable characters, each quite varied and complex, while also showing expected and unexpected sides based on my previous knowledge of their vampire type (or "clan" as they're called in VtM). I enjoyed getting to know my potential companions through their individual quests as well as the main story NPC:s. There were quite a few twists along the main and side quests, which elevated the gaming experience, but a second playthrough obviously won't get the same reaction out of me. There very many highs, but never any lows when it came to the story, although the illusion of choice made me a bit disillusioned a few times, like it didn't matter what I chose. A second playthrough might diminish or reinforce that, but it doesn't matter much, since I rarely replay games. I have a backlog to reduce and most games aren't worth replaying anyway. Visual novels are inherently designed to be replayed, but I'm content with my single playthrough. 

I was surprised that it took me more than 20 hours to complete this game, but with that in mind, I wished I had prioritised certain quests more. The game's store page said that you couldn't see all content if only played once, but I thought that only meant that certain routes wouldn't reveal themselves without playing as a different character or making different choices, not that I'd be left with a bunch of unfinished side quests. The game didn't warn me about when or if this would happen, but I suspected it after a while and focused my efforts on finishing a few of them, not managing to finish all of them. I hate leaving things unfinished... and in the game. Perhaps that also says more about me than anything else.

Anyway, Coteries of New York is a great starting point if you want to sink your teeth into your first visual novel and/or first VtM-related game and/or for those that are fans of either or both.
