column8:
Recently started planning a new V:tM game for my players after several years of running other systems, and thought I'd check out the newest line of game material to see what would be worth incorporating, especially when there's a big sale going on... And I gotta say, outside of Qadir being the most underrated side character of the story who deserved a helluva lot more screen time, this was such trash and I'm glad I didn't pay anything close to full price for it.

It starts strong, with an intriguing enough intro into becoming a vampire and being presented to the local Prince. You're given the usual task of forming up a coterie, but with strangers the game provides. Then the game proceeds to drive itself right off a narrative cliff. I didn't check out spoilers before playing, but front and center of the Community section of the game page of my library was a walkthrough that cautioned to pick a few members to befriend because you couldn't get them all in one playthrough. That raised a little red flag with me because gathering up party/coterie members should just be step 1 of the story. But I figured that maybe the deal was that some of them wouldn't get along with others once recruited, or wouldn't recruit if you picked certain others, so i ignored that warning sign but kept it in mind for pursuing a few story lines. Did the first meets with the four potential members to get an idea of who I wanted most, saw no sign there was any restrictions for who might join based on other choices, but still decided to pick the Nossy and the Malk for fully recruiting and seeing how that would go. There's never any crossover or mentions of the others in their side stories. So my confusion built as to why the blurb of a guide I caught a glimpse of said what it did, but I kept playing without checking into circumstances further.

And the plot steadily descended into the most nonsensical and unrealistic series of events imaginable. I can't say Nossy and Malk didn't have motivations for what they did, but their plans that formed because of motivations they had were threadbare and riddled with gaping holes of logic. And you can NOT point any of it out to them, you don't have any alternatives you're allowed to pose to them. You are there for the ride and to do whatever they tell you to do. You have no motivations or opinions of your own. And one of your new "companions"/"friends" then up and decides to commit diablerie right in front of you, instead of just killing the opposing vampire or just walking away because they already well accomplished what they had set out to do that night. And you're given ZERO options to stop/dissuade her, or quickly kill the enemy vamp to avoid the diablerie happening. They just tell you this is a thing that will happen and deal with it, and then you walk out and let them do it. No options on screen the entire sequence and then fade to black. Sorry, but if this was going down and I had a choice in the matter, I'd either try rationalizing with them to stop the attempted diablerie, or I'd be reporting their ass to Qadir the moment I'm free and clear of them because I don't want to be the next diablerized if I get on the Malk's bad side. ESPECIALLY because this game tries really hard to force internal monologues at you about how humane you personally still are, that doing the right thing still matters to you and you're wrestling with what it means to be a vampire, etc.. If your character is SUPPOSED to be operating like that, then why are there not options or scripted events for your character to actually behave in such ways?

But, unlike the awesomeness that was Bloodlines, this game never gives you any chances to react in meaningful ways that are coherent for even the clear internal narrative. Every story line is very linear and often flies in the face of what any sensible person would do in the situations presented. After the first two members were fully recruited, I got a few extra scenes in with the tremere, another with the Gangrel, and peeped in on the opening scenes for the stalker and religious plots... Then found out that you can't recruit everyone because the end of the game comes flying in like an out of control rollercoaster cart that came off the rails, with the same small-scale localized devastation the theme park ride's crash would cause. Nothing about Sophie's story is making any sense this entire time, it's unfolding at this breakneck speed in just a few weeks and left purposefully obscured to try hiding how flimsy and stupid her scheme is from the player.

And then the big confrontation happens, the "real" big bad shows themselves, and I'm wondering why I can't jump in the river after our boy Torque because this is all such ridiculous bullsh!t. Just because you have Sophia point out that what he's saying makes no sense, doesn't mean you're cleverly lampshading the situation. He continues to give a long winded, pretentious AF monologue and then it's suddenly cut to black and game over. Leaving me with a ton of questions as to what the hell just happened and why. And a quick look online tells me that there's no real alternate endings, and there's no real insights offered if you play other clans and try other options for character recruitment or interactions with the few side characters along the way. I had actually managed to incidentally pick most of the options that would provide most of the available information. The game is quite simply that bare bones for plot and character building, with nonsensical twists and lack of options to be offered. Your one legitimate set of options is being an absolute rude and self-destructive dumb@ss in the intro who gets themselves killed by the vampires you've pissed off. Congrats, you found the second ending for the game and spared yourself seeing the mess that follows.

This isn't a game. It's certainly not within the roleplay wheelhouse V:tM typically operates from. It's a book where you get to pick a clan for the unlucky protagonist (and that clan will ultimately mean sweet f*ck all to the plot) and then watch as they apparently get a free lobotomy with their Embrace and their entire life then systematically implodes in on itself. At least when I had to instruct Dragon Age Inquisition to recreate my former Hawk from DA2, I got to pick gender and one of three personality types and that latter choice actually influenced what their dialogue with the Inquisitor would be like. This supposed storytelling game that glosses over things like fight and hunger mechanics to supposedly spotlight the story aspects of a game fails to even meet the criteria of allowing you to play an actual character. You are a vehicle for plot to happen through, under the most contrived of circumstances at every turn. And the games makes one of the biggest crimes of media in that it is BORING to see unfold once you start catching on to the fact that the strong starting premise and promise of decent supporting characters were inexplicably wasted for whatever the rest of the "game" turned into.

I have the rest of the new V:tM catalog in my library, and I'm going to play through them to see if they are any better, but this one was SO damn disappointing. The only good thing I can say for it is the base outline of characters that were Qadir and the coterie will be getting ported into the game I'm running because there were kernels of good character ideas there, but it'll be in a very different context so they can have a chance to become fully realized characters for players to interact with.

column8: Schaurig sch√∂n.

[b]Merits:[/b]
‚ñ™ Moody writing & location
‚ñ™ Interesting premise
‚ñ™ Detailed characters

[b]Flaws:[/b]
‚ñ™ Sometimes felt forced into a path
‚ñ™ Limited choices

[b]Verdict:[/b]
Of the three WoD visual novels on Steam, this one is clearly the best, but it still left me unsatisfied.
There is a good story here but it felt like I was forced into a path, not allowing me to really make my own decisions.
As there is no neutral option, I'm going with thumbs up, but take it with a pinch of salt.

column8: Honestly, this was pretty disappointing because of the ending. On my first playthrough, it felt like I had just made the wrong choices and that I got the "bad" ending. But no, it turns out that's just the ending no matter what your clan is, who you side with, how successful your missions are, etc. Despite that, I did enjoy the music, the atmosphere, and I found all the characters you interact with throughout the story to be intriguing. It's just a let down that all this excellent character development with whoever you side with ends up not really changing anything at the end. If you don't mind the fact that you can't change the ending, and you just want to have some nice interactions with VTM characters, then sure, I can recommend it. It's a great game... for one, maybe two playthroughs.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34294631/] Follow Far2close - Visual Novel Playthroughs Curator Page [/url]
[b]Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York[/b]
Developer: Draw Distance
Publisher: Draw Distance

[h1]Intro:[/h1]
You're working late and you get invited to a dinner, or you're enjoying a rave and encounter a mysterious girl, then your world gets turned upside down. Congratulations, you're now a vampire and that life you once had is now over. Along that, also your new nightwalker life is soon to be at an end as well. You're going to be put on death by the undead Sheriff but you've been offered a proposition by Sophie Langley: work under her or die. Now that you've been spared, you must learn on how to thrive as a vampire along with making friends into your own coterie. 

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]1.[/b] 
The story is interesting from the beginning to... before the ending. I do like how you MUST learn from scratch on how to survive and learn with your new body in a ruthless New York City. Depending on the character you choose, you witness a different beginning and one specific event related to your character, otherwise the majority of the story is linear focusing on you working under Sophie Langley and gathering allies for your coterie. 
[b]2.[/b]
The characters are extremely entertaining and although they're vampires, they do keep that humanity to them. My favorite is D'Angelo as he tries his best to be a detective and wants to do the right thing, even if cruelty rules NYC. The finale for him is bittersweet and shows a facade might get you far, you can't run from your true self. My second favorite is Agathon as he's a straightforward man but he cares for family and friends. He's that man you can trust with your life, as long as you respect his boundaries. Overall, the characters are definitely the strongest in this, and no matter which allies you gain, they are all well written along with the minor characters too.
[b]3.[/b]
The artwork is excellent. The character art by Rafa≈Ç Gosieniecki is amazing and fits like a glove within the Vampire: the Masquerade universe. The environmental art by Filip Odzierejko from the bright lights of the city to the dirty abandoned districts has great attention to detail, along with the environments having some animations to add life to them.
[b]4.[/b]
The music by Arkaduisz Reikowski and [url=https://soundcloud.com/brunon-lubas]Brunon Lubas[/url] is astounding. "What Comes Next" is a great opener for the visual novel. "We Are the Night" fits in well with Agathon's questline, and "Gehenna" is a great closer. Overall, an excellent soundtrack that is purchaseable [url=https://arkadiuszreikowski.bandcamp.com/album/vampire-the-masquerade-coteries-of-new-york-original-soundtrack]here.[/url]





[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]1.[/b]
The ending is problematic. It does not answer a lot of questions and leaves a new set of them in place. The choices you make only change whether the people you encounter will join you or not, or you can die. It felt like just a huge plot twist that didn't belong. The ending DOES NOT change no matter what character you chose nor what you did. While I appreciate the different beginnings and a character specific event, your actions really mean nothing for the outcome. This means that replayability is not very high unless you really want to see that different dialogue.
[b]2.[/b]
I did die once, that's not really an issue, the real issue was that it's basically game over for that save slot. You don't have a second chance to choose differently. Now skip functions are an important asset in visual novels. The lack of one in this, is that you have to do a lot of clicking to get back to where you were, it gets tedious.
[b]3.[/b]
The artwork is great, unfortunately you can't take a better look by hiding the UI. I wish there was at least a gallery of unlocked arts as you progress.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
"Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York" is a visual novel that had promise but is shackled by its poor ending. The characters and world is great, but I think even fans of the series would feel unhappy with the conclusion.



[b]Score:[/b] 5/10 NOT RECOMMENDED

Got this game as part of a vampire: the masquerade pack off humble bundle, and did my first playthrough as Eric the Brujah.
I enjoyed aspects of the game, meeting characters and doing questlines. And, just as I gathered I was halfway through all the questlines (I had only completed three, being additions to my coterie.) The finale of the game happened, and I became very disappointed.
Looking at other peoples experience, turns out there's only one ending and nothing you do really matters. Not only this, but the ending is incredibly disappointing, feels rushed and incredibly railroaded. Honestly, even though this game was essentially not even a dollar because of the bundle I bought it with I regret wasting the 9 hours I did playing through the story, because that ending absolutely killed it and the only reason I would ever go back to this game would be to try and farm achievements.
  If you want a vampire visual novel game, I recommend looking into the 'red embrace' series.

So damn boring! All you do is read and click, over and over again. And the text is not that interesting. The only good thing about this game is the artwork. There isn't even any voice acting like there was in the trailer. Playing this felt like reading a bad comic book. 

Oh yeah, and they won't even let you click "quit game" because there is no menu in-game. This is a shame to the original Vampire Bloodlines.

Sapevo gi√† di trovarmi davanti ad una visual novel, quindi non un gioco ricco d'azione, ma speravo che le mie scelte potessero avere un impatto significativo sulla trama. Cos√¨ non √® stato: oltre ad una scrittura debole in alcuni punti, il gioco ti porter√† sempre all'unico finale disponibile, che a mio parere √® anche piuttosto confusionario (anche se, visto che esistono dei sequel, posso accettare che alcune spiegazioni verranno date nei prossimi giochi).
Da affezionata giocatrice della versione cartacea di Vampiri, sono rimasta molto delusa dall'inesistente creazione del personaggio e dalla caratterizzazione blanda e banale dei PNG.
Oltre lo spoiler un esempio di come le tue scelte e azioni non abbiano nessun impatto sul gioco:
[spoiler]Durante il gioco io non ho mai usato discipline se non in presenza di altri vampiri, e mi sono nutrita raramente: nonostante questo, la Seconda Inquisizione √® venuta a prendermi perch√© "sei un novellino che √® andato in giro a infrangere la Masquerade". Bah.[/spoiler]

Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York has a pretty good story that's fairly in depth. It does not change dramatically between the three playable characters but some aspects do change. Your personal story is different for one thing. The artwork is quite well done, the ambiance is very good. Music is so-so. It doesn't stand out, but it doesn't become obnoxious. In fact, there's little of it - ambient sounds are much more important to the feel of the game. 

The achievements require 3 full play-throughs of the game. Usually I dislike this, but in this case it works. Especially as there are at least some differences between the three characters. 

Overall I liked it pretty well and will be playing the sequel. 7/10

Manche Sachen in der Bibliothek werfen zugegeben ein paar Fragen auf. Im konkreten Fall, an wen richtet sich dieses Programm eigentlich? Leute, die gerne eine illustrierte Geschichte erleben, greifen vielleicht doch lieber zum gedruckten Buch. Spieler, die evtl. die Zeit zu Bloodlines 2 √ºberbr√ºcken m√∂chten, die m√∂chten spielen und nicht einfach Dialoge weiterklicken. Aber auch, wenn man sich auf die Visuel Novel einl√§sst, liefert dies hier einfach zu wenig. Im unteren linken Bereich wird immer ein kleiner Textblock angezeigt, per Druck auf A (ja, das hat eine Controller-Unterst√ºtzung) oder Mausklick geht es weiter. Gelegentlich kommt so etwas wie Entscheidungsfreiheit auf, wenn man bei einem Dialog eine von drei Optionen ausw√§hlen kann (das passiert aber auch √§u√üerst sp√§rlich). Ab und zu wechseln dann mal das Hauptbild, es wird auch dann und wann mal ein Charakter eingeblendet und die meiste Zeit schaut man auf das Textfeld und klickt weiter. Die Grafiken sind sp√§rlich animiert und verspr√ºhen den Charme von √ñlgem√§lden. Als gedruckte Geschichte oder PDF evtl. eine feine Sache, aber auf dem PC/ Tablet/ etc. einfach nur nervig, da man st√§ndig irgendwas dr√ºcken muss, damit es weitergeht. Absolut √ºberhaupt gar nichts f√ºr mich. Chicken Police, was auch unter Visuel Novel l√§uft, bietet hier deutlich mehr Unterhaltung.

Tentatively enjoying this, even if 5e V:TM is rubbish, but...as a former New Yorker, it's driving me crazy that over 1/2 of the game seems to take place in/around Brooklyn. Especially Prospect Park. The portions set in Manhattan have no real sense of "place," and Queens, The Bronx and Staten Island are all conspicuously absent; but good gravy, the writers were clearly intimately familiar with (I'm guessing) the Hipster Haven of Williamsburg because you'd think 90% of NYC revolved around the Whiter areas of Brooklyn.

Especially Prospect Park. The portions set in Manhattan have no real sense of "place," and Queens, The Bronx and Staten Island are all conspicuously absent; but good gravy, the writers were clearly intimately familiar with (I'm guessing) the Hipster Haven of Williamsburg because you'd think 90% of NYC revolved around the Whiter areas of Brooklyn.

column8:
Fast paced visual novel about a new vampire in the World of Darkness universe, about finding other vampires to alliance with. 

[h2]The New York Masquerade [/h2]
You pick one of three characters, and that one gets bitten at the start of the story in the setting of said character. The new vampire 'childe' gets introduced with all facets and etiquettes of the Camarilla and its clans and hierarchy. But the biggest part of this game are the vampires you try to recruit to your coterie, your group of friends. Those consist of small stories that you can trigger yourself over the course of 3-4 nights. 

Knowledge of the RPG is not required. It might even diminish the experience, because the story isn't very long nor deep. It's about as deep as recognising terms like Nosferatu or Malchavian. I myself am vaguely familiar with this universe, and I'm not an avid reader, so I quite enjoyed this VN! The writing is good, and the writer lets the reader show at occasions that he/she's capable of much more. This game demands rapid text. Readers that like deeper stories should skip this one. Dialogue choices are mostly irrelevant, there is only one branch with flavour options. 

The music is good, and plays with alterations after advancing dialogue. The pictures are nice, they use lighting fluctuations. The game has no manual saving, so you can't go back to choose something else. The mouse is forcibly locked to the window. 

I played this in preparation for Halloween, but it's not really horror - most vampire stories aren't. Although some Hot Topic customers might disagree ;). 

75/100

column8:
Mixed feelings on Coteries of New York. The game is a somewhat short Visual Novel set in the Vampires: Masquerade universe. It felt like it did a good job of introducing the universe with a glossary to explain all the terms and jargon from the setting. Characters are generally interesting, world building is good, interesting well written side-plots, excellent atmosphere and lots of vampire politics.

Unfortunately some standard elements of Visual Novels are not present or not well implemented. There's only one save slot with the game saving your progress when you quit to main menu. After finishing the story, the save is deleted. There is no manual save option. Another missing feature is Skipping Read Text. There's an option to skip all text which lets you quickly skip through text (there's three characters you can play as but bulk of the story is same for each of them) but this will also skip past any text you have no read.

Choices have almost no impact on the story, besides two bad ends at the same point, all choices lead to the same ending overall. Recruiting some of the four possible allies into your coterie can fail if you pick the wrong choice but in the end, despite the Coterie characters having very interesting stories, they just show up for one small moment in the final acts. Failing to recruit any allies ultimately gives you the same ending as recruiting allies anyways so the whole Coterie thing ends up feeling a bit half-backed at the end. The final part of the game in general is a bit lackluster, ending is a bit abrupt.

Recommended on sale - I picked it up on a whim because it was on sale for 90% off. For that price, despite its flaws, its a excellent bargain.

column8:
My love for vampires, just like the vampire dynasty in the key of films, TV series, myths and legends, and especially books, woke up in me back in 2011, when I was just getting acquainted with foreign literature. 
The books by Rachel Kane and Rachel Mead left a deep mark on me, prompted me to take up writing, rave about childhood and adolescent dreams of eternal immortality, its pros and cons, engage in the mythological side of vampires and their romanticization, which probably helped me become a more immersed person in the history of the legends of the origin of these wonderful creatures, completely unexplored, secret and hidden from human eyes.
Of course, this unshakable dream (to see / become / acquire vampirism - there is no essence in what key, the main thing is to get to know it closely sooner or later) will remain a dream, even if it has never been fulfilled in this world, but it is quite feasible in some of the parallel realities.
This series of games about vampires, their drinking in this game universe has completely absorbed me, I returned to those years when I spent days and nights reading and couldn't live without books about vampires.
This game includes an interesting plot, because it is a game of choice and consequences. It will draw in every person, at least a small part, who is interested in myths, legends, the mystification of our real world through the unreal, fictional one. The characters here are worked out both visually and plot-wise, characteristically. Dark (I would even say "darkest"), the color pattern helps you adapt to the story faster than the game was built on light colors ‚Äì it would look like a game color oxymoron. In this game (as in all others, of course), any detail and elaboration is important, even colors, only then does the passage fully contribute to the rapid assimilation of plot branches related to blood, murders, detective motives.
I definitely recommend the passage. I looked at vampires from a new angle, completely different from the one I was used to in my subconscious, because here these creatures follow the trends of fashion, are on the other side of the "mirror" of our world, extremely close and very far away. At the same time. People who raved about this topic just like me will like the game.
I recommend. 10 darkest and most beautiful vampiresses out of 10.

column8:
i really recommend this game, if you like visual novels this is going to be a great adventure, if you like vampire genre you will love the story and the characters and if you are fan of World of Darkness you well its the lore you know
There are some plot holes, or things that do not connect very well and the plot twist of the end divides the community but the game is still worth it

With all this said there are a few things you should know before your first playthrough that are going to help you:

1) The game doesnt tell you but you have 16 nights to complete the quests before the grand final

2) Due to the fact that youre against the clock is imposible to complete all quests before the end but there are 3 playable characters so you have an excuse for playing again

3) The final confrontation can be a bit frustrating because its difficult to realize how it works. For example: [spoiler] I completed the entire questline of Hope and she didnt come to help me  but D angelo and Tamika went to help me and i never completed their respective quests [/spoiler]

If you're just starting with Vampire: the Masquerade and hoping to play the tabletop game: this is a great entry point.
If you're familiar with the setting, or returning to it: it's a great way to get up to date with the fifth edition lore changes.
If you've played Bloodlines or another V:tM game, and are curious about the broader setting: it does a good job of exploring and explaining the lore, but won't have too much you haven't seen before.
If you're curious about vampire stories in general: start here, then play the excellent Shadows of New York right after.
If you're looking for a full fledged RPG or game to sink your teeth into: this won't satisfy that, it's just a visual novel.
If you're reading the other reviews and hear complaints about the ending: it's a bit of a kick in the teeth, though fitting for the setting, so see it as more about making an impression, than telling a complete V:tM tale.

The game feels like a prologue to something else, and I recommend you treat it that way.

column8: "Unstable stability. Cutting-edge tales of thrills and intrigue that push it to the limit... and then return you the tried and tested status quo, gently, infallibly. A system full of distractingly moving parts which simulate conflicts so convincingly that its users never feel a need to direct their energy toward upsetting the system. Achieving the eternal through the disposable. Building a city that's like a ship of Theseus, constantly changing its parts, yet always maintaining the same purpose, serving the same goal at all times. A large-scale infrastructure that has something, like an exhaust system for the spirit... Something that uh, disperses the toxicity around instead of concentrating it in a single place..."

Ends extremely abruptly, forcing player to replay the game to unlock other 'threads' of the story. 
It could be alright if choices would matter at the end, story would be more solid or ending made more sense making it more replayable. Its not like that. So I got hooked in, initially. Then bored, then disappointed. Not to mention i would never expose my players to timed game in my pen and paper WoD campaign. Terrible idea.

column8:
I bought it on a 90% discount, which is adequate for a maybe 10-15 minute, beautiful game.

Of course, I know that the game is way longer... but to get to that, I would need to make a choice which is not authentic for me. VTM: Bloodlines did this way better: a deal was made over my head, which made the acceptance of my situation easier. This way, the only choice I feel fit to make ends the game very early. 

[spoiler] If I became a vampire and committed murder immediately, I would want to get slain. And you do have this option at the very beginning; you essentially need to beg for your life to play the game proper. Which would break my immersion.  [/spoiler]

column8: I was a teenager when Bloodlines came out and it was an absolutely awesome game.... but this... it went a completely different direction. I'm sure the devs worked hard on the game and I applaud them for it, but in my honest opinion it has to be one of the most boring interactive story games I've ever tried to play. It is possible that my opinion is tainted based on the fact that I am a HUGE Bloodlines fan when it came out and this is nothing like it. Sorry guys, i'm gonna get my money back, i really hope there are a lot of people that do like your game, because of all the hard work the devs put in.

column8: Les premi√®res minutes ne m'ont gu√®re emball√© et j'ai oubli√© ce jeu pour le relancer lors d'un long trajet en train et ... cette fois l'histoire m'a attrap√©. Au point que perdant brutalement mon premier personnage, j'ai rattaqu√© aussi sec avec un second pour aller au bout des intrigues. Je retrouve bien l'ambiance du jeu de r√¥le auquel je jouais il y a une bonne vingtaine d'ann√©es et je pense d'ailleurs que je vais d√©poussi√©rer les quelques ouvrages dans ma biblioth√®que.

[h1]Introdu√ß√£o a "Vampiro"[/h1]

Coteries of New York cumpre o seu prop√≥sito e nada muito mais do que isso.

Se voc√™ espera uma super narrativa, com diversos finais e escolhas que impactam de fato na hist√≥ria, eu recomendo voc√™ parar um pouco e checar os fatos. Coteries of New York n√£o chega a ser ruim, mas √© med√≠ocre, linear, e um tanto simplista.

Voc√™ escolhe dentre 3 personagens jog√°veis, o que impactar√° um pouco em alguns di√°logos e possibilidades, mas nada de extraordin√°rio. Da√≠, voc√™ toma conhecimento da narrativa e percebe que seu personagem ainda n√£o √© um vampiro, mas est√° prestes a receber seu "Abra√ßo"; voc√™ vai encarar as primeiras experi√™ncias de uma "Crian√ßa" nessa sociedade secreta, aprender a lidar com seus instintos, entender como funcionam essas novas leis, criar seus primeiros contatos e por a√≠ vai.

Mas o jogo vale a pena? Depende. Pra quem √© novo no g√™nero, gosta do "Mundo das Trevas" e/ou est√° interessado em conhecer mais sobre esse universo, pode ser uma boa op√ß√£o; no entanto, apesar de estar em portugu√™s e at√© ser imersivo, eu acho que sua hist√≥ria b√°sica, falsa sensa√ß√£o de liberdade de escolha, e um final que deixa a desejar, fazem dele fraco para aqueles j√° veteranos das [i]visual novels[/i]. Mesmo com toda essa cr√≠tica, sim, eu irei recomend√°-lo, uma vez que, acredito eu, Coteries of New York nada mais √© do que um introdutor ao cen√°rio de "Vampiro", buscando explicar seus conceitos essenciais de uma forma simples e curta, sendo, portanto, um jogo de nicho.

The story is a short dive in the world that is VTM. You'll meet some interesting personalities along with a lot of lore and the power plays that are a common theme. It has good pacing and the feeling that something is off as you're being led along kept with me for the entire session while also rooting into this new world. The conclusion can be a bit unrewarding or unsatisfying, as none of the things you do really influence the outcome of the story even though you are led along with false choices and sidequests. But perhaps that really befits the story as you're always lead along by others in it and you have no say in the matter with these influental figures that play in the covers of the Masquerade.

column8:
So disappointing.

Art is great, characters are good, story starts great.
Then it allows lots of different side stories (multiple playthroughs needed to see them all)....and then it ends.

What choices did you take? Doesn't matter.
Which companions did you recruit? Doesn't matter.
How did you act? Doesn't matter.
Did you let the beast take over? Doesn't matter.

Nothing whatsoever matters near the end of the game.
There are A LOT of storylines that just kind of disappear. 

Something interesting and mysterious happening? Not resolved.
Characters have interesting arc? Not resolved.
You made some strange decisions which might have consequences? Not resolved.

When I got to last quest (the one that ends the game), I kept wondering "Huh, what will they do now to make MC survive and progress story"...
Answer is nothing. The story will just end with no resolution on pretty much anything.
It's like reading a really good book, then having someone take tore out last 50 pages and saying "it's finished, bye".

???

column8: Discovered this game on a trailer for the PS4 version. Bought this one at a discount in the bundle. This game was so good that it was the game that got me into VTM. Not the world of darkness franchise as a whole, that was wraith the oblivion aftermath ony quest 2. But this one was what got me into vampire. This is by fary favorite visual novel. Can't wait to finish this one up so I can start shadows. I dunno if I actually have to play them in order or not. But I am just in case. I highly recommend this game. Whether you're already a fan of VTM or have never even heard of it before. It's a great game. A beautiful visual novel, the illustrations are amazing, character models are very nicely done, and the backgrounds even more so. If your a fan of visual novels you won't be disappointed.

column8: A√±os que no jugaba un juego de este estilo, si te gusta World of darkness TENES que jugarlo.

Story kicks off pretty good. If you're new to VtM it¬¥s a pretty good introduction but if you're a seasoned veteran you might have heard the story before. Still I thought it was an interesting read through it. The story moves on in a brisk pace which isn¬¥t too bad as something is always happening. The downside is that you (unknowingly) only have a set number of nights to play and can¬¥t possibly do all the side quests or gather all the companions. You have to make a choice what avenues to pursue.

Then we get to the end... And it turns out none of the choices you made, the companions you met and interacted with. None of it matters. And just as you think you¬¥ll get some sort of resolution to an incredibly rushed and unfulfilling ending... they flick a switch and the credits roll.

You're incentivised to replay it to do the side quests and companions you couldn¬¥t prioritise the first time. But since nothing you do matters and it all ends the same abysmal way no matter what I don¬¥t see the point.
column9:
Story kicks off pretty good. If you're new to VtM it¬¥s a pretty good introduction but if you're a seasoned veteran you might have heard the story before. Still I thought it was an interesting read through it. The story moves on in a brisk pace which isn¬¥t too bad as something is always happening. The downside is that you (unknowingly) only have a set number of nights to play and can¬¥t possibly do all the side quests or gather all the companions. You have to make a choice what avenues to pursue.

Then we get to the end... And it turns out none of the choices you made, the companions you met and interacted with. None of it matters. And just as you think you¬¥ll get some sort of resolution to an incredibly rushed and unfulfilling ending... they flick a switch and the credits roll.

You're incentivised to replay it to do the side quests and companions you couldn¬¥t prioritise the first time. But since nothing you do matters and it all ends the same abysmal way no matter what I don¬¥t see the point.

column8:
Really, really bummed about this one.

Coteries is a deeply interesting game, as a lot of Vampire: The Masquerade games seem to be. They tend to have strong, smart writing with deep character explorations in a truly interesting, well-realized world. And Coteries is no exception!

Unfortunately, I'm not sure I'll be finding out how it ends, as I encountered a massive bug that forcibly skipped over a chunk of the main story quest.

Without going into spoilers, there is a point in the game where if your Hunger is too high, it will bug out and start providing the same dialogue that warns you about your Hunger level again and again while force-skipping a story-critical scene. And since the scene is story-critical, the game proceeds assuming you played it out, referencing events I didn't see and choices I didn't make.

So, I hard quit out of the game hoping to find a way out of this mess from my previous save, and my heart sinks when I learn that despite the menu saying "Save and Exit", the game auto-saves after every dialogue box anyway.

And then my heart breaks to learn this bug has been known and reported on since 2020.

Honestly, I can't even tell if the Hunger indicator itself was functioning properly. Do Rests restore your Hunger? Does starting a new event? I couldn't say, because more often than not, the Hunger indicator would just up and vanish on its own. "Oh, I guess I'm good if I don't lean too heavily on the powers, avoid damage and play smart." But then suddenly the Beast is welling up inside of me to dropkick my save file after using my powers just once that in-game night and the Hunger indicator sitting at what looks to be "minimal"?

I just don't get it. And that sucks, because I was deeply enjoying my time with Coteries of New York. If I want to return to this game, I'll have to recreate 5 hours of dialogue choices and decisions. Or just look up someone else's playthrough to flip through the scene I missed. Maybe none of my choices would've mattered, but that's not the point. The point is: this is the game, in a state where it can break *hard* and auto-save the damage. And sadly, it has been for 3 years, apparently.

column8: The music and the art really helps out to get into the atmosphere of World Of Darkness. I really felt doomed when the characters gets to the Court of the Elyseum at first. Each Character had their developed personality and interests. While I still found difficult to deal with a Malkavian Character, I felt my failure in the game as real because even if I try to tackle the dilemmas from a stay in character role play perspective, I can help but to struggle with some of the challenges maybe because I felt sometimes overwhelm by the doubled tongued, perilous, set up of vampire¬¥s society where, each word and decisition could lead you to your Final Death or even worse. This struggle, was really enjoyble. Thanks to the developers.

The graphics are nice, it's always pleasant to enter the World of Darkness universe for a new adventure and the story is overall pretty good.
But when I say I recommend the game it's more like it's objectively pretty good but not great. Some story threads are really rushed, the gameplay is very shallow and the final chapter arrives very quickly and gives you the feeling that whatever you did with your character wasn't relevant (it's kind of the point but also gives you the impression that the story was very very guided).
If you want a deeper gameplay, a longer adventure and more possibilities I would recommend that you turn your eyes to Night Road, which is not a graphic novel but an interactive novel with strong paper RPG vibes, but is so much deeper in its sotry and gameplay and gives you a lot more freedom.

So to conclude, yes this is a good game, and I can't not recommend it but it's far from the best World of Darkness text based game i've played.
Sehr stimmig in sich!

column8: Well written characters and dialogue. Great art/ music. Unfortunately the ending feels rushed and sucks, your choices have no effect on the final outcome. If you replay the game, which you are actually encouraged to do by having multiple different character choices and not having enough time to complete every side quest in a single play through, you start to realize that the choices you thought were having consequences on your first play through were actually just the illusion of choice and 90% of your decisions in this game really don't matter. If you can look past all of these major flaws, you can still enjoy an overall engaging and for the most part well written story. I still enjoyed it though I was left feeling disappointed and unsatisfied in a lot of ways. I feel the game has a lot of wasted potential and could have been so much more, yet I still enjoyed it and if you are a big WOD fan then I would still reluctantly recommend this game.

Coteries of New York is a compelling introduction to the Vampire: The Masquerade franchise and its lore, but it ultimately falls far short as a story. 

The art is well-made and backgrounds work fantastically with the ambient music to create a thick atmosphere. However, the largely decent writing was let down by an extremely rushed, confusing, and thoroughly unsatisfying ending that blindsides the player out of nowhere, shatters the illusion of choice, and leaves most side quests/stories unresolved.

Before the last "chapter" (if you can even call it that) started with a bang, I thought I was maybe halfway through the story. 15 minutes later, it was over. I find myself extremely disappointed after spending most of today engrossed by the world and characters.

I enjoyed Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York, although it felt a bit rushed in the final chapter. All the world building and relationship building did not amount to much in the end, as it felt like the ending (don't know if there are multiple) happened without me really being given a choice to influence it in a meaningful way. That being said, the time until the ending was never boring for me.

My only foray into the Masquerade world was the excellent Bloodlines 20 years ago, but it felt like riding a bike in the sense that there was enough familiarity with the setting for me to know how to approach certain characters. There were some instances, where I felt the story did not adequately change based on my choices or plot threads were left dangling at the end, but this could have been due to my choices of "quests" to follow.

Overall, I think the game (or rather: this visual novel) is a fun time for 4-5 hours and at least a single playthrough. You should wait for appropriate sale opportunities accordingly. For maybe 5 ‚Ç¨ (or $), I think you'll get your money's worth.

column8:
There are better visual novels out there that do horror and mystery a lot better than this one, and V:tM: Bloodlines is the better V:tM game by far if you don't mind the early 2000's jank (and the crime against colons the title employs), but Coteries of New York is probably the best introduction to the TTRPG setting's core identity and themes - especially if it's your first experience going in blind into that setting, with how information throughout is withheld and drip-fed to you.

You're thrown into a world you know nothing about without anyone bothering or caring to stop and explain things to their full extent, moving between vague objective and vague objective without completely grasping anyone's ultimate goal or motivation. This nails the paranoia of V:tM, putting your character and thereby you as a player experiencing the story out of your depth, confused. 

I would rather attribute this to design than just lackluster writing in places and decisions having dubious impact upon the overarching narrative of the game, but as indicated by recent reviews being 'mixed' as of the time of my writing this, aesthetics which hint at the wider lore and play into the intrigue of the ~30 year old tabletop rpg's world isn't for everyone, and can make the game feel lacking - especially with the abruptness of the game's ending which comes without real explained or mechanical warning; thematically on point as elements and plots move regardless of whether or not you do in the world, but not exactly something ideal to be surprised by as a played experience.

Ultimately I like it and think it does Vampire justice, even if there are better options. I however got the game on sale for only a few dollars. The full $20 is steep for what the game offers; I completed a single playthrough in four hours, ignoring me choosing options that deliberately led to my death within the first twenty minutes (which, incidentally, deletes your save), and while there isn't a massive variety between the three characters/backstories you can choose from I can see myself going through the game a second time at least to see the content the abrupt ending locked me out of my first playthrough.

column8:
I'm a fan of VTM and the World of Darkness and the game does a reasonable job portraying it, I'm just not a fan of the visual novel game play style. There seems to be little agency to the game and most decisions don't particularly seem to matter, so there is a major lack of agency. One of the most interesting things about playing VTM is how each clan has its own unique spin on vampirism, and this game really squashes that - you see it in the other characters, but it's mostly flavortext as far as the main character goes. I've played through two of the three possible choices so far (and will complete the game with the third for the sake of thoroughness and investing another hour or two for the achievements) and they both felt very similar; there was no discernible difference in how things played out or what my characters did - the scenarios available for each character are the same, the dialogue options are the same, and things tend to get repetitive.

The saving system is also problematic -  it'd be more accurate to call it a pausing system, because there's no way to go back and try out different dialogue options to see what could have happened or what other threads there might be without doing another play-through (which is why I suppose there are 3 "different" characters to choose from). Once you choose something and progress the story, you can't go back and try out something different since you have to "Save and Exit" to leave the game. To try to see where other lines of dialogue take you, you have to go through the whole game again, which is to say there's going to be a lot of stuff I'm just going to miss because as it stands the game is already a slog for me, but I'm bored this week and have 10 hours to kill on a game I'm not enjoying. I bought the sequel because they were on sale at some point, and I don't plan on even starting that one because my understanding is that it is more of the same.

If you like visual novels and are curious about VTM, you'll probably like this game; it's a good portrayal of the WOD and does a good job of introducing folks to some surface level VTM lore (if you already know what an Antediluvian and the Second Inquisition are, i.e. you've played any other VTM game, then you won't learn anything new from this game). If you play VTM and enjoy the mechanics and customization options for the tabletop RPG, you will find this implementation stifling and think that all of the fun has been sucked out of the system; it's like if you went to culinary school and learned about how to properly season dishes and then go to cook somewhere and all they have is salt - it won't be a disaster, but it's so much less than you were hoping for and missing all of the nuance. If you're looking that kind of experience, go play VTM Redemption or Bloodlines instead.

column8:
If you love VTM and want an interesting visual novel, this is worth a playthrough when discounted on a high discount sale price. If you want a game where your choices have any relevance to the story, avoid. 

Pros: 
- The art and sound effects are all wonderfully put together for a visual novel set in the world of darkness.
- Would consider this a great primer for someone who is interested in a VTM game, as a way to get a better understanding of that world.
- Easily farmed achievements for Steam if you just want to rack up a game completion.

Cons:
- Your choices don't matter at all (aside from a few suicidal actions early on, and who you ally with which only effects achievements). If you clicked through the top option and didn't read a thing, vs plotting and planning out your decisions, the game still ends the same.
- Repeating locations and characters gets kind of boring
- Overall pretty short story.

Think I picked it up at something like a $7 sale, don't regret my purchase as I enjoyed the first playthrough (6ish hours) then just sped through the replays to hit 100%. Also glad I didn't spend full price on it.

As the name suggests, a [b] visual [/b] novel is supposed to represent, visually, the situations described by the text. Guess what? Lazy and poor visual novel, more like just a novel if you ask me.

Ambiance Sonore: 10 - Colle parfaitement √† la mise en sc√®ne.
VtM v5: 10 - Tr√®s bonne s√©ance d'introduction au Mood et Theme.
Personnage: 10 - Tous tr√®s bien d√©crit, inspirant pour vos parties de JdR.

Un "vrai sc√©anario VtM" comme pour vous dire : D√©sol√© t'es pas assez puissant pour comprendre et influencer le milieu de la haute...

Summary: Mostly good, one bad point which you may or may not find a big deal.

This is pretty atmospheric.

The backdrops are well chosen, and the slight animation works well with them.
The music is always in keeping with the events, and really adds to the atmosphere.

Some of the situations bring a genuine sense of tension, and it's not by any means always obvious which of your choices is going to lead you in which direction.

It's a simple format, largely a story with some multiple choice branches, but it's well-crafted and I found it enjoyable, engaging, and immersive. At times it would have been nice to have a broader scope of choices, but that's just the nature of a game with a broadly fixed overarching story.

The characters are well-crafted, and it's a polished experience overall. It took about 6 hours to go through it, but I did have the occasional break to do other things, so there's probably 4 hours in it. A nice four hours, though. Glad I bought it.

The bad point is: The ending. It's abrupt, and although it's coherent enough, it feels sudden, and rushed, and is unsatisfying.

But I never remember the endings of movies, books, etc anyway, and I certainly won't remember the ending of this. Instead, I'll remember the atmosphere and some of the characters, and on that score I'm happy.

column8:
Decent aesthatics, great music that will keep you company and list of pleasantly written characters.

Although the game and story itself are a bit dull in a sense that they were meant to be an introduction to both the world of Vampire the Masquerade and a series of games by Drawing Distance but don't let that discourage you it's writtent well, written short.

3 things I personally find troubling in game design:

1. Save system that doesn't let mess around with the story.
2. Pacing of the story, i would rather enjoy 3 "quests" per night or the system that was introduced in the Shadows of New York.
3. Keyboard layout is rather strict.

All in all it's definitely worth a buy, it left a mark in my soul and I am thankful to everyone who made this game possible.

column8: Durant ces trois longues heures, j'ai pu go√ªter √† l'ennui de cliquer encore et encore (des milliers de fois) pour d√©clencher des sc√©nettes toutes plus ennuyeuses les unes que les autres. Heureusement, le jeu est termin√© et il peut finir dans ma liste des jeux finis (et tr√®s mauvais)

[b]Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York[/b] es una novela visual basada en el popular juego de rol de l√°piz y papel "Vampire: The Masquerade", y el tan conocido ‚ÄúMundo de tinieblas‚Äù. 

La historia se ambienta en la ciudad de Nueva York el que encarn√°s a un vampiro reci√©n convertido, y como buen perro faldero vas cumpliendo misiones para tu ‚Äúsire‚Äù. Adem√°s se te explica como funciona la sociedad vamp√≠rica bajo la Mascarada a la vez que intentas dominar tu bestia interior. El nivel narrativo en general es muy bueno y llevadero. No contiene escenas sexuales como las novelas visuales de porte japon√©s nos tienen acostumbrado.

La mec√°nica principal del juego se centra en la toma de decisiones. Al principio te es posible elegir entre tres facciones, pero m√°s all√° de algunos cambios sutiles en sus habilidades, pocas diferencias tienen. A medida que avanzas en la historia, te encontrar√°s con diversos personajes, cada uno con sus propias motivaciones e intereses. Tus elecciones tienen poca relevancia en la trama en t√©rminos generales. Sin embargo, s√≠ te permitir√°n tener algunos acompa√±antes que te ayuden en momentos cruciales.

La atm√≥sfera es opresiva y sombr√≠a, y te hace sentir parte de la estirpe de vampiros. El apartado visual est√° bien ejecutado, con una est√©tica oscura y detallada que complementa la narrativa. Adem√°s, la banda sonora y los efectos de sonido ayudan a crear una experiencia inmersiva. Se echa en falta algunas animaciones para los personajes que son im√°genes completamente est√°ticas.

Ya dando por cierre, es importante destacar que es com√∫n encontrarlo con un descuento de hasta 90% off volvi√©ndolo una compra asegurada para aquellos que disfrutan los juegos de rol de mesa, sobre todos los amantes de ‚ÄúMundo de tinieblas‚Äù. Es posible jugarlo con gamepad a lo largo de sus 8 horas de juego y pese a sus falencias, es llevadero y mantiene entretenido hasta el final.
Loved this game, its story and characters

column8:
De um modo geral eu gostei, tem um √≥tima atmosfera e a hist√≥ria principal e side quests s√£o interessantes. As vezes parece como jogar um RPG narrado por um mestre (mesmo que o jogo n√£o seja um RPG). Voc√™ pode escolher entre 3 personagens de origens e cl√£s diferentes, onde cada um interage com a hist√≥ria de forma distinta o que √© bem legal.
O problema desse jogo √© que √© cheio de "ilus√£o de escolha", voc√™ pensa que est√° tomando decis√µes que impactam o mundo e seu personagem, mas na verdade n√£o. O jogo s√≥ tem um √∫nico final e as side quests sempre terminam mais ou menos da mesma forma. Eu acredito que eles fizeram assim pra casar com o "tema" da hist√≥ria como √© deixado claro com a reviravolta no final, mas ainda assim acho que seria muito melhor se nossas decis√µes importassem, nem que s√≥ um pouco.
Outra coisa estranha √© que eles introduzem o conceito de "coteries" como se fosse um elemento importante, mas n√£o faz muito com isso. Acabou sendo um pouco decepcionante.
Recomendo pela boa atmosfera e narrativa interessante.

Sympas sans plus, on ne peu pas vraiment appeler √ßa un jeu, serais plus adapt√© en anim√© ou en livre.
La traduction a de toute √©vidence √©t√© faite √† la va-vite sans relecture car il manque des mots ou des lettres ici et la.
L'histoire est extr√™mement lin√©aire, le "jeu" fait semblant de donner des choix au joueur qui n'ont en r√©alit√© aucune importance, pire il arrive (souvent) que vous ayez un choix entre "A" et "B", vous prenez "A" puis un peu plus tard un personnage vous sort une ligne de dialogue comme si vous aviez pris "B".
(Un exemple que j'ai en t√™te: √† un moment on m'a donn√© le choix entre aller parler d'un √©v√©nement √† un personnage ou se d√©brouiller seul pour y faire face, j'ai choisi de me d√©brouiller seul mais un peu plus tard dans la m√™me suite de qu√™te le personnage fait r√©f√©rence √† "notre discussion" sur cet √©v√©nement, alors que je ne lui en ai jamais parl√©...)
Aucune gestion du temps qui passe, les pnj attendent sagement que vous veniez les voir, vous pouvez donc aller parler une fois √† un pnj dont la situation est "urgente" et qui aura besoin de vous "la nuit prochaine", puis le laisser de c√¥t√© pendant trois semaines le temps de faire les qu√™tes des autres, quand vous reviendrez √† lui la situation n'aura pas boug√© d'un pouce en trois semaines.
La gestion de la soif de sang est une vaste blague, le jeu vous met sous le nez des occasions de vous nourrir sans arr√™t (parfois 2 ou 3 occasion en une nuit) alors qu'il m'a √©t√© possible de passer 3-4 nuits de suite sans me nourrir et la soif n'a pas point√© le bout de son nez, je suis sur qu'il est possible de faire le jeu entier sans se nourrir.
Enfin voila comme je l'ai dit au d√©but de mon commentaire ce n'est pas vraiment adapt√© √† un jeu, le style "roman graphique" doit selon moi √™tre agr√©ment√© d'un peu de gameplay, ce qui est habituellement pr√©sent dans les choix ou dans des m√©canique tel que ce qu'aurai du √™tre la soif.
Malheureusement le gameplay de ce "jeu" est inexistant, que ce soit la soif ou les choix rien n'a d'importance.
Pour ce qui est des points fort: les images sont belles et l'histoire est sympas (m√™me si je n'ai pas √©t√© jusqu'au bout car je m'ennuyais trop sur ce "jeu").
Ce qui rejoins mon avis comme quoi cela serai plus adapt√© √† un livre ou un anim√© √©tant donn√© que seul l'histoire a sa place.

column8: #ERROR!

Although playing the game has it's good moments, after finishing it I feel unsatisfied. Story was ok, but I feel not having any influence on it. Done the first few nights twice and despite making different choices it lead me on same railroads. Also I think I did some thing in a way that was not forseen by creators as at some point dialogues started to refer to events that didn't happen.
For fans of V:M or the WoD in general I could reccommentd buying it on sale, for others, I advice to not waste money.
Pros:
- music, graphics and some parts of the storytelling that creates good Vampire the Masquarade atmosphere.

Cons:
- lack of possibility to do multiple saves or easily fast forward some parts, what would make it interesting to replay it and check outcomes of different choice. Now you need to paly it whole again and again, just clicking through all the conversations you already now - that is a huge fail.
- as it's text game with so little free-choices that matter, it would make it more bearable if the text could just go on themself and you can read it like a book, not having to click everytime some character speaks a a word or two... to see another word or two, so annyoing.
- feeling of absolute lack of impact on the story. It's nowhere near role playing game or even paragraph game. Even choice that story tells me are suicidal do not result in "game over". Game just drags me through it, giving feeling of total dissapointment at the end, despite story itself being interesting.

I wrote a bad review for the terrible sequel to this game, so I figure it's only fair for me to circle back and say that THIS game was actually pretty good.   Although it's a straightforward "Choose Your Own Adventure"-style Visual Novel, there are lots of branching paths and so many choices that you can play it through mulitiple times and still have plenty to explore. Some of the characters and dialogue are  predictable stereotypes yanked from the sourcebooks,  but that's charming in its own way.  if you know the V:TM world already then you will  get exactly what you signed up for, and if you aren't  familiar with the franchise then this is a great introduction. The artwork has a watercolor look that's much more evocative than any oversaturated 3D environmenit, and the music is well-calibrated to the scenes. I was genuinely suprised by at least one of the endings and they got the mood right. I hope this studio continues with more games in this vein. (ha! Vampire pun)

Consigliato √® una parola forte che pu√≤ essere spesa in una sola condizione possibile: tempo da poter perdere e prezzo del gioco fortemente scontato.
Aspetti negativi: il gioco risulta prolisso al limite dello sfinimento e le scelte che √® possibile operare sono pochissime. Manca completamente qualsiasi gestione del personaggio che pure ci si trova ad interpretare. Since bloodlines 2 got cancelled I needed a fix for my world of darkness craving.

Many reviews stated the game was worthwhile and i did enjoy an interactive story but I'm always skeptical at how "solid" it will be to play a "book".

I've played through twice, the game took approximately 4 hours each run. I wasn't sure what to expect but here goes:

You choose 1 of 3 vampires (toreador, ventrue, or brujah) each character is namable but has the same appearance, so the story will reflect the gender/ethnicity of the character.

Much like vampire bloodlines, you are a sireless vampire and are spared the fate of dying for it. You are adopted by a Toreador primogen (which is basically the leader of her clan.) She teaches you the ropes of being a vampire and puts you to work doing various missions for her.

Part of the story is gathering allies, each ally has an interesting design and side story. The end has a splash of intrigue and vampire politics which is common in the series. I won't spoil the ending of course, but it wasn't as good as I'd hoped. But regardless, the journey was worth it.

The writing is very well done and keeps you focused on your vampiric journey. There are lots of good sound effects and the background images seem to come to life for still images giving a solid representation of the area you're in. 

Despite being an interactive novel - there is a solid amount of interest to keep you going and it does offer multiple play throughs - not only because of the different character choices at the start, but also there is a limit for how many side quests / companions you can amass before it's time for the ending.

All in all it was a solid purchase. I managed to get it for $5 CDN on sale and it was worth full price (which would've been like $20) I have yet to play the sequel: shadows of new york, but it is next up for me, though the reviews suggest it isn't as good.

If you are new to the world of darkness/vampire series, do give this one a shot. It doesn't rely on any previous knowledge and will explain all the terminology and concepts as you play. It is a nice casual game that doesn't require reflex timing, just careful decision making, and I really enjoyed it. Hopefully you will too!

column8: A lot of fun, great dialogue and characters, and then the game abruptly ends like a punch in the gut, leaving everything unresolved. I wish I hadn't let myself get attached when none of it mattered at all in the end. Not recommended, and this is coming from someone who played and loved Bloodlines.

column8:
This is a not a 'Choice Of' or 'Choose Your Own Adventure' style game, so much as it is a story on rails, but it is good for what it is.  It also acts as an excellent introduction into the World of Darkness and Vampire the Masquerade, with the story following you from the moment of your' embrace', that is, being turned into a vampire, and the short time afterward.

I'll be taking a lot of inspiration from this game in running a tabletop session of Vampire the Masquerade for several players who have never played before.

You don't feel like you can control yourself in this game and not in a good way. A lot of dialogue options are just guesswork rather then skill, which is made worse by the inability to reload your saves. So if you mess up cause the game says so, you are stuck with it. Also the game constantly screems at you to hunt, but doesn't allow you to step back from the main story to hunt. Good ideas, horrible execution.

TL;DR: Coteries is a Visual novel where it starts off strong, but is completely deflated by the ending wrapping things up in all the wrong ways. At least its fairly short, but replaying through it just shows you how little choice you had in the matters. Full review below contains spoilers.

On a first play through, the game sells itself quite well for most of its runtime. You have two events per night you can do, sometimes taken up by a required task. You are told to gather up a coterie (allies), and there are four options all of whom have their own stories. There are three other optional stories as well, along with the main plot that advances no matter how your sidestories are going.

When you get to the ending though, it becomes abundantly clear absolutely nothing you did mattered. The allies you could have picked up? Show up in one scene before the final one to rescue you, then disappear. Did you complete the other side stories? Doesn't matter. Nothing you do in the final scene matters. Its a weirdly non-sequitar ending, zero lead up to it or any hinting. Just...dude shows up, says he's the real mastermind, you've met him once -maybe-, and he ends the story. His villain monologue is downright awful and makes zero sense. The ending literally could have cut to black before the final 'showdown' and I would have liked it about the same.

On replays, its clear everything matters even less. Other than just not getting a game over, nothing you really do in the game matters. Recruit no allies? Still get to the ending, zero real change. Be an obnoxious prick, try to buck the story, want to ally with one side or the other? Doesn't matter, no one asked you, as long as you don't get a straight up game over from blood you'll see the same ending. Which character you picked? Changes some optional power usage and which 'past life character' sidequest you get, but nothing else.

This game could have been made a kinetic novel, just told its stories one after the other, and you wouldn't have really lost anything.

Buy it on sale. The art is great and the writing is good enough to make a visual novel cool. Unfortunately, this train has 1 destination and insufficient branches to at least make the ride fun more than once. The other negative reviews have it right but, essentially, the game gets cut short.

There are stories that aren't followed and the ending is shockingly sudden. I get that it's world of darkness but if I'm gonna ride the train to the end of the line, at least have ways for me to pick or keep my friends on board til it's over.

column8:
[No Spoilers Review]
This game is an interactive story. No action at all, just making choices in a long text adventure with background music and slightly animated high quality stylish pictures. (So it should run on any PC).
If you already know the "World of Darkness", you will probably like this game, just as you would if you're into vampire/goth culture and stuff.
The story is interesting and genuinely exciting at times, but it suffers from what all WoD rpg type published adventures seem to suffer from. You are stuck on a roller coaster, and when you reach the end of the ride, you realise it was going to end there no matter what you did.
So I finished the story once successfully, then died unexpectedly during my 2nd run. There are multiple paths to follow, so you will have to play through more than once to get the whole experience.
I purchased this game during a sale event. At the reduced price it was good value for money.

column8: Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York is a solid visual novel that offers an engaging story and interesting characters for fans of the TTRPG and lore. However, the game is on the shorter side, which may not be appealing for those looking for a longer gameplay experience. Additionally, the limited player choices and paths may not be enough to satisfy those who are looking for more interactive gameplay. Overall, the game is worth considering, especially for those who are interested in the Vampire: The Masquerade universe, but it may be worth waiting for a sale before purchasing.

Overall, the game is worth considering, especially for those who are interested in the Vampire: The Masquerade universe, but it may be worth waiting for a sale before purchasing.

column8:
TL;DR: if you're a VTM fan, buy this in a sale. If you're not a fan, I'd give this one a miss.

Boy, as a big fan of VTM I really wanted to love this game. Starting with the pros: the art is beautiful, the game does an excellent job of immersing you in the morbid atmosphere of the World of Darkness. The writing of the script is adept - it's fun to read and incorporates much of the highly interesting lore of the tabletop game. The soundtrack is nicely dark and atmospheric. Some of the characters you meet are very interesting too, namely Sophie, Qadir, and Hope. It certainly scratches that roleplay itch. 

The cons, however... are many. I think the biggest one that many reviewers have complained about were that your choices really do not matter - not in the sidequests nor in the ending. The ending itself (only one, by the way) is extremely rushed and you find yourself left questioning the motivations of the bigger players in the game that you will never find out. My first playthrough was more enjoyable because I was under the impression that my dialogue choices had an impact on the story, but by my second and third playthrough I'd found that most dialogue options throughout the whole game led to the same outcomes. It was very disappointing. 

Each character that you can recruit into your coterie has their own questline to complete, and each begin very compellingly in a way that attempts to flesh out different aspects of a modern WoD and the clans within it. For example I was very intrigued by a questline that delves into the unholy relationship between vampires and religion, or a questline that explores how vampires use the internet to their advantage. However, each questline (perhaps except Hope's) ends essentially the same way no matter your choices - often rushed, leaving more questions than answers. 

There are ultimately no real consequences to your actions. For example, on my first playthrough I was overly cautious about feeding - which usually risks humanity, masquerade violations, or the ire of whichever vampire owns that turf - but in this game, most feeding scenarios play out with little risk unless the story calls for it. As well as this, using obviously unnatural disciplines such as Celerity in public had little consequence either. This was one of the things that really did take me out of the VTM experience of having to excise utmost caution in order to keep your undead existence a secret. For a game titled "Vampire: The Masquerade" there's not really much in the way of actually upholding the masquerade. 

All this to say, if you're a VTM fan then I feel that this could be worth experiencing for the art and atmosphere alone. Though you should probably do what I did and buy it in a sale. If you're not a fan of the WoD then I'd give this one a miss - besides all the fun vampire lore and beautiful art, the game itself is unfortunately not worth the time.

The cons, however... are many. I think the biggest one that many reviewers have complained about were that your choices really do not matter - not in the sidequests nor in the ending. The ending itself (only one, by the way) is extremely rushed and you find yourself left questioning the motivations of the bigger players in the game that you will never find out. My first playthrough was more enjoyable because I was under the impression that my dialogue choices had an impact on the story, but by my second and third playthrough I'd found that most dialogue options throughout the whole game led to the same outcomes. It was very disappointing. 

Each character that you can recruit into your coterie has their own questline to complete, and each begin very compellingly in a way that attempts to flesh out different aspects of a modern WoD and the clans within it. For example I was very intrigued by a questline that delves into the unholy relationship between vampires and religion, or a questline that explores how vampires use the internet to their advantage. However, each questline (perhaps except Hope's) ends essentially the same way no matter your choices - often rushed, leaving more questions than answers. 

There are ultimately no real consequences to your actions. For example, on my first playthrough I was overly cautious about feeding - which usually risks humanity, masquerade violations, or the ire of whichever vampire owns that turf - but in this game, most feeding scenarios play out with little risk unless the story calls for it. As well as this, using obviously unnatural disciplines such as Celerity in public had little consequence either. This was one of the things that really did take me out of the VTM experience of having to excise utmost caution in order to keep your undead existence a secret. For a game titled "Vampire: The Masquerade" there's not really much in the way of actually upholding the masquerade. 

All this to say, if you're a VTM fan then I feel that this could be worth experiencing for the art and atmosphere alone. Though you should probably do what I did and buy it in a sale. If you're not a fan of the WoD then I'd give this one a miss - besides all the fun vampire lore and beautiful art, the game itself is unfortunately not worth the time.

Here's a bit of a mixed bag. While I definitely enjoyed my playthrough and FELT like things I did had weight and purpose, EVERYTHING comes crashing down at the very end, when it becomes blatant that nothing you did mattered. It only determines what characters get slapped onto the end screen. You feel like "Wait, where did I screw up? Did I do something wrong? How was I supposed to know this was happening?" Which SHOULD make it tempting to go back and play again to see if you can change things, but no, that's just how the one ending works. There are signs of course that that ending is coming but there's nothing that you can do to stop it, and that feels incredibly limiting. Yeah that's probably on theme for something like this, but with everything making you feel like you can change your approach and make things matter, it ultimately comes as a pleasant ride that ends with a sudden and abrupt slap in the face and a stab in the back.

Get it on sale if you really  want, enjoy the illusion the first go around, but be ready for the disappointment.

VTM Coteries of New York has good writing, great artwork, and a nice soundtrack that creates a nice atmosphere while reading.
I must admit, some of the stories where exhilarating and their respective characters were fun, like the Nosferatu and the Malkavian.


Now to the bad:
The game promises 3 defined characters to play as, Brujah, Ventrue and Toreador. When in fact, there is little difference between them and their stories. They all follow the same main plot and have the same side stories. No uniqueness.
By lore, not all Disciplines are not locked to Clans as is portrayed here. Also the game is linear and does not offer the promised "different ethical approaches", only a very FEW dialogue lines differ slightly.

The main goal of your character is to create a gang or "coteries" as they pretentiously chose to call it. You meet 4 characters and can recruit them by completing their story, but you can also fail to recruit them at the very start which locks them for the entire playthrough. Limiting and annoying.
Also after all the work, the ONLY place your gang comes into play is in the very ending, which has of little consequence! Even if you fail to recruit anyone, a complete rando will appear in their place so the story can continue.

The game claimed "Depending on your choice of the Clan you will be able to see the events from a distinct perspective", which was a F lie. This is literally the dreaded Mass Effect 3 different color ending lie.
"One playthrough is not enough to see all the game has to offer!" Wrong, it is more than enough to experience the whole story. The only issue is when you fail to recruit and have to start a new game or due to the limited nights available you are only able to recruit 2-3 out of the 4 recruit-able characters. This is basically backtracking!

Not worth the $20. It goes on constant 90% sales, what does that say about the game?
This game is worth $1-2 bucks but the REAL question is: is it worth your time?

I fell asleep during the game at least 3 or 4 times. Playing at work didn't help, just had the game running in the background. Reason for the 26 played hours on record.

column8:
I'm new to the Masquerade and wanted a bit of background knowledge before starting Bloodlines.
This visual novel seems to have been a good place to start, as it's told from the point of view of a fledgling being introduced into the world much like myself.

I've not had multiple play-throughs so I don't know how the choices affect the outcomes, but it seems to me that the point of this VN isn't to give you freedom, but to railroad you, giving you just a little bit of freedom to understand what are/aren't poor choices. It sounds like the sequel to this novel is more for giving you choices, so I'll give that one a go soon and see if I'm right.

I enjoyed this though.
Pretty sure that the Tremere are my kind of Vampires ^_^

It's good.
I like the story, most of the characters, the music and sound design. 
Has some replayability because you can't finish every side mission in one playthrough. 
One playthrough will take you 8 hours. Very good deal when you buy the game discounted.

The game also teaches you a lot about the world of Vampire: The Masquerade. Even though I played the TTRPG a couple of times, this game taught me a few things I didn't know and gave me a better understanding of some of the clans.

Great artwork and atmosphere. All the choices kinda made me feel like I was actually playing WoD/VtM. I enjoyed the read, and between the different clan and in-game options, it's certainly good for a few read-throughs. The main story doesn't change much but you can see the all of the subplots through that way or change things up a bit.

column8: Bought the game when it went on a 90% discount (just 1.99!) and I thoroughly enjoyed it! I really like the TTRPG, and seeing the different clans/bloodlines in the game and seeing that some choices were available depending on which bloodline you picked to play as was REALLY neat. Story was fun, characters are my beloved (I've only done Agathon and D'Angelo's quest-lines but plan to finish the game as all three characters).
