column8:
A review with quotes from the game: 
[i]"It seems like the worst idea ever, but the man's made it very clear that you have no choice in the matter".[/i]
Actually describes this game very well. The choices in this game do not have any consequence. Choose to remain silent about your boss knowing where you are, yet this vampire stills threatens him.

[i]"You find it impossible to decline her final request"[/i]
As all requests, since we have no real choices in this game. 

[i]"Their [the player character's] behavior since being Embraced has been disagreeable"[/i]
This happens even if the player chose the most polite options every single time.

Okay, enough about the lack of choices in the game.

In one scene, the player character remarks a character has [i]"a beautifully detailed sword"[/i]
But we don't get to see it since nobody bothered to draw it. Nor does the character portrait match the armour this person supposedly put on during this scene.

The same issue occurs later when a vampire is described as being horribly tortured, yet his portrait still looks completely normal, baseball cap still 'inexplicably' on his head and all.

[i]"You are being addressed by the Prince of New York City, Hellene Panhard"[/i]
That a Prince can be 'either gender' was not true, at least not before they retconned it in. None of the previous video games mentioned that it was "gender-neutral", a word which did not even exist when VTM started.

[i]"as you can imagine, there's plenty of licks who use feminine pronouns in this city"[/i]
Pronouns, really? How is this Twitter-speak 'immersive'? And could have just said 'women', but okay.

Clann Brujah members being described as [i]"neo-Nazi claiming to be "alt-right"". [/i] in the in-game dictionary
Yeah, another preachy political reference by the devs that will age like milk. 

This game could have been so much better if they focused on improving the scripting (referencing player choices in later dialogue) rather than shoehorning in needless current-year political references, which are truly immersion breaking.

Como todo v√°stago necesitamos gu√≠a y nos adopta¬†Sophie¬†Langley, una vampira del Clan Toreador que se hace cargo de nosotros a cambio de servirle fielmente. Deberemos controlar nuestra hambre, respetar la mascarada y¬†formar nuestra propia "coterie" reclutando a otros vampiros.

‚úîÔ∏èLa m√∫sica es ambiental, no resulta un estorbo en la continua lectura. Tambi√©n acompa√±an algunos efectos de sonido como por ejemplo: pasos, puertas, disparos...

column8: O jogo n√£o √© apenas mais um de Vampiro: A m√°scara, o jogo me surpreendeu no final, apresentando elementos que n√£o eram completamente previs√≠veis. Como uma Visual Novel de vampiro, cumpre muito bem o papel.

Good game if you're looking to understand the dynamic world of "Vampire: The Masquerade". The characters are great, the dialogue is unnaturally enjoyable for a game of this nature, and I would constantly catch myself eyeballing the various character portraits and art presented. However, I will say that the ending, which I will not spoil, left quite a bit to be desired. On one hand I understand its purpose in the meta-plot and lore; but, with that understanding comes the harsh realization of what you actually represent when placed into this world. Long story short, buy this game if you have a Saturday to kill and wanna get satisfy your vampire itch, just know that the ending, although lore accurate, may leave a bad taste in your mouth.

There are a lot of side stories and a main one. Every night you can only advance a bit on each story (you decide which one) + a bit on the main one (it just happens). Suddenly the main story ends and the credits roll out so abruply that it feels like a crash to desktop and you miss all the other content. 

It is not a replayability thing, the side stories are not presented as decisions nor affect the ending, and I didn't die or anything. I should be able to meet with the guy that agreed to see me next night to continue a conversation, or to participate in the rescue of someone after I offered to help. Hell, at least I should be able to give an answer to the question they asked me before the credits. I liked the characters and stories, but the design feels bad, the game kicked me out.

I've basically wasted my life playing video games. It's been a while since I felt engaged in one. Other games - even AAA ones - are becoming collections of cash grabbing techniques, with nothing but repetitive formulaic tricks. They're a tourist trap for gamers. They are an overmarketed collection of well trained people's day jobs' work in a rat race industry and it shows. They have no soul and you can taste no emotion when you play them nor when they play you.

Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York sucks you in and invests you in the story. As with other games in the VtM series, the lore is superb. You can sense passion in its writing. Someone thought something would be cool, so they did that. Only 13 h in and I've experienced more delicious emotion from it than 60h of playing anything new from Blizzard/Activision or Bioware/Electronic Arts.

To think that a Visual Novel genre could give so much more despite using so much less of what the gaming format offers. It really shows that being productive and being an artist may not coincide.

I recommend Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York. I am a disgruntled gamer disappointed in the uninspired and sketchy gaming market of the past decade, but this game is inspired.

They have no soul and you can taste no emotion when you play them nor when they play you.

Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York sucks you in and invests you in the story. As with other games in the VtM series, the lore is superb. You can sense passion in its writing. Someone thought something would be cool, so they did that. Only 13 h in and I've experienced more delicious emotion from it than 60h of playing anything new from Blizzard/Activision or Bioware/Electronic Arts.

To think that a Visual Novel genre could give so much more despite using so much less of what the gaming format offers. It really shows that being productive and being an artist may not coincide.

I recommend Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York. I am a disgruntled gamer disappointed in the uninspired and sketchy gaming market of the past decade, but this game is inspired.

I've played this game quite a number of times. And the outcome always changed for me, no matter the Clan I was and who I would seek for my coterie. The point is the game never gets old, and everything from the dialogue, the music, and imagery is wonderful.

PUNTOS POSITIVOS

- Si eres fan de Mascarada seguro que apreciar√°s los personajes y algunas (quiz√° no todas, cada cual tiene sus gustos) de las historias. 
- Los escenarios me han parecido muy muy bonitos (nivel podr√≠a ponerme alguno de fondo de pantalla)
- La m√∫sica tambi√©n acompa√±a.
- Te dejan elegir muchas veces entre varias opciones, lo cual se agradece (hay visual novels en las que tu papel es pr√°cticamente testimonial) 

PUNTOS NEGATIVOS
- El juego no es particularmente largo, a mi me ha llevado 5 horas, me hubiese gustado que siguiera un poco m√°s.
- Dir√≠a que no es muy rejugable (pas√°ndomelo una vez mas ver√≠a pr√°cticamente todo lo que no he visto en el primer run salvo evidentemente al tercer personaje jugable, pero pas√°rselo una tercera vez ser√≠a probablemente aburrido). 
- La traducci√≥n al castellano es, simplemente, penosa. Evidentemente se puede jugar en ingl√©s (cualquier obra literaria, que es lo que es esto al fin y al cabo, siempre se aprecia m√°s en su lengua original), pero entonces no leer√°s ni una sola vez todos esos t√©rminos tan chulos que nos gustan del juego de rol.

CONCLUSI√ìN:
- Si te gustan las visual novels (a alguna he jugado pero tampoco dir√≠a que sea muy fan) y/o eres fan de Vampiro: La Mascarada (que es mi caso), este juego te va a gustar si o si. No obstante, debido a que tambi√©n tiene varios puntos negativos, lo aconsejar√≠a sobre todo rebajado.

You will be delighted to hear that in a game called Coteries of New York, there is exactly one coterie. Well, maybe not even one - you don't so much as form a coterie as you pester a few other vampires for a few days until they throw up their hands and say "Alright, fine! I'm your bloody friend!". They never interact with each other, or even you - after this event.
To make matters worse, you can make exactly one choice in the game - to determine which NPC saves you towards the end of the game. And if you dont make that choice? The game steps in and saves you, anyway. All other choices have zero impact on the story.
Please, don't waste your time or your money. Have more self-respect! You deserve better!

As with any "Choose Your Own Adventure" games, I absolutely despise games like this that do not allow us to have multiple save files for a playthrough. Even more so when the only option you have is "Save and Exit" but not "Save or Load or Exit". To make matters worse, the game somehow removes your save file if the character in that save file dies. Either that or it never saved the game because I did not press "Save and Exit" before making a choice that would kill me.

All of these flaws are enough to let me know that maybe none of the choices matters. Perhaps only changes in dialogues? I don't know. The game still progresses either way and from what I can tell, it progresses in a "good" way, as in, not something that could lead to a bad ending. Doesn't seem like there would be a bad or different endings anyway.

Such a waste of potential. It has beautiful artwork, beautifully designed user interface, enjoyable soundtracks and sound effects. I have not gone far yet but those flaws above is keeping me from having an enjoyable experience when playing this game. I may or may not finish this game simply because of that.

column8: Bien que le syst√®me d'aptitudes et exp√©riences, qui contribuait grandement au style de jeu de r√¥le dans les jeux pr√©c√©dents, soit absent cette fois-ci, l'histoire est √©crite bien et vous fournit une ambiance de VTM tr√®s agr√©able.

The game will end before you can finish everything you're doing so you can only pick like 3 quest lines and you'll have to ignore the rest if you actually want to see the quest lines wrap up. In games like Dead Rising that's fine because the game is fairly long, you get to see most of the content in one play-through, and the side stuff is whatever anyway. The big problem with this game tho is there is just as much effort in the side stuff as the main story (if not more), as you have to kill time while you wait for your next main assignment. It's frustrating to have to start a whole new game just to see what D'Angelo is up to. It's a visual novel, there are three different characters to choose from (stinks that you have to play pre-made characters but it's not the end of the world) and that's where all the replay value lays, there is no real 'gameplay' to speak of, just reading and I don't want to read the same dialogue I already read. if I want to see how the Brujah character and Hope interact I need to start another Brujah game and just skip all the dialogue I've already seen, what is the point? Why didn't you just give me time to wrap everything up?

Most of your choices don't matter, your dialogue options are basically, "Will you say 'Oh shit!' or 'Oh fuck!'?" and it seems the end results will always be the same (unless you flat out fail the missions). If you're expecting Mass Effect level changes based on what you do, this isn't the game.

I just stopped getting achievements halfway through the game too if that's something that would bother you.

If you're a fan of Vampire The Masquerade I would still recommend this game. It does a very good job at illustrating the world, the story is pretty alright, and the characters are pretty good too. If I could could give a 'maybe' review rather than a yes or no, I would go with maybe. Maybe wait for a sale too, the game is short and you might want to do a 2nd run just so you can actually finish quest lines and so you don't make any stupid mistakes you may have made in your 1st run, but I don't really think I'll be doing any more.

column8:
Honestly, I wanted to love this. The artwork is gorgeous, the characters you encounter are mostly well flushed out, however...

You can't play more than three characters, no choice of who you are really, and the entire game is an illusion of choice. There's absolutely no difference to any ending or outcome or anything. The ending was hardcore rushed. It just felt abrupt and pointless. 

I've been waiting for a return to Vampire The Masquerade, and this just wasn't a worthy return.

a high quality visual novel set in the VTM universe, you can choose one of three characters, each character is in a different clan, the three clans playable are Brujah, toreador and Ventrue each with their own differences to the dialogue due to the clan disciplines and traits they possess. The core storyline is based around the struggle of power within new york between the Anarchs and the Camarilla, which fans of the series will be used to by now.

the game also features a variety of different paths due to the game being based around you putting together your own Coterie and each member of the coterie has its own path you can follow as well as a few other characters such as your mentor and a few others that ill let u figure out yourself.

the game is about 4-6 hours long (depending on your reading speed) on your first playthrough and you can replay the game a few times in order to see all paths which according to a few sources is about 8-10 hours, i personally havent finished all paths though like i did with Shadows of New York because personally i didnt like the ending for the game because it made me feel like my choices didnt really matter in the end, though that didnt take away my enjoyment up to that point.

if your looking for a good visual novel or more good games set in the VTM universe id recommend this game.

Les +

- L'ambiance est fid√®le √† la licence Vampire : The Masquerade.
- Un sc√©nario qui tient en haleine, sensiblement diff√©rent selon le personnage choisi.
- La capacit√© d'utiliser ou non certaines comp√©tences selon le niveau de "soif".
- Des PNJ charismatiques, avec un semblant de background.

Les ‚Äì

- Un manque d'interaction, beaucoup de narration pour peu d'intervention du joueur.
- Pas de gameplay si ce n'est de choisir des r√©ponses.
- La traduction fran√ßaise est bourr√©e de fautes, ce qui est dommage pour un jeu d'aventure textuelle.
- Des r√©pliques qui s'encha√Ænent mal et qui ne tiennent pas compte des choix faits.
- Malgr√© des qu√™tes secondaires relativement int√©ressantes, un manque d'immersion.
- La mort "ultime" fait revenir au d√©but du jeu, un peu trop punitif apr√®s X heures de jeu...

Note globale de Vampire : The Masquerade - Coteries of New York : 1/6

Si l'on consid√®re que Vampire : The Masquerade - Coteries of New York est un jeu d'aventure textuelle, l'exp√©rience reste franchement d√©cevante et loin d'√™tre digne d'une telle licence. M√™me si le sc√©nario n'est pas mauvais, la narration manque de corps et une relecture du texte aurait √©t√© appr√©ciable - m√™me certains jeux mobiles sont aujourd'hui plus l√©ch√©s. Bref, si vous tr√©pignez d'impatience √† l'id√©e de jouer √† Bloodlines 2, Coteries of New York peut passablement vous faire passer le temps, √† condition que vous ne soyez pas trop regardant quant √† la qualit√© de l'ensemble.

‚û°Ô∏è Suivez notre groupe "Culture Underground" pour d√©couvrir plus d'avis sur les jeux test√©s : https://steamcommunity.com/groups/cultureunderground

O visual do jogo √© realmente incr√≠vel, n√£o deixa nada a desejar. A trilha sonora casa perfeitamente com os eventos.  Por√©m o enredo chega a ser um pouco raso e os personagens com poucas personalidades, tendo apenas poucas escolhas a serem feitas. Por√©m recomendo pra quem gosta do universo de Vampiro A Mascara e n√£o tem uma mesa pra jogar, at√© que da para se divertir e sentir um gostinho do RPG por algumas horinhas. It's a bit point and click so if that is not what you're expecting then this game isn't for you. However I am really enjoying the story and setting. As someone that has played the World of Darkness tabletop, this feels right and if you're a fan i encourage you to play it

column8:
Top-tier horror-style visual novel.
Positives: Art, story and characters. The character art and the art of the environments especially is really gorgeous. The characters are diverse and likeable. The story is already pretty good from the start and it gets only better further down the line. It also includes some pretty memorable moments. The writing is great. It can be both terrifying and funny.
Negatives: There is only one picture for each character, which means that the changes in their face expression are only described in text, but never shown. Also the unskipable exposition dump at the beginning is kinda unnecessary for anybody who is already familiar with the World of Darkness.

column8:
This is short and sweet. I chose a Toreador playthrough. 
The only thing I disliked was that the fledgeling would often have the option of using words and concepts they hadn't heard before and had access to referencing personal details about people they hadn‚Äôt learned on screen. And since the story takes place over a pretty short time period it seems weird if they had picked that up behind the scenes. The game was also referring to the fledgeling as ‚Äúthey‚Äù, and the same goes for other characters on occasion, which seems to be because the game has both male and female protagonists and the programming didn‚Äôt want to take that into account but just did one ham-fisted version. That was a little bit of a bummer for such an otherwise excellent game. 
Everything aside, I really enjoyed it. It has lovely mechanics, it‚Äôs a good story with interesting characters and lovely artwork. It‚Äôs a choose your own adventure style novel and those are lovely in my opinion. Spend a couple of hours with a good Vampire, the Masquerade novel.

column8:
This is a tricky recommendation. There's a lot about this game that's really good -- the characters are interesting, the different substories are really great, there's a lot of really nice exploration of what it's like to be a vampire and the different challenges that come with not really knowing what's going on. There's a bunch of variation in the stories -- from tense detective arcs to action packed sequences to weird romances. Even the way it strips down mechanics from the games is fun.

Mechanically, it could, perhaps, be fleshed out a little more -- something like disco elysium is a great example of how you can added more ttrpg like mechanics to a visual novel to really make stuff pop, instead of this, where even using your powers is pre-determined. On the flip side, this feels... like it'd make this feel a lot more complex and hard to build and it already feels very cut down and minimal.

Spoilers for large sections of the plot:
[spoiler]
The problem, at it's core, is that the player really lacks agency here. The whole main plot is all about picking folk to join your coterie and building alliances but the actual impact on the game is nada -- it doesn't matter i you recruit 0 people or 3 people (probably the max? you might be able to recruit all four if you don't do the side stuff with e.g. the stalker or the reporter?) because their only actual narrative effect is who busts you out of the SI coffin right before the end of the game. And that doesn't really matter -- if you have no coterie, Kaisers stooge helps you, if you have three coterie members, it picks the first two you recruit, and there's like... no actual impact on what happens next based on how many you recruit.

Same goes for e.g. the whole stalker subplot -- it doesn't matter if Adelaide ends up loving or hating you, after you confront her at the art gallery with Sophie, she disappears except to reappear briefly in the ending sequence.
[/spoiler]

The end feel of this is a game that's really close to being great but just feels too narrow, too constrained by the story it's trying to tell to let you be a character in it -- it feels like a bad ttrpg campaign where the GM has already decided what the final scene is going to be exactly, in detail, and so everything up to there is largely irrelevant. And it's a real shame because like... individually, all these stories are so charming? Every one of the people you can recruit is cool and interesting and it's just... disappointing it doesn't come together better.

Even the differences between the characters feels small -- like, it's not negligible but it's also not that big. I think this is down to the powers the actual characters have. Without being able to play a tremere, malkavian, nosferatu or gangrel, you're kinda forced into the most generic vampire types, and so there's not a lot of space to really let their unique abilities shine.

So yeah -- this feels like a really negative review but it's really... I deeply enjoyed this game and I just wish it got more space to really shine, to really let you make a big impact and make the characters you like actually matter to the plot.

column8:
On balance... no. 

There are too many characters and some of them are not fun at all. I couldn't make any sense of Hope's dialogue with all of the @s and missing spaces. 

Also, I expected to be able to make my way through the plot threads in my own time. Instead, I was thrust into an ending before I was ready.

My first foray into the visual novel, and my last I am sorry to say.

column8:
The game is a beautiful story in the form of a visual novel, with an interesting cast, a compelling narrative, and a dialogue and choice system that does a fair job at convincing you your choices matter when ultimately? They might not.

The story is somewhat linear, as no matter how you choose to go about it, it was always going to end the same way, but in a way that's actually pretty poetically accurate to what message the story was trying to convey

Spoilers: [spoiler] A typical Vampire: The Masquerade game that puts you in the role of a Camarilla always tends to have an important message about your role in the game. Most of the time it's a question of whether you'll remain a pawn or whether you're destined for something greater, but sometimes, as is the case with this story, it's an emphasis on how for some of us, there never really was any choice in the matter. [/spoiler]

The dialogue options admitedly don't affect the ultimate outcome of the game, as there really is only one real ending to it all save any "you died" fuck-ups. but the choice between what clan your character is and the sprawling side stories you can explore between the four Coterie members really sells the illusion of this game having more to it than it does.

There are a few spelling errors or glitches in some dialogue choices but never so frequent as to be a burden to the enjoyment. The visuals are stunning and the character sprites look amazing, the dialogue is fun and engrossing, the music is great, and the narrative was compelling and in line with what you'd expect from V: tM stories with some twists and turns I didn't even see coming. 

Normally i'd consider it a strike against a game when the game just sells you the illusion that all these dialogue choices matter and normally i'd say the game isn't worth the play for that alone but the narrative of this one totally sold it for me. I felt like I had full control over who my character was trying to be and the fact that all roads ended up leading to the same path felt more akin to the purpose of the entire meaning of the story than anything. It was SUPPOSED to always end that way, because that was the purpose of your entire story. 
If that kinda destined fatalistic BS doesn't vibe well with you than I can TOTALLY understand if this isn't your thing, but I recommend it for the beauty and the narrative alone.

column8:
Beautiful game, too bad it's not in Spanish.
I would've liked to be able to create my own character, but it is still very entertaining to play with the pre-created characters.
It's worth the price, especially if it's on sale. Several hours of entertainment and many ways to replay it.
I recommend it! :)
column9:
Beautiful game, too bad it's not in Spanish.
I would've liked to be able to create my own character, but it is still very entertaining to play with the pre-created characters.
It's worth the price, especially if it's on sale. Several hours of entertainment and many ways to replay it.
I recommend it! :)

column8: Some dialogue responses are missing the text that tells you what they say. Given that dialogue is the entirety of the game, this is a rather serious bug. At this point in the game's life it seems this is unlikely to be resolved and so while it's a fun visual novel with high graphical production values, I cannot recommend it.
column9: Some dialogue responses are missing the text that tells you what they say. Given that dialogue is the entirety of the game, this is a rather serious bug. At this point in the game's life it seems this is unlikely to be resolved and so while it's a fun visual novel with high graphical production values, I cannot recommend it.

Genderlocked Clans, prefab Characters (which i disliked all) to drive on a railroad through a mediocre story.
My fault to buy a game without research it on youtube, at least it was in a sale.
Still pity the 8 bucks for that one.

column8: Not the best VTM game I've played. It's more of a choose your own story, but with few options. The graphics are nice. I'd prefer to have more clan options and the game has no stats beyond hunger and very little for character progression. Despite the pretty artwork, I'd still choose Night Road and Out for Blood over Coteries of New York.

column8: Ends a little strangely, and confusingly, but up to that point it's good - well written, interesting, and doesn't drag on for too long. Enjoyable.
column9: Ends a little strangely, and confusingly, but up to that point it's good - well written, interesting, and doesn't drag on for too long. Enjoyable.

column8:
I would like to recommend this, I enjoyed my first couple hours, I enjoyed building a coterie with a cast of interesting young kindred who all stood out in their own ways. Hope, Tamika, D'Angelo, and Agathon were absolutely the best part of this story, but they were entirely wasted. There is no payoff to building your relationships with these characters. And you're not given enough time to explore those relationships as deeply as I would have liked to. 
This game also has a pretty severe pacing issue, specifically at the end. Plot threads are slowly introduced through the whole story, only for the game to abruptly end before any of them are really explored. The final scene was so rushed and incoherent that it isn't at all a satisfying payoff to all you've done up to that point. All of the quest lines that you're given the option to explore throughout the game are completely meaningless, and you most likely won't be able to finish any of them if you do what most people likely will, and try to split your time between all of them instead of going through them all, one at a time, in which case you won't have the time to meet all the characters or even touch all of the quest lines. Which I would argue would be great for replayability, except for the fact that it has absolutely no effect on the overall plot and how the story ends. If there's one thing this game does great, it's make you feel like a useless fool, and that nothing you do matters in the slightest in the end. I can't say too much more without heading too deep into spoiler territory, but I really can't recommend this over literally any of the other VTM games available on Steam. 
It's a real shame, because there are things this game does well, but in the end it's all thrown away.

column8: One of the very few games I couldn't bring myself to finish. I loved other VTM games and have enjoyed my fair share of slower adventure, hidden object, and visual novel games but this one didn't click. Nice art and ambiance but still lacking a certain je ne sais quoi. Dreadfully boring. Lacking a quickload or rollback feature is odd, imagining anyone would slog through this game a 2nd time is beyond my ability to suspend disbelief. If this game were a vampire it would be the thinnest of thin-bloods.

5/10 So-So

In essence, a choose your own adventure book set in the universe of Vampire The Masquerade. You get turned into a vampire and away we go. It features three origin stories, but only one ending, which is a shame. There‚Äôs a main plot that mixes in with semi-optional plotlines that you can choose to chase up with.

There‚Äôs not a lot to say really, you use vampire powers to get by and you get to explore a new world of the Vampires, however, the story is very short, like Werewolf Heart of the Forest; you can finish a single run in 3 or 3.5 hours. You can buy full-fledged 10-20+ hour visual novels for half the price of this, and you‚Äôd get more endings and more impactful choices.

That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm not scoring it very highly even though I did enjoy it somewhat. It‚Äôs also worth noting, that despite being called Coteries of New York, and despite the fact you do try to establish your own coterie, the actual in-game impact of it is zero. You don‚Äôt build up relationships once you‚Äôve established the coterie, it doesn‚Äôt play a major part once established, and amusingly, if you fail to establish one, the story carries on regardless. That‚Äôs pretty poor for a ‚Äòvisual novel‚Äô, you‚Äôd expect it to lead to a bad ending or something like that. On top of this, the game doesn‚Äôt use some of the more interesting cast members, and then finishes off with a sudden trap-type ending that whilst amusing, doesn‚Äôt really hold up as an enjoyable ending.

Overall a missed opportunity really, if you‚Äôre interested in a Vampire story, buy this on sale, you can find it for 50p on some dodgy websites, which I‚Äôm sorry to say, is better than paying the full price it is priced at.

column8:
Didn't really know what to expect with this game, but I am glad I got it. I needed a game to fill my need for Vampire content with Bloodlines 2 being a distant hope at this point. I would say it started off slowly, and didn't really capture my attention right away until about the midway point. At that point I really wanted to see where this was going to go and I was hooked. 

Nice visuals, and the writing is very good. If you are a fan of the TTRPG (vs the games like Redemption & Bloodlines) I believe this will certainly tickle your fancy.

Story is meh at best. They do a good job of letting you know how things work while under the Camarilla, but not for the other faction. Your relationship with any character does not affect the ending at all, which by the way is a plot twist that is poorly executed.

Soundtrack is acceptable, visuals are nice.

This being a visual novel, you are better off by spending your money elsewhere.

column8: √≥tima historia e trilha sonora envolvente, al√©m de ser uma √≥tima porta de entrada para a lore de vampiro a m√°scara.

Just as a disclaimer, I'm not a huge VtM fan, so maybe you might like this more than I did.  However, the two main issues I had with the game weren't related to the lore.  First, the entire game is less than four hours long.  Not sure if I went totally wrong and missed all the content, but 3.8 hours after I started playing it (restarting twice, after making a couple choices I wanted to reverse), I was done.  Second, the ending kinda sucks.  Not that I disagree with what happened (it should have been in the realm of possibility for that to happen), but more that you can't change it.  Maybe I'm wrong, but immediately after finishing the game, I had a WTF reaction, googled the ending to see if I could get a "better" one, and found out that no, you're pretty much locked into that.

If I had known that nothing I did ultimately mattered, I wouldn't have bought this game in the first place.  Also, four hours and done?  Granted, I got it on sale, but even so, I think I would have waited for this to hit the dollar sale.

column8:
It is kinda good for one run. I did all three to find any differencies - conclusion - almost none. 
Story is nice, and writing is too. Art style and character design are ok. 
But replayability, branching, consequences and etc are really nothing to speak of. It is really just short visual novella which you can play with different character and choose two out of four companions to read their stories too. I barely recommend it to be honest because from VtM game I was expecting so much more. One example of how such games should be done - is Life and suffering of Sir Brante. I hope devs will learn something from them.

column8: The game itself is not bad, the story is decently paced and the vampires are interesting, but the ending absolutely ruins it. It comes out of nowhere and is possibly the most unsatisfying ending I have ever had in a game before.
column9: The game itself is not bad, the story is decently paced and the vampires are interesting, but the ending absolutely ruins it. It comes out of nowhere and is possibly the most unsatisfying ending I have ever had in a game before.

column8:
So...  I wish they had a "meh" option.  It's a decent story.  Worth playing if you like the universe.

It's also...  oversold.  Sorry guys, I grew up on the "Choose Your Own Adventure" novels of the 1980s.  This, by comparison, is merely a pale imitation.  Yeah, sure, if you play like an utter moron at the very beginning you can get yourself killed.

After that however?  The whole thing is a bunch of Morton's Forks that have no significant effect on how the story plays out.  Yeah, it's a decent story.  The first time.  Playing through a second time to get the side quests you missed on the first pass is probably worth it.  The minor differences between your choice of clan though...  Not really worthwhile.  I only even bothered just so I could be sure there wasn't any way to influence the main story arc before I wrote this review.

If you like the setting it's probably worth getting when it's on sale.  I wouldn't recommend paying full price for it.

column8:
On the positive side this game has a few compelling characters and story arcs.  But that is all I can say positive about it.

This game appears to have one overarching plot with what appears to be several subplots that are inconsequential to the story and if you try to spread around thinking you'll be able to do them all before the game ends and experience the entire game, think again.  I only finished 2 of approximately 8 subplots before the game railroaded me into the ending and this left the game feeling very incomplete.  Why the main plot doesn't have a break point that lets you select it when you're done exploring the remaining subplots is a design choice I will never understand.  Any choices you think you are making are quite inconsequential.  The writing staff of this game tossed their politics into the game in at least 3 occasions that just came across as ham fisted and it felt like the writer's attempted to place an avatar of themself as an NPC into this fan fiction.

And you play through this game to be greeted with the most Scooby Doo of endings possible.

Eeeeehhhh. They had me in the first half, not gonna lie. Since a big beat of VtM:B was the importance of choice, an ending that doesn't change, pretty much no matter what you do, is upsetting, even heartbreaking. But the trip to that ending was surprisingly engaging. On the whole, I had the same feeling as playing Outer Worlds: great style and atmosphere, solid writing, you can see care and affection everywhere. And then it just abruptly ends and, without major spoilers, the Big Bad is a person you could feasibly never meet in your playthrough, which makes the ending that much shittier. The feeling of being a small part of a world that you don't understand and that actively dislikes you is very strong and works incredibly well for the theme, but the ending, oh the ending! Why or how. This game needs twice as much runtime and at least one alternate ending (without SI, ahem ahem) and then we can talk.

column8:
Having played Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines (which I loved) back in the day I was familiar with the setting but I was cautious as Visual Novels tend to be a bit hit and miss in my opinion (esp since I wasn't familiar with this dev). However I really enjoyed this step back into the World of Darkness.
It has a good story, great art and amazing soundtrack/background ambience making it immersive. I recommend this game and its sequel (though that is shorter).

Visuals: 8.5/10. Would be higher but there's only so many visuals you can fit into this type of game.
Gamplay: 7.5/10. Choose your own adventure style choices that feel like they matter.
Sounds/music: 10/10. The ambient sound was so immersive and I'm still listening to the soundtrack at work weeks later. World of Darkness games always seem to sound great.
Plot: 7.5/10. I loved the characters though the story was a little short so I felt like by the time I got to know the smelly yet lovable nior detective it was all over.

Overall: 8/10. Short but very sweet. Would recommend.

column8:
If you like reading, vampires, and choose your own adventure style books then this ‚Äúgame‚Äù is for you.  No intense graphics, I don't even recall an animation or cut scene. It is literally just you reading a screen and making choices. In my late 30s, I find it more and more difficult to sit down and stay focused on a novel so that was a plus for me.  The story is no Anne Rice but captivating enough and forcing you to make important decisions makes up a little bit for the lack of substance.  I usually played it before bedtime and most of time would find myself with heavy sleepy eyes. 

My complaint ‚Ä¶ not many because this is really just a book.  However, I noticed a few times that I would make a decision/choice and then the NPC would respond as if I chose something else. Or later in the conversation it will reference a choice you didn‚Äôt make or reference a choice you did make as if you never did.

Overall, 6/10.

column8: The artwork was beautiful, the music was great, and I liked most of the characters, but something about this one just didn't do much for me. The story was pretty linear, a couple of times the game bugged and said I didn't know information I had just read, there was no save system... All the choices that I did get to make (i.e. spending time with certain characters) ended up being superficial to the point that I might've liked it better if the options were removed and more time was spent setting up the ending - which itself was abrupt, out of left field, and unsatisfying. The aesthetic was wonderful and a lot of neat ideas were thrown around (discussing religion was especially interesting), but the finale felt so detached from every choice you've made up until that point, and weirdly pessimistic for the goal of forming of coterie. So... thematically coherent for VtM I guess? If it goes on sale and you're looking to find a way to spend a day, go for it, but I have no real interest in replaying it.

column8: VtM Coteries of New York captured a lot of the best parts of VtM games.  Although the gameplay is in the Telltale-style story form rather than first person (and therefore combat is not a terribly big part of the game) it still presents plenty of opportunities to develop your character and drive the story.  Exposition is woven into the story nicely so that newbies can pick up on the universe while old hands recognize the familiar aspects.  All in all, really enjoyed the roleplaying and story-telling.

If you care about seeing all the paths and twists the story has, you'll definitely get your money's worth here.

Not that deep of a game, the choices change very little, and very few are game-making or breaking, also very little in the RPG department, tho that's fair enough, it IS a novel.

That said, story's interesting, and captivating for the majority, save 1 character questline that's a little hard to stomach, but again, optional.

If you're a fan of the source material and just want to shut your brain off and deal with vampire politics, this is perfect for you.

column8:
Imagine a really short, really railroady, one-shot roleplaying session. You're given a goal, you meet one, maybe two NPCs, you interact with them for three or four scenes, you either achieve the goal or fail, and you're done, none of it ever comes up again. Now do that five more times. Then the GM drops a meteor on you, for no real reason. That's this game.

The game consists of a bunch of brief, optional side plots, and a _slightly_ less brief, mandatory main plot. These plots are almost wholly independent, and there's zero branching. The titular element, your coterie, is basically a red herring. You're (literally) given a shortlist of NPCs to recruit into your party, you do their sidequests until you run out of time, and then the ones whose quests you completed show up for precisely _one_ scene, in which they do essentially nothing and don't interact with one another at all.

Then the ending happens. That's ending, singular, completely unaffected by any of your choices, and none of your coterie even bother to show up.

So, no points for depth or plot structure. The writing is serviceable, I guess, nothing particularly memorable. Occasionally ends up on the goofier end of classic WoD. Like, you've been undead for maybe a week, and suddenly you're doing text-based Tactical Espionage Action, taking out a dozen Second Inquisition commandos in the middle of NYC, and then that plotline ends and the next night it's back to pretending the Masquerade is a thing.

The game wants your choices to feel weighty and irreversible, and also to hide how little those choices actually matter, and it really doesn't want you to think it's a VN, so it drops most of the basic usability features VNs have: no skipping text, no manually saving, no rewinding. It's a bit of a hassle, I guess, but the game's short enough that it doesn't really matter, and if you really wanna explore all the possibilities, you can always just manually save scum.

In summation, eh.

column8:
As someone who really loves the old WoD, I really enjoyed this. 
I also pretty much am in love with the artstyle - both backgrounds and the characters. 
Some parts of it made me really miss my old VtM LARP I was in, so that def makes me favorable toward it. 

If you're hungry for just more things VtM / WoD, this is good. Short, but good. But you should try to focus on a few contacts for each playthrough so you can get through their stories! Don't spread yourself too thin.

Honestly, I go back and forth on whether or not to recommend this game. Coteries of New York is so incredibly short it's almost like a Vampire The Masquerade promo for people who have never heard of the franchise, and the content you get is not equal to the money you pay. You can sit down and easily finish this game in 3 hours. That having been said, it's an enjoyable 3 hours. The writers had a solid grasp of how a story works, from beginning to end, and things made sense. The mood music sets the tone and the artwork is interesting, giving your eyes something to do while your imagination fills in the blanks.

Like pretty much every product released in the V5 Edition line, Coteries of New York hits you over the head with leftist politics with about as much subtlety as Antifa tossing a brick through a shop window. Boss Callihan is such a stereotypical 'evil white man' villain it's ridiculous, while the main characters are a rainbow coalition of minorities and women. This kind of political pandering is always a major black mark against any game, and makes you long for a day when games start focusing on artforms instead of platforms.

The reason I recommend this game, in the end, is because it's a gold mine for assets when it comes to telling your own Vampire the Masquerade stories online. You can take the music, artwork, backdrops, strip it down to the bone and reassemble it on an online tabletop platform of your choice to run an even better game of Vampire that's much longer than 3 hours. Diablerize what's good; leave the rest for the SJWs.

Mag sein, dass sich das Ende vielleicht nicht √§ndert, egal, was man tut - aber ich mag das Spiel. Seit dem Vampire-The Masquerade und Bloodlines gab es kein gutes Spiel mehr zu dem Thema und da ich auch sehr lange dieses Spiel als Pen&Paper und in Live Action gespielt habe, freut es mich sehr, dass es den Machern gelungen ist, die Atmosph√§re und vor allem das R√§nkespiel so gut einzufangen. Besonders gut finde ich die Malkavianer in diesem Spiel - sie werden als das dargestellt, was sie sind. Nicht einfach Verr√ºckte, sondern sehr gef√§hrliche Wissende (und klarerweise Irre). Sehr gutes Spiel, mit sehr guten Erkl√§rungen der Begriffe und einem Einblick in das System des alten Rollenspiels. Sehr zu empfehlen!

Joguei Coteries of New York ap√≥s conhecer o estilo em Werewolf - Heart of the Forest. Como curtia o Mundo das Trevas nos anos 1990, resolvi comprar um pacote que incluia esse aqui. Assim como Heart of the Forest, CoNY √© um jogo-texto com algumas belas ilustra√ß√µes, lembrando uma aventura-solo das revistas de RPG de antigamente. 

A hist√≥ria inicia com a escolha de seu cl√£ (Brujah, Ventrue ou Toreador), na noite que voc√™ torna-se um vampiro. O jogo serve como uma boa introdu√ß√£o ao universo de Vampire, caso desconhe√ßa o cen√°rio, com direito a um dicion√°rio de termos. Ap√≥s as primeiras noites, que funcionam como um tutorial, voc√™ ter√° liberdade para escolher as 'miss√µes' (na falta de palavra melhor) que far√° nas noites seguintes. Importante entre elas ser√° montar sua coterie, convencendo outros vampiros a serem seu aliados. O jogo tem dura√ß√£o de umas 15 noites, sendo imposs√≠vel realizar todas as miss√µes na primeira vez, ent√£o h√° incentivo para repetir a dose e conhecer todas as hist√≥rias que n√£o puderam ser conclu√≠das.

E √© na segunda vez que os defeitos de Coteries of New York ficam bem aparentes. Na verdade, o jogo √© uma "graphic novel interativa", porque n√£o h√° desafio nenhum. Em geral, n√£o importa muito se voc√™ usou seus poderes vamp√≠ricos para sair de uma roubada ou se preferiu resolver educadamente, ou ainda se preferiu descer o sarrafo em todo mundo, no final √© irrelevante. Os diferentes caminhos que voc√™ escolhe trazem uma ou outra informa√ß√£o a mais sobre a hist√≥ria e os personagens envolvidos, mas n√£o h√° a menor chance de voc√™ n√£o chegar ao final do jogo. Em determinado momento, por exemplo, voc√™ recebe a miss√£o de descobrir o nome da Senhora de um carni√ßal como pr√©-requisito para encontrar um l√≠der anarquista, mas n√£o importa se voc√™ consegue a informa√ß√£o ou n√£o: seu encontro com ele ocorrer√° independente disso.

Ainda assim, curti muito Coteries of New York pela caracteriza√ß√£o do universo de Vampire. Alguns personagens s√£o bem interessantes, como o Nosferatu que est√° investigando uma s√©rie de mortes, ou o vampiro que se questiona sobre a f√©. Mas dava para ser mais que uma mera graphic novel interativa, e sem muito esfor√ßo. Por isso, recomendo que comprem-no em uma promo√ß√£o, j√° que R$ 40 em um jogo que √© basicamente texto e suas escolhas s√£o irrelevantes √© um pouquinho demais.

If you're looking to get a taste of the World of Darkness and Vampire: the Masquerade atmosphere, this is the game to buy. But, it's rather boring. Your choices don't matter (save for the obvious few that can get you killed), and you just get to watch things spiral downwards. I'm not a fan coming out of games feeling hopeless and without agency, so I'm biased against it. I think this whole thing would have worked better as a novel (no false choices, just strapped in and ready for the read/ride).

If you're curious about it, try to get it when it's on sale for ~$5 or less.

column8: Enjoyable. If you are a pen-and-paper roleplayer, you should enjoy this. Also if you played the original Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines. Took about 7 hours to finish 1st play-through. There are 3 characters to play but the plotline is the same so the 2nd play-through is pretty much a re-run and a chance to do side missions you didn't get to first time round. As a minor criticism, it could have benefited from unlocking the story chapter by chapter once you play through once, to avoid literally hundreds of clicks through the same text you encountered in 1st play-through. Still, that's a minor quibble. Was enjoyable.
column9: Enjoyable. If you are a pen-and-paper roleplayer, you should enjoy this. Also if you played the original Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines. Took about 7 hours to finish 1st play-through. There are 3 characters to play but the plotline is the same so the 2nd play-through is pretty much a re-run and a chance to do side missions you didn't get to first time round. As a minor criticism, it could have benefited from unlocking the story chapter by chapter once you play through once, to avoid literally hundreds of clicks through the same text you encountered in 1st play-through. Still, that's a minor quibble. Was enjoyable.

Honestly? It's pretty good. I hadn't heard of the tabletop game that this is based on and I don't even like Vampires much. However, I really enjoyed the story, setting, and characters in this game. There are three characters you can choose to start as, they each belong to a different lineage, have different powers, and personal stories. You also can't recruit everyone to your coterie and do all the side stories, so the game has a bit of replayability. The ending is pretty abrupt, twofold even. However, it is an open-ended ending. And honestly kind of wtf, but in a good way. Not sure how it relates to the sequel or if at all.

I got this on sale and I would recommend it then, if not full price. Not much to complain about really. No voice acting and the ending like I said is abrupt. But, it was a shockingly good one. Like 4D chess shit. The art and effects are also really good. Overall, quite enjoyable.

Quite good story

Worth it on a discount (60% or higher).

Good art, fitting music, characters good. True to the Vampire The Masquerade spirit. 

warning: game as one major bug (it makes you skip an entire night and then reference events during that night that you didn't experience even tho you are meant to), and a couple minor bugs, once (maybe twice) dialogue choices were blank.

It is a good ending for a introduction to the Masquerade world. Its been about 6 years, at least, since my last vampire: masquerade exposure, and while i enjoyed the written story as a "refresh" , there is no way it will satisfy seasoned players who regularly either tabletop Vampire or Bloodlines PC game with mods. 

The ending, though good, is not satisfying because of the a) lack of agency at the end for the player character b) the reasoning/motive for the 'events' (trying to avoid spoilers) is lacking (i can think of one explanation but that would have required more emphasis/development).

The following would make it more appealing to experienced Vampire players (and make it worth fullprice): 
- would be nice if it had just a little bit of rpg mechanics: ie: more character creation choice would be good. an actual character sheet (even if just an very abridged version, made for story book version) and then some xp granted based on your actions to improve the character to give it more variation possibility on how to approach situations.
- a LOT more dialogue choice/story-line branches so it doesn't feel quite so "no choice - scripted outcome". 

won't be able to bring myself to play it a second time. the story is limited in its scope for choice. There is a single road to travel in this game. It is strictly a minimally interactive story. but still, its a good start of a template/foundations that could be something more if the developers wanted to be more ambitious.

Not a big fan of vampires or the original Vampire: The Masquerade PC game, but I had a good time with this Humble Bundle visual novel.
The good: 
Excellent introduction to a familiar world of vampire clans. I'm hungry for more.
Solid art, writing, music and ambiance.
Some truly interesting side quests (Hope's was a standout). 
Three choices for characters from different clans.

The meh:
To tackle all the quest content, you need to do at least two playthroughs; this entails a lot of repetition.
It's a short game. I finished two games in 9 hours total.
Choices don't matter all that much (except when recruiting allies).

The bad:
The ending was rushed and left me feeling a little empty.
You get the impression there will be more role-play mechanics, but all there really is is the need to feed once in awhile.

Verdict: Not worth it at full price, but I'm glad I played and am looking forward to Shadows of New York next.

Mam nadziejƒô, i≈º polska wersja jƒôzykowa kiedy≈õ siƒô pojawi, chƒôtnie bym wtedy powt√≥rzy≈Ça rozgrywkƒô, wybra≈Ça innego bohatera i inaczej poprowadzi≈Ça losy koterii.[/b]

The Good: Excellent writing.  Gorgeous backgrounds and character portraits, with just a subtle touch of animation here and there to spice it up.  Soundtrack is perfectly atmospheric.  Fascinating characters to meet.  The love for the WoD and VtM source material is absolutely dripping from every word and brush stroke.  

The bad: The ending was disappointing.  It felt like it came out of nowhere, rushed and sudden.  I would have liked to spend a bit more time in the game, get to know the characters better, build a stronger coterie, but just as I was getting into the rhythm of things, it was over.

Even with the ending being a weird note to finish on, this is still a solid recommend from me, especially if you are already a VtM fan.

column8:
Although the ending seems a little lackluster, the journey to it was rather interesting. This serves as an excellent introduction to the World of Darkness (Vampire specifically of course), providing a plethora of encyclopedia entries that naturally come up in dialogue to give clarity if the dialogue itself does not provide enough context. It introduces you to all the main clans and many of the sociopolitical structures and laws that serve to maintain the Masquerade and some semblance of order among the different sects. Where the game truly shines in my opinion, is its diverse and fascinating cast of characters. Although the game clearly did not give me enough time to meet and get to know all of them within a single playthrough, it certainly made an impression with the ones I did come across. (I am a big fan of Hope and D'Angelo in particular.)

As for gameplay, it is a very standard visual novel affair minus the mechanic of having to keep track of your blood supply in order to use certain dialogue options and choosing the right moments to feed. Your choices obviously matter to an extent, but as other reviewers have noted, the end destination seems to be mostly the same, which is unfortunate. If you don't like visual novels, even as a Vampire fan, this might do very little to win you over. The art is gorgeous (both characters and backdrops and hell, at times the writing too, to be honest) One fun way to play it, as I did, is to read it to a friend or significant other and do a bit of roleplaying voice acting. (She was a big fan of Qadir for thirsty reasons and the voice helped. :P)

I did briefly start the second game, and I will say this one is worth playing if you plan on moving into Shadows of New York, because there are a LOT of recurring characters alongside new ones. I've already been pretty excited to see a few of my favorites in the beginning. But one last note on what this isn't. This is not a proper pen and paper World of Darkness game. You will not be rolling stats, deciding all the particulars of a character, and having to rely on stats and skills to make decisions to progress the game. For that kind of thing, you're best off modding an old copy of Bloodlines or probably starting a pen and paper game yourself.

All in all, a very solid experience and I would give it an 8/10. Highly recommended for anyone trying to get a crash course on the lore of the world.

Although the ending seems a little lackluster, the journey to it was rather interesting. This serves as an excellent introduction to the World of Darkness (Vampire specifically of course), providing a plethora of encyclopedia entries that naturally come up in dialogue to give clarity if the dialogue itself does not provide enough context. It introduces you to all the main clans and many of the sociopolitical structures and laws that serve to maintain the Masquerade and some semblance of order among the different sects. Where the game truly shines in my opinion, is its diverse and fascinating cast of characters. Although the game clearly did not give me enough time to meet and get to know all of them within a single playthrough, it certainly made an impression with the ones I did come across. (I am a big fan of Hope and D'Angelo in particular.)

As for gameplay, it is a very standard visual novel affair minus the mechanic of having to keep track of your blood supply in order to use certain dialogue options and choosing the right moments to feed. Your choices obviously matter to an extent, but as other reviewers have noted, the end destination seems to be mostly the same, which is unfortunate. If you don't like visual novels, even as a Vampire fan, this might do very little to win you over. The art is gorgeous (both characters and backdrops and hell, at times the writing too, to be honest) One fun way to play it, as I did, is to read it to a friend or significant other and do a bit of roleplaying voice acting. (She was a big fan of Qadir for thirsty reasons and the voice helped. :P)

I did briefly start the second game, and I will say this one is worth playing if you plan on moving into Shadows of New York, because there are a LOT of recurring characters alongside new ones. I've already been pretty excited to see a few of my favorites in the beginning. But one last note on what this isn't. This is not a proper pen and paper World of Darkness game. You will not be rolling stats, deciding all the particulars of a character, and having to rely on stats and skills to make decisions to progress the game. For that kind of thing, you're best off modding an old copy of Bloodlines or probably starting a pen and paper game yourself.

All in all, a very solid experience and I would give it an 8/10. Highly recommended for anyone trying to get a crash course on the lore of the world.

Perhaps the most important thing you need to know about this product is that it is a Visual Novel with virtually no branching paths, and your choices do not matter. Once you've played the game through, you've seen all that the main plot has to offer, and the only ending- like it, or not. I would hesitate to even call this a "game-" that's how irrelevant the choices you may or may not make will be.

With that said, the art, sound effects, and music are absolutely fantastic. While the main plot can be frustrating, with a conclusion roundly considered to be anywhere from disappointing to borderline nonsensical, the sub-plots are better- at times, substantially better. This is where the real substance of the game lies. Each of your four potential "coterie" members have interesting stories; the other sub-plots are almost as good. Once again, however, once you've played it once, you've seen all there is to see. However, here, there is great writing and wonderful visuals to see.

It is a testament to how good the good parts of this product are that the omissions of choices that matter, and multiple endings, are exceptionally felt. If you're fine with that, enjoy great character art, atmosphere, and some good writing, then this might be for you. Just don't expect anything more than what's here.

Story line with D'Angelo seems a bit disjointed at times and does not properly explain thin-bloods to those, who are unaware of the term. Ending of Hope's storyline feels strange somehow, as well. The ending... Well, at the least, I'd end a final choice there. And, possibly, link the saves to the next game (but maybe this is done, I do not know at this point). And it's too bad, that only 2 characters you've helped come help you at the end, even if you helped all 4.
The Hunger system is unclear: visually and in general. it is also inconsistent, because some feedings and actions do not seem to affect the hunger at all.
Some pictures repeat themselves in areas, that are not even related. Nosferatu do not look that "ugly", even Bloodlines had them more beast-like. Characters could use more pictures, as well. At least different poses. I mean, the art is good, so why not?
Not sure about the limitation of only 2 stories per night. I think each story should have had a "timer" of sorts, that increased depending on your choices (where applicable), but still had a minimal value (like 2 hours, depending on each story), so that you could theoretically do 3 or even more stories at one night. On the other hand, that could leave an empty night or 2, but it could have been handle quite easily.
Overall, it's an ok game. It lacks depth in some places, and some choices clearly show, that some information was missed before (and thus do not make sense), but branching dialogues are not as easy, as one may think. It did make me remember portions of original Bloodlines game somehow, so the atmosphere is there at least, which is important for games likes this.

column8:
[h1] Short and atmospheric Visual Novel for fans of Vampire the Masquerade [/h1] 

If you like reading and love Vampire the Masquerade this will be for you. You dive deep into the life of a new vampire and try to navigate the political waters of kindred/vampire society in New York. Ultimatetively this is a visual novel so there is lots of reading and choices. Though the system of hunger sometimes offers better choices or forces worse ones. Still, it is no real rpg like bloodlines or the tabletop rpg. The story itself is great and one of intrigue. But the ending falls short of the former narrative and kinda reminds me of a twist ending in game of thrones, which definitely fits the atmosphere of Vampire the Masquerade. Also, the game is pretty short. For a single playthrough I needed roughly 5 hours. In this time it's impossible to finish all events and quest lines, so maybe you need to play it again to see everything. Like with all games with narrative focus a lot of choices do not really matter at the end, nevertheless as a fan of the World of Darkness (the rpg setting) I had a lot of fun with this and was surprised by the quality and art style. Fans should definitely play it. Others shouldn't expect too much.

Vampire the Masquerade - Coteries of New York is a good introduction to the World of Darkness if you're looking to get into the franchise but feel too daunted to try out Vampire the Masquerade - Bloodlines instead.

However, if you're someone who enjoyed Bloodlines or VtM lore in general, you won't get much out of this game. This game feels like an incomplete experience on its own, but I would still urge you to check it out if you have the chance BUT you MUST and I repeat MUST also get Vampire the Masquerade - Shadows of New York.

The two games played together feel whole, especially since they share the same characters and the same world. The artstyle and backgrounds are also quite good. Besides that, the music for both games are very good and really sets the tone for the World of Darkness. However, don't hold any high hopes for CoNY. 

Keep in mind, it's only an introduction.

column8: Visual Novel-like games have been a guilty pleasure of mine for a long time, and Coteries of New York is no exception. It has some very good writing, an interesting set of characters and an atmosphere befitting of the world of darkness (or just vampires in general). My only complaint is that the ending, while intriguing, felt a bit rushed, and left you off with a cliffhanger that I'm not certain the sequel will ever address given that you'll be playing a completely different character.

column8:
A decent visual novel in the World of Darkness, a role-playing game setting with vampires, werewolves and other otherworldly beings. As per the name, this game primarily deals with vampires.

To sum up story with minimal spoilers: You're an unfortunate soul who, seemingly at random, has been turned into a vampire. You are then given a choice between death and being forced into becoming loyal underling of one of the older vampires. During most nights you have some freedom to do as you wish, while during others - especially in the beginning - you are forced into following the main story line.

In practice this means that every night you are either immediately move into the main story section or are represented with a map and icons for different characters in the game. Each represents their own story line. Besides the main story there are four "main" side-stories: one for each of the allies you can try to recruit. These are always available until you either finish their story or manage to piss them off and fail their story arc. These always take rest of the night to finish. In addition there are lesser side stories, identified with "Part X". These seem to only take half the night, so you should be able to pick one of them as well as a ally-story if you have a full night to spend.

The story is represented with  mostly static images and text. Every now and then you are represented with options on what to say, what to do or how to react to events around you. Some options depend on the background and clan of your character - you get to choose whether your character is a seeming nobody (Brujah), a businesswoman (Ventrue) or a struggling artist (Toreador). Each background provides you with different set of supernatural abilities. These vary from supernatural charisma to supernatural speed and strength. In World of Darkness each of the clans lore also has their own weakness, although so far I've only seen Ventrue's one presented in the game - my initial playthrough was with Brujah.

Overall the story itself is interesting and the game has a decent atmosphere. As someone familiar with the setting it has a lot of interesting details built into it. The game also has a dictionary that helps explain the terminology the game throws around, expanding as they pop up during the story. This should help someone not already familiar with the setting to not fall woefully out of the loop. The characters are also mostly helpful in this regard, treating the main character as a complete newcomer to their world.

Overall the game is enjoyable, but there are some issues that annoyed me to some degree, in no particular order.

- Each game is a single-save play through. This was really annoying, since often with this kind of games I like to check all options just to see what they lead to. This is especially true since as the player you can't always predict what is behind the options provided. This game is mostly good with this - I only had one case in my first play through where my choice ended up going way beyond what I wanted.
- Instead of enter moving the game forward you have a "Forward" icon. Pressing enter first selects it, next press activates it. If you move your mouse, the "Forward" button is unselected. This means you often need to press enter twice to move forward. Enter is also used to select your current choice of options. Unlike with Forward button Enter does not first highlight your option: you press enter without highligting an option and you select the first listed option. This combined with the fact there are no takebacks forced me to restart my game on night 14 because I first accidentally picked wrong story and then promptly fucked it up because of this frustrating control scheme. I soon decided to just use mouse instead to avoid further frustration.
- The main story line doesn't really seem to care much what you actually do outside it. I've only finished the story once so I might have missed something but... In my first playthrough I finished two of the "main" side stories, only doing the first one for the remaining two. By all logic this means I should only have two real allies recruited. Yet at some point in the story when allies are called upon who do I see? One of the allies I had finished recruiting and one I had exchanged less than 20 words with. EDIT: Looking at the achievements, apparently finishing their first story event is enough to "earn their cooperation". There's also achievement for getting their help later on. I have no idea how the helpers are chosen though, since I would've expected to get help from the two allies whose story lines I finished, rather than someone I met once in the game.
- There is not enough time to finish anywhere near all the side stories. I ended up wishing the main story had not been forced upon me (especially since I found it unsatisfying) and would've rather finished all the "side content" instead before moving on. I guess it does make it easier to replay the game, since there's so much unexplored content left after the first play through.
- I did not find the conclusion of the story satisfactory. I won't spoil it, but overall it left a mildly bad taste in my mouth. It perfectly fits the setting though, so I can't blame the writers.

Despite the above mentioned flaws I still recommend the game. It's (mostly) good story telling that respects the setting. It's not a masterpiece and has some technical annoyances, but it's a decent package.

In World of Darkness each of the clans lore also has their own weakness, although so far I've only seen Ventrue's one presented in the game - my initial playthrough was with Brujah.

Overall the story itself is interesting and the game has a decent atmosphere. As someone familiar with the setting it has a lot of interesting details built into it. The game also has a dictionary that helps explain the terminology the game throws around, expanding as they pop up during the story. This should help someone not already familiar with the setting to not fall woefully out of the loop. The characters are also mostly helpful in this regard, treating the main character as a complete newcomer to their world.

Overall the game is enjoyable, but there are some issues that annoyed me to some degree, in no particular order.

- Each game is a single-save play through. This was really annoying, since often with this kind of games I like to check all options just to see what they lead to. This is especially true since as the player you can't always predict what is behind the options provided. This game is mostly good with this - I only had one case in my first play through where my choice ended up going way beyond what I wanted.
- Instead of enter moving the game forward you have a "Forward" icon. Pressing enter first selects it, next press activates it. If you move your mouse, the "Forward" button is unselected. This means you often need to press enter twice to move forward. Enter is also used to select your current choice of options. Unlike with Forward button Enter does not first highlight your option: you press enter without highligting an option and you select the first listed option. This combined with the fact there are no takebacks forced me to restart my game on night 14 because I first accidentally picked wrong story and then promptly fucked it up because of this frustrating control scheme. I soon decided to just use mouse instead to avoid further frustration.
- The main story line doesn't really seem to care much what you actually do outside it. I've only finished the story once so I might have missed something but... In my first playthrough I finished two of the "main" side stories, only doing the first one for the remaining two. By all logic this means I should only have two real allies recruited. Yet at some point in the story when allies are called upon who do I see? One of the allies I had finished recruiting and one I had exchanged less than 20 words with. EDIT: Looking at the achievements, apparently finishing their first story event is enough to "earn their cooperation". There's also achievement for getting their help later on. I have no idea how the helpers are chosen though, since I would've expected to get help from the two allies whose story lines I finished, rather than someone I met once in the game.
- There is not enough time to finish anywhere near all the side stories. I ended up wishing the main story had not been forced upon me (especially since I found it unsatisfying) and would've rather finished all the "side content" instead before moving on. I guess it does make it easier to replay the game, since there's so much unexplored content left after the first play through.
- I did not find the conclusion of the story satisfactory. I won't spoil it, but overall it left a mildly bad taste in my mouth. It perfectly fits the setting though, so I can't blame the writers.

Despite the above mentioned flaws I still recommend the game. It's (mostly) good story telling that respects the setting. It's not a masterpiece and has some technical annoyances, but it's a decent package.

I'm off two minds about this one.  On one hand, it's a great introduction to this world and much of the lore surrounding it, presented with great art and neat music.  On the other hand, it railroads you into one conclusion where your choices seemed to matter, except they didn't, and the story just ends, sort of abruptly.

It oozes style, it's entertaining for the few hours it lasts, and the side stories are great, yet ultimately the main plot is rushed to the point it doesn't do justice to the universe it's presenting.  I hear it was made on a shoestring budget and it sort of shows, nowhere more obviously on how the main characters differ: even though at the start of the story it's implied their different clans will result in different outcomes on similar scenarios, that simply doesn't happen and the (few) differences between them are soon set aside and forgotten.

Similarly, the companions you make through some of the side stories bring absolutely nothing at the end except for some different lines.  Yet, you are introduced to their skills and how useful they will be in the upcoming days for a pay off that never comes, like an idea dropped because there was no time to implement more scenarios.

Still, that first playthrough... I was rather absorbed by it.  What it does well is certainly worth experiencing.  The sequel (Shadows of New York) is supposedly much better about the shortcomings of this one, but if you already own Cotteries or can find it cheap, it's a good snack.  Just don't forget to hunt for a better meal afterwards.

column8: I have played through this game three times just to confirm that my choices dont matter. They dont. They effectively sold a picture book with an awful and unsatisfying ending. If you are really hard up for some good vampire content, I would still recommending you look else where.

It is short, but is replayable. I am not certain one would wish to replay it, as most of the story is the same... but you can. It is basically a digital choose-your-own-adventure book from the 70-80's without the ability to easily flip back when a poor choice is made.
The story is good, but not great, and nearly all of the choices I found are basically meaningless - unless you are just plain suicidal.
All in all, a fun 3 hrs or so that skims the surface of a decent Vampire: The Masquerade tabletop session. There is enough there that it is good vampy fun, but it sadly pales in comparison to the real thing.

I'm a big Vampire fan, and an even bigger VN fan, and the positive reviews on this game are completely undeserved.  I truly believe the people leaving good reviews have never actually played a decent VN before, let alone a good CYOA.
You are presented with choices in this game, which ultimately don't matter because even if you ignore a path entirely it will be referenced in another path.  Furthermore, the ending of the game is a big hurrah about how your choices never actually mattered.  Literally felt like the end was written by a snotty 10 year old who is only DM'ing expressly to bully his friends.  The game also had some serious, game-breaking bugs---audio screwing up, text being misplaced, scenes skipping, entire days skipping (btw, you have a limited number of in-game days to accomplish your goals which, again, don't matter)...this game was seriously broken when I played.  There have been several updates since then, but reading the more recent negative reviews---these game-breaking issues were never fixed.  Seriously, I've played games thrown together in Ren'Py in two days that were massively better written and better optimized than this.  It felt to me like the developers have never played a VN before, let alone built one themselves.
This game is not worth the price, I honestly wouldn't even recommend it at half price.  The only good thing I can say about it is the artwork is nice.  I did also get attached to two of the NPC's, but the game is so very short---I couldn't understand why there was a goal of building a relationship with these characters at all since it just ends so quickly.
Not to mention, the writers weren't very brave with their writing.  It's a very generic vampire story with very generic characters.  Edgy Tremere, Crazy Malk [spoiler] who totally could have been interesting if they wrote her as an actual public streamer instead of just making her audience...herself [/spoiler] and forgettable ghouls and snobby elder vampires.  The only interesting thing about the game were the Nossies.  Honestly, if the game was longer, and the individual stories of these characters established and explored more, it really could have been a neat ride.  But as it is,  Coteries of New York is just bland and broken.

Nice intro into the Masquerade :)

I still cannot believe it's a full game and not just an episode... 7h I got on two playthroughs. 
Just when I started getting into my character and build relationships with other characters, thinking there will be plenty of time to actually role play, the game suddenly... ended. Apparently you cannot play as much as you want or finish questlines if you try to spread your focus around, cause there is a fixed amount of days in-game, that ends in the same, very abrupt, very disappointing manner. 
Moreover - on the first playthrough the game blocked on me when one of the quests didn't start, so yeah.

column8: Nice looking backgrounds and fitting music. I was enjoying the story (albeit a bit railroady) but various bugs in this game impacted my playthrough negatively. 3 times the same hunger prompt in a row that glitched through one of my days, skipping scene that were supposed to happen. I was meeting T and without it happening my character revered as having met C and being beat up by V, when this did not happen. Various dialogue glitches etc. Shame
