column8: One of those choose your own adventure type deals with a twist. Normally these types of games get boring after a few repetitive option. This one however nearly every option you choose raises the blood pressure. Gives a slight tickle in the chest and brings you that much closer to a psychological orgasm. As a WoD fan since its inception I approve of this game, and it is a game. There may be a lot of text but that's the fun of it!

column8:
Coteries of New York is a visual novel game which has immersive atmosphere.
If you want to enter the world of Vampire the Masquerade, you should play this before because you can learn about Vampire The Masquerade world.

Pros

+Great dark atmosphere and music
+It teaches you about the VTM world
+You feel like in a dark world

Cons

-There are three characters to choose from but, it is not affecting the story too much even you choose a different character

I would recommend this game to Vampire The Masquerade fans

column8: Disapointing ending.

It's okay, but... Choices do NOT matter. At all. Zero. Nich.
The game is polished, but the story feels rushed and unfinished. I can also add that if you think on it hard enough it doesn't really make sense: a VERY elaborate plot to reach a purpose that could have been reached in a million simpler ways (and no, it's not refined vampire boredom, it's just bad writing)

column8:
Was it a good game :        Well it was ok, the story was nice
Was it worth the money : Not really even though i got it on discount for about ¬£6, and i would be screaming 
                                          robbery if i'd been foolish enough to pay full price :(

In Brief : As i said it was an ok story that took you from point A to point B and little to nothing that you do or 
               choose during that journey has any real effect on the end, they should of just marketed this like 
               Highway Blossoms ( a straight story nothing else ).

Will I play any others in the series: After this one it is very unlikely, unless i pick them up for about ¬£2 each :(

3.75/5.  A good novel story that adds to the machinations of the kindred in New York City.   If you've played Bloodlines, this will enhance the world a bit.  If you replay Coteries a few times, you'll flesh out all the details.  It took me three hours for one play through, because I read fast.  Ran into a few dialogue bugs, but I could figure out what was being said easily.

column8:
Definitely a job well done. The atmosphere is so: VTM style. The story is interesting. The sound effects and the animated backgrounds are nice. The characters are interesting. The game feels alive. The VTMB nostalgia hits hard.

I am honestly more excited about this game instead of the new VTMB. ;d wow... and there is 2nd game I heard is even better.

PS - the game could use a bit more sound effects tho. Like some music in more of the places or something to distract you from the fact that you are reading from your computer. :) Otherwise. I love it.

column8:
That was adorable. 

Entertaining little story, not too deep or profound but not shallow, either. Captures the World of Darkness very well and has a satisfying cast of characters to interact with. A tasty snack. 

Regarding the much maligned ending. Everyone who complains about the ending should stick to D&D, y'know kids' games with superheroes and happy endings, Hollywood shit. V:tM isn't for them.

Is it a bit cliched, forced, rushed? Perhaps. But it's nonetheless *perfectly* on spec for the World of Darkness. However, mechanically it's a let down. Meaning, why did I spend the entire game making cool friends and at the end they're nowhere to be seen? Yes, I was hoping and expecting my coterie to show up. That's a reasonable expectation even for a visual novel (as opposed to an RPG) and it's a legitimate complaint about the ending -- and about none of your choices being "meaningful." 

Finally, this is a visual novel. Not a sandbox rpg. They're different. I shouldn't have to say that, but apparently I do. 

CONCLUSION: An entertaining interactive novel that does great justice to the setting. I'm not sure if it's good value for full price, but on sale if you're looking to fill that V:tM void it's a good buy.

Music and art style is 10/10 for me. The story is...good but nothing earth shattering. It's fun with some good little moments and it doesn't feel as clunky trying to fit into the modern day as a lot of other franchises do, but there's a lot of dialogue moments where I felt like the PC could have asked another question or done something different pretty easily and the options just aren't always there. All the NPCs were cool but I also felt really rushed through them so that's a downside. Overall I'd recommend tho

I was a bit lazy and didn't immediately write a review for this game, but here it is. I'm not really going to go in-depth, but I still feel obliged to praise its storytelling.

It was overall a very enjoyable experience. Would recommend.

column8: The writing is good and its a fun exploration of the WoD setting that works if you're new or already know it. Like a lot of visual novel games, its very railroaded, so be prepared for your choices to not make much of a difference. The ending is the worst part, it ends on a cliffhanger and doesn't fully explain what's going on. Other than that, I recommend it and its worth it if you find it on sale.

Great story game, not perfect. There are a few bugs where text doesn't display correctly (wrong text, no text, just depends on the situation) but otherwise solid. The artwork is fantastic, the limited animations add to the tone and feeling without being distracting. Music is really good, overall sound design is done pretty well. I beat the game last night after about 5-6 hours and immediately started over as a new character.

It would be nice if you had more Vampire Clans to pick from, but since each clan/character has their own start specific to that clan, I can see why they limited it. It is awesome that your character's abilities - and hence how you can deal with different situations - match VtM 5e clan abilities, so subsequent playthroughs aren't just "what happens if I choose B instead of C," your abilities to actually handle various story elements are different as well.

Aside from the buggy text, my only real complaint (minor spoilers ahead):

[spoiler]It was frustrating to me that I'm building a coterie that never really comes together. That's one of the main things you do in the game. I'm not certain if later-game events are triggered by your actions, or if it just happens after so many in-game nights, but it seemed pointless to have formed a coterie of three just to have one scene where they save you and it doesn't even involve your actions. It's definitely a "glad I teamed up with them" moment but I think I was hoping for more coterie-based activities before the story was over where we worked together on at least one mission. Maybe there is and I missed it, so I'm going to put off doing certain missions on subsequent play throughs.[/spoiler]

Overall though, I felt like the story and game capture the essence of Vampire: The Masquerade nicely. I definitely want to get the other Draw Distance VtM story game, "Shadows of New York" now.

Por√©m, na segunda vez, mesmo jogando com outro personagem, apesar das diferen√ßas na hist√≥ria o jogo se torna bastante repetitivo e d√° para perceber que o poder de decis√£o do jogador sobre os rumos da hist√≥ria √© bastante limitado. Mas vale a pena jogar, principalmente para quem j√° jogou outros games baseados no mesmo universo e achou interessante.

I was a bit torn between thumbs up and thumbs down, but ultimately I don't think it deserves a recommendation for the price.

+ The visuals are stunning, the backgrounds are some of the best I've seen
+ World of Darkness setting is always a plus
+ Fairly good written characters

- All your choices are meaningless. It always leads to the same ending. There are two bad endings that end the game early...but it is really hard to not see them coming. The story is good, but especially the ending felt disappointing...not only because it happens early.
- While the artwork is stunning, sometimes the background and the sounds doesn't seem to really catch you. A few more scenes, especially when some "action" happens, would have done this game a favor!

Now, the worst of all:
- This game is called Coteries of New York. That should mean that you get to build your own coterie...but you don't get to. You get to meet other vampires, and some end up being your "friend". But all there is to it is that they appear in a short scene that leads to the finale. You can't interact with them after you 'recruit' them, ask them for favours, you can't do anything with them after all.

It felt disappointing. So disappointing. After 6 hours I felt like I have seen all there is and that leaves much to be desired.

I hope that they try it again, same setting, more endings and more meaningful choices. And maybe next time they really let me build my own coterie.
Attractive graphics and pretty good writing but a very short and rail-roaded plot.
column9: Attractive graphics and pretty good writing but a very short and rail-roaded plot.

column8:
Game is a fun visual novel, has one bug on the Callihan meet and greet if your hunger is too high, it will skip the meeting but act like it happened the next day in conversation, so try to manage your hunger before this part to avoid it.

The sound effects of the darkness of being embraced are A+

You should play through this a few times to see how things pan out, as Shadows is the sequel to this and while a separate story, things have played out from Coteries to Shadows so you see what the 'canon' endings for this game were in Shadows.

column8:
[h1][b]Introduction[/b][/h1]
[b]Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Coteries of New York[/b] serves as a pleasant introduction to the [b]World of Darkness[/b], which is a grimmer version of our world, filled with supernatural beings, vampires in this case, who secretly live among ordinary people. While I am not familiar with the original tabletop games, I enjoyed playing [b]Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Bloodlines[/b] years ago, so I already knew this world a bit, even though I admittedly forgot a thing or two. Luckily, this visual novel manages to explain the crucial universe‚Äôs aspects engagingly without making you feel lost or overwhelmed. Well, I should not do so either, so let us dive into the review!
[h3][b]Story[/b][/h3]
Before starting this mature adventure, you have to choose one from three diverse characters whose personalities align with their vampiric clan. I started with Amanda because playing as bossy cold-hearted vampire woman appealed to me the most. Due to her leadership skills, she naturally belongs to the Ventrue clan. It seemed like the right choice for me, as the other options were a rebellious activist and depressed artist. After that, I could finally venture into the lively city of New York.

At the very start, you are still a human, minding your own business and going through your daily routines. That changes soon. One day, you get a visit from a mysterious person who is interested in working with you. While you are listening to his compelling proposition, he moves closer to you. You notice his unnaturally glazing eyes. He grabs you with his cold hands, and you notice that his teeth are getting longer. And sharper. You feel them on your neck, and then there is only darkness.

That would be rather a quick end, but believe me, it is only the beginning. You wake up and find out that you are hungry. No, not hungry, but ravenous. For human blood. Your character might be confused, but you already know what happened. From now on, you play as a vampire, and you will have to find a way to survive in this new yet the same world. This tension, which started in the prologue, is present for the whole game, which is about seven hours long if you are a bit slower reader.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2425489919
Not only that the plot manages to stay captivating the whole time, but new, compelling characters and sudden twists make the playthrough gripping from start to finish. Even though you want to find the vampire that turned you, the story shifts its focus to other characters and its world soon. Yet, this sudden change of pace actually works pretty well. That way, the game manages to introduce you to its world, to explain what exactly are those vampires, their clans and their relationships. And it does so briefly without overwhelming you with tons of information.

Meeting new characters and doing tasks for them was definitely my favourite part of this title. Each one of them is unique, with their own motives and fascinating background to discover. I adored Hope, as her bossy attitude clicked with Amanda‚Äôs one, thus creating a great duo. She is not afraid of using the new technologies we are enslaved by, meaning phones and social media. You are not assisting them out of the kindness of your heart because you expect their help in return.

What I truly enjoyed is that the game forces you into uncomfortable situations. Being a vampire changes the way you live and with whom and how will you interact. Sure, it is not your fault that you became the vampire, but the feeling of hurting others clueless people stuck with me, and your character is getting used to it too. You have to survive somehow, though. The fact that you cannot finish every side quest, thus you have to decide which are worth it for you, just adds to that feeling.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2425490186
Feeding on others‚Äô blood is the one and only aspect you have to keep in mind during reading. Throughout the time, an option to feed yourself, meaning drink blood from some poor person, appears. You can choose not to do it, but it comes with a price. Starving for a longer time will lock some of the dialogue options, as you will be too weak to perform them. I like this a lot because it tempts you to hunt strangers.

If you do not feast on someone for a longer time, your character might turn desperate, wanting human‚Äôs blood immediately, and thus impatiently killing someone on their own. That leads us to the Masquerade, which is not just a fancy word but one of the most important rules for vampires. You have to be discreet and try to stay hidden. However, even with the abovementioned desperate murder, I never lost the game or had to reload to some checkpoint. Thus I slowly realized that your choices do not matter.

Sure, the way you play affects your path to your goal, but the ending always has the very same outcome, even if you try to go against the game. I decided to finish the [b]Coteries of New York[/b] with the other characters, and while there were some different dialogues, it always ends the same way. Now, it is not upsetting, and I do not feel that it would ruin the whole time I spent with it, but it still leaves a bittersweet taste in my mouth.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2425488751
[h3][b]Audiovisuals[/b][/h3]
What makes this title appealing at first glance are its visuals, which are just amazing. As the plot mostly takes place during the night, there are lots of lights, neons and such. Backgrounds are not static, so you will often see sweet little details like raindrops, moving eyes, flashing lights, and more. Sound effects and grim compositions fit the game‚Äôs theme perfectly. All in all, I cannot really say anything negative about the audiovisuals, as the atmosphere they help to create is breathtaking.

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]
Despite my problems with the ending, I can still wholeheartedly recommend [b]Coteries of New York[/b] to both fans of the [b]World of Darkness[/b], as well as to the newcomers who are interested in the vampiric setting, as it feels like a competent introduction.

[b]PC Specs & Performance[/b]
[quote]My performance section will be rather obligatory this time, as I obviously did not have any problems. This title ran flawlessly on [b]60 frames per second[/b] on [b]i5 8300H[/b], [b]GTX 1060 6GB[/b], and [b]16GB RAM[/b], at [b]1920x1080[/b] resolution without any issues whatsoever.[/quote]

[b]Acknowledgement[/b]
[quote]This game was provided for review purposes through [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ReviewersParadise][b]Reviewers‚Äô Paradise[/b][/url].[/quote]

[b]Curator Link[/b]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41545671][quote]Remember that Blue Lips Never Lie! Thus, follow my curator, [b]Blue Lips and their Quips[/b], to find more honest yet humorous reviews!

It seemed like the right choice for me, as the other options were a rebellious activist and depressed artist. After that, I could finally venture into the lively city of New York.

At the very start, you are still a human, minding your own business and going through your daily routines. That changes soon. One day, you get a visit from a mysterious person who is interested in working with you. While you are listening to his compelling proposition, he moves closer to you. You notice his unnaturally glazing eyes. He grabs you with his cold hands, and you notice that his teeth are getting longer. And sharper. You feel them on your neck, and then there is only darkness.

That would be rather a quick end, but believe me, it is only the beginning. You wake up and find out that you are hungry. No, not hungry, but ravenous. For human blood. Your character might be confused, but you already know what happened. From now on, you play as a vampire, and you will have to find a way to survive in this new yet the same world. This tension, which started in the prologue, is present for the whole game, which is about seven hours long if you are a bit slower reader.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2425489919
Not only that the plot manages to stay captivating the whole time, but new, compelling characters and sudden twists make the playthrough gripping from start to finish. Even though you want to find the vampire that turned you, the story shifts its focus to other characters and its world soon. Yet, this sudden change of pace actually works pretty well. That way, the game manages to introduce you to its world, to explain what exactly are those vampires, their clans and their relationships. And it does so briefly without overwhelming you with tons of information.

Meeting new characters and doing tasks for them was definitely my favourite part of this title. Each one of them is unique, with their own motives and fascinating background to discover. I adored Hope, as her bossy attitude clicked with Amanda‚Äôs one, thus creating a great duo. She is not afraid of using the new technologies we are enslaved by, meaning phones and social media. You are not assisting them out of the kindness of your heart because you expect their help in return.

What I truly enjoyed is that the game forces you into uncomfortable situations. Being a vampire changes the way you live and with whom and how will you interact. Sure, it is not your fault that you became the vampire, but the feeling of hurting others clueless people stuck with me, and your character is getting used to it too. You have to survive somehow, though. The fact that you cannot finish every side quest, thus you have to decide which are worth it for you, just adds to that feeling.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2425490186
Feeding on others‚Äô blood is the one and only aspect you have to keep in mind during reading. Throughout the time, an option to feed yourself, meaning drink blood from some poor person, appears. You can choose not to do it, but it comes with a price. Starving for a longer time will lock some of the dialogue options, as you will be too weak to perform them. I like this a lot because it tempts you to hunt strangers.

If you do not feast on someone for a longer time, your character might turn desperate, wanting human‚Äôs blood immediately, and thus impatiently killing someone on their own. That leads us to the Masquerade, which is not just a fancy word but one of the most important rules for vampires. You have to be discreet and try to stay hidden. However, even with the abovementioned desperate murder, I never lost the game or had to reload to some checkpoint. Thus I slowly realized that your choices do not matter.

Sure, the way you play affects your path to your goal, but the ending always has the very same outcome, even if you try to go against the game. I decided to finish the [b]Coteries of New York[/b] with the other characters, and while there were some different dialogues, it always ends the same way. Now, it is not upsetting, and I do not feel that it would ruin the whole time I spent with it, but it still leaves a bittersweet taste in my mouth.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2425488751
[h3][b]Audiovisuals[/b][/h3]
What makes this title appealing at first glance are its visuals, which are just amazing. As the plot mostly takes place during the night, there are lots of lights, neons and such. Backgrounds are not static, so you will often see sweet little details like raindrops, moving eyes, flashing lights, and more. Sound effects and grim compositions fit the game‚Äôs theme perfectly. All in all, I cannot really say anything negative about the audiovisuals, as the atmosphere they help to create is breathtaking.

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]
Despite my problems with the ending, I can still wholeheartedly recommend [b]Coteries of New York[/b] to both fans of the [b]World of Darkness[/b], as well as to the newcomers who are interested in the vampiric setting, as it feels like a competent introduction.

[b]PC Specs & Performance[/b]
[quote]My performance section will be rather obligatory this time, as I obviously did not have any problems. This title ran flawlessly on [b]60 frames per second[/b] on [b]i5 8300H[/b], [b]GTX 1060 6GB[/b], and [b]16GB RAM[/b], at [b]1920x1080[/b] resolution without any issues whatsoever.[/quote]

[b]Acknowledgement[/b]
[quote]This game was provided for review purposes through [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ReviewersParadise][b]Reviewers‚Äô Paradise[/b][/url].[/quote]

[b]Curator Link[/b]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41545671][quote]Remember that Blue Lips Never Lie! Thus, follow my curator, [b]Blue Lips and their Quips[/b], to find more honest yet humorous reviews!

J'ai vraiment beaucoup appr√©ci√© ce Visual Novel, alors que je suis loin d'appr√©cier le genre. 
Le jeu se d√©roule dans l'univers du "Monde des T√©n√®bres" et sera agr√©able √† parcourir pour les v√©t√©rans du Jeu de r√¥le, tout en √©tant une bonne porte d'entr√©e dans la franchise pour ceux qui n'ont aucune connaissance de cet univers.
Pour moi les points forts de ce jeu sont le sc√©nario, les illustrations dynamiques et surtout le sound design qui est vraiment tr√®s r√©ussi (franchement, j'ai ressenti bien plus de pression avec les effets de ce jeu que lors de mes derniers exams'). Sinon c√¥t√© "gameplay", le jeu ne propose pas une grande rejouabilit√© avec un sc√©nario principal qui restera le m√™me malgr√© les divers choix propos√©s. 
Le jeu brille surtout au niveau des qu√™tes secondaires et des qu√™tes de recrutement dont vous avez vraiment un impact sur le d√©roulement. Mais pour moi, le truc vraiment remarquable avec ce jeu c'est le c√¥t√© gestion des pouvoirs et de sa soif vampirique, l'absence de sang dans votre organisme pouvant √† certains moments vous limiter dans les choix propos√©s, vous emp√™chant d'user de vos pouvoirs (m√™me si bon, en g√©n√©ral il y a toujours un moyen de parvenir √† vos fins, mais de mani√®re d√©tourn√©e et bien plus fastidieuse). En parlant de pouvoirs, le choix du personnage du d√©part aura un impact sur vos capacit√©s au cours de la partie et quelques passages, la Ventrue, le Brujah et le Toreador √©tant chacun issue de clan √† la philosophie bien distincte. C'est surtout √† ce niveau-ci que vous pourrez esp√©rer trouver un int√©r√™t √† refaire le jeu. 

Conclusion : un bon Visual Novel tr√®s imersif dans un univers passionnant, avec de bonnes m√©caniques li√© √† votre condition de suceur de sang, mais le jeu ne sera r√©ellement agr√©able √† parcourir qu'une premi√®re fois. Je le recommande !

It was nice to get to know the world of V:TM from another point of view. The gameplay's pretty direct: ya read, think and answer and normally I would find it pretty boring but the story is captivating enough to get over it.
All in all 10/10, 13h well spent.

column8:
This game was mostly fine: story was acceptable if not brilliant, choices were mostly consistent with ensuing dialogue, not a ton of typos, etc. It's nice to have something in the WoD universe.

But there was one, huge, glaring issue that ruined it: promiscuous and unnecessary use of the singular "they"

This wasn't some political statement; the genders of the main characters were not indeterminate. Yet for some bizarre reason the developers refused to use he/she pronouns. It's sloppy and makes the dialogue nearly impossible to read smoothly.

column8: Good visual, interesting plot at first. But nothing you do matters, all comes to a shitty ending.

After playing through Heart of the Forest, another WoD story game, I was pretty hyped for VtM Coteries of New York. First playthrough - great impression. I picked a Ventrue lady and went ahead. Dialogues are very well written, characters you encounter are believable and colorful, graphics are really nice and music is fitting and sets the atmosphere. I got to the ending, thought "well, frak" to meself, recreated my little Ventrue and decided I'm gonna do things different! And I did. And got the same irritating ending. This got me wondering. I checked Achievements for a clue, then read up online. Guess what. There is only the one ending. And suddenly, what originally would have been a 9/10 review, dropped to 6/10. 

The whole allure of those narrative games is that they are replayable because you can take different paths. See at least a few endings, or see the story branch out, or get unique dialogues, etc. And the issue with this game is that it's not there. Sure, you can pick different missions, pick slightly different responses, but apart from SPOILER ALERT possibility of dying in the first 30 minutes, they make absolutely no difference. You picked different companions, you alienated everyone, you found out vampires are, after all, kinda afraid of crosses? You were a sensitive Toreador who only fed on the willing or a feisty Brujah who decided hey, lemme see what happens when the Beast takes over? Doesn't frakking matter. 

That was such a huge dissapointment. 

Which makes me biased. After that first playthrough, I could have easily recommended it to everyone, whether they were fans of WoD, Vampire the Masquerade or not. Now, after doing 4 playthroughs - double the Ventrue, Brujah and Toreador characters - and completing all Achievements, I'm not so sure who to recommend it to. So let's break it down, shall we?

PROS:
+ great visuals, both when it comes to backgrounds and character designs
+ fitting music that sets the atmosphere
+ well written dialogues and narrative
+ colorful, complex characters
+ a natural introduction to VtM, the game includes a dictionary where you can check new terms without overexposition and shoving them down your throat in dialogues
+ seamless inclusion of vampiric powers
+ bonus plus for super-cathartic Ventrue "personal encounter" that allowed me to vent all my work place anger ;)
+ an all in all interesting story...

CONS
- ...with a sadly unsatisfactory ending
- and only one ending at that
- your choices don't matter
- no, really, they don't, I checked.

SUBJECTIVE?
+/- There are 3 preset characters to pick from - a female Ventrue and male Brujah and Toreador. In a perfect world, I'd wish you could pick your Clan and gender (because being a game-starved Werewolf fan when it comes to Vampire I play female Gangrels) or play through some introductory chapter where the game sets you up based on your choices, a la the earlier mentioned Heart of the Forest. There are differences between the characters, of course: you get a unique beginning, few lines of different dialogue, different Disciplines to use and each of the characters had their one unique quest. That said, in the grand scheme of things, it doesn't make the game that much different. However, since we don't live in a perfect world, perhaps it would have been better to give the players one character with more options to affect the story. 

To sum it up, I'd still recommend the game, much like you recommend a book. Or a comic book, to be more like it. You don't judge comic books for lack of "rereadability", do you?

Without giving too much away...

The ending is horrible. Your choices don't matter at all through the entire game, and nothing you do matters. You are railroaded into an ending that comes out of nowhere and makes no sense. 

Completely disappointed.

column8:
A decent visual novel overall that I would recommend for those new to the setting an lore of Vampire: the Masquerade. Where it really shines IMO is in the dialogue and characters; particularly the characters of Qadir, Hope, D'Angelo and in the internal dialogue of the PC. In some cases the strength of dialogue reminded me of Bloodlines 1, which is high praise!

The background paintings and visuals were excellent, and I have to say I enjoy the intro music too. However I agree with others that some more facial expressions and body positions for the characters would have gone a long way.

In terms of pacing, it was a relatively slow start, but after a couple of hours play built up to the meat of the game when building a coterie. I especially enjoyed the missions with Hope, and enjoyed meeting Aisling Sturbridge, a classic character from the lore. But I'd agree with what others have said that in the end, the ending didn't seem to involve or justify the main point of the game, which was surely building that coterie. I would have really enjoyed an ending in which my coterie and I teamed up to defeat (or possibly join) the main villain. But in the end they had next to no impact. That was a real shame as, as I've said, the characters and dialogue are the game's strength.

One thing that sometimes frustrated me was that the summarised dialogue choices sometimes didn't match what your character ended up saying if you selected it, in either tone or intent. So sometimes your character would go ahead and say something outlandish that you would never have chosen if you could see the full text, meaning you then have to deal with the fallout of something you didn't choose. So there was always an added element of uncertainty in these selections, leading to a feeling of having limited control over your character. Being able to see, and select, the entire line of dialogue that your PC would say would have prevented this, and surely wouldn't be a huge ask on game mechanics.

Also this game really needs to allow save files, as I want to go back and explore all the possible pathways without having to play the entire game out from the beginning again.

All in all, a decent game with interesting characters and excellent dialogue that's a solid introduction to the world of VtM for new fans, but the ultimate execution and integration of plotlines was off.

2 stars

column8:
Visual novels can be just as interesting to play as other kinds of games, unfortunately, the developers of this one failed in every way that makes Visual novel games worth playing.

The trailer makes the visuals look vibrant, but don't be fooled- poor story development,and the cheap practice of reusing artwork soon devolves the story into a blur of meaningless repetitive imagery and leaves one wondering what the point of having this be a game with "choices" when the choices don't influence the story itself (and in fact, have NO INFLUENCE on the ending at all).  The so-called "choices" in this game are more akin to the "choice" of flipping to a random page of a book that is already written, with bland characters, and a single, predetermined ending.

The trailer makes the game appear to have stunning visuals (more correctly called illustrations for this kind of game / story ).  This is GROSSLY MISLEADING.  The first time one sees an illustration, it may look stunning.  The problem is that you will see that same illustration over and over and over and over ad nauseum.  There is one single cardboard cutout for each character, which is superimposed  on one single background image for each location....  There is no change in characters' expressions, stances, outfits etc.... no change in the boring backgrounds they are stuck in front of...  the weather is always the same, the location is always from the same perspective, and every object in the environment is always in the same place.  Even when there is simple animation (such as weather effects, or club strobe lighting) that is also always the same, no matter when you visit the same boring location.

This is honestly the FIRST time I have ever fallen ASLEEP while playing a game (or reading a story), which is why I didn't return it (my unintentional nap took me over the 2 hour limit to do so).  

Stuck with this, I tried to make the best of it and push through, but eventually gave up.   At least It was on a deep discount, because it isn't worth finishing.   I looked for play thru to find out what if anything I'd be missing, and it turns out: NOTHING.  That's right, all the time you waste in the game, doing this quest or that one, making choice A or choice B, none of it matters.  Everything plays out to an ending that you have no control over, no influence in, no meaning to find in it.   

When a "game" demands you interact by making choices, it is expected that the choices will have SOME bearing on the outcome of the game- that is the POINT of these types of novel-games.... otherwise, it may as well be just a printed graphic novel.

I can't recommend a better visual novel game to play on Steam since everything that I'd actually want to pay money for is free because its Fan-Fiction (yes, with choices and different endings and sometimes even with artwork as high quality, if not higher (and more varied), than what Vampire:The Masquerade offers.).  

If you want an original story-rich, vampire RPG to play with gorgeous scenery (set in 1918 London), an interesting variety of characters that interact with both you and each other, where your choices will actually affect both the landscape, the characters' behaviour,  and which of several endings you get, I highly recommend giving the game "Vampyr" by Dontnod a try.  Just do not mistake it (as others have) for operating in the Vampire:The Masquerade world-as it is based on its own unique perspective and approach to vampirism.   And while it has its failings (as all games do) it is far more interesting and exciting to engage with: definitely worth the money I spent on Vampyre when it was sale, plus what I wasted on this abysmally glorified illustrated novel where choices do not matter aka Vampire the Masquerade.  

Having tried Vampire the Masquerade, I cannot comprehend how/why they can afford to publish new games / glorified illustrated novels.... Meanwhile, I hold out hope that Dontnod makes a sequel to their own game, Vampyr, as they brought together engaging characters, amazing scenery, in a true 'choices matter' game where the world changes around you, and the ending varies, depending on how you play the game.

Skip this boring graphic novel, and instead try a real choices matter game about vampires: 

https://store.steampowered.com/app/427290/Vampyr/
column9:
Visual novels can be just as interesting to play as other kinds of games, unfortunately, the developers of this one failed in every way that makes Visual novel games worth playing.

The trailer makes the visuals look vibrant, but don't be fooled- poor story development,and the cheap practice of reusing artwork soon devolves the story into a blur of meaningless repetitive imagery and leaves one wondering what the point of having this be a game with "choices" when the choices don't influence the story itself (and in fact, have NO INFLUENCE on the ending at all).  The so-called "choices" in this game are more akin to the "choice" of flipping to a random page of a book that is already written, with bland characters, and a single, predetermined ending.

The trailer makes the game appear to have stunning visuals (more correctly called illustrations for this kind of game / story ).  This is GROSSLY MISLEADING.  The first time one sees an illustration, it may look stunning.  The problem is that you will see that same illustration over and over and over and over ad nauseum.  There is one single cardboard cutout for each character, which is superimposed  on one single background image for each location....  There is no change in characters' expressions, stances, outfits etc.... no change in the boring backgrounds they are stuck in front of...  the weather is always the same, the location is always from the same perspective, and every object in the environment is always in the same place.  Even when there is simple animation (such as weather effects, or club strobe lighting) that is also always the same, no matter when you visit the same boring location.

This is honestly the FIRST time I have ever fallen ASLEEP while playing a game (or reading a story), which is why I didn't return it (my unintentional nap took me over the 2 hour limit to do so).  

Stuck with this, I tried to make the best of it and push through, but eventually gave up.   At least It was on a deep discount, because it isn't worth finishing.   I looked for play thru to find out what if anything I'd be missing, and it turns out: NOTHING. Just do not mistake it (as others have) for operating in the Vampire:The Masquerade world-as it is based on its own unique perspective and approach to vampirism.   And while it has its failings (as all games do) it is far more interesting and exciting to engage with: definitely worth the money I spent on Vampyre when it was sale, plus what I wasted on this abysmally glorified illustrated novel where choices do not matter aka Vampire the Masquerade.

column8:
I have thoroughly enjoyed this game (and will probably go on to replay it for quite some time).
Its main criticism is that it only presents one ending, and thus it feels like 'your choices don't matter'. Yes, they do. They determine whether you commit literal suicide in the beginning. They determine whose story you'll learn more about and whose you won't get to progress. Even your background and origin story make small appearances here and there, making the story seem much more immersive.
Incredible sound design (jarring when needed, beware of that one loud noise lmao)
Astounding art (for a visual novel, this type of art style was not something to be expected but very well put together, cohesive and beautiful)
In summary, if you like reading, pretty things and an interesting storyline with memorable characters then play (and replay) this. If not, then skip it.

Most of the time I steer clear of visual novels, not interested in romances and/or manga aesthetics. I decided to give Coteries of New York a try, just because I have fond memories of Vampire: The Masquerade from the old days.... and I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôm disappointed. 

‚ÄùCoteries...‚Äù drops You right in the middle of World Of Darkness and as a newly turned vampire, you‚Äôll discover it‚Äôs unwelcoming embrace. It‚Äôs all here - intrigues, scheming, politics, backstabbing... Vampire society in a nutshell.

It is a decent storyline, very good introduction to the world and a good refreshment, for those that weren‚Äôt particularly interested in World of Darkness throughout the years. 

And yes...addressing the elephant in the room - there‚Äôs only one ending. During the game, there‚Äôs sidequests you can choose from and also main storyline that‚Äôs a bit ‚Äúcustomisable‚Äù. No real failstates either. For fans of a genre, that can be little outrageous. Bear that in mind if that‚Äôs a problem for You.

Still, Coteries of New York oozes with atmosphere. Maybe not a good choice for hardcore visual novel enthusiasts... but a good experience nonetheless. 

Also, splendid soundtrack by Reikowski/Lubos.  Thumbs up!

I really liked this game.... until a point.

Having played Vampire the Masquerade and Vampire the Eternal Struggle for more than 20 years, an interactive book set in the World of Darkness, draw me like a moth to a flame,
Initially the game/book was great. You start as a neonate with your sire leaving just after the embrace. In minutes, you get discovered by the local Camarilla and then that‚Äôs when all you troubles start.

This book/game has some great characters, cool artwork and atmosphere (including the music) that are quite faithful to what I expect from a WoD game. The writing is simple but adequate. Some people complain that there is no voice acting but I like it that way. It becomes your job as the player to imagine what that NPC would sound like. 

The NPC female vampire appearing in all the games screens and advertisings is in my opinion, the best made character in all the game. Some people hated her for her flaws, I loved the way the character was done since its represents the pure essence of her clan. 90% of the fun in the game for me was trying to interact with her and understand her personality and motivations.

Then you start seeing that your choices as a player are not that important or relevant in terms of the story. Most conversation and conflicts will end in the same way, despite your choices and decisions. You really don‚Äôt have some much control over the story.
But I guess that must be like that. It‚Äôs a game/novel, not an RPG session, some limitations have to be drawn in terms of history or the developers wouldn‚Äôt be able to create the game. 

And the game finale eventually comes and the train hits you right in the face. 
The game only has one ending!!!! Nothing you did ever matter to the ending. 

Your decisions were pointless. Even if the amount of influence you can have in a game/interactive novel is limited, the people playing it should have at least the possibility of choosing between 2 or 3 endings. (The usual Good/Neutral/Bad ending).

I understand why the developers ended the game the way they did. It‚Äôs WoD and there is always a bigger fish than you. However WoD is also an RPG and in an RPG you have to at least be able to have some influence in the story or it‚Äôs just a railroad story.
In this game/novel, you have zero influence.
Even when the entire plot unfolds and the big Baddie appears and spends its sweet time explaining his masterplan, you come to the conclusion that the plot makes no sense whatsoever.  Its plan is a non-sense and the entire plot is ridiculous in terms of WoD lore.
Your real life Storyteller from the last Friday night game session probably had a better story.

Bottom line for me: The first two thirds of the game are quite enjoyable. The NPC with which you spend most of the time is well done and well written and you get some sidekicks that are also fun to play with. Some NPC recruiting scenarios are quite funny. 
However, when you reach the game final and you get the full explanation of the plot, you are a left with a sour taste with all the plot holes and railroading you were forced with.
The kind of games must have multiple endings. If not, then they are poorly designed.

column8:
Cool story, very much feels like the pen-and-paper game (if the Storyteller could ad-lib even remotely as this game is scripted - that gap has always amused me as a tabletop roleplayer). 

I'm not entirely sure the choices you make really matter all that much, but it's still at very least a good WoD visual novel. Highly recommended for all fans of the Vampire and other WoD pen-and-paper RPGs

I think I played this for about 5 hours (in offline mode during a power outage), and I really enjoyed getting immersed in the atmosphere of this World of Darkness New York setting. I wanted to read something when I started playing, but calling this a visual novel would be a disservice. The animations, the ambient music and dialog was excellent. Essentially a choose your own adventure with three or so character you can pick.
The pacing was hard to get used to because there was an actual game play mechanic of you needing to feed (i.e. look for blood) that would always be on the back of my mind which might one of my bigger complaints. 
The way the story plays, there's a lot of choices than will change what happens, and even decide how you react at the end although how much it would actually change the ending is something people might complain about. Without spoilers, I will say though I left wanting to play it again with a different character to see some of the choices I missed, if not just for the excellent ambience brought to this world.

Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York is a nice slice of the VTM universe to play through. The characters are quite interesting but some stand out more than others, the plot is interesting but the ending could have been better. One major criticism I have is that when you are done with the "prologue", the game puts you on a time limit, stopping you from doing all of the quests. You can only do a certain amount of them before you reach the finale.

column8:
I honestly did not get far into the game. I can accept grudgingly, the 3 character choices whom are locked to a specific gender and clan. What I can not accept is how it roughly started off near exactly like how Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines did. For that I took likely the fastest suicide ending in the game.

Maybe sometime down the road I will try this game out and play each of the 3 pre-designed characters in full and change this review after that time. but for now, I can not recommend this game.

column8:
[h1] Intro[/h1]
Besides Bloodlines I pretty much haven't experienced any VTM themed games, these graphic novels(this one and the most recent, "new york" one) are usually subject to heated debates regarding as though their quality and contribution to VTM in general; as a "newbie" I found this game to be overall enjoyable and benefitial in terms of getting more familiar with the lore. So if you're someone who craves more of VTM after playing Bloodlines and does enjoy graphic novels as such, give it a go, def wait for the sales though. 

[h1] A few buts...[/h1]
-I did 2 whole runs. Played as a Ventrue firstly and then as a Toreador. Messed around as a Brujah a bit but didn't do a complete run. Besides a few places(which were not trivial at all, they did not affect the ending nor the plot) picking different clans does not yield a difference AT ALL. [spoiler] Qadir might mock you in a different way, Callihan insults you in a different manner and you have a diverging origin story which determines your "last visit to a loved one" part within the game which again does not directly affect anything.[/spoiler] 

-Due to clans being indifferent regarding the plot progression, if it hasn't been for the time given the player to be set as limited, the game's replayability would suffer immensely. It's impossible to finish all quests within a single run, you just don't have enough time. As far as I remember you can fit 4 quests per run, and the game has more quests than that. So the game requires you to play not because of the variability the player's  clan choice may have caused(which is non-existent in this game) but because you simply can't lay your hands on every quest the game offers in a single run. I find it a bit of as a design choice but whatevs.

-Repetetive artwork; [spoiler] So Sophie's valuntary blood stock resides at the same gallery as our fellow Toreador had his exhibition at, lovely.[/spoiler] I expected much more variation, given this is a visual novel.

-The story wasn't too branching, it does not matter which individuals you do add to your coterie; it all amounts to the same conclusion. I expected it to be quite the other way but that was just my expectation so...

column9: Noice

column8: I'm a fan of Vampire: The Masquerade, White Wolf and World of Darkness, so it was easy for me to enjoy this game.  If you like the world, you'll enjoy the game, just keep in mind its more of a visual novel than a game.  Sadly there is no skilling in it or anything.  Its basically a choose your own adventure with lots of reading.  There were some typos in the text, and there was more than one ultra-far alt-left reference which made me throw up in my mouth a little...  (The Brujah apparently went from being freedom fighters to RedGuard BLM/ANTIFA fascist ideologues...)  Even still, I enjoyed it.  I particularly loved Benoit's story and loved the chance to talk about faith as a vampire, on of the reasons Vampire: The Masquerade - Redemption is one of my favorite games (only Redemption is an actual game lol.)  So yeah, if you like to read and like the lore of the Masquerade universe,  you'll probably have fun with it.

column8: Quite a nice piece of game to play while waiting for the upcoming VtMB 2
A short game, but an engrossing one. A great introduction to the World of Darkness which has you actually roleplaying and making intelligent choices.

column8:
I searched online immediately to find out if I had done something wrong after the credits rolled, and the first search result summed up my opinions. "I've never believed that an entire game could be ruined by a bad last act...". This was exactly what happened. In an abrupt fashion, the last act is sprung on you, and you realise quickly that a lot of the choices you made up to that point turned out to be rather inconsequential (I can't elaborate on the why without spoiling).

Basically. Don't go into this game like I did thinking there are multiple endings (not counting premature endings).

That aside, the artwork is amazing and some of the side quest lines with the other characters are decent, which can help mitigate the overall experience, perhaps. Not for me, it doesn't, unfortunately.

column8:
Really enjoyed this game. Went in without many expectations. I'm a big fan of the last VTM. 

Yes, the ending was a disappointment. Right as I felt I was really getting somewhere, it fell flat. I wish I had more opportunity to go back and do the side quests. Instead, I'll have to replay the game. I'm not a fan of replays, so I'll probably skip it and move onto their next one.  

Overall, the game held me captivated and wanting more. Great story and good graphics with some cool sounds. If you're waiting for the new game to come out (whennn will that beeee *pouty face*) and enjoy story games, give this a go. It's a nice refresher.

column8:
I really, really want to recommend this game, but I just can't do that. Visually the game is stunning and I loved how they introduce you to the world of Vampire the Masquerade. I am a VtM veteran, having played the various editions of the VTTRPG since the mid-90s, and I appreciated Draw Distance's approach to teaching a new player without slowing the game down or overloading someone new all at once. The game's atmosphere was brilliant.

I had three serious issues with the game.

The first was subtle but annoying, the disjointed moments in the story when the narrative wouldn't match the flow of my story. For example, at one point I returned to a certain location with another vampire and we handle our business. Then I follow another story lead and return to the same location with a different vampire. The narrative did not take into account that I had just been there the night before and there were lines indicating I had not been there since my last night as a mortal, which was not true at all. It just took me out of the experience and was really unfortunate.

The second was the background art, which was absolutely beautiful, kept being used over and over again. Every alley in New York looks identical. Every crime on the street happens in the same place. Too much repetition and it diminished the effect of the story unfolding.

The third issue is this did not feel like a complete game. There is an Act 1 and maybe something a glimmer of something that looks like an Act 2, and then we dove straight into the climax of the story. It felt too damned rushed. I was still getting a feel for my character and vampiric life, and then suddenly, the credits were literally rolling. And the "surprise twist" at the end really did come out of nowhere. There was no build up for that twist, it was very out of character for the rest of the story, and involved someone I barely spoke to in the beginning of the game and NEVER SAW AGAIN until the last moments of the finale. It felt cheap. No, it WAS cheap. Bad storytelling.

So tread carefully with this one. It could have been absolutely brilliant but suffered in some really key areas. And since I can only choose yes or no to recommend it, the only honest choice is "no". Skip this one.

Real shame, I absolutely love Vampire the Masquerade. This was a real letdown.

column8:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Coteries of New York is based on the setting of Vampire the Masquerade, a renowned tabletop RPG that later was adapted into two video games in the early 2000s. I never played these two games and knew nothing about the Vampire the Masquerade before I played. I don‚Äôt even know a lot about vampires other than some Mary Sue vampire love stories like Twilight and True Blood I watched in my teenage. As far as I can tell, Vampire the Masquerade is not those soft love stories, but a hardcore vampire world focusing on vampire society, cliques, ideas, mysteries, schemes, and clashes, which is my liking.

Knowing what the source material is about, you get a rough idea of what Coteries of New York is. It is a visual novel about a new vampire who was turned unwillingly and forced to go into the vampire society. To survive, you as the protagonist, need to build your coteries (your vampire association), deal with troubles and unravel mysteries around you.

It took me 10 hours for the first playthrough because I am a slow reader, and another 3.5 hours for the second playthrough by skipping most dialogue I have already read. For a visual novel, it is a relatively long one.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Coteries of New York has three different characters to choose at the beginning, which correspond to three different clans (vampire bloodlines). Three characters have different abilities and different related stories, but they are essentially the same as characters do not affect main and side events and how they play out, it is just a nice little addition. 

The story is a mixed bag. On one hand, it has a strong start. It does a good job of unfolding the vampire society to players and creating a cold and alienated atmosphere, setting the tone of the whole story. There is some exquisite writing with delicate choices of words making me feel like I was reading a Shakespeare or something like that. And I genuinely enjoyed the story of D'Angelo. On the other hand, perhaps the story is written by different persons, there is some mild inconsistency in characteristics, mainly the character of Sophie Langley, and the exquisite writing is not from the start to finish as most of the story does not have this treatment. The biggest problem is most of the story is just not engaging at all. Perhaps it is due to involvement. At the start, the story is about you. For the rest, it is about other persons who you cannot care less. It is like throwing irrelevant stuff to you since you are merely an observer, figuratively speaking, who play so little in the events. 

You get to choose which events you participate in, but you cannot experience all in one playthrough as the main event will happen at some point. I usually avoid non-linear narrative games like this because implementing a non-linear narrative mechanic to approach the story is usually unengaging as the focus shifts too much. And they usually fall into the category of trying to achieve too much at once. Coteries of New York talks about the story of different characters, the origin of vampire, the stalker, the reporter. The center of the story shifts so often that it further drives down the engagement. To be honest, all I want is a decent story about my MC (main character) and I couldn‚Äôt care less about the rest.

[h1]Artwork and Sound[/h1]
Artwork in this game has an oil painting style with a little use of bokeh effect. It is aesthetic and well accommodates the mysterious and alienated tone of the story. The most important character, Sophie Langley, has 4 different portraits, the rest of characters have only one portrait and they are reused over and over again. So are the pictures of different environments. Maybe I am spoiled by other visual novels, artwork in this game is just lazy in terms of the number and variety. They cannot vividly show how the story goes and what characters are doing. Artwork is an important aspect of a visual novel, and even more important than the story in terms of sales. For example, Nekopara, one of the best sellers in the visual novel genre, has a crappy story but beautiful and abundant artwork. I am not saying that this game should follow Nekopara and fully dedicate to artwork, because they are not the same sub-genre, but at least it would be better if the dev have put more effort into artwork and maybe the game could have been sold better.

This game has a superior sound effect than many visual novels I have ever played. Lots of sounds are reused multiple times, but they are brief so they never annoy you. Besides, they are very on point to seize the atmosphere at that time being.

[h1]Choice[/h1]
It is a common issue in the genre that the choices do not mean what they mean on paper. Players think the choice means A, but it actually means B because the choice description cannot fully express what it intends to do. They can be infuriating since the description misleads the players to make choices they do not want to.

It usually happens for two reasons. One is the dev want to pursue the brevity of words, so they cut down words that help express the meaning more precisely and therefore affect the effectiveness of language. The other reason is the designers are total pr!cks (no offense) who add unnecessary and additional actions that do not imply in the description into a choice. I expected the dev of this game, as a more ‚Äúprofessional‚Äù developer, can address this issue better, compared to adult visual novels from Patreon I usually play. Sadly, they did not and they made both two mistakes. The ambiguity of description and unpredictability of action can be the major factors why you make the wrong choice in this game.

What I enjoy about making choices in visual novels is that there are clues that you can find in conversations that support you to make the best or right choices. These clues can be something mentioned in the past or the personality of a certain character etc. In this game, some choices do follow this logical design, which is great, but many choices just come out of nowhere. I could not find explanations why these choices pop out and they do not follow the logical design, meaning you are just making wild guesses without any clues. This is another weakness of choice design in this game.

Finally, it is about the choice and the ending. It might come to spoiler territory so read at your discretion. [spoiler] I played the game twice and I have the same ending. According to what I read on the Internet, this game seems to only have one ending (the end ending, not the suicidal endings at the beginning) despite any choices you made. I can appreciate this kind of design showing the MC is just a pawn and powerless to change the events. I am not against this ending if it is used in any other genre. However, for a visual novel, making choices consist of most of its gameplay elements. Having just one ending means all the choices players made are in vain since they matter nothing. [/spoiler] For a game like this with a focus on adventure, it is a bad design choice. [spoiler] What is the point of an adventure if everything is just settled and the choices you made are meaningless?[/spoiler]

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Coteries of New York is not a satisfying experience. It has something good, but there are more questionable design choices. On top of that, it has an unengaging story that tries to achieve too much at once. It is hard to recommend to anyone.

This game could have been excellent. Some of the stories and side characters are really entertaining, the writing is in general pretty fun and thematic. So what's the issue?

The game is pointless. You cannot affect the ending in the slightest - you either fail to reach it by not managing your hunger, or you reach the ending, find out nothing you did mattered and none of your interactions could change it. The coterie you gather has nothing to do with the plot. Those side characters? Pointless. You can speed run the entire game, never speak to or engage with any of them, and the ending is exactly the same. And it's... well, it's not even a dramatic twist. A character you see briefly twice turns out to be behind everything. There's no real reason behind it, and honestly, the character is probably the worst and least interesting in the whole thing. 

So - this game would easily have been an 8 or 9 out of 10 if it hadn't totally wasted its premise on a silly twist designed to put you in your place as ultimately irrelevant. As it is? 2/10 for decent graphics and a legitimately atmospheric soundtrack.

column8: Warning, this is not a game, it is a visual novel.  I thought it was a game coming into it, and was initially disappointed.  Then, I quickly was immersed and enjoyed it, though it is pretty short (4 hrs) and I soon discovered that the narrative is predetermined.  It does make you feel as though you have control, and you do over the middle of the story, but the ending will always be the same, and kind of frustrating.  My one recommendation as you play is to give your character a funny name.  When the other characters say it, it will make you giggle, and bring you back to nights in high school with your friends with role playing games.

Shockingly short. From start to finish was about 5 hours. Was enjoying myself until literally the last scene of the game, which is basically getting hit out of nowhere by a semi truck while you were standing in the middle of the woods. And its not a satisfying kinda "ohh, thats just how the world of darkness goes" kinda thing. Just trust me, you know how we all felt about the end of Mass Effect 3? It's basically like that, at least its on a smaller scale. The whole thing feels like choice matters, but is actually as on rails as a Star Fox game.

It would have made a better movie or like, mini series or something.

column8: An awesome VtM game, it delivers the atmosphere perfectly. The storytelling has a great pace and the characters are well written. Although I am not a fan of visual novels - it helps deliver the feeling that you would get while playing the pen and paper version. The glove fits so to speak so at the end of the day I recommend giving it a try.

column8:
"Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York" is a visual novel.

Illustrations - Fitting for a grim story about vampires.

Gameplay - You can play as 3 different characters. The main story stays mostly the same but you will have different dialogue options and different encounters with some of the characters. Your choices mostly matter regarding how the story is going to unfold (especially during the side stories).

Characters - Actually really well created. Every character seems different - personalities, how they act in certain situations etc... Also, most of the characters that you'll interact with will have a storyline that you can experience. All in all, they've done a very good job regarding the characters.

Soundtrack - It helped with creating the eerie and tense atmosphere.

Story - I really liked it. It's grim, it's funny, it has plot twists, it's able to drag you in, and shock you. However, I would have liked it to be a bit longer. Right before the story ended I was thinking: "Okay, now I'm going to go on a rampage." Then I got hit by the end credits. Other than that it was a really enjoyable and captivating story.

I'd recommend it to anyone who is looking for a game that has a slower pace. Also recommended for all the fans of vampire universes. There aren't enough games about vampires out there.

column8: Really liked this and it actually got me back into the world of Vampire the Masquerade. Its a great introduction to the lore and the twisted world of the Vampire. The game makers weaved an awesome story into a playable game world that is both LARPing and Table top game play, you have to try them both, that is a great adventure into the World of Darkness. The people who do not like this new type of game just do not like reading much, most likely, either. I had a lot of friends growing up that just did not like the pick your own  D&D Books but they were fun too. This is just a modern upgrade with a topping of Vampires! I got the bundle deal and am looking forward to the next one.

column8:
Enjoyed being immersed in the lore of V:tM after a long reprieve. This would be a great game to use to introduce someone new to World of Darkness with how it naturally brings up WoD's lexicon of terms like diablerie, Camarilla, Prince, Scourge, etc throughout the story. As someone that knows the lore though, there were times where I was sort of just like "get on with it", and by the time they did, it was over.

Nice story. You will not have time to complete all the side quests and companion quests in one playthrough, so choose carefully. I only played as a Toreador and I am unsure how different it may be if I had chosen Brujah or Ventrue. I will probably play one more time to see.

The game suffers from the "illusion of choice" problem more than more expensive games (like Telltale ones) do, so understand what you are getting for the price. Plot feels like one arc in a longer story. I enjoyed the companion quests, particularly Hope and D'Angelo's stories. Just be aware that your choices don't really change much in the end and it will end in some Deus ex machina just when it feels like it has really got going.

Going to try the next entry into this series. I am hoping they added more meaningful choices there. I am recommending it but only if you are a fan of text adventures or love/have nostalgia for the WoD universe.

column8: Pleasant atmosphere, but very short (few hours only) and without much agency. If you were expecting to sit down a read a short story then you'll probably get what you came for. If you wanted more game, or even the ability to significantly impact events then this isn't going to satisfy you.

column8:
As a fan of VM-Bloodlines, i was very disappointed with this and the other two more recent versions. They can barely be classed as games in this day and age, more akin to an interactive book. There is 0% gameplay. Had i realised this, i wouldn't have purchased them.

I feel this is a lazy cop-out compared to the original game, the storylines would've been great worked into an upgraded version of the original platform. The Developers really missed out on an opportunity here.

column8:
Kinda fun but really disappointing that none of your decisions matter.

The game hints at having a lot of ambition but doesn't last long enough to see any of those ideas through. It's a bit of a letdown that White Wolf would license a game that robs the player of their agency so thoroughly , I thought that was the whole point of table top RPGs.

column8:
[h1] When night falls upon you [/h1]

It's a good story, it can engage for a long night. The pacing is good and it's up to you, how many nights will you complete within one session. The problem that could've been solved is lack of real choices, there are plenty conversation options but they are just illusionary. Whatever you pick it's impossible not to progress. Failure elements in decisions about feeding and fighting making friends and enemies - these could easily be more spiced and branched.

But as it stands, it's only good at what it does. [b][u]"Coteries of New York" is a one time linear story with only illusionary choices and barely diversified endings.[/u][/b] Adding few CG's for action and more important dialogue elements also would help. There are just so many immersive moments within this game. Why they don't use that feeling more?

 it could've been improved, but even without these imrpovements...
Their work is still charming and stylish. Well done it's worth reading.

column8:
Very, very in depth review can be found here:

https://youtu.be/MhG85kc1n2Y

Now here's a short version to sum up the very long video:

gameplay complaints:

 -- no way to replay parts of an encounter, must start the game again

 -- no way to auto skip till choices

 -- no way to waste time feeding (so you are stuck redoing missions if you're replaying)

 -- no handy in-game gallery for unlocked backgrounds/ characters

 -- very rail'road'y

pluses:

 -- soundtrack

 -- enough new things to learn for a second playthrough to be worth it

 -- length (10 hours to finish it once, 26 hours to finish it 3 times and get 27/28 achievements)

 -- art

overall: 8/10, the story is a lot more decent than I thought, even if it was a bit goofy at times. Overall, it's worth a playthrough, especially at its price and length!

column8:
On first play this game forced me to its end without having gone through all the necessary steps of the storyline. It abruptly started mentioning characters and events that were never met and never took place. I let the game sit for a while before attempting to give it another shot, hoping that whatever the issue was would be fixed by that time. When I did pick it up again the game loaded into a black screen with music and cursor present and nothing else. I tried my monitor at different settings and I verified file integrity. I uninstalled and reinstalled. Garbage.

I really wanted to like this game, but the technical issues have ruined it for me. I asked for a refund.

column8: Bonne ambiance

If you want to know about the world of Vampire The Masquerade without needing to learn the ins and outs of the full RPG system and gather a bunch of people, this is a fantastic way to get into it.

Generally, I understand why it has to feel rushed, and it's short to encourage multiple playthroughs, but it was weird that I could highlight a scenario and it would make it feel like there was a time limit on it, but then there wasn't.  Not really anyway other than the actual end of the game.  Also I only did 2 missions with Hope, and several with Agathon, but I guess maybe I did more things that Hope liked or I pissed off Agathon at some point? ....  Yeah, I did piss off Agathon a couple of times, maybe that was it.  It still seemed weird that Hope showed up to help.

It also ends up feeling a little like a no win scenario, but I guess I have to try focusing harder on one path next time.

Anyway!  The art is really good.  Really solid choices that I had to really think about on more than 5 occasions.  There were a couple of times that I felt cheated by a "Use your powers" option, but if it was always an instant win button that would be dumb too.  I'll have to play with the other 2 types and see if they get different powers and if I can really play a drastically different story.
