column8:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 13.6h (based on Steam, 100% achievement)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (~23 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York[/b] is a visual novel set in the universe of [i]Vampire: The Masquerade 5th Edition[/i]. I didn't have any knowledge of the said universe, but a quick google search shows that the work was derived from a [url=https://www.modiphius.net/collections/vampire-the-masquerade]tabletop game[/url]. Since I never played the tabletop version before, I won't try to compare the game with it and review the game as it is.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Several dialogue choices that lead to the same result
- 3 different characters with minor details

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Skip dialogue button is well-hidden

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you enjoy visual novel games with in-depth world-building and character interactions, buy this game on a sale.[/i]

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Being a visual novel game where you need to pay attention to aesthetics, the game doesn't disappoint. Backgrounds look realistic with high attention to the details. Not only that, the heavy use of lighting in most areas gives more atmosphere to the environment, especially with the night setting. The game also seems to give an extra effort to this department by animating minor parts such as dripping rain and glowing eyes. Characters are also looking beautiful with the painting-like, realistic style - you won't even notice that it's a 2D image from afar due to how realistic it is.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The tabletop version has a good core in its story building and the game does a good job of explaining it to the players. The game will flesh out the details little by little, throwing new terms here and there as it goes on. A dictionary that holds all information about the universe's terms are also available should you decide to revisit them.

Some dialogues will branch at some point, forcing you to choose an option. While this matters at the beginning of the game, even leading you to 2 bad endings, other branching paths will lead you to the same decision. However, choosing different dialogues might give you more information either about the world-building or the other party's true colors - it was interesting to see how each dialogue plays out. Surprisingly, each decision flows smoothly with the next dialogue, except for one occasion.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2364577409
The game seems to take notes of word usage depends on who is talking. People in high standing will use exquisite words that suit their status while people in lower standing will tend to curse as they talk. Despite the different word usage, everything flows smoothly and easy to understand except for some occasions where I had to translate some exquisite words that I didn't know.

Although you'll mostly be kept in the dark about what happened in the main story, the game lets you focus more on the side stories instead. There are 7 side stories that you can play, each having a different focus and interactions. You'll learn more about world-building, meet new people with unique characteristics, or see a unique side of the vampiric society. When all is said and done, the game will return to the main story, and you'll be in for a surprise. There might be slight plot holes and confusion to some parts of the story, but the plot twists outweigh more than those at this point.

[h1]The Game[/h1]
[b]Mechanics[/b]
As a vampire, you need to constantly drink blood to survive. The game will give you an option to drink whenever available, and failing to so after several days will leave a blood mark on the screen. Ignoring this warning will result in losing control near the end of the night, giving risk to your exposure by killing someone near to your home. I didn't know if it's possible to get a game over if you constantly doing this, but this never happens to me unless if I did it on purpose. There was a time when I was close to losing control though since there was one chain quest that doesn't give an opportunity to drink in all of its quests.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2364577448
[b]Side Quests[/b]
Side quests take most of your playtime in this game. You have 2 actions per night which can be used to either recruit up to 4 companions or do other side quests unrelated to it. All side quests will take more than one visit to finish and sometimes, the main quest will also take one or both actions in a single night. It's possible to fail any companions' side quests if you made a bad first impression on the character and even if you manage to convince all of them, you won't be able to recruit everyone in a single playthrough. The most that I could recruit was 3, and that's after ignoring other side quests that are not related to companions.

It was interesting to do the side quests and experience the different characteristics of everyone that you meet. The game always keeps me engaged with the story and the story tends to be unpredictable  - there are times where you have to decide between tough choices or see the harsh life of this society.

[b]Length and Replayability[/b]
It took me 7.5h to finish the game for the first time. However, since I didn't finish all side quests at that time, another playthrough is needed to read all dialogues. The introduction of three playable characters that offer different intro, another scene, and a slight difference in dialogues also gives a good excuse to replay the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2364577370
[b]Problems[/b]
The game never gives any indication that the skip button exists. I didn't realize it during my playthrough but it's actually accessible with the Ctrl button.

[h1]Specs[/h1]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It was an enjoyable visual novel with good-looking visuals. Conversations are easy to understand despite the use of exquisite words in some dialogues. The addition of SFXs in some scenes also helps me to focus on the story and the story never disappoints - I hardly ever get bored reading them. However, it's more focused on side quests and world-building rather than the main story, leaving the main story to be bland. Luckily, the ending plays well to outweigh the con.
column9:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 13.6h (based on Steam, 100% achievement)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (~23 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York[/b] is a visual novel set in the universe of [i]Vampire: The Masquerade 5th Edition[/i]. I didn't have any knowledge of the said universe, but a quick google search shows that the work was derived from a [url=https://www.modiphius.net/collections/vampire-the-masquerade]tabletop game[/url]. Since I never played the tabletop version before, I won't try to compare the game with it and review the game as it is.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Several dialogue choices that lead to the same result
- 3 different characters with minor details

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Skip dialogue button is well-hidden

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you enjoy visual novel games with in-depth world-building and character interactions, buy this game on a sale.[/i]

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Being a visual novel game where you need to pay attention to aesthetics, the game doesn't disappoint. Backgrounds look realistic with high attention to the details. Not only that, the heavy use of lighting in most areas gives more atmosphere to the environment, especially with the night setting. The game also seems to give an extra effort to this department by animating minor parts such as dripping rain and glowing eyes. Characters are also looking beautiful with the painting-like, realistic style - you won't even notice that it's a 2D image from afar due to how realistic it is.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The tabletop version has a good core in its story building and the game does a good job of explaining it to the players. The game will flesh out the details little by little, throwing new terms here and there as it goes on. A dictionary that holds all information about the universe's terms are also available should you decide to revisit them.

Some dialogues will branch at some point, forcing you to choose an option. While this matters at the beginning of the game, even leading you to 2 bad endings, other branching paths will lead you to the same decision. However, choosing different dialogues might give you more information either about the world-building or the other party's true colors - it was interesting to see how each dialogue plays out. Surprisingly, each decision flows smoothly with the next dialogue, except for one occasion.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2364577409
The game seems to take notes of word usage depends on who is talking. People in high standing will use exquisite words that suit their status while people in lower standing will tend to curse as they talk. Despite the different word usage, everything flows smoothly and easy to understand except for some occasions where I had to translate some exquisite words that I didn't know.

Although you'll mostly be kept in the dark about what happened in the main story, the game lets you focus more on the side stories instead. There are 7 side stories that you can play, each having a different focus and interactions. You'll learn more about world-building, meet new people with unique characteristics, or see a unique side of the vampiric society. When all is said and done, the game will return to the main story, and you'll be in for a surprise. There might be slight plot holes and confusion to some parts of the story, but the plot twists outweigh more than those at this point.

[h1]The Game[/h1]
[b]Mechanics[/b]
As a vampire, you need to constantly drink blood to survive. The game will give you an option to drink whenever available, and failing to so after several days will leave a blood mark on the screen. Ignoring this warning will result in losing control near the end of the night, giving risk to your exposure by killing someone near to your home. I didn't know if it's possible to get a game over if you constantly doing this, but this never happens to me unless if I did it on purpose. There was a time when I was close to losing control though since there was one chain quest that doesn't give an opportunity to drink in all of its quests.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2364577448
[b]Side Quests[/b]
Side quests take most of your playtime in this game. You have 2 actions per night which can be used to either recruit up to 4 companions or do other side quests unrelated to it. All side quests will take more than one visit to finish and sometimes, the main quest will also take one or both actions in a single night. It's possible to fail any companions' side quests if you made a bad first impression on the character and even if you manage to convince all of them, you won't be able to recruit everyone in a single playthrough. The most that I could recruit was 3, and that's after ignoring other side quests that are not related to companions.

It was interesting to do the side quests and experience the different characteristics of everyone that you meet. The game always keeps me engaged with the story and the story tends to be unpredictable  - there are times where you have to decide between tough choices or see the harsh life of this society.

[b]Length and Replayability[/b]
It took me 7.5h to finish the game for the first time. However, since I didn't finish all side quests at that time, another playthrough is needed to read all dialogues. The introduction of three playable characters that offer different intro, another scene, and a slight difference in dialogues also gives a good excuse to replay the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2364577370
[b]Problems[/b]
The game never gives any indication that the skip button exists. I didn't realize it during my playthrough but it's actually accessible with the Ctrl button.

[h1]Specs[/h1]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It was an enjoyable visual novel with good-looking visuals. Conversations are easy to understand despite the use of exquisite words in some dialogues. The addition of SFXs in some scenes also helps me to focus on the story and the story never disappoints - I hardly ever get bored reading them. However, it's more focused on side quests and world-building rather than the main story, leaving the main story to be bland. Luckily, the ending plays well to outweigh the con.

column8:
Es una novela visual que recoge perfectamente el esp√≠ritu de las campa√±as del juego de rol original en las que no dejas de ser una marioneta que pretende conseguir hacerse un hueco. El arte es agradable, aunque el sonido se queda algo pobre (falta de variedad musical), pero cumple su cometido al generar una atm√≥sfera decadente y oscura.
Obviamente, no es un juego para quienes no les guste leer o quieran ser el personaje m√°s poderoso en cada situaci√≥n. Ni este juego ni Mundo de Tinieblas en general deber√≠an ir sobre eso. Este juego va sobre ser un pe√≥n en medio de conspiraciones y sobre existencialismo y qui√©n vaya  comprarlo debe tener claro que se trata de disfrutar el viaje de cada uno de los tres personajes, de interpretarlo (el juego no te lo pide, pero resulta m√°s divertido as√≠) y de aceptar que no puedes controlarlo todo cuando eres un reci√©n llegado a una sociedad de vampiros que llevan d√©cadas o siglos jugando a hacerse da√±o.
El juego suele estar de oferta aqu√≠ o en otras plataformas por 2‚Ç¨ o menos, y para m√≠ es un juego de unos 5‚Ç¨, aunque si no te importa pagar y eres un fan√°tico de Mundo de Tinieblas, quiz√° te merezca la pena pagar los 20‚Ç¨ que vale normalmente.

Although the idea and writing is, honestly quite fine.  The game itself is just too short with no real replayability in the slightest, and the choices you make, really all don't make any difference. If you want to hear a vampire story, then this is the game for you I suppose; but if you want an actual game, I'd say look elsewhere.  in four and a half hours I managed to go through the entirety of the game doing as many side missions as possible while also keeping up with the main story when it demanded I continue it. Also 

the ending scene played out of nowhere making no sense to the choices I made.  My two main allies were the wizard and the detective so far as I was working on their stories first, and the ones who came to save me were the detective and the werewolf-wannabe who I only spoke a few words to once; and for some reason they figured I was their friends, when I wasn't friends with either of them yet.  There also was no warning of "Hey the game is going to end if you do this next minor sounding main quest missions so you should finish up the side content first".  Not that there should be one, the main story should have been significantly longer.

All in all, not a bad game necessarily; but also just not a good one, and a waste of the IP.

column8:
Who told me this game was bad? I remember having it on my wishlist upon release and then deleting it. I remember reviews and some backlash, but underneath all the rubble, this game isn‚Äôt half bad.

[h1]The advertising[/h1]

To understand where the hatred is coming from, we need to first discuss the initial release. The game had been advertised as a grand VN with meaningful choices much like the original "Vampire: the Masquerade" game. People were expecting much more content from this new addition, Coteries, but the price tag should already have been a warning.

What can you expect from a game that costs ¬£15,99?

[h1]The actual game[/h1] 

It shouldn‚Äôt have been a surprise that the actual VN turned out to be a watered-down version. A lot of the reviews still complain about meaningless choices, but is that really the problem? So many books have been advertised wrongly and people still buy them despite misleading blurbs. I finally bought this game to actually play it, without my lack of knowledge from the previous games, without any prejudice.

Guess what. It ain‚Äôt half bad.

The beginning is masterly crafted and hooks you in. The characters are believable and truly stand out. As a newborn vampire, you feel powerless and you certainly don't know what's going in. It portrays the life of the vampire in a different light and shows an angle pop fiction can only dream of. But that is also part of the problem. How can a VN (or a novel) manifest a video game that is so well loved because it allows so many meaningful choices?

The short answer: it can't. 
And that's where you have to leave your hatred because if you think a VN can come close to an open world RPG, you are a fool. So, if you have spent the past few hours pondering whether you want to buy this game and still don't know because reviewer X said the choices suck, don't even bother. Come for the story and you will be rewarded, however.

[h1]What's the tea?[/h1] 

One of the feverish debates on here seems to be the ending. I severely regret even looking into the matter because the ending isn't abrupt at all, although some reviewers will try and tell you differently. I have played one playthrough and it took me 5 hours. I'm not a slow reader by any means, but I completed the main story, two companion quests and two side quests. How can people with 2-3 hours playtime tell me they've understood the whole plot? I really wish I'd bought the game sooner and ignored the remarks. Any person who reads books will see the ending for what it is, the completion of the story. If you wanted more story, another arc, you would have needed to pay double the price.

My negative remark concerns the formatting and [b]the interface[/b].The game has formatting issues and I couldn't get the text to align, which meant I sometimes had to scroll up when the text was being displayed. This did hinder immersion, but it only appeared when the box was too small for the text.

On a sidenote: I absolutely hated Hope's arc and that comes from somebody who read "Tender is the Flesh" in 2 nights. I wish she and other characters would have got more time to develop and played a more active role in the plot, but that could have been an entirely different game.

tl;dr Readers will enjoy this version of "Vampire: the Masquerade", gamers not so much.

column8:
A horrible attempt at building a visual novel and a V:tM game. Boring story, Game-play mechanics that makes no sense as a visual novel, Re-used assets....feels like not a lot of effort was put into this game.

No character building, No meaningful choices. No option to to hunt. You can't even exit the game without saving.

Even those free ren'py VNs  feels better to play than this.

column8:
Okay, positive review - however, this games suffers from the exact same problem as Six Ages (a similar game). Railroading!

Stop. being. afraid. to. tell. the. player. they. have. lost.

I do understand the logic - oh but what if they stop playing... trust me, they won't. People play games like this because they want to be challenged! 

There's nothing wrong with saying 'look, we asked you to do X and you didn't do X, therefore you lose the game'.

Still - good read, fun characters - interesting look into 2020 setting of VTM with the high tech we have now compared to in Bloodlines. Will get the next one - just cut the railroading, make it a bit longer, have faith in your readers and maybe add in a few more RPG elements. Money, for example.

column8: a good story with a fantastic set of characters and a poor ending. but the journey is worth it and the world building is awesome. definitely worth reading if you're a fan of visual novels.

column8:
A beautiful visual novel - the art is gorgeous, the characters interesting, and the variety of choices and companions are enough to make you want to replay it as soon as you finish. If you like CYOA games or VNs in general, you'll likely enjoy this one a lot!

Something I also really appreciated: as someone new to VtM as a whole, the game did a great job of giving you enough info to adjust to the setting and organizing it into a dictionary for you to look at, without adding forced exposition.

column8:
Cannot recommend this right now due to bugs making it nearly unplayable. When I start the game, the screen shows me the publishers' name and then the loading screen, but after that the main menu is completely black. The sound works, so when I move the mouse I know that I hover over menu entries. By chance I clicked on the right one to start a new game, so I could choose a character to play - but during the gameplay all the backgrounds were black. I could still see the UI and the character art, but this being a visual novel, having no backgrounds greatly diminishes the experience. Not to mention that after my first game session I have no way of loading the save unless I happen to click on the right combination of places by pure chance. 

I am not the only one with this problem by far as I found out while I googled for solutions. Neither verifying the integrity of the files nor updating my GPU's driver fixed this problem. Some of the other complainants online suggested this is a recent bug, so I hope it gets fixed soon. Until then buying this game is a waste of money.

column8:
A friend is soon to run a VTM game for myself and some friends. Curious, I purchased the game in the hopes to learn more about the setting and the core gameplay of the TTRPG. I've had time to dabble in the three pathways and explore the story. 

The good: 
- Every character is complex and believable. Even the minor characters you only see in passing will eventually have a moment to shine somewhere or another.
- The writing balances its wit and sobriety well, and delivers both  comedy and horror with equal grace

The bad:
- gameplay can be a little monotonous. 
- There's /some/ variation between the three characters in the story, but looking into all three runs I found to be tiresome after trying out one in earnest. 
- The PCs have character, but there's little variation in dialogue options or story beats
- Save points are more like a bookmark; there's no going back after you make a choice. I've found going back through the entire game to change /one/ choice to dampen my enthusiasm in playing. 

In all, I've found my experience to be fun and exciting with some unfortunate lulls. VTM: Coteries of NY relies heavily on the theatre of the mind. If you don't like "choose your own adventure" style games, this isn't a game for you. However, if you enjoy a complex world of both supernatural intrigue and inter-political conspiracy, you'll enjoy the game as much as I have.

column8:
[b]TL;DR:[/b] short, linear visual novel story. Choices don't matter. Only one Ending, where your character is a passive observer as events wrap up to an unsatisfactory conclusion, leaving the story's plot points unresolved.

[h1]Railroading in New York[/h1] 

First of all, I have to mention the good stuff: great artwork, UI and sound. One thing that can be said in this game's favor is that it is very atmospheric for what is basically a text-based Choose Your Own Adventure.

That said, I wanted to like this visual novel, since I'm a fan/player of the tabletop storytelling game [i]Vampire: the Masquerade[/i] (though frankly, nowadays I much prefer its successor [i]Vampire: the Requiem[/i] 2E, but that's neither here nor there), the franchise this visual novel is now part of.

A game like this ‚Äì a visual novel ‚Äì might seem like an easy and simple thing to make, but with such a medium pretty much everything is riding on the story and the player's ability to influence it.
With a setup like that, you need an engaging story and several branching paths for players to explore (which means that, as a creator, you have to essentially write [i]several[/i] stories or at least many different scenarios that can be reached through player choices). Interactivity with the story is a big thing, but again ‚Äì it needs to be a good, engaging story because the game (or visual novel, rather) is literally all about it. 

[i]Coteries of New York[/i] sadly falls short of delivering that story and doesn't bother with branching paths, leaving a linear one-off plot.
Linearity by itself isn't a deal-breaker ‚Äì but your ability to affect the story through choices [i]is[/i] a deal-breaker and that ability doesn't really exist here.

Through the novel, you have few choices to make and literally none of them matter because this is a one-off story on rails and [i]this traaain don't stop[/i]‚Ä¶

Your first meaningless choice is in selecting one of three characters to play. This choice doesn't really matter, the story is the same regardless. They all start the same, they all end the same.
The only difference between the three characters is in some minor details such as the place where they became vampires and one specific person supposedly tied to their former lives. There are very few points in the story where a minor dialogue bit is very slightly altered to fit a particular character.

None of the things you think would matter actually do. Your specific powers (Disciplines) don't matter and many times using your powers doesn't change much than if you didn't ‚Äì only a few scenarios exist where it at least [i]feels[/i] like using a power helped you get something more, but it's largely meaningless in the end.

At some point you get something resembling a choice to make in how to spend your time, by choosing one of several set locations or characters to visit (essentially minor plotlines or side quests) but ultimately none of those choices matter and do not change a thing in the ending.

For example, you're supposed to gather "companions" (they feel more like quest-givers) and the game makes it seem like you need those characters but you really don't.
Most of these quests and "plotlines" can be completely ignored or left unfinished. In fact, a companion will show up in the ending whether you've finished their quest or not and you don't actually need any companions to show up in the end so feel free to burn all your bridges ‚Äì it makes no difference.

Most of the novel feels like filler until the grand finale, which plays out the same regardless of your choices and how you talk to the characters involved.

In fact, at some arbitrary point in the story the ending [i]just happens[/i], and your character is shoehorned through it whether you like it or not.

I'll avoid the big spoilers here but the ending is nothing grand and makes everything you've done until that point feel meaningless. I'll literally save you some time by describing it without naming names:

Your character is a passive observer in a conversation that doesn't really involve them and you are treated to what another reviewer already described as a villain's monologue (and that's basically what it is ‚Äì "Ha! Ha! Ha! I had this all planned all along!"), which would be fine by itself but it's literally all there is to it.

Who was your character's Sire? Irrelevant. What happens with that supposedly important mortal from your character's past? Never heard from again. What about the companions you gathered? Who knows‚Ä¶ 

Throughout the novel there are buds of little stories ‚Äì what's the deal with this mysterious guy? What becomes of you and this other vampire who seems to either spy on you or have a thing for you? What about your benefactor's relationship with this other character? 
None of them get developed. It's all shallow, tip-of-the-iceberg teasers to another story that you don't get to explore.

Nothing really gets resolved ‚Äì the game just ends and someone dies. 

The main antagonist [spoiler]is someone your character meets briefly once or twice throughout the entire story and has only a brief, unimportant interaction with them and absolutely no foreshadowing. Your character is actually completely irrelevant to their plan[/spoiler] and you remain irrelevant throughout its conclusion.

[b]PS[/b]
I forgot to mention that when you get to the ending, the entire story basically nullifies itself. [spoiler]the antagonist's plan is overly convoluted with too many redundancies that could have been avoided on their part and involves an unnecassry layer there just to excuse your existence as a vampire, which is largely unnecessary. Your entire presence in the story is then revealed to be unimportant and your character may as well have just stayed home instead of becoming a vampire and this entire story could have just been happening in a secret document in someone's left drawer and everything woud have been the same...[/spoiler]
column9:
[b]TL;DR:[/b] short, linear visual novel story. Choices don't matter. Only one Ending, where your character is a passive observer as events wrap up to an unsatisfactory conclusion, leaving the story's plot points unresolved.

[h1]Railroading in New York[/h1] 

First of all, I have to mention the good stuff: great artwork, UI and sound. One thing that can be said in this game's favor is that it is very atmospheric for what is basically a text-based Choose Your Own Adventure.

That said, I wanted to like this visual novel, since I'm a fan/player of the tabletop storytelling game [i]Vampire: the Masquerade[/i] (though frankly, nowadays I much prefer its successor [i]Vampire: the Requiem[/i] 2E, but that's neither here nor there), the franchise this visual novel is now part of.

A game like this ‚Äì a visual novel ‚Äì might seem like an easy and simple thing to make, but with such a medium pretty much everything is riding on the story and the player's ability to influence it.
With a setup like that, you need an engaging story and several branching paths for players to explore (which means that, as a creator, you have to essentially write [i]several[/i] stories or at least many different scenarios that can be reached through player choices). Interactivity with the story is a big thing, but again ‚Äì it needs to be a good, engaging story because the game (or visual novel, rather) is literally all about it. 

[i]Coteries of New York[/i] sadly falls short of delivering that story and doesn't bother with branching paths, leaving a linear one-off plot.
Linearity by itself isn't a deal-breaker ‚Äì but your ability to affect the story through choices [i]is[/i] a deal-breaker and that ability doesn't really exist here.

Through the novel, you have few choices to make and literally none of them matter because this is a one-off story on rails and [i]this traaain don't stop[/i]‚Ä¶

Your first meaningless choice is in selecting one of three characters to play. This choice doesn't really matter, the story is the same regardless. They all start the same, they all end the same.
The only difference between the three characters is in some minor details such as the place where they became vampires and one specific person supposedly tied to their former lives. There are very few points in the story where a minor dialogue bit is very slightly altered to fit a particular character.

None of the things you think would matter actually do. Your specific powers (Disciplines) don't matter and many times using your powers doesn't change much than if you didn't ‚Äì only a few scenarios exist where it at least [i]feels[/i] like using a power helped you get something more, but it's largely meaningless in the end.

At some point you get something resembling a choice to make in how to spend your time, by choosing one of several set locations or characters to visit (essentially minor plotlines or side quests) but ultimately none of those choices matter and do not change a thing in the ending.

For example, you're supposed to gather "companions" (they feel more like quest-givers) and the game makes it seem like you need those characters but you really don't.
Most of these quests and "plotlines" can be completely ignored or left unfinished. In fact, a companion will show up in the ending whether you've finished their quest or not and you don't actually need any companions to show up in the end so feel free to burn all your bridges ‚Äì it makes no difference.

Most of the novel feels like filler until the grand finale, which plays out the same regardless of your choices and how you talk to the characters involved.

In fact, at some arbitrary point in the story the ending [i]just happens[/i], and your character is shoehorned through it whether you like it or not.

I'll avoid the big spoilers here but the ending is nothing grand and makes everything you've done until that point feel meaningless. I'll literally save you some time by describing it without naming names:

Your character is a passive observer in a conversation that doesn't really involve them and you are treated to what another reviewer already described as a villain's monologue (and that's basically what it is ‚Äì "Ha! Ha! Ha! I had this all planned all along!"), which would be fine by itself but it's literally all there is to it.

Who was your character's Sire? Irrelevant. What happens with that supposedly important mortal from your character's past? Never heard from again. What about the companions you gathered? Who knows‚Ä¶ 

Throughout the novel there are buds of little stories ‚Äì what's the deal with this mysterious guy? What becomes of you and this other vampire who seems to either spy on you or have a thing for you? What about your benefactor's relationship with this other character? 
None of them get developed. It's all shallow, tip-of-the-iceberg teasers to another story that you don't get to explore.

Nothing really gets resolved ‚Äì the game just ends and someone dies. 

The main antagonist [spoiler]is someone your character meets briefly once or twice throughout the entire story and has only a brief, unimportant interaction with them and absolutely no foreshadowing. Your character is actually completely irrelevant to their plan[/spoiler] and you remain irrelevant throughout its conclusion.

[b]PS[/b]
I forgot to mention that when you get to the ending, the entire story basically nullifies itself. [spoiler]the antagonist's plan is overly convoluted with too many redundancies that could have been avoided on their part and involves an unnecassry layer there just to excuse your existence as a vampire, which is largely unnecessary. Your entire presence in the story is then revealed to be unimportant and your character may as well have just stayed home instead of becoming a vampire and this entire story could have just been happening in a secret document in someone's left drawer and everything woud have been the same...[/spoiler]

column8: Coteries of New York is a great game, true to the spirit of VTM. I've played Bloodlines and this game is in many ways similar to Troika game, it allows multiple approaches and solutions, has good music and art and very well written. It is more linear, but perhaps due to limited scope.
column9: Coteries of New York is a great game, true to the spirit of VTM. I've played Bloodlines and this game is in many ways similar to Troika game, it allows multiple approaches and solutions, has good music and art and very well written. It is more linear, but perhaps due to limited scope.

column8:
I'm really conflicted by this one.  On one hand I'm hooked on the idea of further exploring the World of Darkness universe, and most of the characters and interactions presented are really absorbing and interesting.

But the ending completely invalidates all of your efforts for the sake of having a big twist.  I guess it's thematically appropriate that a story in this world might be expected to have a darker ending, but I can't help but walk away from the experience feeling like I've been shit on.

It's an especially big betrayal to me because I was really enjoying the ride and seeing where it would go until it very abruptly ends.  And it ends badly.  You may think that it's shallow to ultimately give the gave a poor review because of this, but at the end of the day I would say that if the setting intrigues you like it does me to get this only when it's on sale and play it with tempered expectations.

(Also D‚ÄôAngelo is a Bro 4 unLyfe)

The game is short and had a shitful end. And has a bug with dark backgorund on screen that no one answer how to solved.

Written in the second person this game assumes that you're entirely stupid. It kept telling me I had emotions that didn't make sense - for the character, let alone me - and the occasional options on how to respond to specific conversation cues or circumstances tended to have three options: An inane one, a stupid one and one that was the 'correct' one to pick but would only be chosen by a stupid person.

Frankly the character being depicted deserved the painful death my choices gave him; he was clearly too stupid to live. Game uninstalled, the writing is teenage emo grade idiocy.

column8: Good story, good mood. I agree with other reviewers that the ending is a little hastily wrapped up but... Recalls some WoD experiences that I had about 20 years ago. Nowadays, better to have a rat than let the hunger take over, right?

column8:
Listed in importance (Spoilers - but you wont regret them).
Story: Initially good, cuts off to ending as if developer run out of money. It drives into conclusion that doesn't make a sense. Although you can take different paths, you will always end up at the same finish line. Also, the whole name and core of the game is about getting your coterie together. (Band of specialist, like in a heist movies). But no mater who you will pick, or how successful you be, they will just show up and disappear. Nothing. 
Gameplay: Nothing to call home to. Simplistic choose your own adventure type. No inventory, only extra thing is glossary of Vampire terms.
Graphics: Mostly just a pretty wallpapers and the main core of storytelling - text is small in the corner of the screen. 
Audio: No voiceovers, atmospheric music is actually good.

How to save this in the updates:
Developers should rewrite the story at the start and at the end, so it could work as a standalone game and not as paid prequel with extra meaningless options.

What to learn from this:
It genuinely has the same atmosphere as the Bloodlines game, with protagonist making errands for powerful entities, good atmosphere and interesting stories to tell. But, the overall story is not putting it together with satisfaction. Maybe, if you feel there is a week payoff, you should drop it alltogether and just focus on the small stories.

column8:
Jesus, what a clusterfuck. I would swear this game was written by a 90's D&D player who travelled through time to sabotage White Wolf (he doesn't know it doesn't exist anymore), but that would have most likely led to a time paradox which would mercifully destroy the universe and save us from this cringy, teenage, boring drivel.

But let's be honest - this preachy, woke trash isn't worth a time-traveller's time, and neither is it yours. Whip up the books and go play with friends, a normal play session is longer than this game anyway.

I have never played tabletop games but I've always loved reading the lore.  This is basically a visual novel set in the Vampire Masquerade universe.  I'd rate the writing as pretty deece, if you're willing to accept that immortal beings will necessarily be weird to make their undeath more interesting.

If you got this cheap or through a Humble Bundle it's worth a play through.  I had fun.

column8:
This is part 1 of a visual novel series (part 2 is "Shadows of New York"). It takes roughly 6 hours to read through. While there is one main story line, there are numerous side quests that you can work your way through. [i]Just to be clear, this is a visual novel and not a true game.[/i]

[b]Pros[/b]
It's very atmospheric. The art and music definitely set the mood.
Some of the side quests are great stories with great characters.

[b]Cons[/b]
The price. This is a $5 to $10 dollar product. I would never pay $20 for this. Wait for a sale.
The main story ends in a very contrived, lame way. Worse, you cannot change the ending at all (it would have been so easy to have multiple endings that it boggles my mind why they didn't go that route).

[b]Summary[/b]
Overall, I generally enjoyed it and would purchase it [i]on sale[/i] again. The ending (and lack of multiple endings) really hurts it though.

column8:
The beginning was promising. It started as a well-written V:tM story, with the main character Embraced against their will and forcibly induced into Camarilla, similar to the protagonist of Bloodlines. It even makes more sense here, because instead of working for the asshole Prince, you work for the person that persuaded her to spare you. You are asked to build our own coterie while running errands for Sophie Langley and this part is actually where the game is the strongest - all four potential candidates are interesting.

However, nothing we do actually matters. After an arbitrary time limit, the game just wraps up by itself. Your coterie shows up in the ending exactly once and they aren't even necessary there. You aren't necessary in the ending too, because it's resolved by more powerful NPCs talking and fighting while you stand there like a statue. It ends with some guy, whom you had spoken to maybe once or twice, giving you a villain monologue how it was his plan all along and Blood-Bonding you.

column8:
Positives:
- I really liked the atmosphere.
- I enjoyed the music/soundscape.
- It reminds me, in so many ways, of Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines (which is not surprising give they're both born from the same material), yet at the same time it‚Äôs its own thing. 
- I enjoyed the character I played.
- I enjoyed the characters I encountered and the different webs you create with them and the alliances it creates.

Negatives:
- It made me want to re-play VtM: Bloodlines again.
- It made me want VtM: Bloodlines 2 NOW.
- It made want to partake in a tabletop game of VtM.
- I really wish this existed for Werewolves too‚Ä¶
- I wish it was longer or had more episodes or something.

column8: Muito Bom agora em portugu√™s esta perfeito !
tr√®s bon jeu merci √† Amaras pour cette d√©couverte

Je suis ravi d'avoir pu produire un Let's play sur ma chaine (Bruce Livre) de cette aventure d'exception dans le monde des t√©n√®bres. Si vous aimez les jeux narratifs, le jdr papier Vampire La Mascarade, les longs dialogues avec des personnages travaill√©s et les ambiances sombres et prenantes, alors n'attendez plus ce soft est pour vous.

I must admit I hesitated for several months before buying ‚ÄúVtM CoNY‚Äù because the artwork put me off. Boy am I glad that I finally decided to give it a try.

The story is exceptionally thrilling and overall well told. The dialogue is well written, quick-paced and most of the time sheer fun to read. ‚ÄúVtM CoNY‚Äù is a visual novel where your choices really matter. You make your first important decision right at the start when you get to pick one of three possible main characters. Each has a distinctively different set of dialogue options and powers. It is impossible to pick all the different story-lines in one go. While in some nights you have to follow the story in a predefined way you also get to choose different sub-plots. All of this makes for great replay value. Even after finishing the game 4 times there are paths I haven‚Äôt explored yet.

The soundtrack is another big pro of this game, I simply sat back from the screen at times to listen. The music is dark, grimy and atmospherically dense.

My only real grievance is that the ending felt a little too artificial, a bit hard to believe. And yet, I had been so involved in the story and really cared for some of the characters so much that I immediately wanted to know more about them. I would highly recommend buying this title if you are into vampires and visual novels.

column8: I loved the game, really really good, I hope we have the "shadows of new york" translation to pt-br too.

I'm really enjoying this. Longtime fan of Vampire: The Masquerade, from back in the days when not even the Nosferatu had internet access. The game totally nails the tone, and would be a great introduction into what can be a very lore-heavy universe.

Yeah, it's a visual novel. But unlike most visual novels, it's a lot more interesting than creepily ogling a bunch of anime girls. And besides, if you don't like to read... what the hell are you doing playing a World of Darkness game?

column8:
Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York is both better and worse than Werewolf: The Apocalypse - Heart of the Forest.

VtMCoNY is a visual novel based on the Vampires: The Masquerade game. It's based on (I think it's called) V5, which moves the story to the modern nights, what with the Second Inquisition and all. It uses very little of the rules and mechanics (except possibly hunger) and various disciplines, so you don't get a character sheet.

There's no voice-acting and very little ambient sound, but the minimal music is very atmospheric. The art is beautiful, and I like the designs of the various characters. The writing is pretty good and consistent.

You play one of three origin stories, a Brujah, a Ventrue or a Toreador. There are differences enough between them and their disciplines that you can get multiple playthroughs without too much repetition. There are sidequests, and recruitment missions for the eponymous "coterie". The coterie bit actually feels non-consequential; I'd really thought they'd tag along for other side missions, or for the main plot, but they really don't show up much at all, except for one tiny scene. At least their missions are interesting and varied.

The game seems to be on a bit of a time-limit, so you can only do 4 side- and coterie-missions in all during a single playthrough. If you recruit more than two coterie members in a single game, you'll still only get only two of them during that one scene, but I don't know what metric it uses to decide.

It's a good game, I guess. Each run-through will take about 3 hours, so it's longer than WtAHotF, and it's a lot less repetitive. I liked it better, because the art is a lot more interesting, and there's more to the characters. The start can drag a bit, and the ending is a bit abrupt, but the point at which the end happens makes sense in context. If you're complaining about what happens to your character, well, what did you expect would happen?
column9:

column8: ambiance vampire la mascarade...j'adore
buen acercamiento al mundo de WoD, bastant explicativo y el relato esta super bueno.

Okay, let's get the cons out of the way first. You should avoid this game if you have a problem with the following:

--this game not being Bloodlines 2
--a slow opening act
--the inability to do every available quest in one game run
--a fair lack of agency over how things end up
--a bleak and bitter ending

But if you can manage all that, then Coteries of New York is an EXCELLENT game to go with. I look at it in much the same way I do Shadowrun Returns: a game more designed to introduce people new to the setting the various ins and outs on how the in-game universe works (just as an aside: if you are one of those people who object to outsiders wanting to join in something that you've obsessed about for a while...well, ever thought about how you're aping the Camarilla with that attitude?), hence why the opening act is so slow. But given that you're a newly Embraced of one of three clans (determined by you right out of the gate), the confusing first act makes sense in the context.

The artwork throughout is absolutely gorgeous, as is the soundtrack. Both evoke a world that resembles our own while giving sinister hints of this older world you've toppled into that runs deeper than any NYC subway. Add in the occasional animation for spice and there's plenty of pretty things to look at throughout. The few times it made a full screen of certain dramatic moments made me regret that there were not more of them.  

The middle act is the game's true delight. You attempt to recruit fellow vampires for your coterie, do favors for your patron and otherwise just try to make sense of this new world you're thrust into. While the vampires you run into do lean towards clan stereotypes (a Nosferatu detective, a Tremere occult book store owner), there are little touches about them that can still surprise you (the exact nature of Hope the Malkavian being one such, running into your Tremere's grandmother being another). I do wish that feeding was shown to be more important than what I experienced. Then again, I fed at about every opportunity that came my way, so maybe there ARE consequences to denying your hunger.

The final act is where you'll ultimately decide whether you love this game or hate it. I will refrain from spoilers as to what exactly happens. However I will say that the threads for the ending start early, some of your earlier actions WILL play into how it goes down, it's a little inconclusive (possibly because it will be dealt with in a future game or DLC) and that it fits with a thesis of mine on how VTM is ultimately an anti-power fantasy world. I keep hearing the final lines of Robert Towne's most famous screenplay every time I think about that ending: "Forget it, Jake. It's Chinatown."

If this is all a bit too much for you, I strongly recommend that you seek out Night Road, Choice of Games' first contribution to VTM. If you're fine with all the above, then go for it. This game might just stick in your head the way it keeps sticking in mine.

column8:
This is actually the first game I feel driven to write a review for. Yes, I liked it very much. The game gets a lot of justified fire cause the main story is kind of railroaded. However, I love the characters, and really, I mean ALL of the NPC's. They are written with a lot of detail and flair, and you only dip into their vast backgrounds during the game. And in the seven side stories (Benoit, Frank, Adelaide and the four allies) the choices you make actually DO matter. I did three play-throughs just to explore those further and would still like to know more about them (so many hooks unresolved), but by then the inevitability of the main story is somewhat grating. The game would be so much more satisfying if, say, when you go for kissing Adelaide (I finally managed it with the Ventrue of all things), that she would react to that in the finale and you could at least change small things. Sigh.

Still, the characters and side stories kept me deeply involved in the game and it's certainly worth playing!

column8:
Si tratta di una Visual Novel ambientata nella New York del modo dei gdr cartacei "Mondo di Tenebra".
La trama gira intorno alla storia del nostro protagonista che viene "abbracciato" (reso vampiro) e poi abbandonato dal suo sire (colui che lo ha generato) e finisce in una rete di intrighi e complotti.
All'inizio, il gioco sembra prevedere la possibilit√† di diramazioni nella storia ma andando avanti ci si accorge che tutto si sviluppa su un binario prestabilito e il finale √® sempre lo stesso indipendentemente dalle scelte fatte.
La decisione iniziale tra 3 possibili protagonisti permette di affrontare diverse prove ricorrendo a particolari poteri tipici del personaggio scelto. Tuttavia non ci sar√† mai il rischio di bloccarsi o terminare prematuramente l'avventura (a parte un paio di casi a inizio gioco..)
Difatti durante ciascuna nottata √® possibile portare avanti 2 sole (alcune volte solo 1) quest a scelta.. a fine gioco ne rimarranno alcune non terminate che potranno essere affrontate solo avviando una nuova partita.
Le schermate sono artisticamente molto belle ma poche.. durante alcune scene d'azione avrebbe giovato mettere magari dei quadri diversi anzich√© il solito sfondo dell'ambientazione con la scritta della descrizione di come si sta volgendo l'azione.
Purtroppo la visual novel √® solo in lingua inglese e senza audio dei dialoghi. I testi sono molto descrittivi degli ambienti e spesso contengono anche vocaboli da cercare sul dizionario. A ci√≤ si aggiungono i termini come masquerade, thin blood, ecc.. tipici del gioco di ruolo da cui √® tratta l'amb√¨entazione. Per questi termini la novel mette a disposizione un dizionario consultabile in game atto a spiegare queste parole ai neofiti di questo mondo.

In definitiva si consiglia l'acquisto ad un prezzo basso o in occasione di particolari offerte. Se ne sconsiglia l'acquisto per chi ha poca dimestichezza con la lingua inglese.

column8:
BUY WHEN ON HUGE DISCOUNT
No real save state to talk about, you die your save state gets deleted. 
The ending is just horribly bad writing and feels rushed.. In fact thats what this game feels like, rushed. 
The sad thing is it gives you 3 clans to chose from but it feels like it doesnt matter in the slightest.
 The characters are fleshed out and fun to interact with but in the end the whole purpose of the getting a coterie (a word meaning group or gathering of close individuals and the damn name in the game) is ultimately pointless and underwhelming.

column8:
This game has an alluring atmosphere and interesting characters, which make for a fine introduction to the world of VtM. 

As far as the game experience goes, though, something is missing for me. Between the fact that your character is pre-made and that your options in any given situation are very restricted, you have precious little control not just on what happens but also on how you carry yourself. Helplessness, to a degree, is supposed to be part of a fledgling's life, but this goes beyond that: you are forced to antagonize people you quite clearly shouldn't, for instance, or keep a secret that is rather obviously going to bite you in the ass an hour or day later. 
I'd not say this is bad writing: the options are... reasonable. If the protagonist took them in a film or novel, you wouldn't think twice. But it is... insufficient writing. There are a lot more options that are rather reasoable too, and you are denied them. Your choice don't matter enough.

It is still a good story! If you don't mind being mostly along for the ride, I'd still recommend it. 
But I wanted to play VtM, and this wasn't. It felt a lot closer to watching someone else play it.

This game was a "choose your own adventure" type of game. It was well written and enjoyable to a point. But it ended out of nowhere *Spoilers?* I hesitate to use spoilers because it was a spoiler for me! I was playing the game and a character I never interacted with came in and ended the game. It was abrupt and weird. Truly I have no idea. And it sucks because up until that point the story was well done, which makes it all the worse.  Perhaps its a glitch, or they developed like only one ending so all options feed into their endgame. I would say the premise of the game is fun but they gave up before figured out there should be an ending.
 Which is ok in other games, but a narrative "choose your own adventure" type of game, you really need an ending! I'd say skip this one.

column8: If you are a fan of VtM, then you'll enjoy the story. Otherwise, don't bother, you won't get much out of this game.  I really want to recommend this game, but it's very hard, considering how much it crushed my enthusiasm. The main story is actually quite short and was easily beatable in less than 6 hours, maybe just a few if you sit down and blast through it. Also, you aren't given a warning when the story is coming to an end, and if you haven't completed all the side missions before you start the final mission, you're SOL. Also, while I found the story engaging and fun, the ending was just too abrupt, unfulfilling and even traumatizing, lol. Maybe not literally so, but it just felt like a slap in the face. I guess that's how Kindred society works sometimes, though. Buy it when it's on sale. It's not worth full price.

column8:
Well done! Very much the feel of a vampire the masquerade table top RPG story, but made as a visual novel. It's not perfect, feels a bit like an unfinished product, they could have cleaned the stories a bit (spelling mistakes) and many of the early choices ended up having no impact of being completely ignored, like Ventrue feeding limitation, but It did start very good with enough meat to make it interesting for me. 
More positive than negative for me.

column8:
I would love to give this a positive review and recommend it but I cannot in good conscious do so.

1. Unless you are going for achievements, there is no replay value at all.
2. Considering there is no practical reason for a replay, it's far, far too short.
3. The NPC art of the characters you meet is, for lack of better words, absolutely awful. The ones you interact with the most are very bad. Some of the most interesting ones you only see once or twice. If the same detail was put into the cast of characters as it was into the background scenery, it would be great.
4. The cast of characters themselves is for the most part, predictably bad. You're presented with several Malkavians, and every single one of them is God awful. Same with the Toreador. Same with the Brujah. The Nosferatu and Gangrel are by far the most interesting of the bunch.
5. The ending is a ridiculous atrocity where nothing you do matters and you, your coterie, and your "adopted sire" get completely outplayed by a ridiculous looking scrub with a high pitched, giddy, weasel voice who in actuality would get backhanded into submission by anyone who looked at him funny.

If you're going to have a game where the "big reveal" is that I am getting completely outplayed and I'm forced to "lose" no matter what I do, at least make it an interesting individual that is actually cool to lose too, not somebody who it's an obvious insult to lose too.  It reeks of, "Haha. We're going to make you lose to a scrub out of spite because making it be an actually awesome individual is too good of an idea."

Which brings me to 6.

6. You're a Caitiff. A friggen Caitiff. You pick Brujah, Toreador, or Ventrue, and the first thing they do is make you an illegal embrace, serve you up to the Sheriff, and then make you suffer a life boon. That isn't how you start, let alone tell a compelling V:tM story.

If it was longer, had an ending based on your choices, expanded your coterie options, and added some more interesting artwork so there was some replay value than this totally gets a positive review!!!

column8: It is a good game with a strong story focus. I would especially recommend it to fans of the previous games from VtM franchise (or VtM tabletop players!); I feel like the knowledge of the WoD lore was really helpful and helped me get more emerged in the experience and understand the plot better. I wish the player had more time to explore the side quests; the final quest came really suddenly and I was confused as to why the characters that appeared, appeared. I almost thought that I must have skipped something by accident. I am going to complete this game again and do different side quests this time. It is a game worth coming back to.
column9: It is a good game with a strong story focus. I would especially recommend it to fans of the previous games from VtM franchise (or VtM tabletop players!); I feel like the knowledge of the WoD lore was really helpful and helped me get more emerged in the experience and understand the plot better. I wish the player had more time to explore the side quests; the final quest came really suddenly and I was confused as to why the characters that appeared, appeared. I almost thought that I must have skipped something by accident. I am going to complete this game again and do different side quests this time. It is a game worth coming back to.

column8: I don't like visual novels because I can't get past the, normally, bad stories. This one is the exception to the rule for me. I've only played about 6 hours but can tell this is one I will be finishing. Love the story, setting, and plot.

column8: This game is wonderful - the art and writing really capture the tone of the World of Darkness, the characters are really engaging, and they spread some really solid mysteries to unravel through the story - but there are also some big caveats before I recommend this game to someone. For the first, and biggest, thing: the whole game feels like one giant prologue to a story, and the game ends just as you're getting to the first, climactic turning point of the story, without even so much as a single scene to release the tension. I understand that they're making sequel(s) to continue with the world established here, but it still kind of sucks to buy a full game and only get part of a story, rather than one self-contained piece in a broader narrative. The other caveat is that, to see all of the (again, really good!) missions, you need to make sure you stick to specific questlines until they're complete, because the game ends pretty suddenly without really telling you there's a time limit to when you can do things. This means you need either one or two (if you try to go through multiple different questlines on your first playthrough as I did) replays are required to see what the game has to offer. The problem with that is, even when playing different characters, much of your story and dialogue will be repeated without any significant difference, making the whole process kind of a chore.

column8:
A Visual Novel that doesn't require any familiarity with Vampire: the Masquerade to be enjoyed yet I would still say Coteries of New York is helped if you have some. Particularly with the latest edition of the tabletop roleplaying game that updated the setting used here. Is THIS game worth playing, however?

Having only three playable clans; Brujah, Ventrue and Toreador, is an odd choice, but one obviously aimed at representing core values of the vampire ‚Äúgovernment‚Äù that is the Camarilla. Seeing your character was on the receiving end of a rogue Embrace it's not long before your life is spared by Prince of New York and giving lease on unlife under Sophie Langley as she ends up vouching for you. If any of this is confusing don't worry because game has a neat glossary you can reference. One glance at the genre should pretty much tell you everything you need to know and what could set this one apart is actually kept rather vague from the player. Only ‚Äústat‚Äù to really keep track of is your Hunger as the only indicator you have is how much strawberry gem is smeared over your screen. Speaking of stats ‚Äì I can't shake the feeling an actual stat screen could've immensely helped here to fight the arbitrary nature of what your character can do at points. Adding a sort-of timed nightly nature means you'll have to forego bits of content for replays, awkward narrative that should have perhaps given you more to do past errand duties and a single railroaded ending make this a short ride even with rather solid writing.

Other than gorgeous production values for the genre you can't help but marvel at, even if you're looking more at the dialog screen than animated backgrounds themselves, in case you ARE familiar with the source material there's quite a few references and callbacks here. Particularly with canonical characters in such a hotly contested area like New York. Primary issue running through Coteries of New York is just how cut short it plays. Both in how it strings main events and in the ending itself which throws everything to the wind for a sudden cop-out not even companions you worked for can save.

column8:
While I was unsure what to expect of a graphic novel reimagined as a video game, I had no doubt I would gladly sink into the ambience of a new VtM experience. The concept art, the subtle animations, and the soundtrack really make this two-dimensional, written story come to life. The game allows you to freely select which chapters you want play when, which I thought was nice.

Like every review you come across points out, the one significant drawback is that there is not enough time to explore every questline. You could argue that this leaves some blanks open for a replay; personally, I don't see why replayability should be of more concern to the developers than a wholly satisfying playthrough. Because of this needless limitation of opportunities (1 night usually offers you to play 2 chapters), I strongly advise against jumping around between individual storylines. Instead, stick to the same one as long as possible, My other complaint is that, while I did feel that I got a good impression of every other character's personality (as usual, the writing is smooth and descriptive, and stimulates the imagination) - there was hardly anything particularly >Toreador< about the dialogue options, as well as too few dialogue options altogether. I also don't enjoy being told how I'm supposed to feel. 
Despite these weaknesses, I found the experience immersive and exciting. 
I suspect I might have expected a 'Hunger' bug around one of my final nights, which may have overwritten a chapter, because I feel like I missed a part of the main Anarch storyline (after getting the phone). As mentioned, the concept art is impeccable, my only critique there is that they could have added a few different 'back alleys'.

If you're into the World of Darkness/Vampire the Masquerade, you will enjoy this if you think of it as an introductory campaign, a short snack. I suppose the other two main-character options will not change the details of the story all that much much, yet you will probably find yourself replaying the game for an opportunity to read the other half of the story.

column8:
I love the Vampire: The Masquerade setting.  Played the table top game back in the day.  Played the computer RPGs.

This was entertaining as well.

Problem is, is that its a visual novel.

Not a bad thing in itself, but it is a short one.  A few hours and you are done.

For $20.

If it was $5 it would be worth it.  Choices don't appear to have much value except to modify some side characters.

So if its on a 75% off sale, jump on it for a few hours of reliving a great setting with a compelling story, but you will feel cheated if you pay any more.

I was very excited when this game was announced, so it's a bit heartbreaking to tell it ended up to be a major disappointment. Despite its title, the coterie you're building up your entire playthrough is completely irrelevant to the main plot. It comes into play in [i]one[/i] scene only, which I consider a crime because the characters are quite well-written and interesting. Their storylines are solid, yet they exist in a their own isolated bubbles. More than that, you can't finish all the questlines (including side stories) in just one playthrough, and there's no warning about it. It forces you to do a second run, and while I welcome replayability, I don't have an urge to try a new clan and pick other characters as part of my coterie. Four words: your choices don't matter. The game gives you an illusion of choice but it's just that ‚Äî an illusion. No matter what you choose, the plot wants you to pick a certain option and actively "corrects" the ones you took. It's baffling, to say the least. The ending is wrapped quickly and messily, leaving a lot of plot holes and half-baked ideas. It could've been a great game but alas: the only two decent aspects of it I can name are visuals and soundtrack.
The story so far has been very good. The writing, the atmosphere, the art and the ambient sound all come together quite nicely.
column9: The story so far has been very good. The writing, the atmosphere, the art and the ambient sound all come together quite nicely.

column8:
Okay, I haven't finished the game yet, so I'm likely to come back to this when I do.
For those who aren't familiar with visual novels, the core of the experience has a lot of text involved and the interactive aspect typically has the player choose from a list of responses that moves the story forward. 

So far the game is pretty entertaining with some interesting characters. The way it's set up, it should be a fairly friendly intro for people who are new to the Vampire: The Masquerade IP/Setting. There's been a lot of lore built up over the years in general and, while I'm not very familiar with the newer material, the core stuff appears to be in place here. 
The game promises intrigue and not much in the way of fighting (which would be in text format)
[spoiler] so if you're looking for something with more action, maybe go with "Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines" -it's dated but fans have patched the snot out of it and it's considered a classic. In some ways, a little less lore but still good. [/spoiler]

 Worth 20 bucks? Right now, with so many people out of work, I can't recommend it at full price -- but I also haven't finished the game yet!

This game is a good start for a series of visual novel set in the World of Darkness. It does really create a nice atmosphere and brings in a bunch of memorable characters, some which come straight from the rpg books. For someone who loves playing the tabletop game this was a pleasant surprise.
As a visual novel it works well to just sit back and relax and spend a few hours on.
My only complaints is that no matter choosing your clan there is basically little variation in the main story. And seeing the original price point I find it a bit hard to completely justify that.
The story itself is short and to the point. So having a bit more variety between the three clan choices would be nice, now it is only two scenes of personal history that differ.

Overall I enjoyed the game.

As ong as it is on sale,

Go for it. I would never pay full price as the story is too "unexciting" and the choices you have are midiocre at best.

Little example: I chose the toreador yet, this game gives me nothing to actually utilize any feats that are unique to my bloodclan.

It is however, a lovely presentation with good graphics, and a nice introduction in to the world of Vampire: The Masquerade, especially if you are new to it.

It was a difficult recomendation and a "Neutral" would probably fit more if I had the option. But again, if it is on sale and you have the spare change, go for it. Just don't expect a true tabletop experience with freedom of choice and identification with your character, but if you want to enjoy a more relaxed interactive read.

column8: –ö—É—Å—å

The storyline of the game is in itself is quite decent with an interesting twist, but the game has two pitfalls:

1) It will be tricky to complete all the side quests as these can fail and time is limited to work through them. It thus requires multiple playthroughs. Luckily there are three different characters that one can play, so the story is somewhat different, but generally it amounts to the same thing. You will not be able to diverge too far into different directions. It thus becomes tedious to see all these sidequests to their end during multiple playthroughs when the main storyline is practically the same.

2) The game insists on being politically correct to the max. Your own character in singular form will therefore end up being referred to as 'them' and 'they'. This could make sense where it concerns the unique background of one specific character. I do however not think it is appropriate to foist certain values upon an entire player base when it only concerns a minority to which it is applicable. Alternatively the developers could have adjusted it in the settings, so that the text would be different depending on player preferences. The developers however did neither. People come to play a vampire game.....they are not interested in having political viewpoints pushed on them about how some view that the world should be. 

As a result, I cannot but give a negative review. As stated, the game is quite decent, but I find this type of behaviour by developers not considerate, but rather extremely rude. It is just not cool. If there was only the first pitfall, then I would have still given a positive review.

column8:
First up, I enjoyed this game.
It's set in the "World of Darkness" (the same as the other "Masquerade" games) but this is NOT the same type of game as Vampire: the Masquerade - Redemption or Vampire: the Masquerade - Bloodlines.

The biggest change is that this game is effectively one of those "choose your own adventure" books like Warlock of Firetop Mountain, from the early 80's.
What that means for game-play is that combat is virtually non-existent (as with stealth etc) whereas in the other Vampire games I mentioned these were big (though not the only) elements of game play.
You are faced with a few "missions" and you can choose which ones to pursue. After lots of dialogue and narrative you are usually faced with "choices" to make or say. Even combat boils down to fight or not, or use a "vampire skill".
Be very careful with your choices as there is an autosave running all the time.

There is lots of good art work and sound and it makes a great film noir atmosphere. I played it at night after the rest of the house was in bed each night. This game is dripping with good dialogue, well written characters and an atmosphere I thoroughly enjoyed. 
If you liked one of those earlier games you "might" like this setting but don't make the mistake of thinking it is Bloodlines 2.
The first ten or so minutes is the slowest as it introduces you to the "World of Darkness" and your character realises they are now a vampire. Once you get through that the plot proper begins and I found it picked up.
I am still debating whether to do a second play through with the same character or choose a different one (choice of 3 starting characters).
Having said that I can't wait to get my teeth into Bloodlines 2.
My other quandry is whether to grab what I believe is the next "installment" Vampire: The Masquerade - Shadows of New York and dive straight in without replaying this game. A nice quandry to be faced with I know.

Please don't buy this if you are looking for "action" and then review bomb it, this is not that type of game.
I won't give this a score other than to say I had fun with it and I hope you do too.
column9:
First up, I enjoyed this game.
It's set in the "World of Darkness" (the same as the other "Masquerade" games) but this is NOT the same type of game as Vampire: the Masquerade - Redemption or Vampire: the Masquerade - Bloodlines.

The biggest change is that this game is effectively one of those "choose your own adventure" books like Warlock of Firetop Mountain, from the early 80's.
What that means for game-play is that combat is virtually non-existent (as with stealth etc) whereas in the other Vampire games I mentioned these were big (though not the only) elements of game play.
You are faced with a few "missions" and you can choose which ones to pursue. After lots of dialogue and narrative you are usually faced with "choices" to make or say. Even combat boils down to fight or not, or use a "vampire skill".
Be very careful with your choices as there is an autosave running all the time.

There is lots of good art work and sound and it makes a great film noir atmosphere. I played it at night after the rest of the house was in bed each night. This game is dripping with good dialogue, well written characters and an atmosphere I thoroughly enjoyed. 
If you liked one of those earlier games you "might" like this setting but don't make the mistake of thinking it is Bloodlines 2.
The first ten or so minutes is the slowest as it introduces you to the "World of Darkness" and your character realises they are now a vampire. Once you get through that the plot proper begins and I found it picked up.
I am still debating whether to do a second play through with the same character or choose a different one (choice of 3 starting characters).
Having said that I can't wait to get my teeth into Bloodlines 2.
My other quandry is whether to grab what I believe is the next "installment" Vampire: The Masquerade - Shadows of New York and dive straight in without replaying this game. A nice quandry to be faced with I know.

Please don't buy this if you are looking for "action" and then review bomb it, this is not that type of game.
I won't give this a score other than to say I had fun with it and I hope you do too.

column8: A pretty little atmospheric game - perfect pastime until Bloodlines 2 comes out.

column8:
A visual novel set in the World of Darkness. Great voice acting and artistic style, interesting characters and plot (although very linear, and not much in the way of meaningful choices. Super short, even with 3 different clans to choose from (offering minor changes in dialogue and options), a single play through can be completed in about 3 hours.

If you're at all interested in the WoD or Vampire: the Masquerade and enjoy text based adventure games, it's worth picking up on sale. Otherwise leave it on the shelf.

column8:
The game is interesting in the initial play, as you explore the various options available to you. However, its fairly linear in terms of the story-line and the game forces certain events on you when it reaches a certain stage, so that you don't have the full opportunity to explore all the potential branches in a single play-through. 

The game is probably good for 2-3 hours in a single play-through, but becomes somewhat disappointing on subsequent plays as other bloodlines. Recommend that you only purchase the game when its heavily discounted.

column8:
This story is great, even if not perfect (there are some plot holes that get very obvious at the end).
The "obligatory plot twist" at the end is... so so. The idea of it is a good one, but it was poorly implemented so it feels forced. 
The game is highly linear, i gives a lot of impression of choice and no matter what you do you always get the same ending.
No voice acting - I really don't care, since I always read 1.000 times faster than the actors speak, but I get that some people find that important. At the moment, only English language is available as well - again, I don't care, but some find it important for a game to have other languages.
It seems my review is a little harsh, but trust me, this game is worth it if you like the VtM scenario.

Its well written, there are a fair amount of different paths and choices, the most proeminent one being your clan and, therefore, how you begin the game. Not much else to be said about it. Its often dirt cheap and it could be worth a couple of bucks of your money and a few hours of your time if you like the World of Darkness stuff or Vampire specifically.

column8:
This is one of those games where I wish there was more of a gradient between yes/no on on recommending a game.

It's got solid art and atmosphere and is pretty decent and relaying the World of Darkness atmosphere. However, some of the characters feel cartoonish in comparison to the source material. Example: Qadir's characterization almost comes off and childish for one of his position/history, so it's a little off-putting. Choices and their presentation can be frustratingly nebulous.

I'd recommend for people who like VtM/WoD in general and don't mind some of the need for repetition and off-kilter characterizations.
