column8:
This game is interesting. I think many people will be getting into dark and cruel World of Darkness only having knowledge from Bloodlines, and despite Bloodlines being a good game, it doesn't provide that good of a grip on what is the World of Darkness. This game is completely the opposite. It most likely is intended to be as The World of Darkness Experience. It's painfully cliched and formulaic, it follows all the tropes by word. And that is a good thing for people with no knowledge of WoD

From the gameplay perspective, it's not much. It is a visual novel with minimal differences in routes, most only affecting a couple of scenes. The core of the story will always stay the same, no matter how much you will try to disrupt it. And that is a bit disappointing. A lot of the story parts feel like they might lead somewhere, but they never do. Your choices define your flavor, but nothing much.

It's been some time since I've played interactive fiction, but I was really pleased and impressed with how well this game pulled it off. The writing and the art as superb, really capturing the feel of the World of Darkness. The one area which I feel could have used a little more polish are some of the choice tracking, since some arcs didn't follow as cleanly as I would have liked. Nevertheless, I played this game every evening until I was done.

Aunque es una novela visual, o quiz√°s debido a ello, ha sabido captar muy bien el ambiente de las partidas de "Vampiro la Mascarada".

It's simply cringe, in the most hipsteresque way possible. There's a good, if somewhat generic story beneath the eye-rolling writing, but you gotta put up with a lot of the writers' personal ideologies shoved into each of the three stereotypical characters and almost every other character, besides the evil ones, I guess. Makes sense. It sometimes gets awkwardly funny when paired with the art in moments where the writing doesn't match what's shown on screen. The artwork is exceptional in most part, although I am disappointed it's not more animated. I can't help but compare it with a similar but better visual novel, The 39 Steps, which is a lot more dynamic than just press continue and pick the absolutely obvious answer of the three.
And that's about all there is to say about this game. I hope this kind of quality doesn't bleed into the main Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2 game.
column9:
It's simply cringe, in the most hipsteresque way possible. There's a good, if somewhat generic story beneath the eye-rolling writing, but you gotta put up with a lot of the writers' personal ideologies shoved into each of the three stereotypical characters and almost every other character, besides the evil ones, I guess. Makes sense. It sometimes gets awkwardly funny when paired with the art in moments where the writing doesn't match what's shown on screen. The artwork is exceptional in most part, although I am disappointed it's not more animated. I can't help but compare it with a similar but better visual novel, The 39 Steps, which is a lot more dynamic than just press continue and pick the absolutely obvious answer of the three.
And that's about all there is to say about this game. I hope this kind of quality doesn't bleed into the main Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2 game.

column8: This game captures the feel of the World of Darkness perfectly. The story telling and writing are very enjoyable while the rain and music really make the atmosphere come to life. I am a fan of the visual novel style, but be aware that the choices you make don't feel like much overall.  This is definitely one of those games you may enjoy a bit more as a pre-established fan of the tabletop games, though it's a good feeler for those totally new to the world as well.

column8: Putting aside the sudden end and questionable finale, as well as the prevalent heteronormativity in the writing, the game was quite engaging and addictive, serving as a great piece of the franchise mainly through its nightlife setting and some colorful characters like Hope. The music played a major role in making this more than just a text game. Here is hoping that the VtM series evolves even further, regardless of how it's presented.

column8:
Great to have played another VTM video game after so long! I rather enjoyed the new visual novel style; quite an interesting change from from the move and action oriented approach from before. The characters were always interesting to interact with and the music suited each atmosphere change nicely.

If there was one thing that I can gripe about is that I do wish there were multiple endings to this game based on the decisions that have been made and the clan that was chosen.

Besides that, I thoroughly enjoyed all of the hours spent on this and cannot wait to play more games in this awesome world!

Aucune de tes d√©cisions n'a vraiment d'importance, aucun lien avec ton sire, avec la sc√®ne de d√©part, avec ta coterie... le jeu termine 3/4 h trop t√¥t, et il n'a y a pas d'arborescence des √©v√©nements, pourtant la base dans ce genre de jeux!!![/spoiler]. I was surprised to find myself wanting more by the end, and although there was a decent conclusion, it left much room for more story. 

I‚Äôm unfamiliar with the Vampire Masquerade saga but it seems the developers did a great job here because I felt very immersed in the world. Good soundtrack and immersive environmental sounds setting the scenes, but somewhat of a shame there was no voice acting involved. There‚Äôs also not much in terms of gameplay and don‚Äôt expect to experience everything in one playthrough. I do believe the endings are no different ‚Äì except for those who have you finished off prematurely ‚Äì but there is enough for at least two rounds that you can explore and meet new character stories. 

I had plenty of joy getting to know those characters and unliving in the dark corners of a rainy New York. But price is a bit steep for what it has to offer, and I got this from a bundle, so I say: wait for a discount. I can understand its price despite not having voice acting because you can see there was good work put into it, specially on the worldbuilding, oh yes!, but they did not explore the full potential of some of the presented ideas.

I definitely recommend this if you get the chance and the time. It‚Äôll give you some immersive 4-6 hours if you‚Äôre into vampires and daylight quarantine.

column8:
This was a surprisingly immersive game and I genuinely enjoyed the ride. However, the ending was jarringly abrupt. I felt like I had too much left undone, too much I didn't know. There were too many characters with questions unanswered, and I desperately wanted to find out what happened to them before, and what will come next. But it just ended, and that was it.

I feel like this is still absolutely worth your time though (perhaps wait for a sale maybe? at least wishlist it) because although it did leave me disappointed at the end, it made me fall in love with the universe. It has made me so much more excited for Bloodlines 2 and I'm definitely going to go through the first one very soon. I need more! and I really hope they make a sequel to this game so that I can tie up a LOT of lose ends.

column8:
The reason this is a no for me is two-fold: first, the options you have to proceed aren't as clear as they ought to be, and second, there is no backup save option. And the second issue compounds the first. For example, there was an option to 'outrun' a threat, which could either be interpreted as running away, or running to fight - completely opposite choices, with no way to tell which one you're actually making. And, if you pick a choice that does something different from what you expected, the save system means you're stuck with it. I understand the design decision of only allowing one automatically updating save, but I don't think the choices are implemented well enough for the design choice to be acceptable. 

It's a shame, because I was really enjoying where the story was going, and the world of the game was interesting, but I can't see myself going back and finishing it when hours of playthrough can be upset by misinterpreting one choice, and having no way to fix it.

column8: I don't understand what the hell is the story about.

I had not played any of the other Vampire games in the series so this was kind of a gamble whether I would like it or not. Vampires and visual novels are right up my alley though so I thought, why not? The story pulled me in slowly, just like a lover would with candle light dinners, wine, and the feeling of teeth on your neck. It was a bit graphic in it's story telling, really giving you the imagery that the stills were not but in the best way. Just maybe don't play this in the family room on the 65" flat screen. Friendly warning, you'll thank me later. There are a variety of characters with vivid personalities that range from probably normal for a vamp, to beware stranger danger. The game play allows you to be pretty free with your choices so you aren't just reading a Charlaine Harris novel. Don't get me wrong, your choices make make a difference. Mine may have had me cursing and wishing I could reload a past save but alas, that's a negative, Ghost Rider. Overall it was a fun experience and I would play it again. 8/10.

The more I think about this game, the more I feel insulted. This review will contain some minor spoilers, if you can consider this a story that can be spoiled...

DrawDistance has created here a very half-arsed attempt at story telling and game design.
I'm not sure if they thought they were being clever or subversive but what we got here is a 'game' which seems like it was shipped unfinished - they either ran out of time, budget, enthusiasm, ideas or all of the above.

Okay, time for a little positivity don't you think?

The art in this game is pretty good, I can dig it.
The soundscapes and music are fitting and well produced, not that I can remember anything that stood out.
While it was delayed on release - Coteries of New York is available for Linux (and Mac), which I'm grateful for, and was one of two reasons I bought this game. It runs really well without any problems and seems a solid linux build.
(But then again there isn't a lot going on here it's all text and slightly moving backgrounds.)
Now.. I think that's it for the positive...

Lets get ragging on it again!

Coteries of New York is a roughly 6 hour text adventure with a choose-your-own illusion.
Remember when I said before there were two reasons I bought this? (You should it was only in the last paragraph) The second reason was that this is a story set in the cult classic world of Vampire: The Masquerade. Fans of other products of the universe will know that the bar is set pretty high here - I was hoping for something a little special.

Well... in [i]this[/i] game you can choose three clans, coincidentally all three are the most normal, close to human and easily interchangeable vampire types in the series. Anything more intriguing would require large re-writes and diversions of the 'story'.
The reason is clear, there are no branching paths, no alternate endings to this, merely slightly different flavours with the same end result.
The writing prior to the end of the game is totally passable. It's not going to win any awards, just a bit ham-handed, but it's fine. One of the things that I found very jarring though was the extremely contemporary nature of some of the writing, with direct references to YouTube, Fugazi and other on-the-nose comparisons to real world stuff. 
It get's really bad when the end of the game comes (as abruptly as it does) it reveals its colours as a cliched and lazily written gotcha,

I wasn't upset that this game was entirely reading, I wasn't upset that the choices were very limited, I wasn't upset that I couldn't play Malkavian and my options were all boring and 'not me', I wasn't upset that this game pulls the forced diversity and female representation card forcibly hard and even references racism in the most awkward way during dialogue.
I [i]WAS[/i] upset when after so many in-game days playing the game, all of my in-progress friend stories were cut short because SURPRISE FUCKER! ENDING!
See, in this game you're instructed to go and make some friends and are given 6 or so contacts. What the game never explains is that you've got limited time to pick just two so the game can try and make the end more impactful and... unique. SUBVERSION FUCKER. SURPRISED YET? WOAH DUDE.

At the end of this game not only is everything left as an untidy loose end, you can't even choose your fate.
The end doesn't even fit well into the vampire universe, not really.
What's more is that the best written, most interesting character in the game, the sheriff, who has hints about his past dripped in all over, just stops being part of the story about half way in.

If you can't tell I'm pretty salty about my purchase and this was pretty incoherent. Just like Coteries of New York I'll end this review un

column8: If I could I would leave a ~ review for this game. The art is good, the characters interesting and... there's just one ending (aside of getting killed in the first minutes of the game). Whatever you do, it is more about your journey to that one predestinated ending. Who would you have with you and what you will do before it's curtains. Whatever you do, will not affect the ending in the slightest, it will just make the trip towards it different.

column8:
I really wanted to like this game, but the writing was not good enough to make me want to read on. Especially not when there was an achievement in the 17th minute of "gameplay" (meaning hitting enter after every two sentences) popping up, cheering me on reading until getting turned into a vampire. It feels like even the writers know that it was not that interesting to read on.
The story might be interesting, but I don't think I'll ever get to know.

column8:
I love Vampires: The Mascarade, but I'm usually not too big on Visual Novels because they too often show that a simple game architecture requires immense work on writing, music, sound design and artworks alone. If your game is gonna be text based, that text, and everything that carries it along, have to be extremely solid.

It's not the case here. Artworks and music are very good, I'll give them that. The writing doesn't hold up for a VTM visual novel, sadly. Ideas are common, many of them taken and rebuilt from the original Bloodlines game, which is an obvious influence for this. The intro is too long for too little, characters range from completely bland to okay-ish at best. The story takes forever to move on, and player input is scarce, limited, and often just there as a way for the game to make sure you understand what is going on. I don't feel engaged, surprised, concerned or entertained by the 4 nights I've spent in the game's diegesis.

I really love VTM, I do, and I keep hoping we'll get strong games out of it in the likes of Bloodlines and Redemption. But we don't, not just yet.

column8: There are moments where this game shines. Some of the characterization becomes deep and interesting in moments, but almost non of it pays off in any meaningful way at all. Crucially, and this is the one unforgivable sin for any visual novel, all of your choices railroad you into the same ending! There is no reward for your consideration or creativity. The game feels unfinished. You're introduced to a number of intriguing characters and topics, yet almost none of them are revisited in any meaningful way.

Crucially, and this is the one unforgivable sin for any visual novel, all of your choices railroad you into the same ending! There is no reward for your consideration or creativity. The game feels unfinished. You're introduced to a number of intriguing characters and topics, yet almost none of them are revisited in any meaningful way.

Jogo muito bom pra quem curte Vampiro: A M√°scara e novelas visuais. A hist√≥ria √© interessante, bem trabalhada e com ramifica√ß√µes tamb√©m curiosas. Tem muito do universo do RPG de mesa inclu√≠do de forma simples pra quem nunca nem jogou RPG, assim como bons easter eggs para quem joga h√° tempos.

Os pontos fracos que senti falta √© que, por vezes, os di√°logos e hist√≥ria se arrastam demais e poderiam ser mais diretos. Muitas cenas s√£o descritas de maneira muito boas, mas n√£o tem imagem pra acompanhar, poderia ter mais ilustra√ß√µes das cenas e personagens. Por fim, voice acting para os personagens seria outra grande melhoria.

Mas no geral adorei o jogo, busquei fechar todas as rotas com todos personagens e j√° comprei, aguardando ansioso, pra come√ßar a sequ√™ncia do Shadows of New York.

Even being a long time fan of Vampire: The Masquerade didn't make up for the shortcomings of this game. 

Perhaps the creators had lofty intentions of making an interactive novel, a story to be experienced rather than played, but it hits wide of the mark.  It's difficult to be invested in anything that's going on when your lack of agency is so blatant. 

Other than rare exceptions, like a tutorial that forces you to select certain options to continue, you can start the game, repeatedly spam the enter key, and in a few hours you'll hit the end credits.

There's only one ending, unless you count the option choosing to die very early on (and it really is choosing to die). You can't even cause minor deviations within the main ending.

I played through this as all the characters, though there's so little variation between them I need not have bothered. My main reason for persevering at all became the achievements. 

It feels less like an immersive story, and more like you're playing a tabletop rpg where the game master is only interested in hearing themselves speak. They tell you the story, how your character feels, and what they do. I'm left with the impression that if Coteries of New York was a GM in real life, you could walk away from the gaming table and come back an hour later and they'd still be talking, oblivious of your absence.

The world, the characters, and the general story are mostly fine. It's no Bloodlines, of course, but fine. There was no reason for this to be a game though, it would have been more satisfying as a novel.

column8:
Visual novel with decent art but no voice acting. Read lots of angsty and overly melodramatic text from a small box in the corner of the screen. Pick some moderately interesting side quests. Make some random choices that don't matter much. Then the over-arching excuse for a plot closes around you and it ends.

Googling for "vampire the masquerade fan fiction" provides more compelling narratives.

column8:
Overall it looks like a very cheap cliche take on the vampire/VtM theme.
Like decent but solely conveyor work only for buisiness purposes, following the commotion around VtM setting after Bloodlines 2 announcement. 
Zero personal input, zero novelty, zero sincerity.
Nothing that you have not seen before.
As for the story/dialogues... it's more boring and dry than reading a rulebook.
No personality for characters, no notable clan differences or whatever.
When you get an introduction to the VtM world it so... "by the book" and watered down... that you yawn the halfway.

And this thing for prolonging gameplay with only one save for one game.
Want to try other dialogue option replay the whole thing.
(sometimes you want to do it, because answers are shortened, so they not cover what PC is about to say, you may only guess what the rest of the sentence will be about)
And this is particulary cheap beacause choices doesn't really matter as you get the same outcome anyway.
Not even basic comfort options like in RenPy.
(like skipping text that you have already seen, or scrolling forward with a wheel, rather than clicks, etc., you can skip text, but everything at once, regardless of whether you read it before or not)

column8: Jogo Imersivo, com algum conhecimento em Vampiro a m√°scara, melhor ainda.

I played Redemption, Bloodlines, some indies and the tabletop version. 

- Is this game worth playing? Yes.
- Is this game worth it's full price? No.
- Do choices matter? No - but did they ever?

How does this work?

The Game uses the setting from the [i]New York by Night[/i], a sourcebook for Vampire: The Masquerade about the war between the Sabbat and the Camarilla over New York City. You meet some familiar faces if you're acquainted with the book. Aside from one moment when the game designers ask you straight in your face if you want to fail there is no stopping power in terms of finishing the story. The mere fact that the protagonist exists drives the plot. You can call it predestination, or poor writting, but If you're a fan of the World of Darkness you're going to play the game anyway at some point. After playing all other fillers, reading all books you'll still want more. It's like with Star Wars, or with the Marvel universe. The review won't discourage nor encourage you. The setting itself is enough to make you want to check it out.

Ich bin kein gro√üer Review Schreiber, aber zu diesem Titel muss ich einfach mal meinen Senf los werden. Nicht im Negativen... mitnichten. Positiv!
Das Spiel ist einfach klasse und das meine ich im Stile einer Visual Novel. 
Es ist kein Action Rollenspiel. Es ist eine Erz√§hlung eines frisch "geborenen" Vampirs auf den Pfaden in die Dunkelheit und einer Welt der Intrigen. 
Man trifft Entscheidungen im Verlauf der Geschichte, die das allgemeine Charakterbild bestimmen, welches man im voranschreiten formt.
Ich beendete es so eben und mir ist bewusst das [spoiler]es nur ein Ende hat[/spoiler]
Ich bin dennoch versucht es erneut mit anderen Charakteren zu beginnen, um die Unterschiede kennen zu lernen.

Als langj√§hriger Pen and Paper Spieler und Fan der World of Darkness muss ich sagen das ich es mit jeder Faser genossen habe.
Es h√§lt sich an die Welt, die Strukturen und f√ºhrt einen St√ºck f√ºr St√ºck heran.
Es war herrlich dies alles so zu sehen und zu lesen. Die Atmosph√§re ist einfach Klasse.
Wie ein "One-Shot" quasi in einer Pen and Paper Runde.

column8:
This is a very solid title. It's like a introduction to the World of Darkness for those, who never heard of it. Our protagonist is in the dark, just like the player will be at the beginning of the game. The mysterious and dangerous society of the Camarilla will force us to think fast, smart and a few steps ahead - always. The Kindred do not tolerate fools among themselves, and they're ruthless in exploiting any weaknesses.

This game took me about 5 hours to beat, and I think that for a title like that it's a good ammount of time. The music and visuals are very good, and fit the atmosphere perfectly. I love the addition of many, modern slang elements into the dialogues, and there are fascinating throwbacks to the Classic World of Darkness line.

I strongly recommend picking this title up and giving it a go. Sure, it's a simple interactive visual novel, but it's addicting... almost like that sweet, sweet vitae...

I had such incredibly high hopes for this game and somehow... it's REALLY let me down.
As a visual novel, I don't appreciate making meaningful choices from the jump that turn out to mean absolutely nothing to the 'result'.  (No matter what, your behavior is perceived as BAD from siring to Prince judgement.)
As a Vampire game, i'm sincerely disappointed by the lack of options and control over my character.

The writing is decent and the art is pretty good but I just can't get behind this one.

column8:
My native tongue is German, please bear with me here ok? 
I am... cut in two here. The art and all is wonderful but the game and the choices are too limited for my taste, No real developement possible in my eyes. But that could be the gamer in me that usually play's different games as this one. Means, strategy and character developement games. I needed getting used to it's flow first, so to speak. I am more used to Bloodlines and such games. 
What tipped the scale so hugely into the negative was the end. 
I must say, it was unoriginal, truly rushed and honestly told; they could have done better! Could have made soo much more out of it... and dissapointed. 
That was it? Any game I have ever played in my life had at least different endings... or should I say was more rewarding to the player and so, buyer? In an afterthought, I consider this a valuable expirience in what to buy or not. But still have to say that everyone has to decide for themselves to buy or not to buy such a game. 
Well, I wouldn't do it again. 
So, in that order; I give the artwork, the ambiente and the general artistic aproach of it a solid nine on a range of ten. The story; the twists and turns and all, a good six. But the the ending and general flow at the end a barely two for effort.

column8:
First of all, I would only recommend this game as an accessory to other ones, not as an investment to sink in a lot of time. The game lacks the length, depth, or impact to make you play for a long time. I reached the only ending in about 5 hours.

The best thing about this is that it's Vampire the Masquerade. World of Darkness NY is recreated well, and your vampires can use the Blood Disciplines appropriate for their Clan, and have an advantage during the scenes. You can be Brujah, Ventrue or Toreador. You'll also meet some sort-of "companions" with a questline and from several (non-Sabbat) Clans, each with their own identity and quirks.

Otherwise, it's not really good. Even though the game uses Vampire themes, the main storyline is a bit unhinged when considered as part of it. And the most glaring aspect is that it doesn't last a lot, so a fair price is about 10 dollars/euros (which is what I paid). It could go well with playing during Halloween week as part of the holiday.

It also has minimal replayability, but it's something. Not a whole lot of content though. Consider it a very short visual novel in the 5 to 7 hours range.

Eigentlich ein interessantes Spiel und zeitweise ganz gut geschrieben, aber warum l√§sst mich ein Spiel welches nur aus Text besteht im Endeffekt nur ca 1/8 meines Bildschirms nutzen?! So gro√ü ist n√§mlich das Textfeld des Spiels. Hier spielen sich 98% des Spiels ab, der Rest des Bildschirms ist zu 95% der Zeit schwarz, die anderen 5% sind gemalte Bilder, die nicht einmal animiert sind. Wer kam auf die Idee es so herum zu machen und nicht vice versa?

column8: A really good written novel, I like it much. Though I have to admit, choices do matter little only and the story could be much longer. But for that price? - A simple choice to people who love to enjoy a good story, like to read and hear a very good voice-over.

Die ersten Minuten sind durchaus interessant gestaltet, weichen aber schnell der Ern√ºchterung. Die wenigen Storyf√§den bieten 1, 2 nette Ideen, die Gesamtgeschichte ist aber zum einen kaum erw√§hnenswert, zum anderen verdient das vom Hersteller bezeichnete "grande finale" seinen Namen nicht und k√∂nnte eher als Sarkasmus angesehen werden; wie viele andere hier schon geschrieben haben, hat man das Gef√ºhl, der Entwickler h√§tte mitten in der Geschichte einfach aufgeh√∂rt, als sie gerade begann, was √§u√üerst unbefriedigend ist und eher als schlechter Scherz wirkt.

Dazu begeht das Spiel mehrere Kardinalss√ºnden beim Genre der interaktiven B√ºcher: v√∂llig harmlos scheinende Aktionen f√ºhren urpl√∂tzlich im n√§chsten Satz dazu, dass der vom Spieler gesteuerte Charakter strunzdumme und ganz andere Taten begeht, als die Aktion h√§tte vermuten lassen. Daher sind die Ergebnisse der getroffenen Entscheidungen oft reine Willk√ºr und dem Zufall √ºberlassen.  

Davon ab sind die einzelnen Entscheidungsm√∂glichkeiten sowieso Makulatur - sie haben kaum bis gar keine unterschiedlichen Auswirkungen auf die Geschichte. Insofern ist der Wiederspielwert sehr gering.

Au√üerdem scheint der Programmierer nicht mal die einfachste Arithmetik anwenden zu k√∂nnen: am Ende erscheinen gerade die beiden NPCs zur Hilfe, mit denen ich am wenigsten zu tun hatte und die ich kaum kannte, was nicht nur unglaubw√ºrdig wirkt, sondern auch √§rgerlich ist, da man die anderen Charaktere schlie√ülich nicht umsonst interessanter fand.

Auf der Habenseite kann man leider nur die mehr oder weniger statischen Grafiken, die sp√§rlichen aber Atmosph√§re schaffenden Animationen und das Musik- bzw. Sounddesign erw√§hnen. Aufgrund des geringen Inhalts w√ºrde ich verzweifelten Fans von m√§√üig interaktiven Geschichten maximal zu einem Kauf w√§hrend eines Sales raten.

column8:
VtM - Coteries of New York is a visual novel type of game. It is not a traditional video game. If you pick it up, know that you will be doing a lot of reading. Well, basically that's all that you will be doing.
Having said that, I enjoyed it but I admit that I'm biased since I'm a fan of the World of Darkness IP (WoD). I can recommend it if you are also a fan of WoD or have an interest in it, otherwise it's probably better giving it a pass.
In case you are interested, WoD is a horror setting where you are the monster. A vampire in this case. Typically, WoD is a very oppressive setting where vampires are cool but nothing like your glittering Twilight vampires. Here, they are cruel, manipulative and paranoid.

Coteries does a good job in setting the mood and ambiance of the game. Especially the first time you play it. I played the whole campaign twice to explore some of the alternative stories.
The choices you make momentarily affect some of the reactions of the characters you interact with, but overall they will not affect the main story line. It's not a problem if you take this game for what it is: a graphic novel where you click through the story, while it provides you with some nice background music and images while you read. I liked it but I think it's not for everyone.

Pick it up if you like WoD and it's on  sale or in a bundle. The original $20 price is too steep.

column8: This game is a great way to pass the time until the new Vampire: Bloodlines game comes out! Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York is very much like a playable book. The story is a bit short, but overall the atmosphere and characters in the game are believable and interesting. There are a few different ways to play the game, so finding all the nuances and getting all achievements allows for some replayability for a while. All in all, a good taste of vampires for those of us waiting for the new game.

column8:
It was difficult for me to choose whether to recommend this game or not.

Ultimately, I chose not. I got it as part of a bundle and if you did as well (or very cheap/free) then I most definitely recommend playing it. But is it worth the asking price? No.

The art is decent, the world building is great even if you're unfamiliar with WoD stuff. The writing is just okay but the ideas and subplots presented in it are much more clever than the use of language would have you believe.

However, it's obscenely short and the main story arc is trash, frankly. The side quests are all really great, but the main plot is not only extremely meh but also relies on the supremely lame trope of the mastermind who planned everything to happen exactly as it did all along - even pure happenstance and coincidence. The ending happens abruptly, coming out of nowhere, breaking any and all immersion as well as bringing the game and the plot to an unsatisfying conclusion with dozens of loose ends.

Once I finished it I thought it was just an episodic game and checked out the other game in the line - Shadows of New York - but it turns out it isn't a continuation but a stand alone game. 

Knowing that, the ending is so sudden and pointless that feels like the devs just got tired of working on the game and pulled the ending out of their rears so they could start the revenue stream. And to make it insulting, it's presented in such a way as to try to convince you the writers were just being clever.

If you can get it for very cheap and are prepared for the disappointment - sure. Go for it. Otherwise, don't bother.

So this is a game to play if you want to introduce a person to the Vampire the Masquerade universe.  It's approachable, has fantastic hooks, and the story is dramatic in the best ways possible.  But there's issues too.  The game is too short, and there's really only one ending that feels far too rushed.  If this is the beginning of a better franchise, then I say it's a very solid first attempt.  7/10.

column8: A nice and smooth experience with characters that felt rich and reactive to the choices that were made. I really enjoyed it!

The story is interesting but the end of it just feels incomplete as it just abruptly ends. Also there is no save feature besides save on exit. I actually didn't finish every side story as there was no indication saying or warning that by going forward in the main story that it would end the game. Once you finish the game you can no longer load the saved game so you would have to start a new game all over again. I really do not see any replay value in this so no reason to not give individual saves. This is not a bad game overall as far as the story but i can't really recommend it with the game save limitations and how you can't finish side stories if you finish the main story first.

column8: Of all the visual novels I've played, this has been the most gripping and interesting one of them all. Not getting a sequel to this game would be an injustice. I greatly appreciate the work that went into designing the choices, all of them felt meaningful and let you approach the situation in a wide variety of ways. There was shockingly few times when there wasn't a choice I found agreeable. Honestly I don't think it would be a stretch to call this a masterpiece of a visual novel. Bravo.

column8: I am huge fan of VTM Bloodlines and I've read a couple of visual novels, so I was pretty excited for this game and I have to say I wasn't disappointed, I pretty much finished it in one go. The story is rich and art is fantastic. My only complaint would be the choices here - they kind of limit amount of content you see (in one playthrough) but they do not change the story in any significant way. Also you can only save on exit and this is type of game where you have dialogue options but your character says something different and it's not always what you thought it meant and you don't have an option to rollback, which is unfortunate. And the end is a little rushed. But overall the game is great and I enjoyed every minute of it.

column8: If you are a fan of the material you will love this. The story is engaging, the characters are incredibly well written, especially for who they are and their clans. As long as you understand that this is just a point and click visual novel with a little bit of choose your own adventure you'll be able to enjoy this. The story is branching and your decisions do matter. The clan you choose to be a part of of course will influence your powers later on, although some of my powers seem to never work but maybe I was just using them on characters that were too strong. I have no idea if it is a random number generator based success or not. I am a little confused as to why you cannot play this game over remote like on your phone through Steam Link.

column8:
TLDR: This game makes one of the worst  fucking design decisions i've ever had the displeasure of experiencing. Whoever thought the way this game's failstate works was a good idea: fuck yourself with a sharp object. Go play the standalone expansion/sequel: Shadows of New York. It's better in every conceivable way.

I'm in the strange position of having played the sequel/expansion before touching this the predecessor, and in many ways I think doing so has ruined this game for me. Coteries feels extremely underdeveloped compared to the sequel. Lets count the ways: the art is good but not as excellently moody as that found in the sequel (characters only have a single sprite here, in Shadows they all get multiple), the music is far blander, the writing suffers from having to fit a blank protagonist, and let me go into detail about the single biggest problem.

The Fail State: in an effort to evoke the pen&paper ruleset, you have to feed once every two in-game nights, failing to do this twice leads to a game over. Doesn't sound too bad right? The problem is that in a desperate effort to pad the runtime, the game doesn't allow multiple saves, meaning if you hit a failstate 10 hours in *POOF* bye bye, start again, with no skip read dialogue option. 

One of the worst game design choices I've ever seen.

column8: Being a huge fan of Vampire: The Masquerade, when I heard the upcoming installation was coming out I immediately wanted to preorder and was excited they put out a prequel to the story.  Since the series is heavily story based, I avoided watching any game play and was utterly surprised that this is a visual novel.  Though I enjoyed it very much, I missed the freedom of exploring from the previous title.  It is a short title, as I completed my first play through in just under 10 hours.  I absolutely loved the story and it's twists and turns.  Just when you think you know where things are headed, they toss you on your head and you have to learn to walk on your hands.  Since the game is so short, I do think the $20 price tag is a little steep but would definitely recommend playing it.  I do hope that the visual novel aspect of the game is simply to set up the story for the upcoming release and will get some sneak peeks of game play without revealing any story line before I purchase, however.

column8:
This game plays like a CYOA (Choose Your Own Adventure) story. The story is good and it mostly stays faithful to the table top game's source material. Fans of VtM would be familiar although those new to the setting may be a little lost. The game is about 4 or so hours for a single play through, although that can be extended by playing as all three classes. 

You also don't need a beefy PC to run this as there is little 3D, so people with potato systems should be able to run it.

column8: If you like short stories, feel free to play this, if it's under $7. Otherwise, it's simply not worth your time as a "game". Games imply some level of user-input and agency - none of your decisions really matter: the "game" essentially has a pre-set story to tell, and gives you the illusion of choice sporadically with occasional dialogues that don't end up changing much. However, as an introduction to the World of Darkness (specifically with regard to Vampires, of course), it's an excellent novella.

column8:
This game NAILS the characterization of the Kindred involved. They ALSO nail the feeling of being a very, very small piece on a very large and obfuscated chessboard. However, that doesn't always make for the best story, when you are not a central part beyond a certain act. I would love, LOVE to see the storytelling chops of the involved writers get some time to stretch out with more content. There was _ALWAYS_ the 'oh I wonder if they will do X' while I was playing through, and with that amount of expectation, it's... troubling to see where it ends up.

And this is all speaking as a _fan of the series_. I cannot imagine the reaction from someone completely uninitiated to the lore. I recommend, but it is absolutely a caveat-laden reco. Go into it understanding that to get the most out of this game, you will probably be playing it multiple times, which isn't exactly going to take you a whole ton of time. Expect maybe 10 hours max out of this experience, in full. That is NOT a mark against but... just don't expect that something with this much quality can extended the quantity bar past a certain mark, for better or for worse.

column8: The game only has 2 possible endings, a death in the first 15 minutes which the game does everything possible to keep you from going through with. The other ending is a complete disappointment and is insanely rushed. I thought maybe I had done something wrong, but nope, not a single choice matters (other than the extremely telegraphed death) No real reason to play this multiple times other than the achievements. There's not even a difference in which of the 3 pre-generated characters you pick at the beginning of the game.

column8: I was unsure to try this one because of the various negative opinions and the fact that there is only one ending so the choices do not really matter, but I was amazed with how good the story was and how i loved these characters! I wish it was longer, choises did really change the story and maybe there was some romantic plot too, but it's still a great game and I really recomend it.

column8:
Not a true VN.
1 ending where your choices don't matter. More like a book that you read and don't contribute to.
Filled with precious un-harmable snowflake NPCs that you're supposed to love and respect, those who have played the tabletop game realise what a hideous sin this is. 
The whole game is on an event timer, and is done in less than 4 hours, even though I had to leave the game running and attend to my family.
This game is an afterthought, a mere marketing event meant to drum up publicity for bloodlines 2.

column8:
[b]Interesting VN, dark themed and atmospheric.[/b]

* World of Darkness setting.
* Superb art and music.
* You choose between 3 main characters.
* Features only 1 ending (and 2 early game over ones).
* You can find a lot of lore in the codex entries.

[i]P.S.1: Skip was recently added, so yay! Easy to do all achievements now.[/i]
[i]P.S.2: Since you have multiple choices during the game, my only complain is the lack of multiple endings, based on your choices.[/i]

column8: One playthrough took me around 7 hours. Even if the ending is the same for the other 2 characters/storylines I would say this game was well worth it. Some of the negative reviews worried me (that the nights would be too short, that the game would end unexpectedly/quickly, that the writing wouldn't be enjoyable, etc), but I was happy to discover, for me at least, they were all proved wrong. I will be playing it again soon to see the pieces of the story I missed during the first go round. My only disappointment was [spoiler]in not reuniting with the character's sire - I was hoping things might get a bit steamy at the end. ;D	[/spoiler]

column8:
A short, rather formulaic and fairly linear visual novel that normally wouldn't hold my attention for longer than it takes to click next in my Discovery queue, if not for its extremely potent trump card. It is set in the World of Darkness. In V5 New York to be precise. The setting is well established and detailed with a huge backstory, so being given the opportunity to play a small role in this world again was all the incentive I needed to give this a shot.

You get to pick from three characters. A Brujah, a Ventrue and a Toreador. Those characters are set, they have a specific appearance and backstory that you can't alter. The game starts very similar to the original Bloodlines. You are turned into a Vampire without permission from the local Prince. So you are captured and brought in front of a Vampire court to be tried and executed. Luckily for you a local power with an unknown agenda decides to intervene, rescue you and throw you into a cloak and dagger game you are far from ready to play.

From then on the game becomes slightly more open. You have a Haven you can rest in during the day and every night you are provided with a pool of available events, up to two of which you can play. As mentioned the game is very short, it lasts only a couple of such nights, so you won't be able to do all events in one go. Forcing you to pick. That said those events, like the main plot, are extremely linear. In fact you can't really derail anything or die at this point. At least I wasn't able to despite trying. You can simply go through the motions.

Admittedly this absolute lack of impact was rather disappointing. I don't play many visual novels but I'm under the impression they usually allow greater agency than this. Or at least provide you with multiple endings. This one doesn't do either. That said it still succeeds at immersing you in the role of an out-of-their-depth fledgling trying to come to terms with their new reality. I'm unsure if this was the result of competent writing or simply the power of the setting. But I suppose it doesn't really matter.

This game won't blow anyone's mind but for fans of Vampire the Masquerade and the World of Darkness, it can be a fun distraction. We certainly need one with Bloodlines 2 getting constantly postponed. It's not really that expensive either, so yeah, recommended. If you are not a fan though and simply want a great visual novel to play, it's probably better to keep on looking.

column9: While the writing is good and its atmospheric as hell, there is only one ending that completely disregards any choice you made throughout

column8:
I wanted to like it. It's like a Tootsie Roll Pop except that it felt like it really was just 3 licks to get to the center and the chocolate was just meh. 

Game play wise it was good story telling for most parts but it's a story that doesn't actually want you to enjoy it unless you replay it a few. You have no time to actually enjoy each character arcs and you aren't aware of that until the railed plot leads you to the end. 

If this was an actual WoD campaign it would be a story that the storyteller kinda lost steam halfway and just wanted to end it.

This is the worst vn. I have ever played not because of the games story or graphic but because the engine/game design choices and they way saves are handled. 

Saves are buggy still 11 months after it came out.

Only one save slot and auto save. 
Its awful.

column8: This game, unfortunately, is just another click-through text-based story. Your choices of (meaningful [storywise]) interaction are quite limited. If I didn't get this game through Humble Monthly I would have been pissed quite a lot.
column9: This game, unfortunately, is just another click-through text-based story. Your choices of (meaningful [storywise]) interaction are quite limited. If I didn't get this game through Humble Monthly I would have been pissed quite a lot.

column8: This game isn't very good. The writing is awkward and cringe-inducing - I feel embarrassed for whoever wrote the dialogue. There is no voice acting. The music is lackluster and repetitive. The text choices sometimes show little indication of what you are actually going to say or do. The story is somewhat engaging but gets buried in the tedium of delivery. And your choices make little difference to the game. I have played several choice-based games by now, and I am fine with just three main endings, and some minor changes along the way based on choices - I don't need a game to offer more branching paths than that. I don't even mind if some of those endings are similar to each other. This has one ending. Two if you count dying early as an ending. The "vampires is modern New York" just didn't work for me, and nothing rang true. You have some emo-looking vampire who only talks in baseball metaphors? I don't think so.

column8:
I love Visual Novels and VtM. My conclusion is that this fails at both. The new lore is not super familiar to me, but it's really awful and lacks and punch. Where this really flops though is the VN core itself. I couldn't stomach to go much past the intro.

Cons:
-No save grid to save at choice junctions. Can only save when exiting.
-The log isn't bound to the wheel.
-Dynamic BGs make is hard to read. (Yeah, they can be turned off, but still.)
-No voicing.
-Music was lackluster.
-Writing felt pretty cheesy and unnatural.
-Options felt strange and occurred too frequently.
-Not sure why they went through the trouble to three separate characters, and in the fashion that they did. I didn't like any of them. 
- The sprites look awful, don't really do much, and tend to fade into the BG. They're very boring.
- Way too many product placements. 
- Too much exposition.
- Way too preachy.

column8: As Visual Novel Type Games go this one is not bad. I do like the vtm world of darkness setting. It is dialogue heavy but not a huge deal for me. The artwork is amazing. I actually got this one to go without crashing. I personally thought the end was meh at best, Got all the achievements and not a whole lot of time on it. You have some choices and it goes slightly on rails at times. I guess we will have to get our world of darkness fix because who know if or when blloodlines 2 is coming out at this point. Its a decent novel with choices even though some matter and some don't seem to matter,  If you are a fan of visual novels pick this up.

column8: It is wonderful to be able to return to the world of darkness once more.  There is no voice acting, but the founts are large, clear, and easy to read.  The story, (so far) is interesting, captivating, and compelling.  My only gripe?  i would love to see options for more than 3 clans, but still, i recommend this game to any VtM fan.

column8:
I will begin this review with a warning: I am unfamiliar with the universe created here. I have never played any Vampire game - this will be my first.

This game is a Visual Novel.

The game's opening dialogue is excessively exposition heavy, to the point where it removes any sense of the player being immersed in a story, as it's obvious what's being read is exposition. This obviousness comes from the exposition lacking any natural flow within the context of the story. It's just...there. Other Visual Novels do it far better, such as The House in Fata Morgana.

Before I discuss the main element of the game - the writing, I just want to point out that I don't approve of being unable to use spacebar to progress dialogue, to my knowledge, and instead I have to click a forward arrow everytime I want dialogue to progress. I do appreciate being able to click to speed up the dialogue (which is not voiced) however. I also appreciate that the game offers multiple save slots, and saves on exit. Additionally, there are options regarding whether one wishes the backgrounds to be static or dynamic, the resolution can be changed, there's vsync options, and the "quality" can be changed (but there are no advanced options for graphics settings - which is to be expected as it's a Visual Novel and such settings don't seem par for the course anyway). One issue with the UI I have is that it would be nice if the different terms in the "dictionary" were arranged in alphabetical order, it would save time and tedium. I have also noticed backgrounds are re-used, and character art is static, with no variations in appearance between scenes.

The story starts with three options of background to decide from, and I picked the artsy romantic one (the others being corporate executive style, and antifa-like hipster anarchists). So, I assume based on the background selected, after the heavy exposition segment, my character began his story at an art exhibit. The inner monologue this segment begins with was dripping with the edginess of a fifteen year old writer struggling to make something sound aloof and intellectual. The "inner thoughts" he expresses during his conversation with his sister ooze with an insufferable sense of pseudo-intellect and arrogance that borders on a purely desperate attempt to reflect some form of depth to the shallow, edgy attempts at seeming cultured. To give an example of some of the cringe-inducing nature here's one segment, "in your mind's eye, you see yourself as your final artwork, beautifully splattered all over the pavement". I don't think the author of this dialogue could try any harder to convey "ah, I am so melancholic and artistic".

One of the first choices of the game is to "lie" to someone who's asking if you know anyone, or would like to inform anyone, about a given situation. So, I choose the option and instead of merely saying "no" my character launches into such a pitiful attempt to make up a story about a boyfriend (apparently my artistic male character is gay - I find out, which is rather stereotypical). Well, that pitiful attempt, as one would guess, failed fantastically. But it also threw me out of the story - why would someone go into an attempt to give a lengthy explanation about a made-up boyfriend to a stranger asking "do you have anyone you'd like to contact" when a mere "no" would suffice? I don't know either, and it's rather absurd. Then, with no choice to do so or not do so, I tell the truth - so I guess the intimidating, scary stranger isn't that scary after all considering I reveal basically everything about a family member I claim to care about to him, even going so far as giving him my phone, and her number, so "someone" can contact her. Believable. 

A few sentences later my character inquires "why did that man target me? What was their motive?" - Not sure why "his" isn't put there instead of "their". I referred to the individual as a man, so therefore, I should use a masculine pronoun. The character did not indicate he was non-binary, transgender etc., I clearly know what the character's gender is. Thus, the result is that the sentence reads rather awkwardly and unnaturally to me. This continues as the story progresses, in one sentence an individual was referred to as "she" then "he" the following sentence. It's confusing writing, at best, and should have been ironed out in proofreading.

The narrative's inner logic also makes no sense. For example, apparently I belong to a society in which I will "always be watched" to the point where a stranger is there to clean up the body I left, and knows exactly where I was taken, and what I am, but doesn't know who took me there. So how did this "stranger" even know I was there to pick up, or why I was there, or what happened to me? And then the next sentence the same stranger indicates I might meet the unknown man tomorrow - if he doesn't know who the man is, not even a faint guess, why does he know that this unknown man MIGHT be at a given place tomorrow? This suggests that the man belongs to the same society/clan, in which case one would presume, based on the explanations given, the man would be identified - particularly because the "stranger" knew I had been taken to a very specific location, what occurred there and so on. Subsequent events did nothing to clarify the logic here.

Additionally related to narrative, there are several choices to make regarding what to say, and do, but most feel like a dichotomy, rather than a genuinely branching path. The story is not really clear, so far all I have surmised is that I am a new vampire and uh...I belong to some society...that's about it. The narrative is cut up into a mix of several "nights" with several different sub-plots with different characters as well, which lends to the feeling that the game is merely a mash of several different shards, rather than a coherent whole. I haven't faced any decisions that felt deeply meaningful to the overarching narrative yet, either, at least as far as I can see in my 3-4 hours playing so far.

While these complaints may seem "nitpicky" I feel it is essential that, in a game where the writing is the focal point, and where reading comprises ALL of the gameplay, the writing be serviceable enough to not throw me out of the story with typos, inconsistencies, and odd sentence structures that are odd for no reason (meaning, it doesn't serve as a character quirk etc.,).

As I find the writing to be..not to my tastes, and the narrative to be lacking in consistency, I do not recommend this game. I will strive to play it to its completion(though the story has not gripped me) and update this review if my opinion changes, or if I find information later on that changes my reasoning regarding the above issues I had with the game.

Update 10/2/2020 - I am not sure I will be able to force myself to finish the game. The writing is awfully stilted and unnatural. I still have no idea what the main plot is, and the subplots are extremely tedious and dull.

So how did this "stranger" even know I was there to pick up, or why I was there, or what happened to me? And then the next sentence the same stranger indicates I might meet the unknown man tomorrow - if he doesn't know who the man is, not even a faint guess, why does he know that this unknown man MIGHT be at a given place tomorrow? This suggests that the man belongs to the same society/clan, in which case one would presume, based on the explanations given, the man would be identified - particularly because the "stranger" knew I had been taken to a very specific location, what occurred there and so on. Subsequent events did nothing to clarify the logic here.

Additionally related to narrative, there are several choices to make regarding what to say, and do, but most feel like a dichotomy, rather than a genuinely branching path. The story is not really clear, so far all I have surmised is that I am a new vampire and uh...I belong to some society...that's about it. The narrative is cut up into a mix of several "nights" with several different sub-plots with different characters as well, which lends to the feeling that the game is merely a mash of several different shards, rather than a coherent whole. I haven't faced any decisions that felt deeply meaningful to the overarching narrative yet, either, at least as far as I can see in my 3-4 hours playing so far.

While these complaints may seem "nitpicky" I feel it is essential that, in a game where the writing is the focal point, and where reading comprises ALL of the gameplay, the writing be serviceable enough to not throw me out of the story with typos, inconsistencies, and odd sentence structures that are odd for no reason (meaning, it doesn't serve as a character quirk etc.,).

As I find the writing to be..not to my tastes, and the narrative to be lacking in consistency, I do not recommend this game. I will strive to play it to its completion(though the story has not gripped me) and update this review if my opinion changes, or if I find information later on that changes my reasoning regarding the above issues I had with the game.

Update 10/2/2020 - I am not sure I will be able to force myself to finish the game. The writing is awfully stilted and unnatural. I still have no idea what the main plot is, and the subplots are extremely tedious and dull.

Okay, so this game comes with a big caveat, and that is that despite all your choices, there is only one ending. Now, if you can live with that, then go ahead and play it! While I found the ending to be a not very well done cliffhanger after 2 very different playthroughs, the rest of the game is very enjoyable. From the start, to just before the ending, it is a solid story, with good, enjoyable side missions and characters. In fact, I'd say the side missions outweight the main story honestly. But, when only 10 hours is two playthroughs completely with only one ending ever as an option? Only get it on sale. Even with it being a gift, I wouldn't have paid full price for this game.
So, great side stories, good characters overall, and the choices DO affect the side missions. So, its worth getting, but not worth full price, is how I would label this.

column8:
Meh. I like the world of Vampire: The Masquerade, it seems like it could be neat. This was my first real introduction to the world and lore, so I appreciated the dictionary and the characters explaining stuff to a Fledgling character. 

Overall as a visual novel, it's rated a big ol' "meh" from me. 3 hours in and I almost finished several stories and didn't get attached to any of the characters or story. I got it from humblebundle and I'm glad because I definitely wouldn't have paid full price for this. Get it on sale if you want to play it.

column8:
This game would be worth it at somewhere around the $4 mark.

It's atmospheric and mostly well written.  I'm only mildly familiar with the franchise, but based on this, it'd be interesting to know more.

However, it's very short.  And while a shorter length might have been used to allow for a great deal of variation based on your decisions, that isn't the route they took here.  Your decisions end up making less and less of an impact on the plot as the game progresses, with the game ending the same way regardless of your choices.

Overall, I'm left with the impression that the developers had great ambitions, and ran out of time.  May not have been what happened, but it feels like it.

column8:
Short version: The game is simply bad and low-budget.

The atmosphere is great because of the setting, the characters are interesting but don't get the time they deserve, the story-writing is simply awful. Unbelievably bad. The dialogues are also average at best, the mechanics are badly implemented. 

You always feel like nothing you do matters, because it doesn't. This game also needed a proof-reading, as there are enough mistakes that it is bothersome. A big disappointment.

Well, I was about to quit on this game, but then I met Hope. Yep, Hope, as in Hope as a name, she is one of the NPCs/companions in this game. But let me start from the beginning.
This is an interactive visual novel and the game is text heavy, with all your interactions being limited to selecting a response (most of the time you have 3 options), however your choices do not really matter.
The main story is not bad, but neither it is good. It feels bland and fails to engage you (on the positive it has a dictionary that guides you through the terminology in the world of Masquerade). The most joy I had in this game was when I first met one of the companion character (there are few of them and they have their quest lines) named Hope who stimulated my desire to continue with the game.
If you‚Äôd ask me to summarise the game, I‚Äôd say that it has a lot of unnecessary and pointless text, average main quest and awesome companion characters that save this game. I would though only recommend this game to those who love visual novels, others would barely enjoy it and companion characters won‚Äôt be enough to keep you engaged, so in overall I can't recommend this game.
One Grumpy Russian score ‚Äì 5/10 Masquerade is so good it hides almost any reason to play this game, go on, pass by, nothing to see here, just another visual novel‚Ä¶
Follow the curator at [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7279488-One-Grumpy-Russian/]OGR[/url]

column8: I expected a lot more story from a visual novel. I am even okay with games like this only giving the illusion of choice and agency without your decisions affecting real changes. I was very drawn in and unfortunately, the last 30 minutes completely ruined the game with the whole "climax" and ending which was so abrupt I thought my game had glitched and Googled how to fix it. It's like the writers just gave up one day and said, "What the hell, let's just release it." Glad I got it cheap.

column8: I'm surprised at how much enthralled I got in the story. It's really an...experience. The ending came a bit suddenly after all that buildup, but it's okay. I would recommend this to anyone interested in the World of Darkness.

column8: Perfectly captures a lot of what makes this universe so interesting. By separating the gameplay completely out of the picture, you are really just going to be here to experience it. Each of the characters you encounter are a fun way to learn more without feeling like you‚Äôre encountering a walking encyclopedia. That goes to the developer making a very cool decision to have a dictionary separate where you can look up all the different terms people are using. I‚Äôm not sure the core narrative really pans out in a way that it alone would be worth diving in for, but the side stories and moment to moment intrigue make it worth it for me. I hope the standalone sequel they released is going to expand more on personal stories even further.

column8:
It is an extremely 6.5/10 game. Buy it on sale or something because it is not worth full price for sure as it is very lacking in content, especially comparing to JP VNs. This review is a positive IF assuming you buy it on sale AND you are good at role-playing/love the atmosphere of VTM games.

SPOILERS BELOW!!!

This game essentially has 1 route and 1 ending. There are 2 more "endings" but both can be achieved at 1 dialogue option. All other "variability" and "choices" in the game are fake/not mattering. You don't need the help of any of 4 guys, you can't tell anyone to fuck off - you will be forced to do what the script requires you to do. You can't even die outside of these 2 moments at the start of the game. Be rude AF, feed off everyone, use all the powers, try to break masquerade - it doesn't matter. 3 Characters differ only during 2 quests and maybe occasionally during 1-2 lines of dialogue. That's MMO levels of writing. They even didn't bother writing gender specific dialogue in some places. "They" saved them a couple of cents probably.

During the first playthrough you don't know this so you feel that all of the stuff you do - matters. And the game genuinely feels like a VTM game. All this feels like the guys had good ideas at the start, but then ran out of money. All the features and mechanics are there. You have the Hunger, Beast, Masquerade, Clans and powers (why does my Toreador have Potence, again???). This game could be 10/10 if it had 3 distinct stories and at least 3-4 more endings. And the ability to fail/die anywhere during the game. I wanted this game to be good. I really did.

column8:
It's a visual novel.  People complaining about a lack of choices/character impact don't know what the fuck they bought.  I started the game earlier today, intending just to start a game and then quit out immediately because I had work to do and ended up playing it for over an hour.  Great atmosphere and art direction so far.

EDIT:  I have completed a first play through.  I did enjoy the intrigue/art/sound/music design a lot, the atmosphere is amazing.  

My only negative is that being able to choose the missions and whatnot you go on mean... Part of the ending was disjointed and didn't make much sense because there were 2 people I didn't interact with almost at all and they suddenly become center stage for the last like 2-5 minutes of the game.  From a narrative perspective, this is disappointing and completely destroyed the flow of the story.

I'm now left wondering if I should play it again as one of the other characters.

column8:
Already that I am a big fan of the WoD series. There was a time when I did long hours and far too many role play sessions as a Vampire of all kinds, I must admit that the game carried me into an old and pleasant nostalgia.

Everything about the game is of quality, they managed to transport us to the world of vampire Masquarade, in a most interesting way which is reinforced by the style of the drawing, the texts and by the music which such as the song of the siren, we bewitched in a completely imaginary world and yet ...

For all fans of this kind of universe, I recommend playing and discovering the many facets of this game, whether with one person or by trying them all. I give this game 10/10 and look forward to the others.

column8: I just finished my 3rd playthrough mere minutes before writing this review. "Playthrough" really doesn't feel like the right word to use here as this is obviously first and foremost a novel. written to be enjoyed from a first person perspective. There are some choices to be made, sure. But apart from the ones that lead to catastrophic failure, its more like coke or lemonade, rather then left or right. I dont blame the developers for that approach, i would even go so far as to say that, the idea of implementing the choice of 3 different characters to approach the narrative was probably a mistake on their part. I think it could have been a lot more of an intimate experience if they had focused on a single protagonist. they seem to agree with this idea, considering their approach towards the (is sequal the right word?) "shadows of new york". I for one don't mind to find myself in the shoes of a female protagonist and i wouldn't expect much confusion about this from an audience to a game such a this and towards the topic of "choice".. well.. the thing is as a neonate. NO a fledgeling in kindred society. How much choice are you expecting to have ? im sorry this seems to derail into a critique about critiques.. ANYWAY.. I found this NOVEL to be written rather well and enjoyed the overlayed backgrounds and music to help draw me into the scenes described more closely. This is mostly an emotional experience, delivered vicariously through first person narration and if you feel at all intrigued by the setting and not easily offended by the idea of not "really" having a choice of direction throughout the story, i don't see any reason not to recommend it.
column9: I just finished my 3rd playthrough mere minutes before writing this review. "Playthrough" really doesn't feel like the right word to use here as this is obviously first and foremost a novel. written to be enjoyed from a first person perspective. There are some choices to be made, sure. But apart from the ones that lead to catastrophic failure, its more like coke or lemonade, rather then left or right. I dont blame the developers for that approach, i would even go so far as to say that, the idea of implementing the choice of 3 different characters to approach the narrative was probably a mistake on their part. I think it could have been a lot more of an intimate experience if they had focused on a single protagonist. they seem to agree with this idea, considering their approach towards the (is sequal the right word?) "shadows of new york". I for one don't mind to find myself in the shoes of a female protagonist and i wouldn't expect much confusion about this from an audience to a game such a this and towards the topic of "choice".. well.. the thing is as a neonate. NO a fledgeling in kindred society. How much choice are you expecting to have ? im sorry this seems to derail into a critique about critiques.. ANYWAY.. I found this NOVEL to be written rather well and enjoyed the overlayed backgrounds and music to help draw me into the scenes described more closely. This is mostly an emotional experience, delivered vicariously through first person narration and if you feel at all intrigued by the setting and not easily offended by the idea of not "really" having a choice of direction throughout the story, i don't see any reason not to recommend it.

column8: The combination of autosaving, dialogue choices that tend towards 'rude' at best so much of the time, and that the options presented to you often differ so substantially from the result they lead to is a particularly unpleasant one. Every dialogue choice comes across as a struggle against the game itself in my never-ending battle to not say the wrong thing to the wrong person by accident. In my first hour playing I found myself re-playing to avoid dialogue choices I chose only to find out they meant the literal opposite of what I expected so many times that I have no idea how much worse this must have been before the introduction of "Skip".

column8:
rather disappointed with this, given the hype, I was expecting a sequel to Bloodlines... an immersive RPG..
instead I get a virual novel where 60% or more of the options don't make a difference.  Not a whole lot of choices in direction, not a whole lot of choices in clan...   Even when you choose different clans, nearly all the options are the same, even half the disciplines.

was able to unlock every achievement in less than a week.    If you're looking a visual novel, it's ok, but I really was expecting more than that.

column8: This is an enjoyable visual novel. I played a good bit of pen and paper VTM in the late 90s and early 2000s, and haven't really been in the universe since VTM:Bloodlines and this got some nostalgia going. Took me 4 playthroughs to get all the achievements and it was nice to see the differences between the three characters. The new skip feature came in handy on the subsequent playthroughs.

column8: If you enjoy visual novels and/or the other vampire games like redemption and bloodlines then you should enjoy this.  It seemed like many of the choices have no impact on the story but existed just to keep your interest like curtains on a window,you can change them but it usually doesn't have much impact on the room.  I have enjoyed it enough to give it my recommendation.  Many might be disappointed in the length or limited content but a 20 dollar game shouldn't be compared to a 60 dollar game.  In fairness, my rating could be bias as it was gifted to me.

column8:
This is more of mixed feelings review. The tipping point was the length of the game.
Anyhow, the game is good, the writing is entertaining and the characters are believable. The authors put a lot of effort in rendering the V:TM New York City and it shows. The design is also very enticing. 

But the finale is garbage. Not because of the ending itself, that's ok, very in line with the theme. It is because it feels rushed, it comes at a point where the game is still reaching it's climax and then takes away all the power you, as a player, should have. Those are all no-nos.

column8:
The story is nice enough, and I do want to replay it (after a break) with the other possible characters, but I was not excited by the ending. I did enjoy most of the game though (story, graphics, audio). You don't need to know the world to enjoy the story.

However the game feels cheap in that there are some UI (user interface) bugs I encountered, that should have been noticed with half a decent QA in the dev company, and should be no brainers to fix. To me, those felt like they did not want to spend even so much as half a day on fixing those. Also found typos, missing words, duplicate words, wrong words (instead of the one expected, making you read the sentence thrice so you figure out what it should actually read).

The graphics, as I said, are nice. I activated the background animations, and liked them. But as I am the kind of person who takes screenshots a lot, I was very disappointed to not have a keyboard key to hide the UI, or even a screenshot function within the game. 

Eventually, all you get in addition to dialog options to play the game, is a dictionary (which is a welcome feature), and a history of the dialog you just had in the "area" you are currently visiting. It is NOT possible to go backwards in the story to admire the backgrounds again, or pick another dialog options... a shame. I loved this in other visual novels. That and a screenshot tool or UI-hide tool.

All in all, those kind of games are really EASY to a developer (code guy). The hardest part is the story and branches, the animated graphics probably. The ending is probably average, but the story does have some nice moments. What I did not like was the "cheap" side of the game: very poor QA. 

I liked it, and liked the universe and settings. But this game is way too over-expensive given how little care it was given. Feels like we've been thrown cheap stuff to pump our money. Some other visual novels are less expensive and have longer story, fewer typos, no UI issues... I am not recommending it because of the evident lack of care. This should not have been released like this. Just my feeling. Now if they fixed the UI issues and text issues, I'd recommend it.

column8:
It's very beautiful and well written. There's no real gameplay - it's more or less a visual novella, lots and lots of dialogue and choices and art. If you like to read and World of Darkness - you'll like this. You have a choice of three clans.

Sometimes I'm annoyed by the discrepancies - like when a character in a scene is described as "no make up, hair down" - but their art is the same one as for every other scene, or when the same character from different angles looks completely different, but I noticed this in a lot of games (at least the latter). A few typos in the text, as well, but nothing breaking the immersion or making it uninteligeble.

column8:
Like a Sire in the world of darkness, ‚ÄúVampire: The Masquerade Coteries of New York‚Äù lulls you into a false sense that your choices matter, when in the end all you can do is follow someone else‚Äôs Design. 

That is not to say it is not a good read throughout. 

The characters all have a distinct voice and the intrigue is there. The game is relatively short, with 6 hours per playthrough for even the slowest reader.

To do everything, however, or even meet all the characters, you need to replay it once. To get all the achievements you will need to replay it three times, but even with the skip button there is not enough of a difference between the characters to make it worth your time. It would have been nice to have more dialog variations, beginnings or quest branches here. 

Still, the game plays like a night with a good DM, looks lovely, the characters are engaging, the story is interesting, and it serves as a nice gateway drug into the world of darkness. It does fall a little shorth of the sweet spot between not overstaying its welcome, but at the price point it can be forgiven.

column8:
Good story, soundtrack, artwork and ambiance. If you're a fan of Vampire the Masquerade and reading, you will likely enjoy this.

Do not expect this to be a fleshed out RPG game like Bloodlines with multiple choices and a lot of options. It's simply just an interactive "book" with a few options on to what to say or do, many of which don't significantly change the story or development of your character.
