column8: vampires yay

Coteries of New York(short CNY) is a game that I give a thumbs up but with this caveat: it will only please a specific group of players. 

There are two aspects to consider. 

The first is that this is more a story than a game. There are some limited choices that allow you to play a certain way and even allow you to decide which side quest to explore, but this is in now way a game like VTMB:Bloodlines where you get to manage a character, build skills and explore the world and had four possible endings.
The second aspect is that this is based in the Vampire The Masquerade world(or it‚Äôs expanded World of Darkness setting) that focuses on vampires. If you don‚Äôt like vampires, this is probably not the game for you.

For me I enjoyed the art(even though it was something reused a bit too much), the mood of the game(the music, reminiscent of bloodlines makes for the right mood) and the overall feel.
The writers of this story kept well towards the world of VTMB, with its clans, backstory, scheming and conflicts.
This being said, the game has its flaws. The most obvious is that you will find that at times you get forced down a route without any option. This is needed for the story because the writers need to guide you back to the story line. 
 For instance, at the beginning, when you are introduced into the world as a new vampire, you seemingly get to choose between a rebellious route and a conformist one. However, at some point you can only answer in an offending way towards the vampire that picks you up, albeit in three different ways. This is so at some point later in time the Prince, the leader of the Camarilla faction, gets to declare you of a rebellious nature.
Another flow is that I find the writing sometimes under par. The story has a lot of cliche writing(it probably comes with the territory) and only a few of the characters come to live. 
I also would have welcome that there had been some more time spend on world building.
A particular flaw is the end of the game. Not so much that there is a twist, but this twist comes completely out of the blue. Normally there would be some foreshadowing or build up towards it.
Despite this, I enjoyed the game and would recommend it if you can live with its flaws.

column8: Fake choices, railroaded story, terrible ending. Any hope and excitement I experienced from the story was completely flushed away when I realized that nothing you do in the game matter. Just go and buy some game from Choice of Games or Hosted Games (many of them much better, longer and cheaper), where you can actually leave an impact (even if minor) on the world. Or just read a book, they usually have better stories than this hybrid of non-game. Shameful really, the art and the music - the only two positives in this nonsense. Such a waste of time and potential...

column8:
[h1]You can't just draw twenty good-looking portraits, throw on player shit ton of text and pretend that's visual novel.  [/h1]
I got this game from  September Humble Choice, and was so glad, cause I generally like visual novels, vampires, and style of art in this game. However, I'm quite disappointed now.
Last two hours I was just skipping text, blindly pressing buttons, still managing get to the end. I was trying to - don't judge me - get 100% achievements, since I can't get a refund. 
There is onle ONE choice, that really matters, can you believe it? 
So I would recommend you make your choice, and don't buy it.

column8:
This game/novel just gets a thumbs up from me. This is my first visual novel and I enjoyed playing this in slow time, focusing on the story and visuals.

The Pros
-I enjoyed the music and the sound effects when used
-Art style was pleasant 
-The various characters and stories were interesting
-Story goes to places I didn't expect it to

The Cons
-It feels overpriced as it took me about 7-8 hours to finish and I was playing quite slowly
-The decisions you make can quickly lead to results that you didn't want to happen due to less than clear wording
-I don't think that many choices will change that much if anything 
-I'm guessing there is only one ending, it would have been nice to have a few endings for different 'play' styles

Overall, if you are interested in Vampire the Masquerade and don't have a problem with this being a visual novel and not a game you should buy it when it's on a sale, if not, skip.

I got this as part of a Humble Bundle (so not for "free," sadly), and I am vastly glad that I didn't pay anything approaching its full price! I played the original, which was an extremely detailed, third-person, live-action RPG "shooter." I had NO idea when I installed it that this present "game" was nothing but reading PILES of text and selecting some text option from a SHORT list of possibilities. The "RPG" elements are so hidden and lame that they bear ZERO resemblance to the robust skills tree in the first iteration of the game! I seriously don't see how this mess gets so many great reviews, when it doesn't even do the "visual novel" aspects well. (No "Back" or "Skip" buttons, among other problems.) The writing is minimally good, but not great. And if I want to read a vampire novel, there are countless out there! It doesn't feel engaging to me, and many of the "choices" feel artificial. Many of the "choices" are also similar enough that you cannot have any advance sense of what turn out to be the subtle but important differences between them, yet it turns out that much hinges on you choosing one instead of the other; then the fact that the subtleties of verbiage are not distinguished enough has you making bad choices without any capacity to understand what you are doing. The whole mess feels stilted, distant, and perpetually breaking through the fourth wall, perpetually reminding you that you are READING something rather than EXPERIENCING something. This is NOT the way to "experience" being a vampire. The first game immersed you in that experience, while this "novel" is just a lame read. I wouldn't pay a DIME for this if not part of a bundle. Uninstalling!

column8: A fairly linear visual novel with a few small branches in between. I liked the setting and the story. It's been a while since I've played a VTM game. My playtime is one playthrough with one character. It offers limited replayability.
column9: A fairly linear visual novel with a few small branches in between. I liked the setting and the story. It's been a while since I've played a VTM game. My playtime is one playthrough with one character. It offers limited replayability.

column8:
The story started good, but it was short. When I got to near the ending, it felt like the halfway point of the story. A lot of new plot points were brought up quickly, and just as quickly resolved. Meanwhile, lots of dangling plot points from earlier were left unresolved. The ending was linear, and unsatisfying- I don't mind the true ending being a bad ending, but it essentially turned all the tension and mystery laid out earlier in the story as "it was all a ruse," and not in a good way.

The hitboxes for selecting dialogue choices are slightly off, though that could have been my screen resolution. However, unlike other visual novels, it doesn't allow you to make multiple saves or go back. So, this is very annoying when I select a choice that I didn't want to select. It also hurts replayability. Sure, I could go back and play through again to pick up some of the choices I missed, but from looking around the choices you make don't really change much in the beginning, and the ending is always going to be the same.

The writing for the characters was good, which is why I'm disappointed in how the plot turned out.

Based on my first hour of play time for coverage of the Humble Choice: 
 
Vampire the Masquerade is a long-running tabletop RPG and video game franchise. There have been multiple RPG entries in the series and it‚Äôs quite popular. This‚Ä¶ well isn‚Äôt one of them.  Instead this time it‚Äôs a Visual Novel. 
 
I like the concept of Visual Novels. If it tells a good story, it‚Äôs fine, even if it is mostly like a storybook or a choose your own adventure.  As for that Vampire: The Masquerade, the writing though‚Ä¶ I mean there‚Äôs references to Musk, All the Things She Said by TATU, and other stuff that feel out of place. In general, I am not a fan of writing. Maybe this is typical of the Vampire: The Masquerade franchise. 
 
If you want some relatively easy achievements you can hold the x buttons and hammer A and beat the story in around 10 minutes for a playthrough. Otherwise, you‚Äôll sit through a lot of stories about vampires, masquerading, and keeping the secret from normies. I‚Äôm sure this is what fans of the franchise like but as I sat through it, I kind of heard myself sighing because the writing didn‚Äôt pull me in. 
 
Grab this if you love Vampire the Masquerade, or you love Visual Novels and want one about vampires. Otherwise, this is probably a skip for everyone else. 
 
If you want to see more from me or my coverage of the Humble Choice:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W1lnX3dI8Vo&t=635s

column8:
As a fan of the original Vampire: The Masquerade tabletop RPG, I appreciate the throwback to the old vampire clans, politics, and intrigue. This is a text-based choose-your-own-adventure game with supplementary in-game art and soundtrack. Don't go in expecting more, and personally I would only buy this kind of game with a discount from its current $19.99 price on Steam. The storyline has enough variation to be worth a couple playthroughs. I would've liked more possible endings for the main plot.

If you want a text-based throwback to V:tM with vampire political intrigue, then this game is for you. If you want to see fighting and watch your character sucking blood, then you should probably get another game.

column8:
Got it through HB thinking it was the RPG and not a VN but Im not disappointed. Never played a Vampire game but the characters were amazing, the sound was on point and I just finished my first playthrough and oh god is the story and worldbuilding f cool. Wishlisted the upcoming VN and the games.

My only gripe is why isnt there a save function? I understand that It makes the decisions ''heavier'' since you can't just reload and choose another one but I think a save function is indispensable in all softwares doesn't matter if its a text editor, a game or a visual novel (Even more when there are different endings).

column8: Nice storyline until the end when you get bamboozled. I liked it until the last 10mins, so I don't feel cheeted for my play time.

column8:
The concept is really good. The world they chose is fantastic as source material.
And yet they butchered it...it started really well and interesting, you being thrown into the vampire world and into the masquarade and trying to learn the ropes.
But quickly it devolves to a bunch of random short nights where you somehow make lifelong friends with stranges after 2 conversations? 
And all of a sudden out of nowhere before you even know whats happening the ending comes and in 10 minutes end credits where you had no fucking choice to do anything and make a meaningful decision.
In a big game i would say they ran out of money...but here on a visual novel? No excuses.

I got this from Humble Bundle September so im not too upset but to anyone curious...save your money, you WILL be dissapointed.

column8: I'm a big torn about this game. I love Graphic Novels and I love the world of Darkness. The story is nicely told but it feels like your actions have no impact at all. The real Masquerade feeling isn't coming over me either. It just feels incomplete and rushed.
The whole thing was pretty fun, had like an 80s/90s vibe going, which was pretty cool. Definitely liked the Brujah story best, but they each have something different to offer.

column8:
While I liked it more than I hated it, I can't recommend it.

The presentation is on point. The dark, mysterious atmosphere is there. If you've played a World of Darkness game, this title gets the ambiance and feeling right. The characters are interesting, operating within the set boundaries they're given: race, sect, clan, etc. However, they're given personal nuance that makes them more than just cardboard cutouts or stereotypes. The problem is that you don't spend enough time with them to really get to know them.

The story operates as a rapid pace, a little too rapid in my opinion, like I stated above, there's not enough time fully flesh out characters. For example, you're told to form a crew, but you don't really get to do crew-esque things. I wanted to go out on a group mission, see how my assembled team interacted with each other, but it never happens. 

Additionally, regarding the story. You'll make a lot of choices in this game, but ultimately it doesn't really matter. There are only two endings to this game: A pre-mature game over because you screwed up too many times or you do enough right to end up on the road to the game's finale. Speaking of which, the finale wraps up according to the story's themes, the conclusion is logical. But for me it was wholly unsatisfying. And when  I knew that every playthrough would lead me to that one unsatisfying end, it left me annoyed. It doesn't matter which character you play either, all three leads to the same conclusion. 

Long story short: The story moves too fast, the characters don't get time to fully develop, the final act moves even faster, your choices don't affect anything in the grand scheme of things, and I personally hated the ending.

I did like the presentation, ambiance, and characters. I'll get the next product on sale, but I'm not recommending it.

column8:
Ok, so let's start with the good things: the story is quite ok, even if the premise is copied 1-1 from VtM: Bloodlines; World of Darkness is presented really well, the characters are mostly really interesting and a couple of choices (not all of them unfortunately) are compelling (and the game makes you choose the lesser evil ‚Äì which is IMHO the bread and butter of WoD).

So why the negative rating? It is a visual novel where player choices matter and even small, seemingly irrelevant decisions can change how a given quest progresses. Sounds great, right? So now imagine, that being said, once you start your progress (there‚Äôs a pretty obvious choice very early on where you can basically allow your character to die) you‚Äôre getting the exact ending. No matter who you befriend/antagonize, no matter how you approach your humanity, no matter which stories you choose to follow (the game is pretty non-linear up to that point, which would be a huge thing if it weren‚Äôt spoiled by the ending) ‚Äì you see the same exact ending (which also puts your character in a situation without choice ‚Äì irony is so sweet). They even rub it in ‚Äì you get to choose three very different options at the last minute. I would say extremely different. The catch? Whatever you choose, the remaining dialogue is exactly the same, letter for letter.

It‚Äôs a cool story, don‚Äôt get me wrong ‚Äì and it gets quite a few of the concepts right. But it‚Äôs spoiled completely by how it finishes. I never thought I‚Äôd say that, but pre-patch ME3 had a more interactive ending. That‚Äôs how bad it is.

column8:
≈õwietna atmosfera ale przegadane dialogi.
6/10 mo≈ºƒô byƒá

I thought I would never appreciate again reading fictions a very long time ago!

This game has a great and complex athmosphere, you really feel like your answers are impactful, kinda like a real life RPG with a GM and great actors, without the chore of rolling dices and relying on luck. Only your common sense and whole attention are meaningful allies in your story.

You may even discover things about yourself, and not what you would expect giving the context, and that is the sign of a great writing.

I was immediately captivated by the hypnotic charisma of every artwork, in which you never see any trace of haste or lack of time, budget.

The same care is obvious in the mesmerizing sound design, the background animations and once again, the scenario.

It never feels like it's flashy, every detail is always there only to make a great game, a great read, and a memorable experience.

I think I should also add that I am absolutely not into Visual Novels, actually I can't focus on fictional reads usually, but this one definitely deserves a chance, regardless of your appetance for the genre and especially if you like the kinda dark, complex, coherent and deep Vampire : The Masquerade lore.

column8:
I got this game for free and spent a whole 40 mins on it before writing this so keep that in mind, but ...

In that short time, it already looks like the game simply dose everyone "wrong".  At $22, it's reasonable to expect either some voice work or strong writing and mood building to make up for it.  So far I'm finding this game not just falling short of great writing, but just plan bad.  The mood is wrong,  The music is wrong.  There isn't much in the way of sound work.

Even the basics of what makes a narrative game even possible seem to be missing.  The way you click though text, the lack of options for basic things like scrolling backwards without opening up the log of having all the text appear at once are not anywhere near what you would get from using a free visual novel maker.  

Most unforgivable, my choices don't seem to impact future dialog.  I've already seem cases where people are reacting to me as if I made choices I didn't.   After following someone like a puppy, complying unquestionable and not asking questions, I had multiple people tell me they were judging me based on my disruptive, rebellious behavior and refusal to follow direction.  

It completely pulled me out of the experience so much that I had to write this as a warning.  Even if you love the source material like I do, stay clear of this one.

column8:
Unfortunately I couldn't recommend it. Fans of vampire content in general and even VtM specifically both have much better options out there. There is so little interaction and visuals that those interested are better off going to read an actual book - even the roleplaying manual has more interesting stories and content.

+Artwork
+Music
+Writing style gives a decent feel of a new vampire
+Dynamic backgrounds, when present, are nice

-No key rebinding
-Lacks standard VN QoL features
-Only 3 clan choices, all race/gender-locked
-No voiced dialogue
-Too reliant on profanity over substance
-Very little animation, characters and most elements are still
-Most choices are illusion/same effect
-Some 'instant game over' choices

Well, what to say? I was first introduced to "The Masquerade" back in the 90's with the TV series (Cancelled after the first season due to the "Final Death" of the Prince), and loved it.
I've played a few of the games since and found them ranging from pretty poor to adequate.
Coteries of New York falls on the upper tier, presenting a detailed storyline worthy of the series - an interesting adventure, but very linear.
Pros:
The story is worthy of the series. It sucks you right in the the world - loved it.
The complexity of characters is fantastic. It's not just the story arc, but the characters don't always react to your actions/speech as you might expect.
Cons:
Very linear - Same saviour, Same types of options.
Poor Replayability - Same story for all 3 factions.
Short. I finished my first play through in about 2 hours.
Limited options to feed the beast and/or use powers. I found myself conserving my powers constantly in order to stay the beast, but failed at least once which violated "The Masquerade".
The game is more a visual novel (pick-a-path), which while well written, was something I used to read as a 10 year old. I would have preferred something a lot more in depth - which is not to say this is for kids, as there is some very explicit language in the game.
If you get this in the October Humble Bundle, or as a gift or free, it's probably worth it.
Paying full price (About AUD$28.95), you'd be getting ripped off.
Do I recommend it? Yes - conditionally based on the above.
column9:
Well, what to say? I was first introduced to "The Masquerade" back in the 90's with the TV series (Cancelled after the first season due to the "Final Death" of the Prince), and loved it.
I've played a few of the games since and found them ranging from pretty poor to adequate.
Coteries of New York falls on the upper tier, presenting a detailed storyline worthy of the series - an interesting adventure, but very linear.
Pros:
The story is worthy of the series. It sucks you right in the the world - loved it.
The complexity of characters is fantastic. It's not just the story arc, but the characters don't always react to your actions/speech as you might expect.
Cons:
Very linear - Same saviour, Same types of options.
Poor Replayability - Same story for all 3 factions.
Short. I finished my first play through in about 2 hours.
Limited options to feed the beast and/or use powers. I found myself conserving my powers constantly in order to stay the beast, but failed at least once which violated "The Masquerade".
The game is more a visual novel (pick-a-path), which while well written, was something I used to read as a 10 year old. I would have preferred something a lot more in depth - which is not to say this is for kids, as there is some very explicit language in the game.
If you get this in the October Humble Bundle, or as a gift or free, it's probably worth it.
Paying full price (About AUD$28.95), you'd be getting ripped off.
Do I recommend it? Yes - conditionally based on the above.

column8:
Blessings childer of Malkav!

This is a short text-adventure in the Vampire the Masquerade universe.
It's crisp, as far as I know bug-free, and reasonably well written.
The plot is unfortunately very linear and your options aren't necessarily numerous. I have to say that some of the characters you encounter are quite fascinating and they did a great job locating the story in the second decade of the 21st century.

The price for a low replayability game (three Playthroughs in under eight hours with all achievements) is very steep with 20 bucks.

Were this game's story located in any other universe than VtM I'd tell you to stay clear and I'd give it barely a 4/10.
Considering it's VtM and I'm a sucker for that kind of stuff I generously grant 6/10 and strongly advise you to only buy on sale.

column8:
Unfortunately Steam doesn't have a way to vote "thumb to the side"....

The game offers basically a good storyline. However the individual scenes often use WoD terms that your character can't know or hasn't encountered yet in the story, making the flow of individual scenes inconsistent. The worst design flaw is that you only have a very finite limit of "game moves" (for a lack of a better term) without getting any clue the game works that way. If you start all sidequests, you will not be able to finish a single one and that puts you at a severe disadvantage.
The way the game is technically constructed I can also say that it is absolutely not worth the prize of 20‚Ç¨ at full prize. Doesn't even have a isometric environment. While the art is well done it never represents the actual scene. Why not produce the game in a way that the individual pictures show the characters appearing on the spot. Most scenes are recurring empty rooms with always the same 2D characters layered on top of them.
To my knowledge there hasn't been many good vampire games in past years (or shall I say decades?) If you're a hardcore WoD fan, totally starving for any vampire game then you can probably get a bit of fun out of this. But I'd still advise you not to spend more than 5 bucks on it.....simply not worth it.

Despite great atmosphere and an art style that's on-point, the game fails to charm me due to a combination of 2 factors.  

1. You rarely if ever feel as if you have any agency. This is usually an illusion in this sort of games, but it's far too obvious in this game

2. Lacking and lackluster

The game felt too brief. The ending felt entirely detached from the rest of the story.

 [spoiler] A character the player has had met about twice with literally one interaction who left very little of an impression is the impetus for a twist ending and a cliff hanger as that character offers the player a blood bond..... Instead of leaving the player in suspense, it comes so much out of nowhere that it fails to keep any suspense. [spoiler]

So, my recommendation comes with a caveat, and that's that I found the ending to be extremely disappointing in regards to both player agency and narrative quality. 

Up to that point, I had a great time playing through this a little each night via Steam Link on my iPad. It was PERFECT for that nighttime wind-down, and I really liked that experience. Putting the clumsy and head-shaking ending aside, the journey to get there was really fun. I'll be replaying this at some point, for sure.

column8:
An amazing story-driven game!

With the revival of the World of Darkness franchise and the coming of the 2nd V:tM Bloodlines game by the end of this year (at the time of this review, anyways), this game helps to set the mood of the 5th Edition WoD in an incredibly convincing fashion, with its dynamic artistic scenarios, immersive background sounds and soundtrack, and engaging tales of politics, intrigue, mystery, and personal drama.

For a WoD game, this is a fine companion piece that expands on the supernatural universe that it's based upon. Matter of factly, the early Bloodlines game, as cult epic as it has become over time, feels (to me, anyways) somewhat lacking in the environment now that I can make a comparison. Could this be because Bloodlines in the end needed to be more fleshed out before it went to the stores? Maybe. But mind you, Bloodlines is by no means a bad game; rather the opposite, I recommend it to all you people out there who haven't played it.

In regards to playability, expect what you should from narration (just like in tabletop), where you will make choices that will ultimately affect what quests you can follow, and what help you get when the time comes. This being said, mind your hunger; feeding or lack thereof will play an important role in the range of choices available to you.

If you like the narration genre, this should belong in your game library. If you like the WoD setting, this is a game you should have a look at as soon as you can. I doubt you will be disappointed!

column8:
A fun game in a format I haven't played before.  I didn't really think I would enjoy the story format, but it was actually fun and interesting.  It reminded my of the choose your own adventure books of my youth.  The choices you make affect the outcomes and there is the ability to replay with different protagonists and different choices.  I recommend it if you are a fan of the genre.

I give this game 8 of 10.

column8: Great World of Darkness atmosphere with subtle graphical details and music that is on point. Unexpected and gripping ending. A little disappointed by plotlines that were left unfinished. Highly recommended if you are a fan of Vampire or graphical novels.

column8:
Pros:
-Incredible art and music that perfectly fits the World of Darkness.
-An enjoyable story concept that explores the first nights of a new vampire, their emotions and the challenges that come with becoming a part of vampiric society.

Cons:
-A very linear narrative that offers almost no opportunities to make meaningful choices.
-No manual saves. If you make a decision you're not happy with, tough luck.
-The writing quality can go up and down quite a bit. Also, I've found the MC to be somewhat bland with very little to differentiate the three different clans you can choose.

Conclusion:
Get this if you're a VTM fan. If you're here purely for a good story, get it on sale. But really, the art and the potential here is so good that I'm happy giving it a thumbs up. I'm very much looking forward to the sequel and I hope the devs improve their story crafting.

So far I have only finished it with one of the characters. The story was really good. Every choice you make is final. No going back. So you really have to think before you act. And even some seemingly small decision you made can come back to haunt you. Compared to other VN style games there is no option to replay parts or save scum. No way to skip read text. So subsequent playtrhoughs may be a little annoying. The art is pretty good. There is some sparse background animation, fog, and lighting that adds to some scenes but nothing too distracting. Overall it is an enjoyable read. There were times when I made decisions and felt it in my gut.

column8: If you're in to VtM and know what you're buying it's a fun little game. Wish it was a bit longer but putting 18 or so hours in to a game i paid $13 for on sale isn't too bad I suppose. That's one playthrough with each of the three characters not one. So if you only go through once it's probably only 6 hours. I've spent more on games I ended up playing less. That said I wish there were multiple endings but the ending it had was interesting. There is only one ending as far as I can tell so if that's gonna bother you too much be warned. I've seen some complaints about the ending, I feel like it's pretty fitting for the setting though. I'm excited to play Shadows of New York after playing this one  so clearly it wasn't bad. As long as you know what you're buying I can't see why anyone would be completely let down by it.

I would not recommend this game as it is much too unforgiving to a new visual novel player as myself.
After 8 hours played my character died in what seems to be in the second act of three , but the game design includes a save deletion system - meaning that upon death , you would have to start over.

column8: As a reader, and someone who's played WoD games since the early 90's, I quite enjoyed this adaptation! I wish that each of the characters was a little more individual, or certain ideas played more of a role inn the game (like the picky eating habits of the Ventrue). Overall, it was enjoyable to work through each character's story even with the overlapping material!

Overall, it was enjoyable to work through each character's story even with the overlapping material!

column8: I would love to give this a good review because the companion quests were really good and I found characters such as Sophie, Tamika and Hope interesting. The story had me engaged, but when the final night began, it went downhill quickly. There's only one canon ending to the game and it ruined the entire experience and game for me. Your actions in the game barely matter at all other than stopping you from getting the "bad" endings which honestly, all of them are bad endings. Your choices ultimately do not change the ending whatsoever, your clan slightly changing things in the end, but with the same result. The game doesn't expand upon characters that I was interested in much detail and leaves many story details and character stories unfinished. I love Vampire: The Masquerade which made me enjoy alot of this game, but I cannot in good conscience give it a good review due to the railroaded singular ending. I would have loved this game a good review, but the final night shows the flaws in the games and ruins the whole thing. The only thing that wasn't ruined was my interest in the characters even though, their stories were never finished and theres no real conclusion.

column8: Besides the fact of it being a timed game, I enjoyed the artwork, music and atmosphere of the game immensely and the story is tight. Just don't try to complete every questline in your first playthrough. It's meant to be played multiple times over.

column8:
I liked the story of the game, but the game has quite a few shortcomings: 

First of all, its very short (6-7 hours) and ends very abruptly. I know, they are going to release a DLC to fix it, but that does make up for the fact that the game is too short on its one. Giving that they are selling a full game, I feel a bit cheated...

Second of all, the so called "art and soundtrack" is VERY overestimated. There are hardly any sounds in the game (and no speech), and the graphics merely consists of still pictures. Don't get me wrong, the game does have a great a atmosphere, but text-based games died a long time ago...

Third of all, its very expensive (all things considdered). Maybe if was 5-7 euros, it would be priced right, but 20 euros is simply too much!

I am a big fan of the Masquerade universe, and the games does have a good (although short) story, but it does not live up to the previous games. All in all, I can only recommend this for longtime fans of the series.

1. It is part 1, you have to play shadows to understand what happened in this game.
Your choices which are make or fail to make a friend, retrieve research, deal with beast, save R, save S don't have anything to do with the end.
2. Same pictures all over cotteries and shadows, and in the case of Ellysium an empty room is supposed to portray a room full of vampires
3. Game with bad vibe energy


day 1 becoming a vampire
day 2-3 some things happen
day 4 you are told to make friends with 4 Vampires, each one of them needs 4 days/meetings for their quests
day 5 sidequest appears. 3 more people and each one of them needs 3 meetings/days
day 6 your Patron gives you a quest
day 17 game ends and some sidequests are left unfinished no matter what.
They added a skip feature so one save file isn't a big problem now.
It is an 8 hours game. Shadows took me 14 hours.
Choices don't seem to matter most of the times and sometimes they are there to give you the illusion it is not a long long narrative. The secret achievement is a joke, you died early you unlocked a secret achievement. The first thing I do is die because this is how the writing is. As I said there is the skip button now so it was just one of the things I hated.
And there is so much talk about smoking, specially in the next game, that I just can't stand in a game. I have to face smokers in real life everyday, I don't want to read about them in a game too.

Coteries of New York is a novelette, not a video game, and you do not get a lot for your money.  The story itself is fine, if short, with emphasis on your coterie members which are the highlight of the game.

The graphics are in short supply and reused with things like an abandoned garage also being a high tech facility and an office hallway also being an apartment hallway.  There are a few attempts at very basic animation but mostly you're looking at a still image for each scene.  The art is okay although the characters have a sameness to them that detracts.

Like the art, the music is in short supply, being re used over and over for what is a 3-4 hour game.  The music is fairly basic but does an okay job for atmosphere.  There are very few sound effects given there is very little animation.

Even descriptions can be lacking in many areas with it reading like a novel where only the minimum is told to you and not an RPG where you can search around for things to read or ask questions to get in depth information on the world and main characters.  You are left with very little information on much of the world although the coterie members are fleshed out well and are interesting.

The story itself doesn't branch so much as limit what parts you can read, and reading is made tedious with only a small amount of text shown in the bottom left of the screen with extreme amounts of clicking required to advance.  The story is inconsistent so you're never sure when something will require blood or not and I found the dialogue options frustrating as they often suited neither the character or the situation.

I encountered a bug where the story advanced a day or two on me and suddenly it was referring to a fight that I never read about involving a character I'd never read about.

The ending is unsatisfying and there really should have been a few more "days" beyond what you get.  You're left feeling that the main character of the story is less fleshed out than the four main supporting characters.

Overall if you're a World of Darkness fan you'll probably get something out of it, but wait for a sale.  If you don't know what World of Darkness is, just buy a book, it will save you a lot of clicking.
column9:

column8:
The Good:
 - It looks good.

The Bad:
 - Locations are repetitive.
 - The first long part (~about fourth) of the game is really just a tutorial, a boring interactive encyclopedia of VtM lore.
 - Besides the above this could have simply been a noir detective story really.

The Ugly:
 - Never for a minute did I feel that I'm part of the story. I was a bystander at best. 
 - No real decisions.
 - The game has a fixed length and I either spent too much time exploring otherwise boring and useless side quests or it's bugyy anyway, but the main story line was rushed at the end and it referenced sub plots and characters I've never heard about before but it sounded like I should know what's going on.

column8:
Good as a snack before Bloodlines 2. It's more a fanfiction than a video game.

Pros :
_the atmosphere is nice. ish.
_the dialogs do have some spiritual phrasing, from time to time.

Cons :
_No gameplay whatsoever.
_"Multiple choices" my b... ! The choices you make change pretty much nothing to the storyline. Most of the time, only the next sentence is affected by what you do, no matter how smart nor dumb. The only significant way you can affect the story is your clan choice. When the game begins, you have already done all you could to influence it.
_It could have been a pleasant novel, but the characters are desperatly what they seem to be at first glance. The toreador redhead is a cold [spoiler] traitor [/spoiler], the stuck up ventrue is shennaniganing, the cynical nosferatu is trading info, the anarch brujah is revolting, and so on. No psychology, no history, no nuance, no nothing. Everyone is just the stereotype of his clan.
_Terrible replayability. The time limit suggest a second walktrough, but it end up being just a canal carpian ordeal, where you fast forward everything you already did last time, for very little new discoveries. It not worth the osteophaty sessions.

I enjoyed playing the game. But the ending is the worst ending in the history of bad endings. No specific spoilers here, but, as a storyteller I can pinpoint at least two cardinal rules on ending a story being blatantly ignored here.
Play the game- It's great. But when your character boards a boat; Quit! The game is over - and the last few minutes just destroys too much.

column8:
The description "Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York is a narrative experience..." applies perfectly here. It's not really a video game or a visual novel or a role-playing game, but contains some elements of each. But yes, it's definitely a narrative experience, and most importantly, it's Vampire.

It would be easy to concentrate on the shortcomings. The lack of gameplay, the low importance of player choice, or the missing RPG character development. However, the narrative experience trumps all that, because the writing works, because the story stays together and because it feels like Vampire.

In the 5th edition Vampire: The Masquerade RPG product, the everyday (or night, rather) hunger and feeding mechanisms for vampires were changed and became an ever so important part of play. Coteries captures this wonderfully; when events made my character hungry and denied him opportunities to feed, I felt his anguish and constantly kept thinking about finding sustenance while stories and events moved on. To me, this speaks volumes of excellence and subtlety in writing.

It's easy to recommend Coteries for hardcore Vampire fans and tabletop roleplaying gamers, but other players who like the more traditional story driven games or action-oriented roleplaying games might not be satisified with just and only the story. Coteries is a niche product for sure, but I know I was happy to return the wonderful world and mindset of Vampire.

column8:
One of those cases i wish there was a neutral button. I enjoyed the game a lot however there are a few major flaws. The biggest one is probably the game length. It took me about 2 hours to complete one run. 
     Thats so short it makes the order feel long. The second issue is the railroading. There is really one path and its just from start to finish everything in between is just there to mask it. The last thing is the voice acting there isn any. That certainly takes away from the atmosphere imo and I just don't think its worth the full 20 bucks. I did however enjoy it but it is so very short.
      Its a little snack for vtm fans but this game will really just make you go play redemption and bloodlines for the 50th time.

Better than neutral, but not ecstatic.

As others have said, the ending is a bit abrupt, though I didn't find it as confusing or 'wrong' as some.  It just felt like a bit of a rush. And there are some continuity goofs I noticed- for example, a story thread where you're supposed to get a name from someone, and in the very next dialogue, you don't know the name you've just gotten.  Some threads are left dangling, as well, in part because of the time-based nature of the game.

A few spots where your choices don't quite seem to have the effect you'd expect, and there's assuredly some railroading in the plot.

That said, the characters and mood are excellent, and the basic plot is, I think, good overall. Not sure how well it will hold up on a second playthrough, though there are obviously options you don;t have time to explore going through just once.

Definitely recommend if you can get it on sale, otherwise, it depends on how much you enjoy the theme and VN genre.

column8:
This game is a lot of fun.

I like Vampire games and lore. My first experience with Vampire the Masquerade was Bloodlines.

Coteries of New York is a short choice based Visual Novel. Some choices seem to be non-choices in the end. This however didn't change the fact that I enjoyed playing this game a lot.

The story was great even though it was a bit short. I would have liked it if the game was longer.

If the development team keeps making these games I will keep buying them. Just make them longer and have more meaningful choices please.

column8:
While I didn't really enjoy the ending, I had a lot of fun along the way. It's not a perfect visual novel game, and it's not everything I hoped it would be before I played it, but I feel like I got my money's worth. I enjoyed many of the characters in the game, they all had their unique flavours. And the art style was enjoyable. 

Some kind of chapter select or manual save system would really have helped cutting down on the tedium for seeing all the content on replays. In future VTM visual novels I would hope they add a feature like that. Some kind of humanity indicator would be nice as well, as the game only seems to represent hunger.

column8: Usual issues with choice based games. You make a choice and the game decides you mean something completely different. Normally not an issue but the developer thought their game is completely flawless so they never created any means to get around this. 6 hours of gameplay absolutely wasted due to bugs in the game that would require me to start from the beginning in order to "fix". Hard pass on this game, just wait for VtMB2

column8: Nope.  Really super bummed.  I played Vampire the Masquerade bloodlines over and over for years.   I loved that game.  I've never played a narrative before and didn't know what to expect.  I am super disappointed.  If I wanted to read a book, that's what I would do.  When I play a game, I want excellent graphics, great acting voices, and I want to participate by not just making choices, but moving my character around, killing, and causing general mayhem.  This game?  It's not a game.  It's a bedtime story.  I'm snoring.

column8: I absolutely loved this game, good graphics and atmosphere. The characters were interesting, i'm glad the setting is being reused by drawdistance foor their next game. The only complaint is the story is a bit short for the price your paying.

column8:
I'm a bit sad to not recommend this game but there are some major flaw, and while it's perfectly acceptable if you can have the game during steam sales it's not worth the full price at all for a visual novel that short(I would say it's worth no more than 10‚Ç¨).

Pros :
- It feels like vampire the mascarade 
- Graphism are nice
- Most part of the game is well written
- the different character involved are nice
- the story is ok

Cons :
- There is no real choice in the game (except at the start...) you are on a path that you will follow willingly or not, that's the biggest flaw, your choices will put some flavor on your playthrough but don't expect much more than that.
- No save/quick save that let you try the different replies of your character (like in the other visual novel games)
- No skip "already read" button, this hurt the replayability big time, Since most of the text is the same (like 80-90% from what i experienced) you get fed up of clicking continue all the time ... (especially since if you click on enter it auto select your reply so you can't be blindly fast... even if the choice don't really matter)
- Dialog tree is not good, since you are able to choose between different activities during your night you are sometime pushed forward in time a lot,  your character also know things he didn't learned yet or have no way to know  because he never asked them but is still able to reply as if he did.
- Passing of time is not good (like in 2 activities of the same night the text say that few night pass making the timeline quite strange) and you have no real indication there is a time limit on your playthrough, I guess it's made with the idea of making your replay the game but ... with the no skip/rewind/save policy you'll have to be a very very very patient person to clickclickclickclick through all the text you already read x times ...

column8: bom

Let me say it first: I love VtM. I have played the game in varying systems for almost 10 years now. Big big fan.

However, as for this game, I will admit I was disappointed. I got this on release day and I know some of the mistakes that were in it (like misspellings, italics when someone speaking, vice versa) were patched, but I feel like, as a visual novel medium, there should have been multiple endings. I understand the importance of storytelling vs typical gaming mentality in the realm of VtM itself. I am very much a story based storyteller rather then focusing on combat, grinding, being the best. However, it feels like even though there is some variation based on your choices, none of them matter by the end and that takes away so much player agency OOG. If I did a tabletop and was forced down this one path that was, frankly, really disappointing, I'd never RP with that group again.

Despite my complaints, the world itself is fairly well made. I will agree with another comment I saw, in that, a lot of the characters aren't exactly groundbreaking in the realm of VtM. A lot of these characters are kind of caricature's of the clans themselves more then dynamic people. Good for someone who has never encountered VtM before, but very much "same" for those who have been playing this game a bit. Not a terrible thing, but I would love the creatures of these games to show us different ways to play their game rather then recycle similar character ideas.

I love this series. I know they've been releasing patches to improve the game and there are lots of things this game does well. I (sheepishly) recommend this, mostly as a more modern way to get into the universe of VtM. I'd put on a wishlist and grab it on sale.

Good for someone who has never encountered VtM before, but very much "same" for those who have been playing this game a bit. Not a terrible thing, but I would love the creatures of these games to show us different ways to play their game rather then recycle similar character ideas.

I love this series. I know they've been releasing patches to improve the game and there are lots of things this game does well. I (sheepishly) recommend this, mostly as a more modern way to get into the universe of VtM. I'd put on a wishlist and grab it on sale.

column8: Wow its the worst game ever!!!
column9: Wow its the worst game ever!!!

column8:
I think this visual novel game is the best to introduce somebody to the World of Darkness Vampire the Masquerade role-playing universe.
 The feeling for the setting grasped me well, but may be because I'm familiar with the setting and role-played myself in it, knowing what to expect. Though I felt that a person, who not yet familiar with the universe, will be comfortable embracing himself in this world. 
 I'm surely had my fun playing it for the first time. And I really want to play it again as other characters. I'm sure in the end the choices will not really matter but it doesn't matter for me, because I would rather experience a well designed story once again from a little bit different perspective, than too much of a branching half-stories. 
 I only had two complains for this game. First, my screen resolution was not supported. A small tech nuance, though a few times I had to change screen resolution to be able to read some text on screen. 
Second. Sounds design, when done right, was suspended me to the fking roof. But at some points... it slacked too much I was losing the feeling for the surroundings. For example, background noise for car driving still playing when you long inside the building. Or the sound of loud concert not coming back when you came back from the quite room (muffled sound of music also would be a good option for that scene). 
Some polishing for sound design would have kept my immersed into the scene far better, but as I said, where it was done right, it was fking amazing.

column8: Nice story - very deep setting
column9: Nice story - very deep setting

column8:
I had a lot of fun with the game. Sure, it might be a bit short, but there's three different characters, so you can see the story from different angles.
The visuals are good, a voice-over would be nice though.

The ending makes a 2nd game possible as well. Looking forward to it.

[b] TLDR: Creative and beautifully written characters, the ending left me wanting more. It's absolutely worth it, even if you haven't tried visual novels before. [/b] 

Before playing this, I've already played Bloodlines 1 and watched LA by Night (the Geek and Sundry show) and loved both. I can confidently say that Hope is the most interestingly written Malkavian I've ever seen. Heck, she's one of the best written vampire characters I've ever encountered, and this game had a lot of them. For example, the two main Nosferatu characters, the 'architect' (can't mention anything else about them without spoiling). It's absolutely worth it, even at full price.

column8: Very linear if somewhat entertaining. Moderate replayability though I only played it three times to clear the achievements. Nothing groundbreaking or memorable...Bloodlines 2 will DEFINITELY be that. A very shallow but fun run for creatures of the night.
column9: Very linear if somewhat entertaining. Moderate replayability though I only played it three times to clear the achievements. Nothing groundbreaking or memorable...Bloodlines 2 will DEFINITELY be that. A very shallow but fun run for creatures of the night.

column8:
Decent writing and a very adept WoD atmosphere and soundtrack, with noir-like artwork fitting for the setting.

On the negative side, a little short and somewhat railroaded. The "abrupt-ending" thing, although implies wasted potential on an otherwise brilliant, albeit neglected IP, was not a deal-breaker for me.

All in all, very worthwhile for VtM fans, especially if it's on sale. The announcement of an expansion on the way is also good news.

column8: F√ºr alle Vampire the Masquerade Fans und alle, die ihre ersten Schritte in die Dunkelheit wagen wollen. Gut geschrieben, mit liebevollen Illustrationen, coolen Charakters. Ich hoffe es gibt bald mehr davon <3

Entertaining, quick game with for a ventrue playthrough. There isn't really a character creator: you choose one of three presents, and I don't see myself trying either of the man presets any time soon. Maybe the Toreador.

I can see how there's replayability (e.g., limited number of subplots you can finish each run, some opportunities to get worse or different outcomes from different choices), but I'm not likely to replay it. A lot of the allure is finding out what's coming next, and now I know the answer to that.

column8: Meh.. I like VTM, and although this game captured some of the atmosphere, it was mostly a pretty shallow experience. Why am I interacting with these other vampires? I loved this game! If you love the VtM setting, chances are you'll like this game.

column8:
I absolutely loved VTMB, which is why I decided to purchase and play this version as we all (not so) patiently await for VTMB2. I don't usually write reviews, but I wish I had read deeper into existing ones prior to purchase. This game is, while intriguing, very dull. There was not much of a climax and the story just kind of ends.

There is also not a lot of choices when it comes to your character needs. There were many times I needed to feed and was never given an opportunity to do so. This obviously made it very complicated to play the game how I wanted without going into a frenzy or being able to use my abilities. I would muddle through 30 minutes of basically a book just to find out there was no one to eat and the sun was coming up. I feel like there should have been a "hunt" choice in the midst of all the character meets.

It was not good but it wasn't terrible. It just... wasn't.

column8:
As an old fan of the tabletop and the original Bloodlines title by Troika, I was happy to see a new narrative Vampire title. And to be fair, its hook was well done. It introduced interesting characters, setup tension and interplay, and had me all ready to invest time learning what the authors had in store.

And then... It just ended.

So, here's the thing boys and girls who are thinking about authoring in this format or any other. There are certain rules to storytelling. You give an interesting hook, a solid middle and a satisfying climax. That's the contract. I give you my money and my time. You give me an enjoyable story in those three parts. This game had a good hook, a fraction of a middle and then simply closed.  I understand developers, you maybe had to ship. Money had run out, whatever. The fact remains, you have failed in your obligation, and that's not something the market is likely to forget or forgive.

That alone is why I'm panning this game and not recommending. Tone, spot on. Handling of VtM lore, well done. Interesting characterizations? Definitely. However, one act does not a solid story make. I could have gotten more meat (or blood in this case) out of any paperback for half the price. So potential buyer, consider yourself warned. Wait till this is in the most bargin of bargin bins. If you're a VtM fan, you will love its promise, but you will be VERY angry when it doesn't deliver.

column8:
Actually, I like the game. But I still wouldn't recommend it to anyone, at least not without a solid discount. Because despite the fact that I liked it and enjoyed my 10 hrs, I feel it could have been so much more.

All the main reasons have already been discussed - lack of variability, insignificant fluff choices that don't matter even to your character and static cardboard setting that can be placed anywhere in the world or be removed from the game altogether. At the very beginning you are presented with three different characters belinging to threee different clans with different personalities... the epitome of catfishing.

The game has only one final scene - saying this is not even a spoiler. There is one kinda sorta alternative in the first 30 minutes which is extremily obvious and extremily dissatisfying (do it only if you want to pop those sweet Steam achievements). Everything else invariably leads you exactly to the same spot. And see how I said "final scene" instead of "finale" or "ending"? That's because the thing looks like the cliffhanger for the Chapter 1 out of 5 at least... but seeing how your save get erased when you finish the story, ain't no chance for it to be finished with those you started with.

You also cannot save at pivotal moments. Therefore if you want to try a different option, you have to start anew and click-click-click-click-click. This greatly decreases the replay value (not that high from the start tbh), because in the end the true challenge is "how fast can you click continue without accidentally skipping a dialogue option that doesn't matter at all but you want to read the fluff text anyway?". I ended up reading a few alternative endings online. It was a much more satisfying experience.

Static universe. It could be Coteries of London, Singapore or Moscow. It. Doesn't. Matter. Like pretty much anything in the game. Maybe it could have been saved by dymanic characters? No. We see oh my gosh THREE angles of Sophie. She was the only one to receive such honour. Would it kill the devs to use several images for the essential NPCs at least? The visuals and the ambiance are stunning but how much will you really stare at the exactly same image over and over again? Spoiler: you won't. Another wasted potential.

There are some threads that remain tangled. [spoiler]Who is Samira? Who in the end is your Sire? (apart from someone indebted to Arturo) What's the deal with those vampire hunters? The Scarred one? Who's the man eyeing you when you get Special Reserve for Kaiser?[/spoiler] Faces just come and go but I guess our characters will never find the answers.

In the end CoNY left me extermily frustrated and yeah, wanting for more just like the very misleading ad says, but not in the good way. It had great power that could be tapped into, even for the 3-4 hour visual novel - a few DIFFERENT endings, a couple of truly important choices, a bit more love for the backdrop, but we are stuck with what we have and it seems the game will not be updated in any major way to deal with these problems pointed out over and over and over and over again.

column8:
Schwierig zu bewerten. Einerseits spannend und mit interessanten Storylines. Andererseits sind die verschiedenen M√∂glichkeiten der 3 vorgefertigten Charaktere doch zu √§hnlich um mehrfaches Durchspielen wirklich interessant zu machen. Das das Ende immer gleich ist, ist aber der gr√∂√üte Nachteil und f√ºr mich der Hauptgrund das Spiel nicht zu empfehlen.
Es sind noch einige andere Nachteile, die man nicht verschweigen sollte. Z.B. Ben√∂tigt man zwar regelm√§√üig Blut, hat aber keine M√∂glichkeit aktiv welches zu bekommen, nur wenn man die zuf√§llig auftauchenden Gelegenheiten nutzt.

[PROS]

The world is awesome. Vampire the Masquerade is one of the oldest and most interesting fictional worlds.

The writing is great. The writing is the game. It's a choose your own adventure book, digitized.

It's slightly replayable.

[OK]

The visuals are static pictures but nice

Music is decent

[CONS]

For a game that uses mainly text and not much else, it's really surprising to me that this game has very little actual choices that affect the world. There is also only one ending. This means that there was no excuse not to have better graphics and voice overs like a Tell Tale game. What's the point of having a text based game if you're not going to allow lots of major world changing branching choices? Everything is just a diamond of choices. Very disappointing of something that had so much potential based on game style.

[VERDICT]

It's a short, quick money grab. This should be ten dollars at most.

column8:
The only other Vampire: The Masquerade game I've played is Bloodlines. I also happen to like visual novels and this is a good one. I've played one route (took me 5 hours) and enjoyed it a lot. I've never played a VN with side quests before and I loved having a visible day/night cycle in the game. I feel like this game is a good intro to some of the lore before VTMB2 comes out (especially with all the Second Inquisition stuff).

The prologue and end of the game are a little rushed, but the actual meat of the game is where it's at. I did run into one bug where my Hunger notification caused me to skip a day but I got the gist pretty easily. I'll see if it happens on subsequent playthroughs. I'm a little sad I couldn't play as a Tremere but the three Clans you can choose are good to start you off. I'm looking forward to the expansion of this game when it comes out.
column9:
The only other Vampire: The Masquerade game I've played is Bloodlines. I also happen to like visual novels and this is a good one. I've played one route (took me 5 hours) and enjoyed it a lot. I've never played a VN with side quests before and I loved having a visible day/night cycle in the game. I feel like this game is a good intro to some of the lore before VTMB2 comes out (especially with all the Second Inquisition stuff).

The prologue and end of the game are a little rushed, but the actual meat of the game is where it's at. I did run into one bug where my Hunger notification caused me to skip a day but I got the gist pretty easily. I'll see if it happens on subsequent playthroughs. I'm a little sad I couldn't play as a Tremere but the three Clans you can choose are good to start you off. I'm looking forward to the expansion of this game when it comes out.

column8:
This game will take you for a spin (but will leave you wanting for more)

If you are looking at this game, I am sure you know already, but just to be clear, this game is a story rich, "click and choose game" With such games, the story is the most important. On this part, this game delivers. The story is intriguing and will keep you wanting for more...

One thing though, it's not necessarily a negative point, but this game feels like a part of a grander series. Not all of your questions will be answered in this game and some things will be left in the dark. Just though I will point that out.

Thanks

column8:
Got excited to buy this after playing VTM Bloodlines. I bought this with understanding that this is a Visual Novel and I have played plenty of VNs. I have to agree with what others negative reviews have pointed out. This game lacks consequences. I don't even see the point of having different kindreds teaming out with me.  Then there is the ending...rly? I found myself highly disappointed. Aside from VNs, I bought a lot of text based choice games and found many of them have far more consequences than this game. Luckily I bought this on discounted price or I would have regret it even more! 

I hope this is not going to be some indicators of the new VTM Bloodlines 2 game coming out soon. Because I'm rly rethinking of buying one.

column8: Je ne sais pas combien de fins alternatives existent sur ce jeu, mais avec la plus grande complaisance possible, j'ai dur√© 5 heures de jeu. Ce jeu ne m√©rite m√™me pas son prix en solde.

Pros:
-	Vampire ‚Äûthe masquerade‚Äú Feeling
-	VERY good visual Art
-	Some cool characters
-	Not exiting but ok story

Cons:
-	Much to short for a 20 ‚Ç¨ game
-	Central point and task of the game ist to build relationships to a bunch of charakters. But these relationships have absolutely no impact on the story. Not only that: Your choices seem even irrelevant for the developement of the relationships themself. And before you get to really know anybody, the game is over.  
-	Second point of the game is to keep ‚Äûthe beast‚Äú, your hunger, in check. But there is no mechanism to hunt, no selection of ‚Äûprey‚Äú and no strategy you can follow. There are only random enconters in the story where you can choose to bite a random somebody.
-	There is no way to change the overall storyline.
-	Absolutely no voiceacting.
-	You can not freely choose your vampirebloodline. You have to choose between ready made characters. If you want to play an average underdog, you have to be a bisexual guy. If you want to play a noble vampire, you have to be a woman. If you want to play an erotic vampire, it has to be a gay dude.

Liked it, but a bit short for the price they are asking.
Get it on sale.

The most boring "Interactive" anything I've ever tried.
Only good for helping insomniacs fall asleep.

column8: The ending was... just disappointing. Bad and just really disappointing. A major let down to how the game as it seemed so promising.
column9: The ending was... just disappointing. Bad and just really disappointing. A major let down to how the game as it seemed so promising.

column8:
TLTR: VtM Coteries of New York is a good virtual novel. It's a continuously pleasant experience throughout, with a few extremely good parts and a couple of bad ones. I can easily recommend it to anyone looking for a VtM VN.


First
-This is a pure VN with a few simple choose-your-own-adventure elements. The route you take affects what content you choose to experience and what achievements you unlock. I'm pretty sure they don't change the ending. It's not an RPG and it does not have RPG-elements, although some of the elements are framed in a way that gives it an RPG-feel as you play.

-I'd estimate it would last me 3 hours for a single playthrough if I just read it really quickly. I used 12-14 hours for a single playthrough when doing it laid-back, sucking in the atmoshpere and thinking about what is being said and what it means over a cup of coffee.


The Good
-There are some very interesting characters portrayed in Coteries of NY. The Malkavians portrayed are almost as good as in Bloodlines.

-The art, music and narrative are all appropriate and well made.

-The story itself is ok and the plot is really good.

-The story is broken up in instances, and you have some choice as to which of them you want to pursue. Let's call these instances "quests" for lack of a better word. Many of these quests are very good.

-There are enough quests that you can't do them all in one playthrough. 

-The 3 available characters you can play have some mutually exclusive content. All 3 must be played to experience all the game has to offer.

-Most dialogue choices have intuitive results close to what you'd expect. This is really good.

-I finished the game wanting more, and not for lack of content. I'll be getting the next installment once released.


The Bad
-There are some few dialogue-choices that inspire head-butting a nail. For example there is an instance where attacking with Potence will make the protagonist shout and shake his fist at the enemy in the middle of a short-ranged firefight. He then gets shot to pieces and only then decides to actually attack, only now the power seems to have run out and no longer applies. There is no evidence I rage-quit.

-There is no option to save or roll back dialogue-choices. It's bad the few times a dialogue-choice leads to something nail-dating silly.

-The get-created-and-rise-to-power-in-2-weeks trope is getting old.

-A couple of the characters and quests are pretty boring. Which in a way is pretty good come to think of it.

-Auspex is useless. It makes you able to notice things before you stumble upon them, as opposed to just stumbling upon them for the same effect and then have another power as well.

-There are 2-3 dialogue-oversights throughout the game. Places where the devs have lost track of the continuity of the story and the resulting dialogue becomes nonsensical. "Didn't I tell you to stay away from(...)!?!". "No actually, you didn't".


The Wishlist
-I wish there were some subtle hints about the main plot is all about. Or maybe there are and I was just too dull to pick up on them? I hope it's the latter.

-Some of the characters could have been explored just a little bit more, just enough to understand their role properly once the plot is fully revealed.

-I wish there was a skip-text-you've-already-read button.


Conclusion
In all, VtM Coteries of New York does what it tries to do very well, and better than most VNs I've played. It's continuously pleasant throughout, with a few extremely good parts and a couple of bad ones. An easy recommendation.

column8:
Can partly recommend.
Got this 30% off and it was still a bit pricy I feel.
Took me 6 hours to get through the game.

Some interactions and part of the story feel pretty crafted. Also I don't feel like going for a second playthrough since the end is made in a way that doesn't seem to have a possibility for another ending. So it would just offer me additional or different details on how to get to the big finish. Which by the way was kinda underwhelming.
The game itself is not hard or anything, although it is possible to kill your character, it really is more of an deciding on how you want to approach situations and it will work out one or the other way.

But that being said, I liked the characters, I liked the vampire feeling, the artwork, and I did play through it, which means I enjoyed it... So yea partial recommendation

column8:
A lot of people have commented on the ups and downs of this game.  I'll refrain from going over them- most other reviews have it spot on, in different ways- and simply say this:

  You like VTM?  This is worth playing.  Doesn't have a whole lot of replay value (maybe a second playthrough up till the endgame for missed quests), but it knocks it out of the park when it comes to atmosphere, tone and characterization.

  Get it on sale if possible; I spent a full 20 bucks on it and, though I enjoyed myself, I'm not quite sure it's worth THAT much, it's just too short.  Maybe 10-20% off.  Here's hoping they make a proper sequel with some community feedback.

column8:
This is a good visual novel but a poor VTM roleplaying game. It has the illusion of choice but there are no choices that seem to make any difference. As I was trying to complete the quests for all the members of my coterie I ended up finishing none. The ending comes very quickly and seems rushed. Were parts cut out ?

Shame, as I quite enjoyed the writing. The characters were fascinating but everything felt rushed. Not really selling me on another playthrough, let alone getting the sequel.

column8: I've played most things based on the pen and Paper RPG "Vampire" like the Jyhad collectible card game when it came out,  every PC game, read several novels set in this world, but oddly never had the chance to play the actual RPG.  So I'm very familiar with this world. This is a nice introduction to the Vampire RPG and should be a nice lead in to the new Vampire PC game coming out.  I did get a bit frustrated that you really don't have much affect on the outcome, but it gives you the illusion you do and it's short enough that this didn't bother me.  I hope they make another that is a more involved choice specific type game with far more branches that occur due to your own choices.  But for now we have this and it's pretty good if you ask me.

column8:
I hesitated before giving this game a ‚Äúno‚Äù as it‚Äôs not bad, just disappointing (and not because it‚Äôs a visual novel, I knew that from the get-go). Overall, the story is interesting and the NPCs mostly memorable as they should be in such a rich setting as VTM. Art style is good, even if static, and music does a good job to set the mood. The characters are not voiced, but I can‚Äôt fault the indie team for skipping on voices as that would obliterate their budget. 

Where the game falters is in the choice department. As I replayed the game to get all the achievements, I realized how little our decisions really matter. There is only one ending (aside from two ‚Äúbad endings‚Äù at the very beginning) and we get it no matter what we do. Changes are negligible, maybe a sentence here or there, or a character cameo. I tried to be as uncooperative and rude as possible to everyone and the outcome was the same as when I was the patron saint of New York. The differences between the three protagonists ‚Äì Brujah, Toreador, Ventrue ‚Äì are barely noticeable aside from occasional use of powers of their respective clan. After the short introduction as they get Embraced in varied circumstances, you play each of them largely in the same way with barely any flavor to their personalities. If it weren‚Äôt for their portrait popping up during dialogues, I would honestly forget who am I playing as currently. Another thing, is the Hunger mechanics. You basically need to feed from time to time to keep the Beast at bay. But‚Ä¶ why? There are no consequences to ignoring it. Yes, you might lose control and suck some loser dry but the game never punishes you for that. If the game doesn‚Äôt care about your humanity, why should you? This lack of consequences really put a damper on my overall experience. 

[b]TL;DR[/b]: Good vampiric story to be experienced once if you don‚Äôt mind knowing that choices don‚Äôt matter in the end. Get it on discount.

column8: The art is beautiful and the narrative is true to the VTM setting.  The music was not to my liking but it was suitable to the setting. My only complaint is that the different clans presented as playable, play the story out too similar to each other with minor variations in NPC dialogue. I didn't feel that there was much difference.  I want this franchise to do well, so I am going to recommend this game to fans of VTM, but I am also hoping that a future installment will allow for diverse multiple endings based on player's choices and clan selection.

My only complaint is that the different clans presented as playable, play the story out too similar to each other with minor variations in NPC dialogue. I didn't feel that there was much difference.  I want this franchise to do well, so I am going to recommend this game to fans of VTM, but I am also hoping that a future installment will allow for diverse multiple endings based on player's choices and clan selection.

column8:
Unfortunately this is not Vampires Masquerade I like and want to have :( Maybe this is new direction to original license or something, but everything feels kinda different from previous games I've played. This being visual novel is not a bad thing. Heck, it could be even to its benefit, however...

Bad and not fun things

1. There is no indicator of your level or power. So all those actions they suggest you to perform may backfire(?), may get you killed(?), may bring success(?)... did I experience success in those checks? Do they even have checks? Extremely unclear which is in my opinion not fun for any RPG system.

2. Story. It's less bombastic so to speak than previous. There is no love, barely any lust, some minor stalkerish thing, but it feels super short. Sadly all of those doesn't compare favourably for me with Redemption. That Christof story will forever stick with me! Unfortunately Coteries of New York don't take time to develop some sort of intruigue stories, stories of overtaking something, someone. Basically story - don't like here.

3. What the hell happened to nosferatu... before they looked like a freaking nosferatu, now they look like hobos who got in some dangerous fights... that's... probably gonna sound like an asshole, but those are not my nosferatu...

4. Doesn't look like you can run all side quests and maybe even main quests for gathering crew in one go. Not sure why that was made like that, but also not a fan of that decision.

So basically there is kinda no freedom, you don't understand if you're powerful enough to do anything (assuming there are some RPG checks under the hood) and story is kinda... bland. Art is good however. That looks great. Really enjoyed their approach to visual novels. A bit refreshing and something new.

column8: This is a great little game for anyone who's already a fan of the Vampire: the Masquerade setting, and also works as a good litmus test to see if a new player would like the settings and themes of V:tM. It's a pretty simple little text-adventure game, but it does a lot with a little: the animations and music create excellent ambience, and the characters are unique and memorable. It only takes about five hours to finish a playthrough, so newcomers don't have to invest a ton of time to get a great dose of what V:tM has to offer, while veterans of the setting can do multiple playthroughs to really squeeze every option and bit of lore from the game. My only complaint is that, between the multiple routes, backgrounds, and powers, sometimes the text doesn't quite line up with your choices. It's a rare thing, though, and didn't overly impact my enjoyment of the game.
