column8:
"Different paths leading to a grand finale that will leave you surprised and eager to see more" Is a quote on the front page of this game as a highlight in the games favor. The truth is they mean the game is incomplete and will end so abruptly you might think to google and  see if you glitched your game to skip to the ending credits. 

Eager to see more is accurate. I very much wish to see more as the story just started to get moving when it ended. With the current knowledge the next game in this series is a stand alone I feel assured that I will be just left hanging here after that abrupt stop. Even if it were to tie into this game since it is a different character and start it cannot bring fulfillment to this journey with our character. 

The experience leaves me feeling as if I just went thru a demo of the actual game. The groundwork is all laid out and quite enjoyable, but rather than not stick the landing it is more like they simply didn't show up for the landing at all. 

There are positives here. I found two of the side characters quite interesting, A third that was quite serviceable even if I did think "Well that just a malkavian." Even the fourth my least favorite I didn't find bad just not of interest to me. I was quite sucked into the world the ambience from the music quite nice and the world itself a good introduction to the WoD for those who are not familiar. The story I wanted to see where it was going and want a satisfying conclusion to how it plays out. However, It just rolls the credits the moment it started picking up.

I really feel this game needs a middle ground rating. I don't want to say no as I don't feel this needs a flat out don't buy this or support this developer kind of message. Yet I find the abrupt stop for the story which also bleeds back making your choices feel pointless as there isn't enough story to see them have an effect over all leaves me with a terrible taste in my mouth from the experience.
column9:
"Different paths leading to a grand finale that will leave you surprised and eager to see more" Is a quote on the front page of this game as a highlight in the games favor. The truth is they mean the game is incomplete and will end so abruptly you might think to google and  see if you glitched your game to skip to the ending credits. 

Eager to see more is accurate. I very much wish to see more as the story just started to get moving when it ended. With the current knowledge the next game in this series is a stand alone I feel assured that I will be just left hanging here after that abrupt stop. Even if it were to tie into this game since it is a different character and start it cannot bring fulfillment to this journey with our character. 

The experience leaves me feeling as if I just went thru a demo of the actual game. The groundwork is all laid out and quite enjoyable, but rather than not stick the landing it is more like they simply didn't show up for the landing at all. 

There are positives here. I found two of the side characters quite interesting, A third that was quite serviceable even if I did think "Well that just a malkavian." Even the fourth my least favorite I didn't find bad just not of interest to me. I was quite sucked into the world the ambience from the music quite nice and the world itself a good introduction to the WoD for those who are not familiar. The story I wanted to see where it was going and want a satisfying conclusion to how it plays out. However, It just rolls the credits the moment it started picking up.

I really feel this game needs a middle ground rating. I don't want to say no as I don't feel this needs a flat out don't buy this or support this developer kind of message. Yet I find the abrupt stop for the story which also bleeds back making your choices feel pointless as there isn't enough story to see them have an effect over all leaves me with a terrible taste in my mouth from the experience.

column8: It's far too short, and navigating the minor details is numbingly tedious. At first, it seems like there's going to be this long, dark journey mired in vampiric politics and gory fantasy. I thought my choices mattered. They don't. There is a cryptic monologue about fate at the start, you become a vampire, and after what is little over an in-game fortnight you've arrived at the ending. The allies you choose don't matter, your disrespectful attitude or appropriate behavior choices have no pay off, and it's over by the time you have an inkling of how the game works.

Coteries of New York is one of those rare things that I can both recommend to longtime fans of VtM or people who have never engaged with the material at all. The game does a really good job of providing explanations for terms that may be second nature to longtime fans, but in a way where it doesn't feel like you're being condescended to. It also has really beautiful art and it was fun seeing the ways things changed depending on which character I was playing. It's not tremendously long and it doesn't take a ton of time to get all the achievements, but I believe it's totally worth it. I'm really excited for more of these to come out.

column8:
The writing is okay. The characters are very stereotypical archetypes of vampires. Adding voice acting could have helped the game immensely.

The blood/Feeding mechanic is shit. You have to rely on events that happen in the middle of your tasks to get blood. You cannot just go "forage" for blood. If you find yourself low in blood, you have to go into a mission and hope there will be an opportunity to feed.

If you don't feed enough, you go into a frenzy. If you go into a frenzy twice, it's game over. Which can be fine, but there are no checkpoints or save states. The game literally deletes your save. Your only choice is to play through the entire game again.

Somehow there are bugs in this multiple choice novel. For example, at some point you are tasked with getting a name from someone. Despite beating it out of them, in the very next screen, the name isn't in the list, causing you to fail the mission. I have encountered 3 such instances.

column8:
Overall, seems to be a pretty good game but not at the price of $18 of my local currency. Especially since its mostly a pretty linear storyline that lasts an hour or so.  Get it during a sale because honestly, there are quite a few reused assets and in my view doesn't really warrant that high a price for me.

Albeit the short story, it is great for Vampire the masquerade fans to revel once again in the world of darkness, as you progress through the similar fashion as the old adventure books that have you flipping page to page depending on the results. Players/readers new to the World of Darkness lore would probably find this refreshing as well as there aren't many RPG vampire games out there that focuses on story and it isn't more of your typical chick-flick handsome boy vampire movies or novels either.

Would've been better if the story was a whole lot more fleshed out and longer, possibly give some pen and paper elements allowing players to customize powers or stats that affected decision making.

TLDR: Wait for a big sale, even if you frequent visual novels on a regular basis. 

If you're a fan of VtM, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. This game is intended for people not familiar with VtM. As such, it adds nothing new to the lore or indicates anything to Bloodlines 2.

I like the art style and the character designs of the characters. 
The music is decent. It's fitting but not memorable.
For its price, I expected more scenes and voice acting. 

The pay off of making allies is nonexistent. Building a coterie doesn't do anything besides adding two of the coterie members intervening in the last few moments in the game.  

I found myself more invested in the side stories than the main plot. 

Ending was abrupt and unsatisfying.

I like the Vampire games, but just understand what you are buying as this is not a typical Vampire: The Masquerade game.  This is basically a choose your own adventure book.  Get ready for A LOT of reading.  You read the story, make a choice, and then read more story.  There is no voice acting or action sequences.  If you like Vampire: The Masquerade and don't mind reading, then you'll like the game.

column8: I feel like this was a really good idea that they gave a sweaty 15 yr old dude to write the story. Every Vampire you meet is literally the cliche you tell your players not to portray. The Occult Shop Owner Trem, the Noir Detective Nos, the Crazy Sado-Masichistic Malk etc etc. Then I'm supposed to make a coterie out of these people with little to no motivating factors on their part, like why? Why are they even associating with me, someone who could seriously fuck their standing with the Cam? Why would I, the outcast be the leader? The story never gives satisfactory reasons for this. The world also feels very small, 20 Vampires at the gathering in NYC? Are you kidding me? I have seen more in shitty backwater gatherings of Anarchs. Also, come up with an original idea lol, the start of the game is basically word for word Bloodlines 1 intro. I recommend this ONLY because we have so few choices in the Vampire world for games.

column8:
Before getting this game I read a lot of comments that expressed frustration because choices might not matter much. I'm happy to have ignored those for the following three reasons:

First: Your choices matter to some extent.

Second: If you are a fan of VtM you'll know when you shouldn't expect your will to matter. Some characters are just too powerful and way too many steps ahead of you. This isn't a Crisis game, so put your entitlement to f everyone up aside.

Third: If you are into WoD for the storytelling, just stop worrying whether or not your choices are going to create another branch in the story and enjoy the plot, because the plot makes sense. Choose your lines/actions and face the outcomes without thinking about the meta-game and you will have a great time.

As a fan of the first VtM:Bloodlines game, I was excited to pick up Coteries and I'm glad I did. 
The plot had me hooked instantly and I couldn't put the game down until I finished my playthrough. The storyline and characters kept me engaged as I kept wanting to see what would happen next.

The art for both the backgrounds and characters are gorgeous as well, and I actually ended up buying the art book. Though I was disappointed to see some art reused for different scenes. The art style definitely helped with the atmosphere and I love how it's animated. I feel the characters should have been drawn with different facial expressions, as that would have helped immerse me into the game more. Some of the music tracks are something I could definitely just chill out and listen to as well, it's never too distracting which is important for me when I'm focusing on reading. I wish the game could have given you the option to have voice actors read the lines though. 

I wish the characters' choices that you decide would have more consequences further on, and the later part of the game feels rushed [spoiler]once the SI agents come into play[/spoiler]. In addition, the side characters stories deserve to be elaborated on more as there were still loose ends to be solved, for instance [spoiler]Benoit, once you escape from Father Anthony or Hope when you leave her with Cara[/spoiler]. I strongly feel as though there should have been more endings instead of just one, and the ending just feels abruptly slapped on as though no one knew how to wrap up the game due to possible time constraints. The publishers for the game should definitely have allowed the developers more time in fleshing out the storyline more as well as the characters instead of meeting an earlier deadline.

Overall I thoroughly enjoyed Coteries. For a first time player just getting introduced to the universe of VtM or a long-time fan, both would would enjoy this in some way. Just be aware of the faults, but don't let that stop you because this is still an entertaining game.
column9:
As a fan of the first VtM:Bloodlines game, I was excited to pick up Coteries and I'm glad I did. 
The plot had me hooked instantly and I couldn't put the game down until I finished my playthrough. The storyline and characters kept me engaged as I kept wanting to see what would happen next.

The art for both the backgrounds and characters are gorgeous as well, and I actually ended up buying the art book. Though I was disappointed to see some art reused for different scenes. The art style definitely helped with the atmosphere and I love how it's animated. I feel the characters should have been drawn with different facial expressions, as that would have helped immerse me into the game more. Some of the music tracks are something I could definitely just chill out and listen to as well, it's never too distracting which is important for me when I'm focusing on reading. I wish the game could have given you the option to have voice actors read the lines though. 

I wish the characters' choices that you decide would have more consequences further on, and the later part of the game feels rushed [spoiler]once the SI agents come into play[/spoiler]. In addition, the side characters stories deserve to be elaborated on more as there were still loose ends to be solved, for instance [spoiler]Benoit, once you escape from Father Anthony or Hope when you leave her with Cara[/spoiler]. I strongly feel as though there should have been more endings instead of just one, and the ending just feels abruptly slapped on as though no one knew how to wrap up the game due to possible time constraints. The publishers for the game should definitely have allowed the developers more time in fleshing out the storyline more as well as the characters instead of meeting an earlier deadline.

Overall I thoroughly enjoyed Coteries. For a first time player just getting introduced to the universe of VtM or a long-time fan, both would would enjoy this in some way. Just be aware of the faults, but don't let that stop you because this is still an entertaining game.

column8:
Very short (<4h unless you read really slow) and surprisingly linear, considering some of the early choices that might make you think there's a lot more to this game. While you can't see all the content in a single playthrough, there is really nothing that fundamentally changes if you play through the game a second time.

The story is pretty engaging the first time around and there are some interesting characters. The game deals with wod vampire hierarchies  and overall worldbuilding pretty well. Overall it was a satisfying experience the first time I played through it. Some of the characters were well written and they nailed the feeling of helplessness and confusing of our brand new fledgling. 

On the second playthrough you notice that none of the choices really do anything, except give you bad endings. The Coterie aspect is pretty weak. While the initial storylines of your vampire buddies are pretty fun, then it kinda doesn't go anywhere. They show up a single time later in the main story and that's it. Weird for a game that literally has Coteries in its name.

The ending seems to be a point of contention. I didn't hate it, but I can understand that some people might not like it. In my opinion it fit the setting pretty well.

Also not sure why they deviated from the standard ren'py controls. No clue how to skip seen text or hide the interface. Having to click on a tiny button to advance text is a fucking joke aswell. Why not just let me click anywhere on the screen?

The art is very good, but there is not much variety. A lot of backgrounds get reused multiple times, even if they don't really fit the descriptions too well. Which I understand, it's hard to produce a lot of quality art, but still, this is not really a cheap game compared to a lot of other VNs. I would probably call the artstyle "gritty", which fits the setting.

I would recommend it on sale if you are a wod fan. For full price it's just too short. And waaay to expensive for the little amount of content it has.

column8: "Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York" ist ein solider visueller Roman, der von verschiedenen Vampirclans handelt, f√ºr die man diverse Quests erledigen soll. Man hat zu Anfang die Wahl zwischen drei Charakteren mit unterschiedlichen Skills. W√§hrend die Hauptgeschichte im Allgemeinen dieselbe bleibt, gibt es Unterschiede darin, wie verschiedene Ereignisse je nach der von Ihnen ausgew√§hlten Person ablaufen k√∂nnen. Abh√§ngig von den Entscheidungen im Spiel und davon, wie viele Freunde oder Feinde man sich macht, er√∂ffnen sich einem neue Dialogoptionen und Erz√§hlstr√§nge. Leider bleibt das Ende immer gleich und es war auch etwas ern√ºchternd. F√ºr Fans der "Vampires: Die Masquerade"- Saga ist das Spiel eine sch√∂ne Erg√§nzung und nat√ºrlich f√ºr diejenigen, die gerne Visual Novels spielen.

I'm a big fan of the VtM setting and of visual novels (and of paradox, for that matter), so I had  pretty high expectations from this title. Alas, I really cannot recommend this game. 
It's not a bad game, mind you. Art direction is good, writing is decent, although plot is nothing to write home about. Some of the characters are quite interesting (D'Angelo the nosferatu I really liked).
What is wrong with this game is the "game" part. I've read a lot of "choose youe  own adventure" books in my childhood, so I think I can see a good one when I see it. Coteries of New York is just not one of them. 
When you have a chioice to make, it always feels like a coin flip, as you do not have any element to base your choice on. That basically ruins the entire experience for me. I would have enjoyed it more as a simple visual novel, without choices to make. Just tell me a good story and we're ok.
I just hope we'll have  better luck with Bloodlines 2.

I did like this game with a few reservations. The writing is great and I enjoyed the side stories a lot. The artwork is basic but decent and manages to be decently atmospheric.

It does have a few problems though:
The first is that is seems VERY railroaded. Don't want to split up, bad luck you have to. Don't want to meet with someone, bad luck the story says you have to. Want to sneak attack? Your companion will auto ruin it and make it a frontal attack anyway etc. It's not even done in a round about fashion. You make a decision and it is automatically cancelled. Don't expect a deep and branching narrative here where your decisions frequently lead to large overall story changes.

The second and larger complaint is the ending. It just kind of stops. It feels as if it's lacking a number of extra chapters but the designers ran out of time, or never made part two. You're left on a cliffhanger that will never be resolved which leaves a bad taste (pun not intended) after doing so much right to make you invested in the story. 

Anyway, recommend if you like visual novels, are willing to overlook the ending and focus more on the side stories, and don't plan to play it more than twice at most as its replay value will likely be very limited. For a deeper, longer game with more bang for your buck try Vampire masquerades bloodlines instead. If you're looking for a VTM story to fill the gap, this one is worth a read though. Recommend on sale.

It's a visual novel, it's vampire the masquerade.  If you like both you will probably like it.  If you dislike either you probably won't like it.

Classic story of an embrace and introduction to kindred politics.  Ends with a bit of a fizzle.

Decisions mostly affect which scenes and side-quests you experience but don't have a lot of impact on plot or outcome.

column8:
In terms of visual art, the game is azaming and the plot is great BUT as a narrative role-playing game is quite disappointing:
 1. The end is the same, no matter what options who choose. Different paths for the same conclusion.
 2. There are not as many as player interventions as expected. And those interventions vary little among characters.
 3. I can't help but have the feeling that ther is some unfinished business with some characters. For example the Sheriff, it seems that is more story to tell but the game ends anyway and you dont learn anything else about him.
 4. NO VOICE ACTING. I cant belive how a narrative-pc-role-playing game has no voice cast. It takes away a lot of vibe from the game, It makes it plain. 

I give it a  "meh", and i really hope to see a better, more developed version of this game because the main idea was great and it could offer much much more.

column8:
I've played a few visual novels in my time, and this is a pretty run of the mill one. it offers a fantastic insight into the latest development of the world of darkness, vampire timeline; how the world of vampire would survive (or struggle) in the modern day. 
it could greatly benefit from a better or easier save and load function. i enjoy exploring my options and their near lack of a save and load function AND any semblance of a skip button, would make navigating different branches tedious. im not looking forward to it. 
i can respect a game that makes you commit to your options, but in a game where its primary purpose is to provide exposition, that decision just seems senseless?

column8: Interesting drama and history +10

This game really does the dark dank atmosphere of VTM well, even though its merely a VN I was captivated and engaged with each scene, environment and character. The soundtrack is perfect and blends seamlessly into this dark world while retaining a VTM flavour. I enjoyed my play through and liked how during my entire experience I felt as though I was carving my own path, although the locked ending made it feel as if my choices were all for nought. The pace was great throughout most of the story but felt a little rushed towards the end. During my time playing there were many moments where I was left staring at my screen unsure what path to take which I LOVED and I really appreciated the feeding system, its the little things that truly bring immersion.

I LOVED the characters in this VN, and hoped the coterie I forged would play a larger role in the grand scheme of things.
My favourite characters would be Qadir, Agathon, D'Angelo, Tamika and cute lil Silvia who pulled at my humanity strings while being in the mindset of a monster and I thought that was a clever touch.
Well done guys x Looking forward to more.

column8: A little disappointed. Nothing really matters no matter what you do and you are forced into only one path. This game is great if you have no idea what VTM is so I think it's great for a beginner looking to get into the lore but otherwise, I felt bored that I had to sit through the same conversations with no difference of who my character was. I did like the explorations into further lore and it helped me grasp how 5e runs roleplay wise, but yeah :/ I wish the side quests were the entire story. I hate that you have to be a b1tchass bootlicker no matter what. You die unless you lick them boots the entire time and that's p lame. I guess we'll see how VtMB2 goes. I do think it's a little more expensive than what it's worth sadly.

column8:
Sono un giocatore di Vampire: The Masquerade dalle prime edizioni del cartaceo. Ho sempre amato il WoD. Ho giocato tutti i giochi del WoD. Sono stato quindi preso dall'entusiasmo all'uscita di Coterie of New York. Ho appena finito il gioco, dopo circa 10 ore. Sostanzialmente, si tratta di una visual novel ambientata nel WoD. A parte qualche animazione sullo sfondo, non aspettatevi combattimenti mozzafiato o creazione del personaggio. E' un libro animato, sar√† tutto nella vostra testa, il che assolutamente non mi dispiace. Ma sinceramente non consiglierei di acquistare il gioco se non a prezzi scontati, e solo a chi gi√† possiede libri del WoD, semplicemente perch√© non c'√® gioco. Si presenta come una visual novel dove le proprie scelte contano, ma in realt√† ci si muove praticamente sempre su binari prestabiliti e la sensazione andr√† peggiorando man mano si procede nel gioco. La storia di per se √® molto corta e alcuni punti della narrativa sono abbastanza deboli. Non si avverte mai una reale sensazione di pericolo, il gioco tiene la sua strada e vi racconta i fatti. 
Se volete leggere un racconto breve di WoD, √® ok, sopratutto se preso scontato. E' degno di nota anche il comparto artistico, tanto che consiglio di comprare i nuovi DLC contenenti colonna sonora e artbook, sopratutto quest'ultimo √® notevole. Ma se cercate un gioco dove le scelte contano, Coterie of New York non fa per voi. 

Da qui in poi spoiler.
[spoiler] La cosa che pi√π mi ha turbato del gioco √® stata la fine. Pensavo ce ne fossero una discreta quantit√† disponibili, invece √® sempre e solo la stessa. Non importa se riusciate a tirare su la vostra coterie oppure no. Se ve ne andate in giro ad azzannare gente oppure no. La fine rimarr√† sempre la stessa. Questo distrugge completamente il senso di scelta che il gioco, almeno fino alla met√†, dava l'impressione di avere. La maggior parte dei capitoli sembrano lasciati a met√†. I vostri compagni, ognuno dei quali ha a disposizione un capito di quest da completare per aggiungerlo al proprio gruppo, sono caratterizzati fino a un certo punto, come se il nocciolo della storia fosse stato lasciato appeso per qualche altra possibilit√†. Si inizia facendo sperare a una caratterizzazione importante del personaggio, per poi essere lasciati a met√† a fine del capito, con una sorta di "grazie, arrivederci, adesso faccio parte del tuo gruppo". Fanno parte del tuo gruppo, che non esiste. Infatti la tua coterie non verr√† mai messa in gioco o visualizzata se non poco prima della fine per cinque secondi. Anche questo contribuisce al senso di inutilit√† delle proprie azioni. Il gioco trova sempre un modo per costringerti ad arrivare al finale.[/spoiler]

I liked it as a visual novel type of game. I enjoyed the characters and the missions. However the final chapter happens suddenly and out of nowhere, forcing the player out of any sidequest or build up and abruptly ends the game. Leaving you with no choice what so ever. After that you are forced to restart the game from scratch. Needless to say that ruined my experience. It's kinda annoying that the characters are set and not customizable but not game breaking. Played as Ventrue first but regretted that decision as the clan flaw is basically unmanageable when feeding is limited to scripted scenes.

column8:
What I did like: I really enjoyed the art and setting of the game. Having played both the pen & paper RPG, Vampire Bloodlines and Redemption, it was nice to see another Vampire: The Masquerade game.

What I did not like: Players have almost zero agency on the game ending. The choices that you can make basically do not affect the ending, so it does not have a lot of replayability. You can learn more about other NPCs stories, if you are into that, thought

column8:
I just finished the game and my opinions are very mixed. 

The game is pretty short in that it cuts off a lot of the quest paths. It ends in a way that feels extremely premature. You start building your "squad" in anticipation of some sort of building... then suddenly the story gets thrown into fast forward and then is abruptly stopped on a cliffhanger. It made the relationships you were trying to build feel meaningless. It made your decisions feel meaningless. 

I think the game had a ton of potential but it's just so damn short and I can't help but ask why it's so short since the things that usually make a game take longer to make are absent (there aren't graphics, a combat system, nor voice acting). I dunno. 

I guess if I had to summarize: Thematically fun, sets an fun atmosphere and despite no voice acting or combat system it's surprisingly engaging. But it's short, the game moves forward rapidly... cutting off questlines for what seems like no good reason (force replayability?). It's an okay game but I'll say that I don't think it's worth $20. At all. Catch it on sale.

column8:
I've enjoyed this game.

I'll start with my two complaints: this first one may be because I chose to play the only female protagonist, the Ventrue, but my first impression of the writing is very much "men writing women." Sexism (what men think experiencing sexism is like, really) is overplayed, and the introduction to this character feels kind of weird in that way. Second, the way this game is structured assumes you've never touched VtM or World of Darkness in your life - which, granted, can be really useful if you haven't, but as someone who's been playing the tabletops since the 2000s, the constant dictionary updates are more intrusive than anything. Although I have no problem playing as a neonate, that's something I wish I could turn off - I know what a coterie and elysium are. Most Vampire players do.

Now for the positives: this game is GORGEOUS. It's immediately obvious how much attention to detail went into the artistic construction of this game. Backgrounds are immersive and visually pleasing, character art is beautiful and expressive. I don't see a ton of visual novels that go out of their way like this to include well put together animations. Shadows on the wall, lighting changes, rain, little details that really make the impression.

Character writing is also very strong. Lots of consideration went into character building. I'm reminded of Mass Effect 2 - meeting new characters, completing quests to earn their trust. I enjoy that kind of thing, and the freedom this game gives you to pursue whatever storyline intrigues you most. Significantly, the character writing does a great job of avoiding some cliches you often run into in VtM. I'm really taken by them all - the Tremere, the Nosferatu, but I'm extra appreciative of the Malkavian. Her introduction is one of the most creative conversations I've ever seen, and I seriously admire how much attention was paid to these characters' personalities, philosophies, positionalities, and motivations.

I think this game is overall enjoyable and extraordinarily well written. This game gives the sense of intrigue and political storyline that many VtM storytellers aspire to, and I'm glad I got this game.

column8:
The game is really interesting and you do feel that VTM vibe through the game. I'm just gonna say my points, good and bad.
- Wait for a discount
- Your choices don't have an impact because there is really only one ending
- Not a long game at all (I beat it in 6hrs)
- Can't flesh out the interesting side-characters because the game feels like it rushes you into the main quest
- Some plots will never be finished at all ( Don't want to spoil)
- The entire story leading up to the ending is actually good

Overall, the game's story is actually interesting (Besides the ending), the side-characters and even the main ones are really fun to explore and learn more about, and this game really gives you an informative dip into the VTM world. It's worth a buy just wait for a cheaper price, won't recommend it full price

Overall Coteries of New York is a decent Vampire: The  Masquerade experience so if you need your fix before Bloodlines 2 comes out then you may want to check this one  out.  
  
However the game is rather short (it can be completed in 3 to 5 hours) and the ending came out of nowhere and kicked me in the balls as the plot was starting to pick up speed... or in other words I thought the game was fun but ultimately unsatisfying.

I wouldn't recommend this game at 20‚Ç¨/$ so I would advise people to wait for sales.

column8:
Big fan of the tabletop and I was looking forward to a well written, atmospheric adventure type game. The writing is good and images are great but the 'gameplay' is very limited. The story is presented one or two sentences at a time which gets very monotonous as you sit there pressing continue all the time. 
Occasionally you get a choice in what to do though Im not sure if it really makes a difference. What broke it for me were the bugs. I got to a point where some of the text looped but worse I was presented with options and text which didnt match the choices I made earlier and obviously corresponded to a different story branch. As a professional software developer and a gamer there is no excuse for this type of error. Technically this is a very simple game whose strength is on the writing and presentation - this type of bug is inexcusable and completely breaks it for me.

column8: This game could have been a great Vampire: The masquerade visual novel; and at first it actually is. It also gives a great introduction to the 5th edition of the RPG. Unfortunately, it is a very very rushed game and after the first couple of nights you realise the game is far from a finished product. It is definitely a shame because with more depth to the story arcs and more paths and endings (now there is only one, and its plottwist is horrible from the lack of depth given to the characters implied) it can be a memorable game.

column8: So far, and about 2 hours in; I could write this up as the most immersive Vampire game to date. It started out as a Dark Ages Quest for the Brujah---and then, it was added a 'flippy combat system' in Bloodlines. This is great for gaming and storytelling in general. It's just as ambitious as the previous titles and its clear that its content; which is what fans are truly after- pulls no punches. It would be great to see an expanse of the WOD universe in this vein - although I would recommend a SQL style Dice box and equipment mini game. (locations and progressive stats items, to reflect a possible 'gang-land' or 'Chaos Overlords'(mac) like a card game overlay....can't think of one that would suit....this...) Or something to create a sense of actual progressive combat or development for the characters. But even as a true blue, novelization-based adventure- its top rate for setting, style and characterization. I am enjoying this title and am excited to see what the Studio has to offer in the future. I think its been long over due for story campaigns.
column9: So far, and about 2 hours in; I could write this up as the most immersive Vampire game to date. It started out as a Dark Ages Quest for the Brujah---and then, it was added a 'flippy combat system' in Bloodlines. This is great for gaming and storytelling in general. It's just as ambitious as the previous titles and its clear that its content; which is what fans are truly after- pulls no punches. It would be great to see an expanse of the WOD universe in this vein - although I would recommend a SQL style Dice box and equipment mini game. (locations and progressive stats items, to reflect a possible 'gang-land' or 'Chaos Overlords'(mac) like a card game overlay....can't think of one that would suit....this...) Or something to create a sense of actual progressive combat or development for the characters. But even as a true blue, novelization-based adventure- its top rate for setting, style and characterization. I am enjoying this title and am excited to see what the Studio has to offer in the future. I think its been long over due for story campaigns.

column8: Your choices do not matter, the ending is the same regardless of how you proceed, and the main antagonist is a minor character you only ever see twice before the finale. Honestly, this game just feels like a cash grab sporting the Vampire: The Masquerade title, knowing those of us who are eagerly waiting for Bloodlines 2 would buy this just to tide us over while we wait. Don't buy it, save your money for a better game.

column8:
Great idea, pretty shoddy execution. I love the world of Vampire The Masquerade, and the game almost manages to catch the mood of the world of darkness perfectly. It hits notes constantly with decent characters and fitting gameplay.
The problem comes when you start getting into the story. It is not particularly well written, it is WAY TOO SHORT, and the ending is mildly speaking as disappointing. 

Especially the lenght of the game is terrible. It ends where it should begin! This makes me hate the game and become very very critical of the writers since it makes the storyline weak and pointless. So even though I like the gameplay and some of the characters, the lack of immersion into the world of darkness and the weak writing combined with a very very short story, I would not recommend this to anyone.

column8:
The only people I'd recommend this game to are Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines fans who are starving for more content, and even then, it's iffy. I had high expectations, and while the game is pretty, those expectations were let down. Hard. The biggest design points of the game- story and character development- are neglected, and this is mostly due to how fucking short this game is. Your choices mean nothing, and the characters are dry and uninteresting.
Overall, I feel this game would do better with more impactful choices, different endings, better character development, and a longer story. VTM: Coteries of New York was not worth what I payed for it, even though I got it on sale.

column8:
Although I'm not very fond of vampires in general, I really enjoyed playing Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines, so I was eager to play another game in the same universe.
While Coteries of New York is a game in a different genre, it clearly inherited the spirit of Bloodlines: one can notice it both in the dialogues and in the music.
The three characters you are offered to choose from represent three different stereotypes, but you are not forces to play the roles assigned to them by the developers. Your choices will mark the way for your chosen protagonist.
As a visual novel, Coteries of New York is quite complete. It has an interesting story, some charismatic characters and even some unexpected twists.
The only downside of this game is that there is only one ending. Yes, you can die, but, if you survive through the ordeals, the finale is inevitable.
Despite that last point, I enjoyed this game and definitely recommend it to both the fans of Vampire: The Masquerade and the visual novel fans alike.

column8:
If you love Vampire: The Masquerade and are okay with visual novels, this game is definitely worth considering. Don't get me wrong, Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Coteries of New York is a deeply flawed game with some glaring issues. The game is a bit short, the ending is a mess, several popular clans are missing, and there's limited choices to be made, especially at the end. 

Despite these flaws, I loved this game quite a bit for what it is. The atmosphere and tone matches the tabletop game nearly perfectly, even more so than VTMB I'd say. The story is gripping enough, the characters are quite likable. There is expressive role playing options in the form of flavor text. Most of these dialogue options don't lead to actual choices, but they are good enough to allow the player to get into the roleplay. This plays out especially well in the tense social exchanges. 

This game is definitely worthwhile for fans of the tabletop game and/or bloodlines/redemption. There's some merit here even for new players too. The game is a pretty great introduction to those who have never experienced the setting before and want to give it a shot.

column8:
This game has it's own charm despite being simple. The visuals are stunning, however this game is all about reading and clicking therefore it may not be for you if reading throws you off.

Story: A little cliche, due to the initiation of the main character. The selling point would be Sophie who you serve, she keeps a mysterious aura that keeps the player wanting more. The other characters along the are diverse in personally and background.
Gameplay: I have seen and understood why there have been players disappointed because at times I have noticed the story seems to be pushing the player in a linear direction despite having choices in conversations. I will say though when dealing with certain quests choices have varied in results.
Conclusion: I want to show games like this love because to repeat it has a unique charm in the visuals and music that draws the player and seduces them

column8: All the characters have nice stories, except you -- only one final available!

Enjoying the table top version of Vampire: The Masquerade, I got into the game quite excited, and I must say the early part capture the ambiance very well. Then the last night comes up, and it captures very well the feel of a rpg session where the dm ran out of time, and expose everything at the end before you just end. It's abrupt, brought in a non natural way and completely independant of your actions. You barely get to say anything then, you're just recieving exposition, non of what you before had consequences. 

In the end a great start but falls completely flat at then end, which ruins the game

column8:
This is a game more reminiscent of a choose your own adventure, and honestly it is way too short.  Just when you feel that you are starting to get into the game, it ends. The ending felt very abrupt to me as well.  I finished it in 4 hours, and was not rushing at all.  Hell, I didn't see the ending happening, and was shocked when the credits started to roll.

It's not a bad game, but not worth the 4 hours for the price.  Not sure if they have any intention to add to it,  but if they doubled the size of the game, or gave more clues that the ending was coming, then maybe I would recommend it.  But in it's current state, it needs to be under 10 to buy.

Just finished my first run through the game.
Writing was excellent, story was a bit slow at the beginning as it has to instruct newcomers to the whole VtM lore and rules, but then things started and I was really hooked. Different paths and quests to focus on, great characters and awesome setting.
With some more money and a bit more polish this could have been a masterpiece.
As it is (too short, now I really want to meet those characters again!), it a solid visual novel set in one of the most fascinating gaming worlds ever.
An appetizer to Bloodlines 2? Maybe that's the main issue here: it could have worked beautifully also on its own, so if you love vampire stories, visual novels and the WoD setting, you'll love it.

column8:
5 stars out of 10. The good elements are quite good, but the bad elements are extremely disappointing. 

Pros:
Beautiful artwork
Good story
Interesting characters that, despite the simplicity of the game, are really well fleshed out

Cons:
It's a railroad masquerading (pun intended) as an RPG. Your choices don't matter. And for a game that's as simple as this one is - in interface, art, and story - which presents you with so many choices, that is a cardinal sin. I was so close to giving this a thumbs down. It's fun for a couple playthroughs (which you can finish in a few hours), but once you've seen everyone's story, there's no point in ever playing it again.

column8:
This is my first visual novel type of game. I purchased it because I am a big fan of the World of Darkness.

The game plays like you would expect it to, like one of the old "Make your own adventure" type books. You choose your option and the story progresses with the consequences of your choices.

The backgrounds, while primarily static, are beautiful and capture the spirit of the World of Darkness very well. The characters are interesting, and all of them have an agenda. The music is fine, but nothing out of the ordinary.

I am sad to say, however, that the game devolves with time. For the first 90 minutes or so the story was consistent with the choices I made. Some slight incoherence with what information I have been given, but nothing major.

At later stages, it happens more and more that the answers I can give all rely on things that never happened, and none of the choices can ignore that.

Feeding is a weird mechanic that doesn't work. The designers probably wanted to incorporate it more subtle, so they decided to make your blood hunger a border around the screen. The more red, the worse the hunger gets. However, the rules are inconsistent most of the time, and do not work some of the time. You cannot go feed. You only can progress in the story and hope there's a choice where you can feed. Sometimes, even feeding doesn't do anything to the red border. Sometimes, the game claims you needed blood to heal wounds, yet my decisions prevented the wounds. You lose the blood anyway, with the consequences that brings.

Buy it at a reduced price, but do not expect the game to follow your choices.

column8:
The game has a lot of pros and cons. A lot of the cons are disappointments I have with nearly every visual novel game, so it was still worth recommending despite them.

Pros:
*Beautiful Art
*Diverse and inclusive character design
*There are choices in which side stories to do. Depending on how you interact with side NPCs, it changes who helps you in the end.
*Immersive music
*UI is easy to control/understand
*Nice edition to VtM world.

Cons:
*Other than choosing who your allies are and having a choice in what side stories are completed, ultimately, your decisions mean squat. You come out to the same ending no matter what. Sadly, although this is disappointing, not many VN games really do any better... 
*I specifically tried to be nice. 1st NPC response would play. I specifically was a pain in the ass. 1st NPC response would play...Again, you'd think there would be more divergence in how NPCs respond to you. But alas...nope. You pretty much end up at the same place with the key NPCs. For the side characters you DO have a chance to change their decisions, as stated above, but that again doesn't really change how the game plays out. Which in a good narrative, it SHOULD.
*There was some lack of care with side narration. As before, I would react in different ways with each play through, with each character, and the narration would either miraculously be the same despite the events of the night before being very different, or the player character's inner dialogues were all exactly the same. Not exactly immersive.
*They left several big threads hanging. I kept thinking, maybe there is some way, some dialogue I can choose, to see that character again? Nope...(Examples: Juno and the other faction! Let's continue that arc! Nope... Had to beat down a spy to get his master's name and with great success, I get it! But that goes no where...etc...etc..)

Over all: The game was still fun. I am big fan of VtM and always welcome more content. And I am sure that a game with the art and sound design as beautiful as it was, took a lot of hard work and I commend them. But the narration and story could have been soooo much better. Play it for the simple story and the beautiful vamps, but don't expect a deep, immersive story.

You pretty much end up at the same place with the key NPCs. For the side characters you DO have a chance to change their decisions, as stated above, but that again doesn't really change how the game plays out. Which in a good narrative, it SHOULD.
*There was some lack of care with side narration. As before, I would react in different ways with each play through, with each character, and the narration would either miraculously be the same despite the events of the night before being very different, or the player character's inner dialogues were all exactly the same. Not exactly immersive.
*They left several big threads hanging. I kept thinking, maybe there is some way, some dialogue I can choose, to see that character again? Nope...(Examples: Juno and the other faction! Let's continue that arc! Nope... Had to beat down a spy to get his master's name and with great success, I get it! But that goes no where...etc...etc..)

Over all: The game was still fun. I am big fan of VtM and always welcome more content. And I am sure that a game with the art and sound design as beautiful as it was, took a lot of hard work and I commend them. But the narration and story could have been soooo much better. Play it for the simple story and the beautiful vamps, but don't expect a deep, immersive story.

column8:
Well, this is really hard. If steam had the "meh" rating, I would probably choose that one. But I'm more leaning to "it's good for what it is, but flawed".

So, anyway. First of all, this is a VN, choose-your-own-adventure book, basically. This is not the first time VTM ventures into this territory, but the previous attempt, called "We Eat Blood and All our Friends are Dead" was... in my opinion, horrible (suffice to say I basically forced myself though it, and didn't enjoy it very much at all). So first of all, Coteries is leagues better than that piece of... unique gaming history. Is it good though? That's the big question, ain't it. Well, let's get into it.

The good:
+ Writing, for the most part, is good. Some parts are better than others. I've especially enjoyed the Maklavian girl, who is... rather unique, to put it lightly. The ending though... not that good. And there's only one, except the "you died" ones, so the experience is somewhat railroaded.
+ Art. While nothing ground-breaking, it's pleasant enough to look at.
+ Replay value. Not as much as it would've had with multiple (and better-written) endings, but there is some, given you have three clans to choose from (which in fact change the backstory for the protagonist).

The not-so-bad:
* Music... it's there. It's not distracting or awful, and it's not amazing either. Although sound design in places is a little... let's call it questionable. Like for instance at one time you go into a bar with a live band playing. Background music doesn't stop there, and it keeps clashing with the band's "performance". The segment is thankfully short, but it really got on my nerves while it lasted. These lapses are rare though, for the most part, it's alright.
* Character graphics are mostly static. It's not a negative per se, and the images themselves are beautifully drawn. But for some of us who are more used to Japanese VNs this might look a little... well, stilted, at least at first.

The ugly:
- There's no "save at will" function, as you would expect with a VN. Which means no undoing choices. While this might be a deliberate choice on the devs' part, I think it's not a good one. For one, I mis-clicked a couple times, and had no way to correct that. For two, after I've played through the story once, I basically know "the truth", and in the absence of multiple endings, it makes replaying the game to find little tidbits I might've missed needlessly tedious.
- There's no "skip" function either (or maybe I didn't find one, but then it's pretty well-hidden). Which is equally bad for the reasons explained above
- The ending... it's just... well, to keep it spoiler-free, it's like an unholy union between a Chekhov's gun and a deus ex machina. And I'm willing to bet a couple hundred crispy American dollars that the Chekhov's gun part was inserted into the story when the finale was already written. And the finale was probably written after the writer realized that the thing they were building up to made little to no sense and they needed a resolution, stat. Hence the "deus ex machina" comes out of the clouds and resolves the plot, almost exactly like in bad ancient Greek tragedy. So yeah, if you couldn't tell, very disappointing, 0/10 yadda yadda. The thing is, until the last night, the writing's mostly good, except the main plot kinda makes less sense the more you know, until it doesn't make sense at all.

So, to summarize, it's mostly okay to good. But it lacks some quality-of-life features that make it harder to recommend, and writing takes a sudden left turn for the worst by the ending of the main plot, which ends up leaving a sour aftertaste after an otherwise pleasant enough experience.

So yeah, I'll give it a weak "thumbs up", but it's not all good.

column8: This is far superior to your average "visual novel" style of game. You're not just on rails through the story, you have lots of choices to make, powers you can use and a hunger mechanic to deal with. If you like to roleplay in the World of Darkness, this is good fun! Short but with good replay value since you cannot get to every story in 1 play through.

column8: Excellent game.  Felt like playing a real life chronicle that unraveled night by night...cannot recommend this game enough.  If you don't like visual novels but do like role-playing...give it a chance.  If you are looking for a genuine VtM experience prior to Bloodlines 2, this is it!  I am about to search out more source material related to this game.  Hoping that a New York setting becomes available as canon and this game's characters continue.  Well done!

column8: This game had a lot going for it, but in reality it is really just way too short. It definitely has some good stories and was fun to play, just to short to really enjoy it. As what others have said it has a great feel to the Vampire: The Masquerade table top, but right at the time you are getting settled in playing the game it rushes to an end, which is a big let down. Personally I would like for it to be very long, expanded stories, more characters to meet and work with, deeper involvement (getting your own haven, cash flow, ghouls, feeding, etc..) , and maybe add some more clans available to use. In its current state, I do not agree with the cost, maybe around 5 dollars at most, since once it ends you feel like you just did only a tutorial or a prologue, not a full game. Maybe they will improve and expand the length and add more content...

column8:
I'm not really sure what to make of this game.

It captured the world of World of Darkness well; Many of the characters were well written and engaging, some had even a little bit of depth to them and some were even refreshing.  The background art is well drawn out and the background music adds a nice ambience.

But the ending? It just feels like a big let down. This is a complete game, folks, with no part two or known sequel in the works as of this date. And it ends on what feels like a bad car crash of a cliffhanger.  And maybe Cliffhanger isn't the right word, but whatever.  You spend all this time engaging with other vampires, building up a network of "friends" and in the end the way they're used is rather insulting, at least to me.


I do not recommend this game at full price. On a steep sale? If you like VN's with some choices, sure. If you're a diehard fan of the WoD/VTM franchise? Maybe, it should at least scratch an itch while we wait to see if VTMB2 isn't going to be a complete letdown. For people looking to get into WoD/VTM? Stay away, go play VTMB1 and grab that unofficial patch to make it run on modern hardware. (or pick it up on GOG where it *should* run out the gate)

column8: It's more a book with choices than an RPG. But it's a good book with interesting characters and a good story that i truly enjoy.

es entretenido pero claro bastante debil si lo comparas con una novela grafica como las desarrolladas como las walking dead de telltale  o life is strange de dontnod, y aun con todo en contra, lo que logra salvar este titulo es que las historias de vampiro la mascarada siempre enganchan con la premicia de que ninguna historia es tan tan simple como se ve, no hay buenos ni malos en el mundo vampirico, solo un jugador mejor o con mas suerte que el otro en este mundo de oscuridad que nos presenta VTM, respecto al dise√±o de los personajes me dio la impresion de que unos fueron hechos con flojera o desidia y otros con mucho, mucho mas detallados
This is an excellent visual novel that pays great homage to its inspiration, "Vampire: The Masquerade", a fantastic table-top RPG.

column8: Good game, a bit short but does have the vibes of world of darkness. Good mood varmup while waiting ro WtM2.

EDIT: I wanted to change my iffy review to a recommendation but, unfortunately I'm changing it to a HARD PASS. The developers were promising new content but actually released a more expensive "deluxe version". They release zero additional game play and didn't include branching story lines. YOUR CHOICES LITERALLY DO NOT MATTER. SAYING THEY DO IS A BLATANT LIE. THE ENDING IS THE SAME. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. 

Initial Review:
I was torn on whether or not to recommend this game. For the full price, $20, it's a no. If you get this on sale, I'd say go for it. I enjoyed my time with it except for the ending. The ending is very, very bad. [spoiler] The end is like a terrible campfire story where "it turns out it was the minor character you met once and didn't care about all along!" I honestly couldn't even remember who that character was or where I'd met them before. [/spoiler] As someone else said, if this were a prologue to a real story, it would be much better. I hope the developers add to this so I can change my recommendation to yes.

column8: I love Vampire the Masquerade! And Coteries of New York provides solid base knowledge about the Kindred society. Because everything is so well explained, I would definitely recommend it to freshly introduced Ghouls. The artworks and character designs are stunning and the music... I could sit there and listen to the title screen music for hours! It creates an atmosphere, the feeling of the beast lurking inside you, while you have to keep it "tame" and slake your hunger. The game really makes you feel like you're part of this Kindred society and politics. I just adore it! (Even though I think a Malkavian playthrough would've been super interesting)

column8:
Like most other reviews say, it's a VN with a terrible ending and your choices don't matter. Still, it could be worse (it could be Preludes), so if you're heavily invested in the Vampire: The Masquerade mythos, it's not the worst read. I don't regret my time or money spent, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone but the most hardcore VtM fan. Even then, a heavy discount is the way to go.

Pros:
- Great art
- The game kept me interested enough to WANT to keep coming back to get to know the side characters and side stories

Cons:
- Dialogue choices are essentially fluff and often don't turn out the way they appear when you choose them. Sometimes they go so far as to make your character say some straight up edgelord garbage
- Speaking of edgelord garbage, there's a good amount here, in sadly typical Vampire: The Masquerade fashion. Honestly though, not as bad as I expected, to be fair
- Choices don't matter
- Your "coterie" doesn't matter
- The ending is sudden and nonsensical. This is made worse by the fact that it also includes characters you may have had little to no contact with unless you've done specific side stories that you likely did not have time to do, depending on your priorities/interests
- The game also ends with a literal choice, but it cuts to the credits before the player can make it. Really cements the pointlessness of the player's actions

I don't regret my time or money spent, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone but the most hardcore VtM fan. Even then, a heavy discount is the way to go.

column8:
From the start, this was the first game i picked up which follows the masquerade series (even if its supposed to be a side one). I liked the game, and was excited to play more of it, until the ending came in. 
In terms of gameplay, its just a lot of reading .. 
The story starts pretty good, and keeps on building up itself, but sadly drops really hard and ends (when it really should continue) 
As an RPG, u get to choose what to say and what to do, but it has limited effect on how characters will react to u (or even remember u said it after a while). And ur actions are pretty much meaningless XD 
However, since this was the first game i picked up, it still introduces me to the world.. explained most of the things and kinda took my hand through it all.  

im looking to try the bloodlines one, and then wait for the second's release in April!!

column8: As someone who has played VTM since 2002 this was really enjoyable. It took about 3 hours to play through one story line with one set of choices.  There was a lot of other choices I could have made.  I would say you could play through each clan's story a minimum of three times.  There are three clans to pick from, so this has a good amount of game play in it to me.  Beautiful artwork, great story, lots of replay value. 10/10

column8: It is very good as a choose your own adventure but it does seem to have the one ending, besides early deaths, unless some one has found out something I haven't.
column9: It is very good as a choose your own adventure but it does seem to have the one ending, besides early deaths, unless some one has found out something I haven't.

column8:
Interesting choice for all VtM/WoD lovers. Its a good game, even though you will probably play it once (maybe twice if you really want to check all possibilites). If you play it at late night, alone in your flat, sipping good wine (assuming you are adult!) it will surely make immersion better. Dedicated players will probably finish their gameplay in one night. 

On the positive side:
+ carefully played WoD theme
+ nice, ambient music
+ if you like intriguing vampires, you will love the story
+ if you played classic VtM, you will find yourself in well-known atmosphere
+ nice visual side, even if almost static (no animations)
+ good story

On the negative side:
- very linear storyline
- your dialogue choices usually are rather narration-building than storyline-creators (apart from critical failure triggers, which are rare)
- your first choice of a protaginist makes very little difference in the story
- only predefined characters (3 of them)

My score: 4/5.

Pretty nice, yes it is linear, but it's better to have a good linear story than garbage with "choices". The only bad thing about the ending is that it comes too soon, otherwise its 100% true to the setting [spoiler] There are only 12 players in this world (debatably 1) and everyone else is pawns no matter what they think about themselves [/spoiler]. 

On the pro side:
- The art style is on point
- The tone is 100% correct
- Interesting characters with interesting stories
-A lot of references and obscure things that are never explained but do much to enrich the game and show the mastery over setting [spoiler] just for example, Sabat is never mentioned directly but Benoit is Toreador antitribu and Juno uses thaumaturgic disciplines unique to the Sabat Tremere which pretty much defines their alignment. Also countless interpretations of tabletop mechanics into the text narration[/spoiler]
     Overall, the game is perfectly true to the original and that is what matters
On the cons side:
- Pretty much all the games with so-called "multiple choices" have only decorative ones and that's fine, the problem here is that it's done very cheaply/fastly resulting in a very shallow see-through effect
- Remember how i said character stories were interesting, well it would be better if 2 out of 4 would actually resolve, another nail in premature ending coffin [spoiler] Tamika and Agathon namely never really get to end [/spoiler]
- Game is very short, just when you think it will be even better it ends, which makes ending more effective in what it tries to portray [spoiler] VtM is a terrible place where everyone is forever cursed through ancient blood bonds and nothing can save you no matter what [/spoiler] but that doesn't justify it
- Extremely cheap ways to hide the lack of replayability and scale [spoiler] Limited turns, no manual save, e.t.c. [/spoiler]
     Overall, when people say: "the ending is terrible" that means: "story was actually good" because if the story was bad no one would care to separate ending from it. There are passion and skill in this game but it is really transparent that it was made as a fast ad in the light of recent WoD reanimation which is a shame since developers seem to care deeply for the setting. I hope they get to do something bigger with the universe.

column8: A long-time fan of the Vampire: The Masquerade franchise, I entered into this game with considerable expectations. To my delight, the game held to them, with well written narrative and incredible artwork. If I had a criticism, it would be the lack of clan choices, as well as the fact that choices don't seem to have as great an impact on the overall storyline as one might hope.

column8:
OK, first off, this isn't a "game game" where you pew-pew-pew things into gore.  It's an atmospheric visual novel more-or-less which draws on a pretty rich world from the "Vampire: The Masquerade" role playing game. So if you like reading, vampires or role playing games, this game might be for you.  If you like pew-pew-pew-splatter, this game is definitely NOT for you.

This game is pretty short - you can complete it in 3-4 hours if you want. You can replay it to find out what happens when you make different response choices or pick different protagonists or different side-quests - there's no "text skip" button which can make clicking through dialog on replay a bit tedious.  I've played this game for 11 hours and I've gotten all the achievements unlocked except one and I'm not sure I want to bother with the one I don't have. 

But all in all, I had a lot of fun - I thought the audio cues were *right on* with the rest of the game play and overall, I hope that this studio decides they want to continue this story line - I would definitely play a "Chapter 2".

column8: I don't understand why everyone is raving about this game and how this is even considered a game? For the last hour, all I have been doing is reading text and picking choice answers, which apparently according to the reviews does not have an effect on the outcome.  So basically, what this is, is a story.  A novel.  An interactive one that really has no bearing on what interaction you take.  If this is what you think a GAME is, I want my money back. I want to play a game, not read a novel, I'm already doing that.  There is absolutely no game play involved.

I also like the music.  I enjoyed playing it quite a lot.

column8:
So reading the other reviews i can say everyone's criticism is valid in both the good and the bad. Coteries of New York does an incredible job of exploring the universe of the World of Darkness. the atmosphere, the characters and the world are all well written and interesting from the vampire politics to the personal stories of the characters. However this same strength highlights one of its biggest weaknesses.
  This story is unfinished, which is weird because many of the side stories within the game are complete and enjoyable from beginning to end. Unfortunately it is the Main story itself that has problems, while all the side stories have satisfying ends the main story in my opinion feels like the set up to a much larger story and the thing is, i want to continue this story because what it set up is actually very interesting and has some great potential. As someone has said here if this was "Coteries of New York Chapter 1" i think many of these reviews would be different and i even believe many of them would be a lot more excited.
  I also see people critiquing how your choices don't matter and honestly coming from someone who's played multiple visual novels i can definitely say this isn't uncommon, but thats still not an excuse. This alone might be a deal breaker for some but personally I enjoyed the story regardless.
  Still until we can get confirmation on if this story will continue you might want to leave this one alone if you don't like cliffhangers, but I will say the characters, side stories, and overall execution of the atmosphere makes the game worth it to anyone who loves the WoD universe or even to anyone who needs something to tide them over until Bloodlines 2 releases. Its a flawed game but still a worthy one.

column8:
To begin with, if you don't like visual novels, you won't like this visual novel. 

CoNY is possibly the best video game representation of Vampire: The Masquerade so far. It has the right vibe, fantastic art, great sound. If you're a V:TM fan, this is worth your time. 

I wish there were more. The game felt short, even playing through as all 3 clans and getting 100% achievements. Many of the options don't matter, nor do they feel like they matter. It would have been nice to have some more art of some of the more important moments. However, my criticisms are all basically "I want more!".

Bravo Draw Distance.

I've been a long time fan of the Vampire: The Masquerade franchising. I play the pen and paper since the first edition. I'm no expert in video game analysis and I won't pretend to be one here... The game is fun. It feels a lot like the real deal. It might be kinda boring at the beginning with all the texts and few animations, but as soon as the story catches up you'll find yourself curious to see what comes next. Well... at least I was. It's kind of a bummer that you only get to play as a Brujah, Ventrue or Tremere, but still, I had a good time playing it. I think it might be a little bit overpriced for what it offers... I mean, for a non-fan player. With just a little bit more one could buy a Telltale-like game with more animations and stuff, but as I said... I'm a fan, so I paid the full price and I don't regret doing it. If you are into reading, is a fan of the franchise and enjoy immersive stories, you'll probably like the game. If you didn't play the actual pen&papper, usually skip the dialog on games and just wanna kill stuff, this is not for you. Save your money.

So, hab das Spiel jetzt nach ca. 8 Stunden durchgespielt. Auf jeden Fall nicht das letzte mal, vermutlich fange ich gleich direkt nochmal an....

Meine Englischkenntnisse sind bestenfalls fragw√ºrdig. Aber f√ºr das Spiel hats, vlt auch weil ich ganz gut in der Vampirelore drin bin, locker gereicht. 

Was jedem klar sein muss ist, dass es sich hierbei nicht um ein Rollenspiel handelt, sondern um eine Art spielbaren Roman. Man bekommt ne Geschichte zum lesen in der die ein oder andere Entscheidung selber getroffen werden kann. 

Mir hat es sehr gut gefallen und wer die WoD mag wirds vermutlich auch m√∂gen.

column8: I thought I'd give this a try since Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines 2 comes out this year to re-familiarize.  First thing I noticed while playing is the choices you make doesn't matter at all.  The story line is a bit rushed and a bit confusing being at one place for a small amount then being like across town the next second and the night is gone.  For the price totally not worth it ($16.99 on Humble Bundle sale) I would be more comfortable with paying $5 to $10 but that is pushing it.  Very short play through, the ending was horrible.

column8:
So I just finished my first play-through after 9 1/2 hours.
As others have said, it's short and you are going to want more, but I truly enjoyed every single minute of it. And I will definitely start a new play-through again, choosing a different character, different style and attitude when it comes to making choices in the game, picking quests and dialog options. (You cannot finish all quests in one play-through, so to see it all, you must re-play.)

The art is just absolutely gorgeous and I want to bathe in it. The music is great, too. The characters are well written and the plot takes its surprise turns. 

I'd love to have some more indication about current hunger levels and how hunger works in the game. I'd want to see more content, more story. I would like some more different character portraits and some more sceneries (e.g. more than one back-alley). However, I know that Draw Distance is a small development studio and they certainly had a very limited budget for the game. I am not at all disappointed, but hoping to have these points addressed in the future - in bugfix releases, and free as well as paid DLC

I would buy it again. I will play it again. I absolutely recommend it. And I'd be very happy to see a "part 2".

So after 3 different playthroughs and 100%ing the game, I can happily recommend this game with some significant caveats. 

Pros
First WoD/Vampire game in 15 years, the clans, the universe, the tone. 
Gorgeous art style
Interesting and varied NPC's
Great atmosphere/audio

Cons
Visual Novel
Static predefined characters to choose from
Clan choice makes almost no difference during the entire playthrough
In fact, most choices make no difference to the story outside of the initial 3 options where two lead to game overs. 

All said and done, I enjoyed it for the first playthrough and got lost in the tone/atmosphere of the WoD. I really enjoy the lore of VtM and this gave me that. That said if it had not been so long since a Vampire game I might not have played though it more than once.

column9: Very short visual novel for fans of V:tM mostly. Ending wasn't great, felt very contrived and sudden. Overall: clever writing, pretty art, striking mood. Worth it IMO.

column8:
For those who have played Bloodlines back in the day, this brings the atmosphere back perfectly. The music, the looks, the characters. It's the first game based on the 5th edition, and it pulls it off really well.

I fully understand the choice of clans for the playable characters. It's not easy to get the disciplines working with a visual novel, and having only 6 disciplines work with really makes things simpler. However, the only character that seems to have it's clan disciplines only is the ventrue. I've got the presence, dominate and fortitude options throughout the story, but I got a dominate option with the torie once and dominate and auspex with the brujah a few times. Not sure if it was inteneded or not.

The ending feels weird as so many things are left unfinished. it feels like there has to be a sequel or some DLC coming.

In conclusion: This is a great nostalgia invoking experience for old WoD players or people that played Bloodlines. It's a game that takes vampire to the current age of social media and big tech. An awesome introductory experience for those who are just getting into WoD. And last but not least: it's an awesome filler whilst we wait for Bloodlines 2

column8:
[h1]Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York[/h1]
It is a visual novel based on the [b]Vampire: The Masquerade[/b] Pen & Paper RPG from White Wolf.
It combines some pseudo-RPG Elements, an appealing main story and interesting side quests in a short and sweet package with great soundtrack to back it up.

It is very intriguing and dark reflecting properly the entire style and experience of the *Wold of Darkness* Franchise that it takes place in. It is based on the fifth edition of Vampire and does give the player a bite of what it means to be unliving in the Camarilla dominated new york as a fledgling. 

While looking and feeling a lot like a traditional Visual Novel, VtM: CoNY does a few things right, but also seems to be falling short on quite a bit.

[u]Pros:[/u]
  - It implements the mechanics of the P&P game quite well for a visual novel.
  - It has amazing soundtrack that complements the grim dark and gritty nature of its world.
  - Unlike typical, usually static Visual Novels all backgrounds blend interestingly and include animations that make the background world pop and feel more alive.

[u]Cons:[/u]
  - It has some minor glitches though nothing actually game breaking, mostly text bugging but you can read it back from the log.
  - Seems very linear which sort of hurts replayability. since it only has 1 actual ending. 
  - Lacks typical extras you would find in other visual novels:
     Like an in-game artwork gallery, No Auto-progress for the text, or skip. Limited save slots without the option to quick-save/quick-load to explore alternative choices.
  - The character sprites are rigid and static while many VNs use several alternates to show different emotions.

Shortcomings aside, I did quite enjoy the game but the way the pacing and story went 
I would suggest to probably get it on sale than on full price. I also very much would love to see a sequel to it as the story feels a bit rushed and also shows signs of potential continuations happening in the future.

A press copy of this game was provided to me for content creation and review.

column8: Its a fun visual novel. Dont expect too much of it, but its well made and understands the setting.

column8:
Great game for a solid price. The story is very nicely done, some of the twists I did not expect and really took me by surprise, which I hardly ever see in this kind of games. The graphic and sound are not stellar, obviously,  but very adequate to the kind of game the developers actually intended to do.

What I lack? There is no kind of customization of your character, which would have been very appropriate for this game. I hope the developers will add this feature in some later update. There is lots of potential to expand the story, add new twists and endings etc., so I hope they will keep working at this aspect also.

Anyways, in its current state, I found it a very playable game and can wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone.

column8:
I think this is a beautiful introduction to the World of Darkness.
I'm by no means a veteran of VtM but I've played a bit and I think this game perfectly captures the tone and aesthetic of the setting.
Some may complain about the choices being meaningless but to me that's partly the beauty of the setting; you've just become part of this world. You're a fledgling who doesn't know anything about this world, so why would you be able to change everything in under two weeks?

Personally I felt it was a fantastic story which felt like a part of the world and felt much like a prologue-esque story you might have a group play through before starting a full on tabletop campaign.

I think if you go into this focused on the characters and the setting, rather fulfilling a power play fantasy, then you're unlikely to be disappointed.

I'd love to be able to recommend this game. I was longing for some of the good old 90's V:tM realness, and in many ways that's exactly what this VN serves up. Intrigue, backstabbing, side stories, all the good stuff. Unfortunately, I can't recommend it for a couple of reasons. First, because of the interface. Although a visual novel in most respects, Coteries does not have the option to fast forward dialogue you've already seen, or if it does I couldn't find it. It also doesn't let you keep multiple saves. Both of those things are standard with VNs, and the lack of them drastically reduces replayability. I really want to get through all of the side storylines, but at the same time I don't want to have to sit through the same intro and tutorial screens every time. The other issue is that there don't seem to be any branches to the story paths. There's a ton of atmosphere, as you'd expect, but you'll always be taken in by the same character and brought to the same conclusion. There are a few spots where you can get killed, but they're few and far between, and no matter how you act toward major characters, the story and their reaction to you doesn't change. I'd love to see a really great World of Darkness visual novel, but this isn't quite it.

column8:
100% Achievement completion in 15 hours, and that was with a bug that prevented some from working on my first couple of playthroughs. That's right, 15 hours and that is at least 3 playthroughs start to finish, one with each character, not to mention the partial playthroughs just to hit certain achievements.

Your choices mean nothing, which I guess is kind of the point of the ending? Even so, it does not make a good game. Several key events shake out exactly the same, no matter who your party is or what choices you have made up to that point.
