Frustratingly short with a VERY lackluster selection of playable clans, BUT ... the storytelling was EXTREMELY strong and engaging and leaves me hopeful for more. It ends just as things are getting REALLY good, though! UUUUUGH!!! 

For what it was, though, I still enjoyed my time with it a lot and look forward to further installments (which are DEFINITELY coming, the ending makes that painfully obvious). Maybe with a different selection of playable clans on the next time around...? <_<

column8:
Well. I don't even know where to start. There are a few things I find bad in this game.
Some of my friends didn't like it because it is based on the V5 core book, and I don't really care about that. But as a visual novel, it is just not good at all. Visuals are nice there, music is also fine. The main story tries to be accurate to VTM atmosphere, where your character is not a hero, he is a pawn and your actions are meaningless in the big picture. But this game made me feel like all the pieces on the board were already there and the MC is an extra that nobody needs. Personally I don't really get the reasons why MC just *had to* be at the place of story climax, or why they *had to be* the one running all those errands that progressed the plot. MC's involvement in things felt forced. Your interactions with NPCs doesn't really change anything, so does your clan - ending for the main story is always the same. So I just feel like this whole game just had no meaning, and not in a good way like VTM games are supposed to be.
The "journey" to the end is also disappointing. Some parts of the plot are plain boring to read, and I don't even know if that is the writing or the story itself. Honestly, probably both. 
And as for "replayability" marketing for this was talking about - there is none. At least for me. I would like to collect come more achievements or choose a different clan. But you can't save your game before you make choices to go back to them later. You have to just replay the whole game each time, and you can't skip dialogues you had already read. So it just kills all the curiosity I may have had for the other options.

I had fun with this game, however, I beat it in 4 hours.  This was with no failures and taking it kind of slow.  The rules of "bang for buck" dictate that this game costs too much.  I would pay $7 for this game tops, as it is, if I knew what I know now.  It's likely too much for me to hope for some free DLC with even something as simple as more clans.

Allow me to reiterate; it's fun (in a passive way) and pretty.  The art is decent and the animations on top are nice.  The story... exists.  No need to spoil anything.  You'll get whiplash or a small amount of neck strain from it.  More sophisticated save states would be good, although, it would be similar to using bookmarks in "choose your own adventure" books.  If you choose to do it that way without the intended consequences of your actions, I believe you should have the option to do so.

I can say that I enjoyed the characters.  Those tend to be the most important parts of any ttrpg game of WoD that I've played.  I cared about quite a few of the individuals I met in my playthrough.

50% off may be as good of a discount as you could hope for.  75% would be perfect.

I don't believe that visual novels will ever be capable of receiving the highest accolades (unless they have nudity).  In RPGs, the dialogue choice is just part of a greater game.  Without the meat of the game, you probably would be left underwhelmed.  Maybe that's just my hot take about why Visual Novels haven't caught on here in the West as heavily.


Edit:  The wiki claims, "Additional stand-alone story expansions are also planned to be released."  This is based on a rockpapershotgun article that doesn't have a direct quote from the devs.  Playing as other clans in different stories for the not full price (I'd go with $5) would maybe bump my opinion of the entire package, that is this game, up a bit.


Edit 2:  I am racking up the hours by trying for every achievement.  Would not recommend.

column8: Enjoyable read. As long as you go into the game knowing it is designed using a Choose Your Own Adventure format it will not disappoint. Good way to introduce the WOD gameworld for those who are not already familiar with it.

column8:
Coteries of New York is a great visual novel filled with vampire myth/lore, secret societies, and a great cast of characters.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Intro

Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Coteries of New York is a visual novel set within the World of Darkness universe. It‚Äôs the first video game in the Vampire: The Masquerade setting since the release of the original Bloodlines RPG back in 2004. The visual novel acts as a side story and takes place on the opposite side of the country, in New York City, instead of Seattle like in Bloodlines. If I‚Äôve caught your attention, read on to find out more about the game.

Story

Coteries of New York puts you in the role of a newly sired vampire who must learn to adapt to their new life as a vampire and to make a name for themselves in the world.

This is only a simple explanation of the story. The game goes much, much deeper than this, starting with the fledgling vampire learning of their newfound powers, their weaknesses, how to hunt/feed and many other things. The teaching stage takes a few hours to get through but if you love vampire lore as much as I do, this was all quite entertaining to read through. If not, then this section will bore you quite a bit.

As you might have guessed, the story starts off quite slow. If you don‚Äôt find the first hour or so interesting, chances are high that you probably won‚Äôt like the rest of the game either. That said, the game does get a lot more interesting the moment you‚Äôre able to start doing side quests for the various vampire factions.

The Masquerade And Being A Vampire

What I love most about Vampire: The Masquerade series is the amount of lore that is built into it. It‚Äôs not simply about being turned into a vampire and then running amuck. There‚Äôs an entire system called The Masquerade that governs the vampire‚Äôs way of life and you must adhere to it, or face the consequences.

In this series, vampires are nothing more than myth and legends to humans. This is due to the strict laws of the Masquerade which exists to protect vampire kind from extinction. This tradition was introduced after the first inquisition claimed many vampires in medieval times.

There are 6 laws (or traditions) that every vampire must adhere to are as follows. 1: Thou shalt not reveal thy true nature, 2. Thy domain is thine own concern. All others owe thee respect while in it, 3. Thou shall only sire another with the permission of thine elder, 4. Those thou create are thine own children and their since are thine to endure, 5. Honor one another‚Äôs domain, without the word of acceptance, thou are nothing, and 6. Thou art forbidden to destroy another of thy kind. The right of destruction belongeth only to thine elder.

Disobeying any of these traditions leads to a trial by council and instant execution. The main character of this game is brought into the world under the third tradition and was to be executed but was saved by a vampiress named Sophie who takes them under her wing as her Childe.

Vampire Factions and Side Quests

There are quite a few different vampire factions in the game including the Brujah, Malkavian, Nosferatu, Toreador, Ventrue, Tremere, Gangrel, and Thin Bloods. Each faction has it‚Äôs own unique appearance, abilities, and overall goals.

As an example, the Nosferatu are the most hideous and deformed of the vampire factions and are keen to stay in the shadows out of sight of humans. Their information network is vast, however, because they have eyes and ears everywhere and can go about unseen. One of the Nosferatu you help in the game is a private detective named D‚ÄôAngelo.

You‚Äôll wind up meeting various types of vampires over the course of the story, many of which have side quests for you to complete. Side quests can be taken whenever you‚Äôre on the map screen at the beginning of each night. Each side quests will have different endings depending on the dialogue choices that you choose but they ultimately have no effect on the overall story, they‚Äôre just self-contained stories to enjoy.

Verdict

Overall, I‚Äôve really enjoyed this visual novel. I will admit that it‚Äôs not exactly the greatest visual novel that I‚Äôve ever played but what it has was quite enjoyable. The biggest thing that‚Äôs kept me playing is the characters. All of the characters that you meet in this visual novel are incredibly interesting. They have their own motives, personalities and each of their stories is very entertaining to play through. All of them are well written and the side quests were easily my favourite part of the game.

While it‚Äôs not the most impressive visual novel that I‚Äôve ever played, it is one of the best Vampire: The Masquerade games that I‚Äôve experienced and has everything a VtM fan could want. It‚Äôs also nice to have more games in a series that wholly deserves to have more games in it. I hope this one and Bloodlines 2 leads to more games being set in the universe.

In the end, I‚Äôm going to save this one for later, if you‚Äôre a fan of VtM like myself you‚Äôll love it, but I recommend waiting until it‚Äôs on sale.

{For More In-Depth Reviews, do visit us at SaveorQuit.com}

column8: huh? its over? after 5 hours. being playing this over a few nights and was super engrossed about to finish tonight thinking i was only 20% through the game when credits roll. wtf is that it? i thought it would be much longer. what happened was starting to plan my charcters future. honestly quite disappointed at how abrupt the ending was, especially after such an enthralling start.

I do recommend this, but only at least 50% off the full price. There isn't 20 EUR worth of content here, not by a long shot. The story is engaging and oozes VtM, but its short and ends suddenly. I haven't had a more unsatisfying ending since last night in my bedroom.

Gameplaywise - what gameplay? Choices here only matter in the sense that you'll see a different street if you go left than if you go right, but you're still gonna end up at the same destination. I had hoped there was a "real" branching storyline here, but alas not.

Usually in VNs you're treated to some vignettes or cutscene-like segments. Not here. You see the same sprites over and over again, doesn't matter if you just beat the shit outta someone, their sprite remains the same. Even name-your-own-price indie VNs does a better job at this.

There's plenty to like here, but I feel like this whole game is more a prologue to something with a bit more blood in its veins, so to speak. I'm hoping there'll be more content, where you can go on some meaningful adventures with your new coterie. The framework is there, so I hope the developer will not let it waste away.

I understand this game has already recouped its development and marketing cost, so don't feel bad about waiting to pick this up from the bargain bin. If gets under 10 EUR and you're into VtM, I'd say you should consider it. Otherwise go spend your hard earned money elsewhere.

column8: Great game. The atmosphere and story are exactly how they should be in a World of Darkness game. Unfortunetely, it's hard to tell almost anything about Coteries of New York without getting into spolers. But I can say that it's totaly worth its price.
column9: Great game. The atmosphere and story are exactly how they should be in a World of Darkness game. Unfortunetely, it's hard to tell almost anything about Coteries of New York without getting into spolers. But I can say that it's totaly worth its price.

column8: This is an iffy thumbs-up. The game is buggy, and the translation gets rough in spots. Not everything makes perfect sense, and the parts that do make sense feel like they're on rails. Still, I enjoyed my time playing the game and I'll probably play through a couple of times.

column8: Áõ∏ÂΩì‰∏çÈîôÁöÑÊñáÊú¨Á±ªÊ∏∏Êàè„ÄÇÊúÄÂ§ßÁöÑÈöúÁ¢çËá™ÁÑ∂Êù•Ëá™‰∫éËØ≠Ë®ÄÔºå‰∏ªËßíÊ≠ª‰∫°ÂêéËá™Âä®Âà†Ê°£‰πüÊòØ‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÂÜçÊúâÂ∞±ÊòØÂÆö‰ª∑ÂÅèÈ´òÔºåÂΩìÁÑ∂Ëøô‰∫õÂØπ‰∫éÈÅø‰∏ñË°ÄÊóèIPÁöÑÁãÇÁÉ≠Áà±Â•ΩËÄÖÊù•ËØ¥Ëøô‰∫õÈÉΩ‰∏çÊòØÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇÂª∫ËÆÆÂØπÂê∏Ë°ÄÈ¨ºÈ¢òÊùêÂçÅÂàÜÊÑüÂÖ¥Ë∂£‰∏îËÉΩÂ§üÊ≤â‰∏ãÂøÉÊµ∏ÂÖ•Ê∏∏ÊàèÁöÑÁé©ÂÆ∂ÂÖ•Êâã„ÄÇÂè¶Â§ñÊúüÂæÖËøô‰∏™Ê∏∏ÊàèËÉΩÂá∫dlc„ÄÇ

distinto, pero de alguna manera, tan familiar, quiza no sea la misma frenetica experiencia que los otros juegos rpg de Vampiro, pero logra mostrar el mundo de las tinieblas, quiza de la  manera mas exacta y leal  a la idea original que he visto. La exposicion a veces puede ser un poco larga. Pero todas las pregutnas se resuelven y son explicadas, en parte gracias a un diccionario de terminos dentro del juego. Y lo mas importante es que se siente completamente  como algo de los juegos de Vampiro: la mascarada en los que se basa. de hecho, resulta algo natural. La experiencia se ve un poco estorbada por bugs y a veces se vuelve un poco lenta, pero tiene una excelente historia y te deja esperando y queriendo  mas. De hecho quiza un problema sea, que el juego puede resultar un poco corto para alguna gente. 
Pero la intriga, las traiciones, los personajes y la atmosfera, la historia, todo lo que hace tan especial a los juegos de vampiro y los ucbre de su propia aura diferente y especial, esta aqui.

Very short game, my first play through was <5 hours. The music is decent, and the images are very in fitting the atmosphere of Vampire The Masquerade tabletop game.

Pros:
True to source material
World building is good

Cons:
Very short
Limited replay options
Only 3 clans to choose from

column8: Fun little mutiple choice adventure in World of Darkness, I like the vampire politics and how your choices have real consequences.
column9: Fun little mutiple choice adventure in World of Darkness, I like the vampire politics and how your choices have real consequences.

column8:
5 hours.. One playthrough. But with many to follow.. And wow. Just... WOW

Okay so.. Positives and negatives!

- Like most rpg multiple choice things.. what you think you pick, isnt always what you pick. You thought you went with the cute sassy option? NOPE now you're suuuuper agressive. Fun!
Didn't happen so often I got mad though. Might also be a language barrier thing, idk?
- Theres a 'cutscene' w a loud sound that shocked me the first time and REALLY set the mood but after a while, when it got used so often it just sorta.. lost a lot of its effect?
- Three clan options to start are awesome and appreciated.. buuuut.... I really hope they expand and let us play as more/different clans as well..

+ The artstyle... Love it. It's beautiful 
+ The conversations are very well written. They feel like actual conversations - like things people would actually say to for example overpower, confuse, undermine or threaten you. 
+ If you fail, you fail. You done goofed. Sometimes if you're smart you can talk your way back but it's tough! Feels like there's actual consequences to your actions - which makes the sucesses all the better. Good job!
+ That ending... yoooo..

column8: I enjoyed this quite a bit even though i usually don't see the appeal in this genre myself. The tone of Vampire: The Masquerade is present even though this is essentially an interactive novel. I don't feel the game was too short personally, as my first playthrough took 7 hours and i still have the two other clans left as well as about four companions to recruit and their each additional 3 side quests. The finale comes quite close to ruining the experience however, as it seems to be set in stone from what i've seen and happens suddenly before i would have liked, given the choice.  If you want to see more of VTM- Bloodlines world before the sequel then this does nicely, as long as the above doesn't turn you off.

column8: F√ºr alle Vampire: The Masquerade ein muss! :D

I'm a big fan of Vampire stuff, I'm a sucker for em', especially the WoD IP, I'm a big fan of the lore of not just Vampires, but all the other game lines, so seeing a game like this made me excited. But...There are some problems.

Setting: First off, this game is using V5, or Fifth Edition, which is...A continuation of Old World of Darkness but in modern times. The Apocalypse didn't happen, not yet, anyway. If you're a fan of the old lore, you'll see a lot of it once more, like the Camarilla and such, however, there are notable differences and this serves as a good introduction to the 'updated' lore. A quick run-down though, is that the Sabbat are in Africa to presumably stop an antediluvian from rising, having left all other provinces, and the new 'Big Bad' replacement is the Second Inquisition, which is a sort of Paranormal XCOM, a coalition of nations wanting to defeat the 'Blank-bodies' (What they call vampires.) Most of the clans that used to be Sabbat or Independant are now taking sides because of this between Anarchs and Camarilla. The Tremere also got hit hard in Venice, having their Prime Chantry, where Tremere himself was, being destroyed and bombed. There are other changes, but you'll learn those as you go along. If you're totally new to the setting, this also helps get you into it.

GOOD
- Atmosphere is very, very good. It's like, spot on, really.
- Characters are very well done and interesting for the most part.
- Lore Codex so new people can read and understand what is happening and what terms mean.
- For the most part, even though you're a newly embraced vamp, the game doesn't overly hold your hand.


NEUTRAL
- If you're not a fan of changes to the lore made with V5, you might not like this, or maybe it gets you into it.
- There's a simple Hunger Mechanic...Gives you a bit of something to think on and utilize, but it doesn't make too much of a difference. 
- You get two actions a night, in an already short game. 
- Main story is...Alright? But, the Coterie is what carries it for me.

BAD 
- Three characters that you can't really customize. Each with their own set clan. The set clan isn't a problem, but each of the characters don't have much of a personality, and you change their name but not anything else. Not that you will be seeing your own character much, but kinda wish I could be a female Brujah and a male Ventrue. This wouldn't be bad if each character had more of a personality rather than just clan stereotype, though. The word 'several' was also used to describe the characters we had and clans to choose from, but it was recently changed to the three we know now, which is more fitting and honest, but still sad to see.
- Not much of a reason to replay the game other than achievements and some comments, or to explore the characters you didn't finish before. You're a pawn in this game, not a player.
- Remember the 2 actions a night thing? Some nights just steal an action from you, robbing you of more time, when you could just...Make it an option to go do the main story.
- Don't bother getting more than 2 characters in your coterie. Choose 2 people and focus on other side-stories, as the game will only act as if you had 2 members when your coterie does become important/comes together...Which is once in the game. (Note: This is mentioned in the steam store description, but it can be obscure, as I didn't see this when I bought the game.)
- Just a minor thing, but there is no way that your character can figure out what's going on in-game, even if you do a few runs and think you could get 'clued-in' with certain conversations/actions. It doesn't have to change anything that happens, but would be nice for it to be a little nod for completing the game already.
- No multiple endings aside from deaths, if you count those, to my knowledge.

Overall, this is just from me doing two runs of the game, with a third as a sort of test-drive to see what trouble I could get in that was only half-done. However, if the game has been updated, or will keep getting support, well, I'll probably change this up whenever I play through it again. I wish there was a neutral button for Steam reviews, but, I'll unfortunately have to go negative unless you can get this on a sale, or maybe when it gets more stuff.
column9:

It doesn't have to change anything that happens, but would be nice for it to be a little nod for completing the game already.
- No multiple endings aside from deaths, if you count those, to my knowledge.

Overall, this is just from me doing two runs of the game, with a third as a sort of test-drive to see what trouble I could get in that was only half-done. However, if the game has been updated, or will keep getting support, well, I'll probably change this up whenever I play through it again. I wish there was a neutral button for Steam reviews, but, I'll unfortunately have to go negative unless you can get this on a sale, or maybe when it gets more stuff.

column8:
Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York is a brilliant introduction to the Vampire: The Masquerade setting. It has everything someone that never played Vampire need to get into the setting and get a grip in this gigantic universe. It also appeals to Vampire veterans out there that would die to play a couple of sessions but don't have a playgroup or the time to do so. 

Most people disliking and giving the game mixed reviews thought that the game as too short and with a bad ending. I beg to differ, as I thought the story is very well written and convey all the soul of a real Vampire: The Masquerade session. It is like playing only the good parts of Bloodlines.

My only complaint is some typos here and there, but this I'm sure will be fixed soon.

I hope Draw Distance continue creating stories like this.

column8: Un univers ultra fid√®le, une ambiance sonore et graphique au top qui permet une tr√®s bonne immersion.

This is visual novel in Vampire: The Masquerade setting.
The story is pretty good, even if ending seems bit rushed it's still pretty decent, but that's about where my praise ends.
Story is very linear, there are choices but they don't influence almost anything. Only thing you can really chose is if you die or continue the story ....
That said this game doesn't let you save ... so if your choices kills you, you start from beginning. But then you find out that this game DOESN'T EVEN HAVE SKIP FUNCTION! So you have to click thru all the shit again! And you cant click just anywhere, there is tiny "continue" button you have to keep pressing to advance the story. The game doesn't color already read text differently, doesn't color already taken choices differently. 
THIS GAME IS MISSING BASIC FEATURES EVERY VISUAL NOVEL SHOULD HAVE BY DEFAULT! 
Its like devs attempted to make visual novel without ever reading any of them .....

Music and ambient sounds are pretty well done, but game has no voice acting.
Graphic that is there is good but every character has just one unchanging sprite, no different facial expression, nothing.
Main story is linear but there are side stories that you can explore and they are pretty good as well, but you have only limited time so you cant chose to explore all of them, so you have to start again to read them, BUT WHO IN THEYR RIGHT MIND WOULD REPLAY VN WITHOUT SKIP FUNCTION?

If some resourceful person remade this game in Ren'py, it would make whole expirience so mutch better ......

The Story is still good so if you are into vampires you should propably grab it .... in some sale.

column8:
I recommend this game only because it‚Äôs been quite a while since we got anything set in ‚Äúworld of darkness‚Äù universe. [b]The whole thing is clearly unfinished so get it for no more than 5 Euro [/b]

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]World of Darkness
[*]Nice art style
[*]Decent writing 
[*]Nice dictionary [i]‚Äì all entries short, to the point and will easily help people not familiar with ‚ÄúWorld of darkness‚Äù lore[/i]
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Short [i]‚Äì 5-6 hours of gameplay[/i]
[*]Only 2-3 ‚Äúevent‚Äù graphics [i]‚Äì rest is typical VN character on location background[/i]
[*]Plot keeps you in the dark [i]‚Äì it‚Äôs easiest approach to the whole mystery theme but not most sophisticated one. The game [b]will not[/b] send you on wild goose chase, drop some confusing hints, cleverly mislead you. Whole mystery is based purely on lack of information.[/i]
[*]Unfinished ‚Äì [i]as I‚Äôve mentioned before, I‚Äôm 100% sure it was supposed to be a lot more ambitious then it actually is. Hunger, vampire power and allay mechanics are clearly underused[/i]
[*]Linear [i]‚Äì your decisions do not matter[/i]
[*]Characters are ok but a little bit flat and stereotypical   
[/list]

column8:
[b]Buy this if you're a sloppy mess for VTM or if it's on sale.[/b]

[b]Cons[/b]
- Not especially polished 
- Demands a replay then makes the replay punishing
- The pop culture and meme references won't age well
- Choices don't matter much
- Have to select from premade player characters
- Ending makes the entire game feel like a prelude
- Shortish

[b]Pros[/b]
- Vampire the Masquerade

[h1]***[/h1]

Things like spelling errors, formatting inconsistencies, the game misremembering player choices, etc killed the immersion a little. You can't complete every quest in one playthrough so if you want to see them all (or if you want to play as another character) you need to replay - but as of now there is no option to skip or speed through text you've already seen, nor any option to reload an earlier save, so get ready for a hard slog of endless clicks through old dialogue hoping you won't accidentally skip anything new or select a wrong option. No matter what you do the ending is the same. You're stuck choosing from three pre-made characters with little payoff because they have basically the same experience of the story anyway - and they're gender locked despite the fact all the writing uses gender neutral (and indeed clan neutral) language. I finished my first playthrough in under 4 hours, and I still had time to die and restart twice.

column8:
I love the World of Darkness, loved Bloodlines 1 and was excited to have something tide me over until Bloodlines 2. Very big letdown.

Pros:
- It's Vampire: The Masquerade, that's a pro on it's own
- The art is very nice

Cons:
- Sprites are static and never change. Every character has one sprite that remains the same regardless of circumstance or emotion.
- The game is short, 4 hours for $20 (at full price). And that's not 4 hours of gameplay, that's 4 hours of reading dialogue, occasionally responding, and choosing which mission you want to pursue.
- Although I've only played the game once, it doesn't feel like your choices really affect anything, and reading other reviews here confirms it.
- You have a set number of nights in every game, and mandatory events take place every X amount of actions. The game decides when it will end. This means you have missions you won't finish. There are whole missions that feel completely pointless and don't affect the characters at all. Too bad if you waste half a night shooing a greasy reporter from Sophia's doorstep instead of wooing a potential coterie member, not that who's in your coterie ends up mattering at all.
- Some typos and skipped dialogue. None of it to the point that it was too hard to follow what was happening, but this should have been caught.
- Ends on a cliffhanger with many relationships, missions, and questions left unanswered. (What's between the Sheriff and Sophie? How does the detective know the Scourge? Why is a serial killer on the loose?) A clear ploy to convince me to purchase the next installment. No thanks.

If you love WoD, maybe pick this up on sale for <$10. Can't justify anything higher than that.

And... what in God's green earth is a cl*t-measuring contest?

column8:
As a person who worked on V:TM back in the 2/3e era, I can say I really enjoyed this game, even if I haven't been a fan of 5e's initial output. It's weird playing the Camarilla in New York, as in my head, it's Sabbat Central and always will be, but this was a fantastic visual novel that captures the true essence of V:TM.

What's nice is that there are three playable characters, each with their own stories, even if the bulk of the game's plot is the same across all three characters. There is plenty of replay value (but only three possible endings, two of which are extremely early in the game) as you only have a fortnight to explore before the endgame, and there is no way to complete all the subquests for kine and Kindred alike. 

The ending is abrupt and if you're not truly versed in V:TM, it will probably seem like a let down, but it encaspulates what it means to be a childe wonderfully. Everyone is engaging in subterfuge and playing a long game for power via manipulation. Just because you are a PC in V:TM does not mean you are immune to it. In truth, it usually means you are the focus of it. So the ending is what it really is like in the World of Darkness, and if you've experienced otherwise, you probably had a Storyteller that simply didn't get the world background. EVERYONE is a pawn in the Jyhad. There are no exceptions, from the lowly fledgling to an ancient member of the Black hand or Inconnu. EVERYONE. 

As visual novels go, each playthrough is about 90 minutes. I 100%'d the achievements in five and a half hours across four playthroughs (six if you count the early on bad endings). The writing was solid, the characters were interesting and the game was a lot of fun. Yes, i wish there were multiple endings as a gamer, but as an old VTM writer, it makes sense. It doesn't matter which character you are, as there is no other way for things to turn out. It's like a published tabletop adventure. The players have some room to go off rails, but regardless of what clans your crew are playing, everything starts and ends the same. 

Here's hoping to see more.

column8:
Starts off right but the ends in a whimper. 

Pros
Great atmosphere - the soundtrack, color scheme, and art style really immerse you into a darker side of the city. Adds an unease and tension to your decisions.
Interesting Characters - most of the characters you come across are interesting and rarely dull. The art style helps with this as well. 

Cons
Spellcheck/ Editing - There are numerous errors throughout the dialogue texts. So much so that my grammar teachers are shaking their heads in disgust. Not acceptable for a final product.
Limited Speech Options/ Strange Choices - Overall this wasn't too numerous but in certain situations the character had text options that she/he wouldn't know about or were out of character. Is instantly noticeable to people who know the lore and series.
That Ending... - None of your choices matter. No matter which way you play it. Game builds you up on thinking that your choices and actions will matter but it doesn't. Makes replaying it pointless besides seeing characters you missed.

Overall Verdict - If you want to get this game.... wait for a sale.

column8:
4/10 blood bags

+First half
+Interesting characters
+Masquerade feel on point

- Dosnt develop said characters - at all
-second half rushed and MANY Plotholes
-ending makes NO sense
-choices dont matter

SPOILERS TO FOLLOW

So its 5 am and I've finished playing my second run through and also read other reviews to make sure I didnt miss anything. Because sadly this game leaves you feeling like some kind of bug occured and you skipped half the game to an unsatisfying ending.
(aside form actual bugs I encountered along the way)

I was lead to believe by an amazing introand media before game release that this - like any companion or visual novel game- would allow you to get to know the characters, make choices that matter, be friends etc. and each of the 4 characters have 4 quests that amount to barely an introduction to each. I could tell you maybe two facts about each character not to mention that you only have time to do the quests of TWO of FOUR charcters per run through, which, means you miss out on other stuff as each night barely gives you two actions or scenes.
some of these scenes made NO sense, and seemingly no sense to others who have played and posted reviews as well. examples SPOILERS:
1.part 3 of 'somebody's watching me' no reaction realistic to your stalker being in your haven, seemingly knowing who they are out of thin air, and just no explination to that tiny but time expensive arc.
2.simialr to benoit at the church, just rampant religious nonsense for seemingly no reason
3.the ending. i mean....what? why? the point? there is none.

Its a damn shame because the first half got me like: this is cool, the writing is dope, they got the feel, the art is cool, game play is right and then BOOM - rush this, ignore that, finish the game for release rinse and repeat. I wish they had taken another damn year to flesh out the second half, so that I can tell people how it ends because I honestly dont know what i just saw.

Overall, glad I got it discounted. VTMB2 will have to make up for this next year.

column8: This game has an interesting story, good music, and the right ambiance and that's about it.  Big fan of the Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines.  So I picked this up to scratch that vampire itch.  All I can say is that the story while good is very linear, none of your choices really matter at the end.  All three clans have the same ending regardless of what you do.  So there's no real point in replaying the others ones after your first play through.  Really can't recommend this game at the price that's being asked for.  Feels more like something that belongs in the $5 bin vs. the $20 that's being asked for.  It's not worth buying full price for something that offers very little.

column8:
Coteries of New York is one of the weakest visual novels I ever played, most of your choices are useless, and you have access to the same ONE ending, no matter what Clan/Character you choose.

My recommendation comes from the sole fact that every character and the overall story is very well written and delightful to play through, although I believe the replay value is terribly low, the game is worth a shot if it is on sale.

TLDR: Game is linear as fk, with only one ending. But has a charming cast in a well built world with a solid story.

TLDR: Game is linear as fk, with only one ending. But has a charming cast in a well built world with a solid story.

So far this game is fantastic, if you are hoping for a "choose your own adventure" style comic based in the world of darkness, here it is, i especially recommend this title for people who are new to the World of darkness lore, i personally am a veteran of the original bloodlines and the Live action game and i must say the creators did a fantastic job of writing a story rich game.

now a few critiques, I would (so far) liked to have seen more choices provided in regards to in game dialogue options and different clan options (though the game is written so well its hardly a draw back)

now if the other two clan of vampires that are playable have utterly unique story lines i will completely resend my previous criticisms.

all and all its pretty darn good though

column8:
TLDR; I feel sorry for the skilled people who designed this game, Everything in here from the art to the music and UI design blends together perfectly to produce what really feels like a World of Darkness setting (Which I didn't expect given how V5 has turned out).

It's obvious that a few more months of development would've done the game well, the last third in particular, But as is the trend for Vampire: The Masquerade games, They're made to a strict deadline and released a disappointing yet inspiring mess. Pick it up if you're really starved for a decently written Vampire experience while waiting to see if Hardsuit Labs drops the ball like everyone else has.

column8:
Pros:

- Art direction
- Soundtrack
- Character design 
- Side quests

Cons

- Cost. For 4 hours of entertainment, a bit much
- Main storyline. Starts very suddenly and is over way too soon.
- Choices not having a serious impact on the ending.

For someone new to the setting, this is a good intro. Expensive for what you get, but good. I'm very curious to see what comes next from this studio, because they have a lot of the tools in place to make some great games, but I'd like their next effort to have a bit more meat to it.

column8:
The story was intriguing but because of the abrupt ending i felt it was a missed opportunity to make one last choice. There's also not enough time to complete everything in the game which is fair since it makes you consider where your time is best spent. The background art and music does a good job of setting the atmosphere in the game so it's a nice touch.

Even though I've only finished one playthrough as Ventrue I did feel like the game is pretty linear. The Hunger system didn't seem that important compared to the story and I question if not feeding or using disciplines affects anything. Despite all this I was still invested in the game and some of it's characters. Having to guess motives of people you encounter or do some quick thinking on how best to help others was cool. The game also tells you about the world of vampires as you go through the game with a dictionary feature which is great for someone unfamiliar with the setting.

The game has it's flaws but I felt it was enjoyable enough. I would recommend waiting for a slightly better sale before getting it.

column8: At first I loved this game, I love the world, the lore, but it quickly became apparent that the choices you make in this game has ZERO impact on the story... Three different characters to play as, the only thing different is the starting cutscenes, I played it through two times, the same lines, same paragraphs of speech no matter your choice. You can kill everyone, not kill anyone, be polite, be an asshole... Doesn't make a different, besides 1 paragraph of flavour text right after, and then BAM back to the linear story... So disappointed.

column8:
This was a classic case of loving the concept a lot more than the execution. 

Overall the game has excellent writing. The characters are vivid. The overall atmosphere is great. The problem is there just isn't enough of it.  This is more akin to a single PnP session rather than a full blown campaign. 

Your choices seemingly matter very little.  Outside a few "bad" choices resulting in Game Over, it felt fairly railroaded to the same route and ending.  The titular coterie does exactly jack squat after recruiting them. None of the characters interact much with the main plot outside of, literally, two brief scenes.  Maybe I was expecting too much, but this was by far biggest disappointment stemming from the overall shortness of the title. 

Your character is predefined, and the game does not reflect any style you try to follow. The Brujah is treated mostly the same whether you answer like an asskisser or an asshole (outside the game overs.) You amass no power. You do little more than follow errands until the plot ends. Which, while somewhat true to the setting, has no sense of accomplishment . Outside a few cases of powers, I saw nothing that acknowledged or even explained limiting gender and clan choices. Maybe pronouns and portraits are more expensive than we realize. 

I liked it, but there just isn't enough to recommend at the $19.99 point.  If this were Chapter 1, in something bigger, it would be different. As it is now, too brief, too shallow.

column8:
The game had a lot of potential, but it was very short. The developers should have put more effort into it. I would be more forgiving, but this game wouldn't have even been particularly difficult to create. It's text-based, with some animated backgrounds and a few characters. They COULD have very easily expanded it further once the elements were in place. They just chose not to. This game was limited by the creator's laziness, a lack of funding, a lack of creativity, or possibly all three. Nothing else.

They seem to have set the game up for a sequel, but I won't be buying it if they make one, as the world, while having potential, failed to hook me, and I don't have any faith that any such sequel will have any more effort put into it.

P.S.
I finished the game in six hours. I'd imagine that playing the game through with the other two clans would take about the same amount of time.

column8:
$$$$$ - A lot of people complaining about the price but that is not fair to the devs and the game.  It took me 5 hours to play through at $20, which is about the same price as going to a movie /w popcorn and coke, so yeah I think $20 for 5 plus hours of entertainment is worth it for this story.  

The plot is awesome and you get to make some really cool decisions.  It is a read along story game so if that isn't your cup of tea then don't buy it, but if you like a good story that allows you to steer parts of the journey then this is the game for you.  I honestly can't wait for an expansion to come out to take the next steps in the story.

column8:
Coteries of New York is a very entertaining visual novel, highly engaging on the first playthrough, and hosting a range of interesting characters. Playing it rekindled an interest in the tabletop game, and a desire to spend time exploring the world with friends, as well as wanting to go back and replay the game with different choices.

There's a lot of small errors in the text; things that say 'Feeding Opportunity' but aren't part of a choice, poor grammar, and repetition of a section of text near the beginning of the game, regarding hunger. The grammar's a minor detail and understandable given that Draw Distance is a Polish game development studio, but other pieces are things that should be fixed in updates.

The biggest disappointment for me was replaying the game and realizing the limitations of the choices presented. There's a number of situations where your options don't change what happens- they just change how you get to the same end point. While it appears there's some behind-the-scenes calculations to decide details in specific instances, at some of the most important points in the game, things are predetermined.

I cautiously recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of Vampire, or vampires, as your first playthrough will be quite entertaining and perhaps give you some excellent ideas with regards to the tabletop game. If you were to attempt to get all of the achievements or even just play each of the three character possibilities, you'll get in excess of one hour of play time per dollar of investment, and even a single run will provide you with at least as much entertainment-per-dollar as you'd get going to the movies or something similar. But, I would not purchase this with the expectation that it will be installed more than once.

column8: What a ride! Finished this at a little over 11 hours in my 1st playthrough with the Brujah clan. I loved the story and the events that led up to the end. It was all unexpected! Hope there is some kind of sequel to this VN. The only thing I‚Äôm sad about is that I wasn‚Äôt able to finish all the quests and felt rushed into the final. I like to take my sweet time doing all (or most) of the side quests and other less important parts of the story but I wasn‚Äôt able to. This means I will likely start a second playthrough with a different character. I don‚Äôt know if it was due to my choices but I would have loved to finish all content with one playthrough. And... to the people complaining about choices... Game is a VN! Not all VN's allow for different endings and various ramifications in the storyline. I see VN's as what they are, a visual version of a story, a book for example. You are just there for the ride. This was never meant to be like Bloodlines. Lastly, I really recommend this game overall. Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines 2 fans and those who appreciate the lore, will find this a nice title to sink their fangs in until BL2 release.

column8:
All in all if you're a World of Darkness and especially Vampire: The Masquerade fan, I think it has some value that will entertain for a couple of hours at minimum. If you're new to the series then I'd only pick it up if you're a fan of visual novels, preferably with slight choose-your-own-adventure elements (emphasis on slight); otherwise I'd skip it and pick up Bloodlines 1 instead. That's why I'll give it a thumbs up rather than a thumbs down for lack of a middle option; I don't think it's a game a fan of the series (or maybe even Vampires in general) would dislike when playing. But how much money is it worth? Hopefully you can determine that reading below. 

Gameplay: 4/10
Overall the game is decent and I never felt bored playing it, but it's a flawed game and it suffers from the worst sin a game with choices can commit: Your choices don't really change much. Yeah you can fail a task or a few if you choose poorly, mainly when putting the coterie together, but regardless it isn't gonna change the at best bittersweet outcome the story wants to go in. It also suffers from that the Clan options don't change a great deal in the story, just your mortal circumstances, the Disciplines you get and a short line of text or two.

It's like the game is ran by a railroading storyteller that allow some options on less important issues, but when it comes to the main story it's gonna go down the way he wants it. You can try to stop it the climax, but not succeed and the end effect that muddies the waters of the game and reduces it to such a painfully average score because it severely hurts the replayability of the game and makes the otherwise well-written characters feel shallow when they just repeat the same lines no matter what you wanna do. 

I think you have two, MAYBE three shots at the game before you've seen and done it all, and that's if you don't mind the fact that it's gonna play out the same way in the end a lot of the time with at best minor tweaks around the edges (and I do mean at best).

Writing: 6/10
For the most part I think the characters in the game are portrayed quite well and recognize many of them from the New York by Night supplement of Revised era days. I find the characters believable as people and charming in their own respective ways, and you have at least four or five people whose opinions you can actually shape via your actions; those being the coterie you form. That's what makes me wanna put it slightly above average despite not for the big drawback the game has that I mentioned above. That's the positive side of this section, here's the negative one (spoilers): 

The game's outcome won't change. The plot significant scenes are gonna happen regardless, they're gonna work out regardless to build up to the climax and the climax will always go down with your adoptive sire thinking you betrayed her in her last moments even though the big bad behind the man told her to her face you were just an ignorant pawn from the beginning, you can't save her or reject/attack the baddie when all's said and done or win the final battle in any way no matter how much you might try and build yourself up for it. 

That coterie you're building up that the entire game's premise is based upon? Yeah they show up once, just before the climax, and briefly bust you out of a Second Inquisition daytime grab n' stake operation (if you're Brujah you can almost make it out on your own btw) and then they fuck off and you have no option to ask them to come along for that final battle where you really could've used them. The plot hooks that you go through to get them on your side are nice and easily the best parts of the games, but the ending is paramount and in this game it falls flat because all they do is briefly show up and then leave again and you'll never see them again before the game's over, no epilogues, no nothing. 

This left a somewhat... dull taste in my mouth, like the game is incomplete. Not just in the parts leading up to what's there in the story, but in tying the story up too; like if Bloodlines 1 stopped after you get a Blood Hunt tossed on your head right after the Werewolf fight and just before you fight your way out of Santa Monica the next night after learning about it. I don't know if it's laziness, sequel/DLC baiting or a failed effort at mysticism on the writer's part. Even so though, the first time going through it was overall nice up until the ending where you're pretty powerless, and I'd like to remind you reading this that I didn't feel bored playing the game. Just not as entertained as I feel I could've been if the promise it shown had held up.

Atmosphere: 8/10
The atmosphere is on-point and excellent for World of Darkness... If a bit repetitive at times. I don't hold it hugely against the developers, but to me it breaks immersion (which is what these games by and large banks on) a bit when I see reused assets for places that are supposed to be different. Still, as said the images are well-drawn, have some casual animations to them to piff the scenery up. It's dark, gloomy, gritty, I especially liked the soft glow in the Vampire character's eyes; it's World of Darkness. Saying anything else is a disservice. The music was for the most part competent but could get annoying sometimes. Especially cuz of the..

Technical: 4/10
For the most part the game worked fine and it never broke, but I often had hang ups in sound effects that made me have to reload to reset the game so I didn't hear crickets in my apartment or the distant screams of children at a carnival well after I left the area and so on. Furthermore I think some choices bleeded into other paths, where I noticed I could suddenly Auspex as a Brujah or Dominate as a Toreador. The amount of customizable options were very basic too and don't change a great deal. Being able to change the size of text is nice, I guess, but that's all that stood out. Would've liked a instant text option so I don't have to look at the text writing.
column9:
All in all if you're a World of Darkness and especially Vampire: The Masquerade fan, I think it has some value that will entertain for a couple of hours at minimum. If you're new to the series then I'd only pick it up if you're a fan of visual novels, preferably with slight choose-your-own-adventure elements (emphasis on slight); otherwise I'd skip it and pick up Bloodlines 1 instead. That's why I'll give it a thumbs up rather than a thumbs down for lack of a middle option; I don't think it's a game a fan of the series (or maybe even Vampires in general) would dislike when playing. But how much money is it worth? Hopefully you can determine that reading below. 

Gameplay: 4/10
Overall the game is decent and I never felt bored playing it, but it's a flawed game and it suffers from the worst sin a game with choices can commit: Your choices don't really change much. Yeah you can fail a task or a few if you choose poorly, mainly when putting the coterie together, but regardless it isn't gonna change the at best bittersweet outcome the story wants to go in. It also suffers from that the Clan options don't change a great deal in the story, just your mortal circumstances, the Disciplines you get and a short line of text or two.

It's like the game is ran by a railroading storyteller that allow some options on less important issues, but when it comes to the main story it's gonna go down the way he wants it. You can try to stop it the climax, but not succeed and the end effect that muddies the waters of the game and reduces it to such a painfully average score because it severely hurts the replayability of the game and makes the otherwise well-written characters feel shallow when they just repeat the same lines no matter what you wanna do. 

I think you have two, MAYBE three shots at the game before you've seen and done it all, and that's if you don't mind the fact that it's gonna play out the same way in the end a lot of the time with at best minor tweaks around the edges (and I do mean at best).

Writing: 6/10
For the most part I think the characters in the game are portrayed quite well and recognize many of them from the New York by Night supplement of Revised era days. I find the characters believable as people and charming in their own respective ways, and you have at least four or five people whose opinions you can actually shape via your actions; those being the coterie you form. That's what makes me wanna put it slightly above average despite not for the big drawback the game has that I mentioned above. That's the positive side of this section, here's the negative one (spoilers): 

The game's outcome won't change. The plot significant scenes are gonna happen regardless, they're gonna work out regardless to build up to the climax and the climax will always go down with your adoptive sire thinking you betrayed her in her last moments even though the big bad behind the man told her to her face you were just an ignorant pawn from the beginning, you can't save her or reject/attack the baddie when all's said and done or win the final battle in any way no matter how much you might try and build yourself up for it. 

That coterie you're building up that the entire game's premise is based upon? Yeah they show up once, just before the climax, and briefly bust you out of a Second Inquisition daytime grab n' stake operation (if you're Brujah you can almost make it out on your own btw) and then they fuck off and you have no option to ask them to come along for that final battle where you really could've used them. The plot hooks that you go through to get them on your side are nice and easily the best parts of the games, but the ending is paramount and in this game it falls flat because all they do is briefly show up and then leave again and you'll never see them again before the game's over, no epilogues, no nothing. 

This left a somewhat... dull taste in my mouth, like the game is incomplete. Not just in the parts leading up to what's there in the story, but in tying the story up too; like if Bloodlines 1 stopped after you get a Blood Hunt tossed on your head right after the Werewolf fight and just before you fight your way out of Santa Monica the next night after learning about it. I don't know if it's laziness, sequel/DLC baiting or a failed effort at mysticism on the writer's part. Even so though, the first time going through it was overall nice up until the ending where you're pretty powerless, and I'd like to remind you reading this that I didn't feel bored playing the game. Just not as entertained as I feel I could've been if the promise it shown had held up.

Atmosphere: 8/10
The atmosphere is on-point and excellent for World of Darkness... If a bit repetitive at times. I don't hold it hugely against the developers, but to me it breaks immersion (which is what these games by and large banks on) a bit when I see reused assets for places that are supposed to be different. Still, as said the images are well-drawn, have some casual animations to them to piff the scenery up. It's dark, gloomy, gritty, I especially liked the soft glow in the Vampire character's eyes; it's World of Darkness. Saying anything else is a disservice. The music was for the most part competent but could get annoying sometimes. Especially cuz of the..

Technical: 4/10
For the most part the game worked fine and it never broke, but I often had hang ups in sound effects that made me have to reload to reset the game so I didn't hear crickets in my apartment or the distant screams of children at a carnival well after I left the area and so on. Furthermore I think some choices bleeded into other paths, where I noticed I could suddenly Auspex as a Brujah or Dominate as a Toreador. The amount of customizable options were very basic too and don't change a great deal. Being able to change the size of text is nice, I guess, but that's all that stood out. Would've liked a instant text option so I don't have to look at the text writing.

column8:
TL;DR: If you're a Bloodlines or VtM fan and you got a few hours to kill, definitely give this game a try. But if you're expecting a lot of replayability like I did, don't get your hopes up. Although the story is good and enjoyable, the game doesn't really care about your choices.

Now, I hope I can leave some constructive criticism here and I hope people will actually read it. Keep in mind, I actually enjoyed this game - I just hope to address some issues, in case the developer company plans to make another VtM game in the future.

Pros:
- The VtM dictionary was a very good idea for people who are new to Vampire the Masquerade. I imagine the whole game would be really confusing for uninitiated players otherwise.
- Absolutely gorgeous art. Both the backgrounds and the characters are so well drawn. Torque's, Tamika's and D'Angelo's designs are my favorites. <3
- Very nice soundtrack (loved the track that plays when the coterie comes to save you) and sound effects - the scary sounds that play every now and then paired with the black void visuals... loved that. It's one of the reasons I liked the beginning of the Brujah playthrough so much)
- The main story and the side stories are generally pretty interesting. I really enjoyed Tamika's questline, and D'Angelo's story was really impressive, not to mention how interestingly Hope's Malkavian "affliction" manifests.
- There's a good mix of characters with genuinely good intentions here, as well as your usual "we're all liars here" bunch of Kindred, both Camarilla and Anarch.

Cons:
- The biggest flaw this game has is the lack of impact your choices have (and how your character does things automatically without you deciding said things). You might not notice the first time you play this game, but on the second playthrough it becomes obvious that what you do or say barely matters (I played a cowardly Toreador the first time and a rebel Brujah the second time and nothing in the main story changed for me. The ending I got was exactly the same, and with a game like this, I think it's very important to have a handful of different endings).
- The way time passes doesn't make a lot of sense. How come I go to Sophie's place immediately after waking up, talk to her for like 5 minutes and when I leave her apartment, half the night is already gone? The problem here is you can usually only do about 2 things per night, one of which, by the way, sometimes you don't even choose to do. Sometimes you'll wake up and your character will go someplace without you having a say in this, and that's how you waste half your night.
- The game is way too short. The main story itself is short and the game doesn't allow you to explore all the sidequests properly. I didn't know this on my first playthrough and basically didn't get to finish the questlines for any of my coterie members, only the Nosy Reporter quests. I understand that this was probably meant for more realism and to encourage replayability but I really don't think forcing this time limit on the player is the way to go.
- The story felt really rushed right towards the end for some reason. I don't know if this was due to lack of time before the release date, but that's what it felt like to me. I feel like the main storyline could have really done with some more time put into it, because it feels like nothing very big happens for the first 75-80% of the game, but then everything important happens all at once and then, the end.
- The game is literally called COTERIES of New York, but the only coterie we (maybe) get to see is ours and it barely even functions as such. You can't even call it a team of people working together, because for pretty much the entire game, you'll be the only one talking to each individual character, while they don't even know about the others' existence until the very end of the game where *maybe* they show up to help you out, and even that moment ends very abruptly and you're all alone again. I personally was very thrilled to be able to build a coterie in this game, like in VtM Redemption, and the lack of an actual one here really bugged me.

Did this game disappoint me? Sadly, yes. Can I still recommend it? Actually, YES.
I suppose the way to go about it is, don't expect it to be a masterpiece and play it however recklessly you want the first time, because you might not have the patience to play through the same story a second time. 
I felt like there was a lot of potential in this game that got wasted for some reason or the other (again, maybe lack of time?) - but this is precisely why I wanted to leave some feedback here, not only for potential players, but for the developers as well. Again, I see the potential Coteries of NY had, I still have faith in the developers and I would like to see (and definitely would support) a proper sequel or a similar VtM game (not a DLC) if they ever decide to make one.

column8: Laid back and atmospheric.
column9: Laid back and atmospheric.

column8: Fun but a little short. Veterans of the VtM setting may be a bit disappointed in how much time is spent explaining basic setting elements. Still, a great little story with good writing and excellent characters.
column9: Fun but a little short. Veterans of the VtM setting may be a bit disappointed in how much time is spent explaining basic setting elements. Still, a great little story with good writing and excellent characters.

column8:
While a Visual Novel, meaning you should temper your expectations based on that, this game has a lot to offer for people new to Vampire, and us old ones as well.

It's got absolutely amazing art, first of all. It REALLY feels like a World of Darkness setting, complete with dark alleys, imposing skyscrapers and decrepid graveyards. The music is great too, very fitting for the game, and the character design is top notch.

The writing is overall very good, if sometimes a little all over the place. There are still some grammatical mistakes here and there, despite the patching, and sometimes it feels a little... overtly sexual, which as an older Vampire player i find unfitting; between Vampires, sex stops being a thing pretty quickly, and it's mostly used as a tool to ensnare mortals, but eh. It's not a big problem.

Backgrounds are dynamic and beautiful while the characters have moderate depth. This game is a first step in the right direction of what it could be.

column8:
A pesar de su final apresurado, Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Coteries of New York es una novela visual que cumple como cap√≠tulo introductorio de este fascinante mundo incluyendo mec√°nicas que se sienten fieles al material original. Es una aventura a peque√±a escala que no arriesga tanto como quisi√©ramos, d√°ndonos personajes predefinidos, solo tres clanes para explotar y apenas un acercamiento a las disciplinas y las debilidades de cada Vampiro. Pero eso no quita que haga gala de grandes personajes, y de un guion bien escrito y atrapante, incluso con sus problemas hacia el final.

Lo bueno:
- Una presentaci√≥n fiel a Mundo de Tinieblas en todo aspecto. El juego sabe con qu√© franquicia est√° lidiando
- Mec√°nicas fieles a Vampiro que aportan interactividad a un g√©nero que a veces no la tiene
- Historia atrapante con decisiones que influyen en la trama...

Lo malo:
- ...pero que al final desembocan en una conclusi√≥n precipitada
- En todo momento se siente como una aventura que es acotada, que podr√≠a profundizar en varias cosas m√°s, a pesar de que lo que ofrece es bueno.

While I understand the disappointment from whomever expected this game to be close to either the tabletop experience or Bloodlines, as a big fan of both Vampire: The Masquerade and visual novels, I'm very happy with it. It does a wonderful job bringing the mood of VtM through beautiful artwork, interesting characters, and engaging writing (even if the ending can be understandably controversial; I personally liked it).

If you're looking for fun gameplay, affecting the outcome of the story, or living your own story in a VtM setting, Coteries of New York isn't for you. This is more akin to reading through someone else's campaign, or a short novel.

That being said, I really need Qadir to fuck my ass

column8:
So, I am a long time fan of the Vampire: The Masquerade series. Played the table-top version, and Bloodlines when it came out (yes even the other game that we don't really talk about before Bloodlines either) and for someone who has played the table-top and Bloodlines, I appreciated this game for the lore. It is a good intro game for the series for those unfamiliar with it, but it came with a cost.

The story to me was heavily disappointing (especially the ending) and I won't post spoilers. I will however, say that the game makes you feel like your choices make a huge impact and that there could be multiple endings or your choices may actually make some sort of impact. In all seriousness it all just comes to the same shitty conclusion no matter how many times you play, no matter what choices you make, and definitely no matter whether you pick the Brujah, Toreador, or Ventrue character. It all comes to the same shitty conclusion that was semi-interesting but the plot twist was kind of half-assed.

Honestly this game is NOT worth the $17.99 I payed for. The art is beautiful and the music is cool. Hell, the mechanics are also nice but it's just another two-dimensional storytelling game. I play a LOT of different storytelling games and enjoy them, but I draw the line at crappy storytelling and that's what this game did in my eyes. You don't get to really learn about the characters much or their backgrounds either. I'd say this is a $5 game max. 

I definitely won't be going back and playing more either. I recall spending hours replaying Bloodlines and going through the different clans and choices but this? This almost kinda feels like a slap in the face as a fan. Whether this was some sort of rushed project or the staff was not allowed to go into certain depths like they may have wanted to, I still just am super disappointed.

column8: i like it. It has quite the art, interesting story. Im not through after 2 hours but theres quite the replayabilty.
column9: i like it. It has quite the art, interesting story. Im not through after 2 hours but theres quite the replayabilty.

column8:
This game has potential and I really want to like it but in its current state I cant recommend it. Other than what the other reviews said I can add that 

-It's a pretty good and interesting visual novel game with a good amount of reading.
-Really cool playing as a new vampire in the VtM universe.
-The game could do a better job showing your Hunger status or explaining stuff! My first playthrough I had no idea when the Hunger would kick in and I would die. 
-Possibly my biggest gripe is that when you die you cant load your saves. If you die 4 hours into the game, that's 4 hours lost, you need to start from 0.
-There were some bugs here and there like a string of text repeating itself 5 times before actually continuing but nothing major. 
-Half way through the story there's still no clue as to what your preferred blood type is (as a Ventrue).
-Your choices dont actually matter that much.
-3 somewhat different stories.

It's not really that bad of a game but it needs some work. I'm looking forward to some fixes and QOL stuff before I can recommend it.

column8: The initial realisation that the game was a text based pick-your-path adventure was disappointed at first, but the characters are interesting, the story line engrossing and the twists startling enough to overcome any hesitation at the games format. It is a lot of fun, and has surprising replay value.

It is a lot of fun, and has surprising replay value.

column8: I was disappointed. Choices don't have enough impact, and there's only one real ending. The art is spectacular and the lore of the source material is well represented, but those are the only positives. If you want a pretty picture book, this is okay. If you want a well crafted visual novel, look elsewhere.
column9: I was disappointed. Choices don't have enough impact, and there's only one real ending. The art is spectacular and the lore of the source material is well represented, but those are the only positives. If you want a pretty picture book, this is okay. If you want a well crafted visual novel, look elsewhere.

column8:
For the price it is absolutely not worthwhile.
Three basically identical playthroughs, poor tracking of decisions, little to no ability to influence the story. Maybe 5 hours of playtime.
If you can get it for 5 Euros or less it is a nice virtual novel/choose your own adventure game.
Other than that, forget about it.
And I say that as somebody who dearly loved both Bloodlines and Redemption.

column8:
Only 3 clans available. 
Very linear story line in which your choices barely matter. 
Graphically nice to see but it is sad some pictures are reused repeatedly illustrating different scenes / areas, I would have liked more illustrations to accompany the story for the price paid.

There are discrepancies with the canon lore (e.g. many non clan disciplines available for a neonate, Nosferatu clan being told as unnaturally monstrous which would lead to masquerade breached contrary to v5 errata, Ventrue bane only played in the early beginning, but not followed up later on).

The game seem to have been rushed to meet the deadline, unfinished. This is way too much expensive for the content proposed. Hopefully additional content and correctives will be added for free in the near future.

column8: I enjoyed this, although I wouldn't exactly call it a game. It's more of a short story that you can affect to a small degree by your choices. The story was quite good, though, so I found it worth my time. It was a bit like playing a vampire game that's had all the combat removed, and just left the story line. I really like the whole Vampire:The Masquerade environment, so this was a nice addition to the lore for me.

column8:
‚ÄúCoteries‚Äù is like your friend with a drug problem - he asks for money, he gives many promises, he never fulfils them.

The characters are interesting, but there is no time to develop them. The story starts with a bang but ends in a puddle. There are a lot of choices but they all lead to one outcome.

The mood is consistent and thoroughly written, but it lacks inspiration and creativity. All that seedy motels, clubs and landmarks look like a wholesale purchase from gothicpunk-express.com. I bet there are still ‚ÄúMade in China‚Äù labels on some of them.

The plot looks like a magician with OCD - it shows the same trick ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an ambush bwahaha!‚Äù again and again. After the third time you want to dial 911 and report a case of lazy writing.

The protagonist is not ideal either. They should be more helpless. Wouldn‚Äôt it be great for them to fall into a coma right at the beginning of the game? Then we could get rid of those pesky personal agendas and freedom of choice!

Jokes aside, Coteries is a curious example of ‚Äúanti-power fantasy‚Äù. It can be a great success as an object of research. Sadly, it‚Äôs a complete disaster as a game.

column8:
A nice little visual novel game to tide us over until Bloodlines 2 comes out. The art style is great and the characters are cool. There isn't any voice acting but that's fine since the background ambience and music are all well done. There are branching choices you can take but ultimately the ending is the same. It feels like they're teasing a sequel of some kind or a tie-in with Bloodlines 2, but I ultimately doubt it. Worth getting for the low price during a sale if you're a fan of the medium, adds a bit to the lore and helps get you ready for Bloodlines 2.

p.s. to devs: give us a spin-off with D'Angelo or my mate Gregory please

column8:
A great game! Plus points, its a great story from begging to end. Really in touch with the WOD (World Of Darkness) Its all reading. If that's not your scene, don't buy it. But if you don't mind, its very intriging, brutal and very on point. (just the way it should be)
Lots of replayable missions. All in all an awesome game! Would defianlty recommmend.

column8: I didn‚Äôt think Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Coteries of New York was going to be 'my type', but it was clear after an hour in that I had been embraced; an alluring storytelling experience, new fans to the franchise will find a short but sweet title that is sure to please. Veterans of the saga might feel perhaps a little letdown by the same things that the newbies enjoyed, but there‚Äôs so many peripheral aspects to bolster it that it‚Äôs all-too-easy to overlook the few shortcomings. If you have even the slightest interest in vampiric visual novels, Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Coteries of New York definitely belongs in your Steam library.

If you have even the slightest interest in vampiric visual novels, Vampire: The Masquerade ‚Äì Coteries of New York definitely belongs in your Steam library.

column8: The game has a promising start, but it turned out to be too short, and ends with a silly cliched cliffhanger that doesn't make sense. Not recommended.

column8: Forces SJW politics down your neck.
column9: Forces SJW politics down your neck.

column8:
"Show, don't tell" my teachers said in school. 
This game constantly tells me how I am supposed to feel about the lazy writing in this game. No, I'm neither horrified, nor impressed by your bleak Vampire story with pointless choices.

column8: Beautiful art direction, audio design and atmosphere is on point. Very pleasing to look at, but even for a visual novel, it seems a little lacking at the moment. Recommending it with the caveat of: don't buy it full price and as long as you're aware that it's on the shorter side.

column8: If you like roleplaying (and visual novels), know or are a great fan of the world of darkness, this is a game for you. :) I enjoy the story telling and the navigating of the world, trying to survive and recruit members to your coterie. I think it's definetly worth it.

column8:
My first time playing this type of 'choose your own adventure' novel-type game. I think it's great! Detailed story, interesting characters. Wordy at times.

If you're a VTM fan, I really suggest getting this game!

column8:
If you like visual novels and the world of darkness, I definitely recommend this game!
It's not quite a visual novel, but still close enough. It has perma-death, so if you die, your save gets deleted, so do be careful. Overall very cool! Haven't beaten it yet. Only constructive criticism I may have is the game could use an automatic button, for the dialogue to continue automatically, as well as maybe a skip button, to skip through dialogue fast.

column8: I liked it, it was nice to play a visual novel around choices. I was hoping for more clans and more different female and male characters to choose from.And maybe a bit more lore behind the characters clans.. But i am glad they at least had one female in it to choose. I spend a good couple of days casually playing this game.

column8:
Dieses Spiel ist eine Art interaktives Buch. Es scheint das 50% der Spieler zufrieden damit sind und 50% eben nicht. Das ist Geschmacksache. Ich bin froh das Spiel gekauft zu haben. Mir scheint dem Spieler wird hier etwas abverlangt: Das Gef√ºhl verantwortlich f√ºr das eigene Handeln zu sein um seine Umwelt zu beeinflussen. Wie reagiert mein Gespr√§chspartner darauf? Gehe ich zu weit? Bin ich ihm gleichwertig oder gar minderwertig? √úberlebe ich die n√§chste Entscheidung und kann ich mit dieser leben? Es sind diese moralischen Fragen die das Spiel f√ºr mich so interessant machen.

Kurzum ich bin begeistert! Bitte mehr solcher Titel im Universum von "World of Darkness".

column8: Die Artworks sind echt gut gelungen. Die einzelnen Begleiterquest machen Spa√ü und erz√§hlen viel √ºber das System und das Setting per se. Jedoch ist der Hauptplot absoluter Mist. Ich bin vollkommen entt√§uscht. Ich bin ein Fan von dramaturgisch Wendungen aber das hier schl√§gt echt dem Fass den Boden aus. Wer Spa√ü an kurzweiligen tragischen Geschichten hat, der wird hier seinen Spa√ü finden. Aber f√ºr mich hat dieses Spiel keinen Wiederspielwert.

Coteries of New York at times feels like its missing pieces, but that didn't stop me getting sucked into a enthralling and atmospheric story. It really nails the atmosphere of Vampire: The Masquerade, putting you in a position of hopelessness and despair in the gloomy new york streets. The characters all feel unique and engaging, making you a little sad that the experience is only 3-4 hours for a playhtrough(though you need more than one playthrough to do all the side stories).

column8: You know I was likeing this game until the ending. When the game takes all control away from you, shoves one of the worst "twists" I've seen for a long time down your throat, implys things that are untrue, and makes it very clear that your choices don't mean a damn thing.  I haven't been burned by a game in a long time and I can't even say I should better because of the type of game this is. I've played better visual novles and dating sims that had better writting and more respect for the player than this. Theres no excuse, this is just lazy and malicious. I'm so glad I didn't piss away money on this game and I'm so sorry for those who did. Please, don't get this game. Theres no reason to when you could be playing bloodlines, Bloodlines will treat you better.
