column8:
I was looking forward to any sort of Vampire The Masquerade type of game for years, especially since Bloodlines 1. With the failed MMO and rumors about other games I was super excited for this game when I heard it was coming out, especially since nothing else in this "world" will be out in the foreseeable future.

Now does this game live up to the hype? Or at least the hype I put on it. I would have to say no, the game is lacking a lot.

First is the price, at ~$20 this game is rather short, with very little replay-ability as you will see in other reviews your choices really dont matter and the clan/character you choose (not even a male/female customization, I mean I dont code video games but how hard would it be to switch male/female pronouns throughout the story based on the character you choose) doesnt change much either aside for Ventrue only being able to feed on certain people (which I hear is bugged/tough to figure out) and random vampire powers which give little change in how things play out.

I will say the game is great in capturing the feel, lore and atmosphere on this gameworld and the music/art are pretty enjoyable too.

What I dont like is the save function. You cant backtrack if you misclick something or dont like how something played out. I accidently misclicked something and a result I didnt like - I dont want to say any spoilers - but basically I failed at being stealthy, HOWEVER, at the end of the mission the person who was evaluating me said I did a great job of being stealthy so theres more proof choices dont really matter.

As mentioned this game is short, it ended on a cliffhanger if you can call it that and it didnt leave me satisfied. Also I had plenty of other quest-lines to finish but the game forced me into the finale before I had the chance, they should at least give you the opportunity to save the finale until after youve completed the other quests given how short the game is.

Maybe my expectations were too high? Maybe I got caught up in the hype? In any case I will try this game again in a while once I forget about the story a little and see if my experience changes.

If you love Vampire the masquerade or are hyped for Bloodlines 2 and want a feel for the world/lore I would definitely check this game out, just temper your expectations and know what youre in for. I would wait for a sale as well unless you just NEED to play it/something right now.

The game is average with the obvious flaws youll find in most reviews and its extremely short for a visual novel style game but it does have its merits. The main one being its the only Vampire the Masquerade "game" in a long long time.

Anyway, I recommend this game.

column8:
Really disappointing. I went into this excited, I don't mind visual novels so I was interested in what a VtM brand visual novel would be like but it was nothing special. 

1) For a game that was more visual novel than anything else, it has none of the quality of life features that VNs usually have. There is no skip function or skip read text function so replaying the game is annoying. The save system is very limited, and even if you try to cheat and force close the game to avoid the "save and quit" option (I tried this because I wanted to go back to a previous save spot so I could choose a different dialogue option) it still seems to autosave. This save system also makes it difficult to playthrough the game, especially when either due to bugs or dev choice, a lot of the time the outcomes of your choices lead to the opposite of what you thought would happen. It just felt like they wanted to make a VN but didn't look at the standard QoL functions VNs usually have to make playing them not a chore. 

2) Numerous little bugs in choices and outcomes + railroading. I think they patched some of them the first day but others still remain. It was also annoying how sometimes the player would either be railroaded or not given enough information when it came to choosing dialogue options. For instance (slight spoilers ahead), [spoiler]in the beginning you can choose to be docile and polite. But after a few of these, you get a set of choices where you have no other option but to suddenly be rude/insulting. And then that rude remark is commented on later and acts as a little strike against you. Why would we suddenly be forced to only be rude when up until then we could be either/or? [/spoiler]
An example of not being given enough information was in the Ventrue playthrough (another slight spoiler ahead related to feeding habits). As a Ventrue, [spoiler] you're a picky eater and so in the beginning (it seemed to not matter toward the end) your pc would fail to feed off of people whose blood they couldn't stomach. So you get a few options of choosing where to feed from and maybe I'm just stupid, but with the little info we were given about the person whose blood we DID like, I felt like I was just guessing. I got it wrong the first time and restarted the game to try over. [/spoiler] There was also similar lack of info to make informed decisions in the Nosferatu Detective questline. 

3) The feeding/beast mechanic was confusing to me. Not every scenario had an opportunity for you to feed, and in some instances, feeding seemed like a bad idea (ie: you were trying to be stealthy and feeding on someone with a dog might cause the dog to bark and alert people, etc). So there were a few times where I ended up accidentally starving my character because I ignored a feeding opportunity that seemed like it might hurt me/ruin the mission, and then didn't get any other opportunities. 

Overall, the good things about this game were definitely the atmosphere, that feeling of hopeless dread, of thinking "HEY I'M A BADASS VAMP" until you realize you're nothing to most of your vampire peers, the artstyle, some of the npcs, and the music. I would have liked to at least not be genderlocked in the character options, and would have liked to see more clans to choose from. It was also disappointing that your clan didn't really seem to matter in the game that much. Usually the uniqueness of the clans, their quirks and differences, is something highlighted in VtM but here no one in the game ever even comments on your character's clan (unless it happens in a sidequest I didn't do). There are small things like Ventrue [spoiler] picky eater [/spoiler], and the different disciplines but for the most part I would have liked to see more dialogue options and npc comments related to my character's clan.

I would recommend getting this game on a decent sale only. I can't really say it felt worth $20 and the ending left me feeling cheated.

column8:
This game IS NOT WORTH 19.99, in any sane universe. It is an extremely short visual novel where you could find yourself on the mission to end the game totally by accident: there is absolutely no warning. Myself and a number of other reviewers, apparently, found themselves ending the game with a number of missions still left on the table, unfinished, and I for one did not enjoy this game enough to suffer through another playthrough just for completionist's sake.

Another thing to note is that this game had a very different description upon release. They've recently changed it to more accurately reflect the actual content of the game. Some people give them kudos for listening to the player base and making the appropriate changes; I find it to be deceitful business practice. The developers should have had the insight to write an accurate description of their game from the start.

column8: Quite fun, even if main story is heavily railroaded. I was disappointed with how short it was, but I guess it makes sense with the price tag. I really hope there will be a sequel at some point as it felt that it finished just as it was getting really good.
column9: Quite fun, even if main story is heavily railroaded. I was disappointed with how short it was, but I guess it makes sense with the price tag. I really hope there will be a sequel at some point as it felt that it finished just as it was getting really good.

column8:
A simple visual novel with VTM and at a great price? why not? VNs are not really my thing but I can say I really enjoyed this. Mind you, i've only completed 1 play.
If you don't mind a bit of reading I think you'll enjoy the characters, writing and music of what this has to offer.  

With only one play I cant say how important your choices mean to the overall game, but they seem to help steer the story in the direction it goes. Hopefully after I start/finish Brujah i'll know more.

I do agree with a few of the reviews about the ending, at least the one I watched. Assuming other plays would be about the same, if not, but it was a bit of a "sudden" end BUT hoping there would be more to follow with more? who knows.

column8: It offers less than expected, as a VTM game, and it's awfully short with and ending that make me play again to be sure that I didn't have chosen something wrong and got killed. I love VTM and I'd like to have more games set in the World of Darkness, but this one isn't a very good one. I hope they keep on updating more story, because at the moment it's just a waste of money and time.

column8:
I've wrote this review after my first walkthrough. So everything is based on it.
First of all, I must notice that storyline is splendid. Such tension, based on brutality and toughness of WoD; an unforgetible vibe of predatory world that can break you down in every second. I personally felt the goosebumps 'cause it is THE World of Darkness, or it is should be for me. All those faces in game that I've seen in role-playing game, like Hellene, Qadir or Callihan were moved in PC game, and I was really glad to see them in it. If you've read about them, you can see the hints of their biographies in game, so you do understand what made them tick. 
Second, but not least it is the music and pictures. It is important part of visual novel and I can give developers a credit, 'cause these thing make the game bloom. At least two of your sences can fully enjoy the game. I liked what I've heard and what I saw. Not to mention of what I've read!
I confess: I'm more into 3d edition of VtM (revised), so at first I was really sceptical about this game. For some reason I thought that I will see some things that I didn't like in 5th edition, but now I can tell that there were nothing that I didn't enjoy. There are no rough edges to point at. Maybe 'cause the mechanics is different (hey, it's a visual novel after all!) or just 'cause the storyline was really exciting so I didn't notice things that I'm no fond of.
If it were my decision (it's not, but I still want to say) I would add more clans in choice of a main character. I know it's hard work, even to have those three, but it can really change the game and do it more interesting. You could play a nosferatu, goddamit! If it's not enough to totally change the game then I don't know what can.
And have an opportunity to change sex of your character (so you could play a toreador-woman or brujah, or a ventrue-man) would be the best. It's very motivating for players like me - I'm a girl and I REALLY like to play characters of my own sex, so maybe I'm not the only one in this.
Of course I understand that some things that I've proposed can change the game, add more choices and lines, and it's a big step (financially and intellectually, 'cause it takes a big effort to put it in game), but it totally worth it. Maybe with an addon (that comes with a price of course, 'cause work must be rewarded), or something.
I tell you what: if there were a visual novel from these developers about Werewolf: the Apocalypse it would be no less interesting to play in. Such a team can take every single line from the old World of Darkness and make it a candy. 
So thank you for this game and your efforts; some of us are really appreciated.

column8: Ambiance fid√®le aux oeuvres originales, pnjs pour la plus par charismatiques intrigues secondaires toutes aussi int√©ressantes  que la principal . les 3 seuls d√©fauts constat√©s sont l'absence de traduction, de choix de personnage et de fin alternative ( pour autant que je sache )

Very atmospheric text based roleplay, true Vampire: The Masquerade style. This game isn't about winning. It's about experiencing the drama and the misery that a newly created Vampire has to go through in cainite society, getting caught up their corrupted political games of deception, greed and betrayal. Personally I wish there would be more clans to choose from as well as more diversity on how the game plays out based on the decions you make. This would also increase the re-playability of this game immensly - just take a look at VTM Bloodlines to get an idea of how it can be done right. Also the abilites you're able to use in certain situations don't always align with the clan you chose but I hope this is just a minor bug. All in all an entertaining experience though. The artwork is gorgeous, the soundtrack matches the atmosphere the game is trying to create. Hoping for more content to come.

CONTAINS SPOILERS!!!
_
_
_
_
While I do recommend this game, it is lacking. While the ending is alright in and of itself, the lead up is quite linear and seems a little rushed. My first playthrough I was so unprepared that I hadn't advanced any of the coterie's plots too far and yet two still showed up to save me. Thought that was kind of odd, two strangers popping up and suddenly my friends. That being said though, I loved the characters and found the story engaging (granted in some places more than others).

For the price, it is a very enjoyable visual novel game that involves vampires. Looking at it as a VTM chronicle? Ehhhhhhh.....

column8: Massa!

I'm sorry to say it, but I'm very disappointed with this game.

CoNY has an interesting plot, VERY well written characters, but sadly fails in being a GAME!
I know, this is a visual novel and I don't have any problem with this... BUT many of your character choices doesn't matter at all, the ending feels rushed and forced without any meaningfull player's options. The clan choice at the beginning brings only a few different lines of dialogue...

This game could have been so much better, it's a wasted opportunty in many ways. The thing that absolutely makes me angry about it is the lack of attention for details... like: I've been nice with one character in one scene and the next time I meet him he doesn't even recognize me! From that moment I could no longer take the game seriously.
I repeat, this could have been a great interactive novel with memorable WoD characters, maybe the first chapter in a story about New York vampires, but instead... :(

column8: An amazing game full of intrigue and action. I loved every second of it. If you are a fan of Vampire the Masquerade do yourself a favor and pick this game up!

column8:
Should be a must have for fans of the WOD. It does a good job of portraying the bleak atmosphere and what it feels like to be a fledgling, in a world that you no longer understand. It stays faithful to the source material, and to the VTM cannon. 

Does the visual novel system work? 

Short answer? Yes! The visual novel structure seems to fit the quirky nature of the World of Darkness quite well. It puts into perspective both what the protagonist might feel, and the limited way he interprets the world around him as in inexperienced fledgling, hoping to live long enough to become a neonate. As a storytelling medium, i hope more iterations will come out in the future. 

Mood and Ambiance

The music isn't very memorable, but it fits the graphic style and setting perfectly! All three combined knit together an eerie atmosphere that can follow you throughout the day, even after you stop playing. There are a few moral choices, but the story itself still feels organic. It still conveys a story about flawed individuals, and their attempt to hold on to their lost Humanity.  And for me at least, that's exactly what any first contact with the WOD should be all bout. 

Should you buy this?

Yes! The game has a lot of potential, and could be a start for a new direction for both WOD fans and more indie devs to explore. Supporting the devs and encouraging them to make more games like this one will result in more polished and more varied mediums for people to explore VTM and all of its subtle intricacies.

column9: Fun vampire stuff.

column8:
Sadly, I can't recommend this game... It felt like reading a soft novel instead of actually playing. 

As a long time V:TES fan, this was rather underwhelming and disappointing, with very limited actions/choices that actually affect the story you're playing. 
Sure, you have enough plot to get you through a few hours of gameplay but that's it, and I will of course finish the game with all available characters but I cannot recommend this to someone else when there's much better games out there in this genre...

And now I'll wait patiently for Bloodlines 2 to come out.

column8: I am quite torn on this one. While I loved the story, the characters, and the setting, the game is just too short and limited in replayability to be worth the price. Your choices pretty much don't affect anything, and there are no multiple endings. If you are an absolutely huge VtMB fan, then I would buy it, I enjoyed it a lot. That being said, everyone else should get it with a good discount.

column8:
I really wish there was a "eh, maybe?" button for this game. I'm a sucker (I know, I know) for the V:tM setting. The atmosphere of this game was very engaging. There's a lot of love for the setting shining through. That's what had my vote. I looked forward to playing, and I had fun.

By my second run-through though, the shine was a little tarnished. It's a visual-novel railroad. Few choices offer any substantial effect on the story. 

As other reviewers noted, there are still a lot of bugs, such as character portraits missing, or odd responses from an NPC given your selection. Some dialogue seems to infer reactions or choices that you didn't make, and some parts of the story seem to come out of the blue without sufficient context.

Finally, it is crying out for a skip function. You'll find yourself repeating a lot of the same scenes, and it'd be great to zip along by the time you're on the third character. That is, if you stick around.

column8:
Hate to say this but Red Embrace Hollywood is a better VTM visual novel than the actual VTM. It is HEAVILY inspired by VTM but more anime style. Amazing visual novel. Create custom character (very limited options but still) Tons of outcomes. Relationship panels. Check it out seriously it is great!

Writting after one play through and just starting the next...It's just OKAY. Would STILL RECOMMEND because it slightly scratches that VTM itch while waiting for Bloodlines 2. The art and music are both fantastic. HOWEVER, it is missing some really important things (in my opinion) most importantly that there is no ability to quickly skip already seen dialogue! Very frustrating going through your second playthough and dying (because you are a rebel this time so why not try escape lol) and not be able to skip and having to mouse click the little continue button (because thats the only way to move forward WHY NO SPACE BAR???) over and over until you get back to where you were. There are no relationship panels, no unlockable art, and really nothing beyond a log of what has been said and a dictonary for those who may be unfamiliar with the lore of the game. That was pretty disappointing. Also can only have one save at time per play through. I was okay with that as it made it seem like choices mattered more. But since no skip would have been nice to load a previous save. All in all I liked it. Still need to do 2 more playthroughs to really say. On starting the second it is clear that they all play differently but also overlap. I am curious to see how the others play out and hoping endgame will be different. Plan to talk to people I could not get to the first time.

OVERALL its great in art, music, story, characters. Missing very helpful and desired game mechanics. RED EMBRACE HOLLYWOOD IS BY FAR THE BETTER OF THE VISUAL NOVELS.

column8:
This game is a Mixed start to what i hope will be a series. I recommend it full to fans of Vampire the masquerade and those who are wanting to explore the IP but if you are just looking for a visual novel this may not be for you due to the linear story not fitting well with the format.

Pros:
wonderful art
great writing
Fun characters
True to the WoD
good introduction

Cons
Railroad plot (suits VtM but not a VN nor replayable)
Buggy (dialog/power oversights and all, nothing game breaking)
Autosave System, while making you stick to you mistake can be good if done right, this wasn't IMO
Stories and characters are too isolated, a came about building a coterie has little to do about a coterie and just everyone's story.
Lack of a Tremere player character, for shame :p

column8: Never played any VTM before but tried this game and was surprised to find how quickly you get pulled into the world, gained a fan of the series. Only complaint is I played through it too quick and am hooked too see it followed up!

column8:
There's some interesting interaction and mini-stories around the whole thing. And it does a pretty good job of maintaining that VtM atmosphere for the first playthrough at least, even if that's largely just the effects of good background art and ambient music selection. 

That's about as far as the good goes. Otherwise I can't decide if this is a quick IP-based cash grab or a rush job on an already-unambitious visual novel. The only branching options are picking some missions over others which don't have a significant impact at any point, aside from choosing which side story you get. And the main story is A) permanent and unmalleable, B) deeply unsatisfying especially given the fact that there's no branching at all, and also C) about as short as any of the individual side stories anyway. The ending was so abrupt, weird, and lame that I had to go back and read up on the secret achievements as a way to determine if there was more to it. I ran through all three character stories and although one has a slightly different, more interesting flavor in a few text boxes, they are otherwise functionally identical. It would be trivial to go back and get my last couple secret achievements in one round but there's absolutely no reason to bother.

I could nitpick further... there seems to have been some missed items in QA, some of the dialogue is at the level of fan-fiction cliche, blah blah. There's no point. There's no satisfaction to be had here.

column8: I just love this game. There is so much insight into the World Of Darkness universe.
column9: I just love this game. There is so much insight into the World Of Darkness universe.

column8: I'd buy it on sale, it's not really worth $20, but it does serve as a fantastic primer to the universe if you're looking to get into the lore of Vampire: The Masquerade. As an actual game it plays more as an interactive comic book than anything else.
column9: I'd buy it on sale, it's not really worth $20, but it does serve as a fantastic primer to the universe if you're looking to get into the lore of Vampire: The Masquerade. As an actual game it plays more as an interactive comic book than anything else.

column8:
Did I enjoy playing through VtM:CoNY? Yea, I did.
Would I at this point recommend the game at full price? No, I wouldn't.
Or at least, not without a caveat.

It was a nice lore refresher, and decent way to hold over before VtM:Bloodlines 2 comes out. But I'm going to be honest. It took me just over 6 hours to complete everything - including all hidden achievement conditions.

That's a tall order to justify a recommendation for a ‚Ç¨20 game. Even if you pick it up at a discount.

So if you're considering getting this, because you want some Vampire: The Masquerade to hold you over till Bloodlines 2? Know that there's not a lot of content to this game. What's there is pretty decent. There's just not a lot of it.

column8: Precisely what I was looking for: a spiritual successor to the extraordinary if uneven 2004 Bloodlines game with its virtuoso opening.  It is a visual novel that is hopefully a positive sign for the full game Bloodlines 2.
column9: Precisely what I was looking for: a spiritual successor to the extraordinary if uneven 2004 Bloodlines game with its virtuoso opening.  It is a visual novel that is hopefully a positive sign for the full game Bloodlines 2.

column8:
Coteries of New York delivers four hours of immersion into the WoD setting. If you are looking for a game, this is not for you. It's a visual novel that puts you straight into the WoD, amplifying the atmosphere with well designed visuals and excellent ambient music.

If this is what you're looking for, buy it. I enjoyed it thoroughly.

Âä†ÂÖ•[url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/GHYX]Âπ≤Ë¥ßÊ∏∏Êàè[/url]&ÂÖ≥Ê≥®[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35106417/]ÊàëÁöÑÈâ¥ËµèÂÆ∂[/url]Ôºå‰∏çÂÆöÊúü‰∏∫Â§ßÂÆ∂Â∏¶Êù•ËØöÊÑèÊª°Êª°ÁöÑÊ∏∏Êàè‰ΩìÈ™åÂπ≤Ë¥ß„ÄÇ
[/quote]

Get on sale if interested. There's just too many better competitors for the price tag and if you're looking for a better introduction to VtM (and don't mind googling a mod) Bloodlines is always there.

For a game named "Coteries of New York" both the Coterie aspect is severely underplayed (remove it and it would change absolutely nothing in the plot) and the New York aspect feels more of a paint job than a proper setting, which is a downer since other games do so well with it's particular geography, districts and culture.

[list]
    [*] The script (most important aspect for a VN) is pretty good 90% of the time. There's definitely some scenes where the writers bit more than they could chew and it's distracting, or the unusual reference, but overall it's as good as you would want.
    [*] Artwork is pretty good and the soundtrack meshes just fine even if it's not remarkable.
    [*] Individual questlines are intriguing and the highlight of the game. There's enough for 2-3 playthroughs of 4-5 hours.
    [*] While you do get to use your powers quite often, very few ocassions feels like you actually acomplished something you couldn't have without (which is quite understandable since you're a newborn but still feels as a wasted mechanic).
    [*]There's very little agency involved, even for a VN. There's also a noticeable lack of traditional QoL improvements you would expect in one relased in 2019. 
    [*] [spoiler] I don't mind open ends, but there are so many open-ended plotlines at the end it just feels like too much setup too little deliver. Outcomes of cotery members, for once, could be solved while still leaving the MC in the open. [/spoiler]
[/list]

It pains me to not recommend since I had a good time and will play it again, but it's not something I can recommend in good faith. The coterie aspect (by far the would-be-highlight of the game) could be fixed in the future with more content, but I'm not holding my breath.

column8:
I have completed a single playthrough of this game at the time of writing. Overall, the game was pretty good, but not perfect. I'd give the game a solid 7/10 noting that I'm pretty crazy about the genre and love VtM tabletop - so I'm not certain if my expectations were simply too high or if I liked the game even more for being desperate for VtM content.

PROS
- The environmental art was pretty amazing, particularly the excellent placement of animations to make it come alive. I frequently found myself staring at environments and loving them
- The general quality of the writing was very good, and I often wondered how much trouble I'd get into if I did obviously dumb things, so there was a sense of danger and emotion about the story
- The coterie quests that I participated in (Tamika, Hope, and D'Angelo) were interesting and generally exciting (esp Hope and D'Angelo). 
- There's a clear sense that you can't do all of the content in a single playthrough, and you can see your other choices even if you don't get to them the first time through.
- It's pretty clear that there are multiple endings and multiple story options woven together
- There's a strong variety in clans and factions that you encounter in the game, and you have to pick and choose which ones you dig into
- The game was fairly strong in terms of 'canon' representations of the different characters and sects that I encountered, and generally well done in that regard

CONS
- The environmental art outshone the character art. It was okay, and thank goodness not yet another anime look, but I expected better 
- Character generation left something to be desired - 3 clans only (UPDATE: I just went to reply, looks like one option is female, 2 male)
- One thing I highly dislike in a 1st person narrative is being told how I feel, and it broke my immersion a few times even when it was appropriate
- It felt a little short - like the first chapter of a three part book. I was surprised when it ended and a bit disappointed that it ended so quickly because the game doesn't go on long enough to feel 'settled' into your coterie or really attached to the characters
- I felt like the ending I got could have been stronger in terms of a climax
- I'm not sure if I'm intrigued enough by the other possibilities to play through again.
- I'm weirded out about the woman on the cover holding a half-eaten apple with fangs. VtM vampires generally don't eat food

All in all, I wanted to love it, but instead just liked it. It's still head and shoulders better than several of the other visual novels I've played, so it gets a recommend, but as I said - 7/10.

column8:
I purchased this game primarily because I love the genre. Iv'e been a huge White-wolf fan since I was a child. I pay for the things I love because I want them to continue being made and the fact of the matter is if we don't pay they don't make... NOW..With that being said 

This game was indeed a lot of fun in the beginning the immersion was top notch and I grew fond of the characters and was truly intrigued with the story... That's when things seemed to somewhat spiral. I couldn't complete the stories I wanted to finish before the game decided that it was the end and then basically the game forced me into decisions that seemed abstract to my initial choice of game-play. ( I wanted to go FULL cam) I feel like its just a tad incomplete.. but if they work on it and get the kinks out I can see this being a really enjoyable interactive read. I give it a 3.5 out of 5 because I feel that there is potential here if worked on. OH also you can't pick your sex and there's only 3 clans which kind of sucked but I imagine they will release more options later..

column8: This is no Bloodlines, or even Redemption, but I am still happy to have a little Vampire the Masquerade game to tide me over till Bloodlines 2 is out. The format is a visual novel, so you are not getting much in terms of gameplay. The main mechanics are making dialogue choices in the narrative, deciding whom you will help or not, and how you will hunt to keep the Beast at bay. There are three clans that you can play as, a male Brujah, female Ventrue. or Male Toreador. As the title implies, the setting is New York and you play a newly embraced vampire. Graphics are typical White Wolf style illustrations. The music is suitably dark gothic-punk. If you don't like Camarilla politics, this might not be the game for you. You have an adopted sire, and form a coterie of other neonates. It seems like the most you can add to your group are two allies, even if you complete more NPC side stories, only two help you in the climax. The game is pretty short. A single play through can be done in under four hours, and since there are only three characters you can play, that gives you around 12 hours total game-time, though the story line is mostly the same no matter what character you play. It feels more like a prelude to a larger game than a complete game to me. The end is pretty abrupt and I felt that it leaves unanswered the fate of your character and the resolution of the main conflict. If there is a part 2, I will definitely play that too and be happy to pay full price, but if there isn't then I will be retroactively a bit disappointed in how short this game is and say maybe you should wait till it is on sale.

Did you know that if you repeat the same words over and over it just sounds like animal noises?
Did you also know that an interesting but short story is still a short story? This game was good but then it ended too fast. This had so much potential but it was apparently rushed. The plot twist wasn't bad. It would've just been more bearable if it either wasn't followed by the end credits or if there was more to do before it was introduced. What could be worse than that? The fact that the ending will always be the same no matter what you do. Your choices don't matter when it comes to the story sequence.

column8:
Tough to say but I'm gonna lean on yes for now. I'll try to be spoiler free as possible but yeah. maybe spoilers

My biggest gripe is that [spoiler] the story doesn't matter. The ending is always the same. No matter who you help, how well you help Sophie, who you get into your coterie, you end up at the same ending. The ending that completely makes everything you did irrelevant. Sophie dies, the plan has no effect. It was all planned for from the start and you were a double agent.[/spoiler]

The story though is fun. Each individual quest-line I've tried so far has held my interest which has led me to, despite my personal gripe, play through it multiple times. Save for The Baron, I find the characters to be intricate and well written.

column8:
Offenses:

1. You have no gender options.

2. There are only 3 clans available.

3. They attempted to make the Ventrue woman look strong willed by stating she told HR about a hot female coworker list that was being passed around by her male peers. That's not strong, that's sniveling snitch weak. The fact that other peoples personal criticism of you made you cry to human resources shows what a weak self conscious spine this individual has instead.

4. The Ventrue female was allowed to choke, cower and emasculate her former male boss while the Brujah dudes ex girlfriend was allowed to openly assault him twice because she was upset and walk away without so much as being given the chance for a reprimand. Why does the green light for assault changed based on genitalia? That's what we call sexism in English and no, it ain't a one way street. I suggest whoever wrote that be corrected on their views of right & wrong.

5. I was feeding on a woman in the park when the author seen fit to interject with "There is no need to discriminate" and forced me to feed on her boyfriend too. Problem is I'm not into feeding on boys. Everyone has their immutable preferences and trying to low key dictate them ain't gonna get you anywhere but negative criticism and lost sales. 

6. Despite the title flaunting 'Coteries', you only get 1 mission with your crew and even in that, you're just a captive audience. You spend all that time recruiting these Vampires and then you don't see them again until the mini mission at the end where they go their separate ways. That's weak and borderline false advertising.

7. The grand scheme of the story itself is flimsy. You become a Vampire and go through these 'trials' simply because another vampire is upset they were damned and so does the same to you in turn because they want to show that they can shape others fate too. Choices didn't matter just so the author could announce they wrote a linear game. It's really pathetic and anticlimactic. Whoever wrote that needs to work on getting their creative juices flowing a helluva lot more.



Pros:

1. The npc characters personalities are written very well.

2. The independent stories you do on the map are very well written. 

That's about it. 


Overall I wouldn't recommend this. Its not as bad as that collectively panned trash "World of Darkness Preludes: Vampire and Mage" that they just stealth pulled off the steam store but it has repeated a few of its sins. Primarily the railroading and dictating preferences.

column8: I enjoyed it for what it was.  A short choose your own adventure story set in the WOD.  I would recommend picking it up when it goes on sale given it isn't as long or engaging as a novel a quarter of it's price.

column8: A visual novel that does the world of Vampire: The Masquerade justice. It makes you feel truly as a Kindred would in its universe; small, almost desperate at all times, left in the dark while being expected to play this high stakes game of political intrigue the right way, even on your first night in.
column9: A visual novel that does the world of Vampire: The Masquerade justice. It makes you feel truly as a Kindred would in its universe; small, almost desperate at all times, left in the dark while being expected to play this high stakes game of political intrigue the right way, even on your first night in.

column8:
PROS
#1 Replay Value
Despite Con #1 - which I'll get to - it has a high replay value. After finishing, my first playthrough, I immediately started a new game. And upon finishing that, I immediately started another, which, as of writing this review, I‚Äôm currently playing through. The game is fairly short and you have a limited amount of time to complete your numerous tasks, so you can‚Äôt possibly discover everything in a single playthrough. This is great, because it allows you to play characters from the three available clans and still discover new things in each playthrough.

#2 Characters
This game has excellent characters in it. Every character has depth, a backstory, and motivations. It‚Äôs really fun getting to learn more about each one, seeing what makes them tick, and figuring out how to best assist them. I found the potential coterie members of the Nosferatu and the Malkavian to be especially well-written, but truly, every character is brilliant.

#3 Atmosphere
The stunning artwork and the ambient soundtrack and sound effects really help to immerse you into this universe. The sound isn‚Äôt particularly important from a gameplay standpoint, and you could theoretically listen to your own music while playing, but you‚Äôd really be souring the experience doing so.

#4 Storytelling, Prose, and Dialogue
The prose is beautifully written and the dialogue is believable and varied. The characters all have their own unique voice and perspective. As for the storytelling (once again, despite Con #1), there were several revelations that made me audibly gasp, and several situations where I was completely torn on the best course of action, forcing me to weigh my options carefully.

#5 Introduction
This is a wonderful introduction to the World of Darkness setting. There is a daunting amount of terminology and lore for this universe and this game makes it digestible. You slowly uncover more and more lore through quests and dialogue, and every time there is a new term, you can always look back at the ever-growing dictionary page.

CONS
#1 Railroading
After two and soon to be three, albeit rewarding playthroughs, it looks to me like you can‚Äôt change the ending. I‚Äôm curious about future DLC and if it will progress the story in ways you can affect or if it will continue to railroad you.

#2 Coterie?
The title is a tad misleading. You don‚Äôt ever end up traveling around the city with your coterie. You basically always have your encounters with them in an individual context. They also don‚Äôt accompany you on your personal missions.

#3 Glitches
There are typos and minor glitches here and there, but they‚Äôre easy to overlook and never affected the gameplay. Occasionally a character would be talking without their portrait on the screen, or there would be a small issue with the audio. Updates are still happening as well, so I believe these issues will be disappearing.

OVERALL IMPRESSIONS
I would absolutely recommend this game. I‚Äôve never played a game three times in a row, in immediate succession before, let alone even once. This is also the first game on Steam that I felt the desire to write a review for. It‚Äôs beautiful, it‚Äôs enthralling, and it comes highly recommended. Get it.

This game is way too short and it ends abruptly in what promised to be an interesting story line.
column9: This game is way too short and it ends abruptly in what promised to be an interesting story line.

column8:
Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York is a visual novel set in the World of Darkness, a dark fantasy TTRPG setting produced by White Wolf Entertainment. 

First, I have to say that the game/visual novel captures the essence and the atmosphere of the World of Darkness very well. It is a a treat for all fans of the TTRPG.
The music and the artwork are on point. Honestly, I like that it takes a turn from the cringy LARP-centric photography design of the V5 rulebook and use a more familiar digital art approach that leaves room for imagination.

Unfortuneately, the game is not without flaws. It has tremendous potential but seem deliberately behind:

The choices you make do not seem to hold any real meaningful consequences. In fact, in the end, I am really unsure what I did build my coterie for? It seemed like it was part of a bigger plan, and then the game just ended. Weird.
The time runs on a clock. A few nights and the game ends. You don't know that on the first playthrough. Chances are you start a lot of quest and don't finish any of them. I am honest, this one pissed me off. I didn't even finish the second coterie quest before the end struck me.

The game is pretty short, especially since it rushes you. Playing the campaign takes about 9 hours. It might be a decent time and reasonable for the price, but then again a proper book still gives a few hundred pages more to read.  Mixed feelings. 

The story suffers under this, too. I try not to spoil anything, but it doesn't make any sense. Schemes and plots and all the talk about destiny are completely meaningless when you realise that everything would have happened as it happened even if you weren't there. You, as the main character, have as much impact on the story as somebody screaming at the television. 
In many sense, the game therefore seems a preface to the actual game! 

Technical difficulties: You can only choose 3 clans (Brujah, Ventrue and Toreador). (Maybe the most vanilla and blant clans VtM has to offer and certainly not my favorites) My disciplines as a Ventrue were Fortitute, Dominate, Presence and ... Auspex? Wait a minute... Why Auspex? Seemed like some code leaked out of the Toreador. But in the end, it also really didn't matter, I never had the feeling that I really required any of the disciplines. Or the choice really played a role. Another example of this would be the clan bane. In the beginning, it mattered a lot and I loved it for it. You drink from unknown blood sources, you puke. But as soon as you find your first tasteful victim and suddenly anyone could walk in the door and be editable - literally.

This also reflects on the story. Everything just screams for a sequel. The very first scene makes clear that the entire game is basically just a flashback! You expect it to end at some point, but it doesn't. It feels like a filler episode in the greater context of a season. 
I can only hope that this is also the future plan. Maybe next time the other view of some other coterie members. Then again, I noticed that savegame was deleted upon completion, so thats a setback for that thought.

... Yeah overall, I liked it and would recommend it for the story and atmosphere and would like to support the fascinating IP of Vampire the Masquerade, which screams for a Netflix adaptation at this point. For the game however, and any potential sequel,I would wish for a little bit more courage, alternative storylines and consequences.

column8:
[h1]PROS:[/h1] Beautiful art, great soundtrack, intriguing characters
[h1]CONS:[/h1] Few choices, no player agency, lacking critical visual novel features

[h1]OVERALL SCORE: 7/10[/h1]

Visually, this game is fantastic. The backgrounds and character art are beautiful and really fit in with the concept art of VtM. The design concept as a whole really fit with the new V5 aesthetic and it was nice to have things feel so seamless. The UI was really aesthetically pleasing as well. I also enjoyed the dictionary feature and I feel like this game could be a good introduction to some of the lore of VtM because it breaks down essential terms in a really simple way.

I liked all the characters in the games. I thought that each of the coterie members was unique and held the potential to be interesting. The problem was, they never got a chance to be developed further. You get three or four scenes with each coterie member and that's all, which just isn't enough time to really develop any attachment to them. When you get to the finale of the game, their presence isn't really noteworthy and changes very little of the scene. The same is true of the side quests - there are three unique side quests where you interact with a different side character, each with three parts, but neither of them is explored enough to really feel satisfying.

The story itself just felt too short. It's about 6 hours of playtime, depending on how fast you read. Because of this, it feels like you're booted out of the game just as the world is starting to become familiar. The ending itself is a cliffhanger, which almost makes things worse. Just as things were getting good, and we're left not knowing where the story goes.

Player agency is a big issue in this game. You get three different clan choices to choose from, each with a different backstory and that lead to small changes in dialogue after the prologue. You get to choose which coterie members to pursue, and if you want to pursue side quests. But that's really where any sort of agency stops. It doesn't matter if, for instance, in the beginning of the game, you're aggressive or if you're compliant - you still get declared unruly. In another case, you can talk to a guy twice in the same night, he clearly knows your face, and then the next night, he can go "Who the hell are you?" There's no variation of endings, unless you get an early end and die. None of your choices throughout the game reflect in the ending, except a brief scene where the coterie members you pursued will show up.

The other major problem is the features of the game. You only get three save slots, and they're a bit pointless because it's an autosave. Also, if you get a bad ending and die, your save is deleted and you have to start over. In a visual novel, I'd usually expect a plethora of save spots to help with replayability, or at least saving the game to go back after a bad ending has been achieved. The other issue is there's no speed-up or skip option for text - you have to keep clicking constantly through text for each playthrough, no matter how many times you've already read the text. There's also small things, like you can't access a CG gallery for the few CGs you can see through the game.

I think it's worth it to play if you do like VtM. The atmosphere is really nice, the art is gorgeous, and the writing is good, if railroad-y.

column8: I quite enjoyed the game, played through only one of the stories so far. It does end a bit abruptly though, felt as if something was missing there. For me I guess it was worth the cost in the end, but if I could wish for something it would be that it was a bit longer, that the story continued on a but more.

column8:
Story Options:
-There's 3 clans/characters to choose from: Toreador, Ventrue, and Brujah. I played the Toreador. 
-You start out as a new vampire and quickly have to learn the ropes. 
-After a tutorial of sorts you'll be presented several quest chains, which you can do in any order. 
-4 of these chains are about recruiting a coterie: a Tremere, a Nosferatu, a Malkavian, and a Gangrel.
-There's also a main story. 
-You have limited time during the night to accomplish your goals. You can only do 1 or 2 things a night, Sometimes the main story or quest will take the entire night and you wont be able to do anything extra. 

I enjoyed it overall, but there are some things I had issue with:
-Great art and sound. Music will change depending on what's happening, very atmospheric.
-Terms glossary for those with limited knowledge of VtM. 
-There's a lot of characters to remember and no character glossary. So you may want to take notes. 
-It's a little slow at times, but it picks up the further you delve into it. 
-You're in the dark literally and figuratively. You have to uncover the secret plots and try stay one step a head of your enemies. 
-Your coterie doesn't really do anything. 
-Sometimes you'll choose an option and it does the opposite of what you think you were choosing. This is always a problem with these types of CYOA games. 
-Saving/loading is weird. You can have up to 3 save files, but you can only save when exiting the game. If you finish the game it deletes your save file. 

Final Verdict:
-I really enjoyed the story, especially the ending. BUT I know it won't be everyone's cup of tea. For me it was worth full price and I hope we get a sequel. It's more fun if you're familiar with how CYOA games work and love Vampire the Masquerade.

column8:
Wellp... The first half of the game was neat, I especially loved the parts with the coterie building... but then as the main story forced it's way trough, the game's pace picked up speed to the point where I fell out of the story entirely immersion-wise. By the end, I barely felt like I was part of the story at all. It felt as if the game decided to force an ending on me, when I wasn't even done with 50% of the side content, and the way it did it just ripped me straight out of the experience.
The way the game is now, I wouldn't recommend it, which makes me feel a bit sad, as I love the setting and the characters started to grow on me, before the ending just popped up out of the blue and ripped it all away.

column8: Honestly I thought that this would would be about as good as a cell phone game. I didn't have high hopes for this game, but I love the WOD and needed something to tide me over while waiting for Bloodlines 2, so I gave it a go... and you know what? I was pleasantly surprised. After a bit of a slow start I have really enjoyed this game. I am shocked to see that it has mixed reviews, because I think it's great. I think any fan of VTM will enjoy playing this game, so if you are one, then but it, I don't think you'll regret it. One gripe though, if you're going to make a game where I can only save when exiting the game, then make it more stable. I have a very new up to date system, and computer crashing  bugs are a common and irritating occurrence.

column8: I am very happy with how the visual novel feel in the World of Darkness. Anyone who has interest in the WoD this is a good intro, i would recommend play VTM: Bloodlines (and use the fan updates) it's a older game but still very loyal to the source material. Can't wait for more games of this quality.

column8: It nails the mood of Vampire in the spirit of its best predecessors, which is basically just Bloodlines. It's fun if you like visual novels, and it integrates vampiric powers and the Beast really well for a novel-game.

column9: Really a fantastic intro to VtM

column8:
It's a decent enough visual novel, the story is fairly good, however it's really only 4 hours long. In the long run your choices in dialogue responses really don't seem to matter, however it's the ending that truly ruins the overall product. It's short, blunt, unchanging, and gives you absolutely no choice or closure, it ends in a very minor cliff hanger, and all the relationships your character has built mean nothing.

If this is on sale, pick it up for 5 bucks, but full retail price? No way is it worth that kind of money. Character animations don't even change. Is the Kindred I'm speaking with happy? Sad? Anger? Who knows!?!? Because their face never changes.

column8:
This game is good for those who like interactive stories, play Vampire: The Masquerade, or are interested in Vampire: The Masquerade. It should be noted that this game doesn't have any voiceover, although the trailer for it implies it does.

The writing is very good and the characters are interesting and unique. You get an option of 3 characters to play: Ventrue, Toreador and Brujah. However, you don't get to change those characters or make them your "own" in any real way. It's essentially like a CyoA novel. You can choose to give your character an "attitude" and make sassy comments, but ultimately the game will force your arm to either comply with the story or it'll kill you. If you die, your saves are removed so you have to start all over again.

Where this game flounders is in overlooked mechanics for a game like this; namely, having the option to "skip" or fast-forward through dialog you've already experienced before because you're on another play through. There are also some visual issues that make reading the story confusing at times that should have been caught before release. (Examples being sometimes quotation marks are used when someone is talking, but most of the time they're not used; actions are conveyed in italics but sometimes dialog is mistakenly put in italics or actions are not italicized and display like character dialog.) My first play-through was as a Ventrue and I encountered a glitch that skipped over a huge part of the story. Since it was my first play-through, I was extremely confused as to what everyone was talking about in reference to this part of the story. It hasn't occurred since, however, so maybe it's been corrected now. Finally, the biggest mechanic I struggled with was the Hunger mechanic. If you don't drink blood, your screen should fill with a gradually growing bloody overlay. However, that overlay doesn't appear on every screen and can be difficult to see with some of the backgrounds.

This isn't a terrible game. You're looking at about 3 hours for each character, plus maybe a little more to clean-up and collect the rest of the achievements. I don't think it should be nearly $20US, though. Considering the limited options and the rather short story (endings are all the same, missions are all the same, etc), it's really only worth $10US, in my opinion.

column8: Three hours so far that have flown by like seconds. Even though the embrace is not as strong as in VTMB it still brings back that old spirit. I think 20‚Ç¨ is a fair price for this short but fun trip back to the VTM universe. Also it works quite well as an appetizer towards Bloodlines 2.

column8:
I was so excited for this game to be released. And then I was let down.
I agree on most things other negative reviews already stated (about the ending, choices don't really matter, etc..), but there is one thing I'm confused about. Many say that this is a game for "hardcore fans", but I think it's the opposite. With all the lore there is in the world of darkness, the depth, this game wasn't doing it justice. At times a bit boring, a bit sketchy and way too short. 
I hoped for at least 30 hours (in the first walkthrough; I played every Clan and couldn't reach 30 hours) of interesting storytelling in the World of Darkness with more options, but instead I felt rushed and not content with the superficial plot of this game. No explanations, no bonds, no betrayal I didn't see coming, just an abrupt ending.
I love the World of Darkness and I started buying books, so I consider myself a fan. And as such I cannot recommend that game which disappointed me so badly.

column8: Mi piacerebbe che fosse anche in italiano ^^

I don't mind a choose your own adventure type game.  In this game however all you can really choose is not to die.  Your decisions have no effect on the big story.  Plot armor blocks any action you take.  Events happen no matter what precautions you are allowed to make.  How about adding an option to just go hunting?  How about stay in friends haven?  

Overall for a game that ends after 3 hours of reading what you can't change.  I can't recommend buying it.

column8:
Coteries of New York
The newest game from the Vampire the Masquerade series developed by Draw Distance. Really great atmosphere and writing. Its one of those games that really do transport you to another world, bringing with it that rare feeling of being so engrossed in it that you lose yourself to it, that only some great novels can bring. 
Not without its short comings though, such as the lack of voice acting, but it's still really worth it if you're a Vampire the Masquerade fans!

column8:
Ultimately, this is a book, not a game. 14 hours, 100% achievements, it wasn't worth it. 

There's a reasonable story to discover in the first playthrough. Then it's a clicker simulator that takes way too long to get anywhere specific in.

This game does a thing that a lot of recently made games do: the first 5 minutes you can die in a few interesting ways to make you feel 'danger'. And like all those other games, once it makes its point and sets the tone that it wants to set, you basically can do anything and nothing really matters. Morality means nothing, personal choices don't really impact much beyond what text drives you to the next scene. The scene order for main story is always the same no matter what you do, with dialog trees doing the work of making you feel like your choices did something different this time. There are not different endings. You get there and it happens. 

In the different arcs for individual clan stories in the beginning and intermediate parts of the game, the formula is so straightforward and paralleled between the three that I could see the 'drop in scene here' aspect of how the whole game was put together. 

For exploring, you get an illusion of choice in a half put together UI that segments out varying points of view and ally snippets within the story, but once you understand what you're doing with the interface, it's quickly revealed as just another arbitrary 'whatdya want tonight?'. Menu.

If you're new to Vampire and World of Darkness and you like reading, this is a reasonably priced introduction to whet your appetite. If you want a Vampire experience, just wait for Bloodlines 2.

column8:
A must have for WoD fans. Not necessarily for the others.

Visual Novel is a type of game that I usually skip over. In this case, I tried and I do not regret it.
History draws you in, allows you to delve into the world of darkness without a break.
The game constantly reminds you of your need for blood, which means that you often make irrational decisions.
Unfortunately, it seems that the decisions made have little to do with how the story will unfold.
Establishment of a coterie also exists mainly by name. It is not possible to gain additional benefits from the alliances created, you will not learn new powers. Profit from acquaintance will be revealed only once in history.

The game seems endless. Namely, it looks more for season 1 than as a full story.
I also lacked some options to influence the shelter or something like inventory.
I just don't know if it would still be called Visual Novel :)


Pros:
- Climate
- Music
- Story
- Characters

Minuses:
- Coterie building only by name
- Unused potential (DLC?)

Edit: After second thought, I have changed my opinion to negative. Becouse I cannot agree with false marketing which was used here. 
You can read it more here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/1096410/discussions/0/3145133215257738981/

[h1]Description[/h1]

[b]Vampire the Masquerade - Coteries of New York[/b] is a visual novel taking place in the official universe of the pen and paper RPG Vampire the Masquerade 5th Edition.

You can pick one of three characters (and with them, one of three Vampire clans) and tackle a handful of optional side quests as well as the main quest's scripted events in a variety of ways.

While it is not a kinetic novel (i.e. a visual novel without choices), be aware that the central theme of the story is fate and you might be disappointed in the lack of impact of your choices, beyond what amounts largely to flavour text.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] Excellent atmosphere (at least for a VtM fan)
[*] Story stays true to its VtM roots
[*] Good graphics and soundtrack that help setup the atmosphere
[*] Interesting and varied characters
[*] Multiple ways to tackle challenges
[*] Multiple vampire disciplines to play with
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*] No way to skip seen text and no option to make text instant... even though those features have been staples of the visual novel genre for many many years
[*] As in many VtM campaigns, you are but a pawn in greater schemes, set in motion by Elders whose powers make them untoucheable... unfortunately, that means very little player agency to be found here
[*] The game does a relatively poor job of introducing some of the VtM concepts... sure, there is an in-game dictionary, but I still think a complete newcomer to the VtM universe will have trouble understanding what's going on
[*] Very little romance in a genre that almost always features a lot of it and in a RPG universe that is quite famous for its sexiness... wasted opportunity if you ask me
[*] Some bugs here and there, especially continuity bugs (e.g. a character you've met already talking to you as if it's the first time or your character mentioning a term they've never heard before)
[/list]

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

It's my first time regretting the lack of a neutral option when it comes to recommending a game...

If, like me, you are a huge fan of Vampire the Masquerade and feel like there haven't been anywhere near enough VtM video games so far, chances are you'll enjoy this game as much as I did.
Just be sure to set your expectations low in terms of player agency.

If you dislike or know very little about Vampire the Masquerade, if you dislike visual novels or only like visual novels if they have many branching storylines... stay away from this game. At any price.

All in all, I'll pick "Yes" not because I believe I can recommend this game to most players, but because enough other reviewers have picked "No" that potential buyers will hesitate.

column8: It's a great introduction into VtM, I love the lore, the dictionary, the art. It's well-written, too. My only complaint is that it should be at least three times longer -it ends just when it feels you have gotten started, just after you had formed your coterie, if that's what you spent your nights doing. To be clear: you do not have enough nights to do every quest in a single run. You have barely enough to do your coterie missions as long as you don't take a single side quest. As far as I can tell, there are no multiple endings, I would love to be proved wrong. I'm 90% sure the engine is RenPy, but unlike RenPy you can't rollback decisions, and the game saves your game even if you Alt-F4 out of it. For that, you need to keep manual copies of your saves at C:\Users\[your name]\AppData\LocalLow\DrawDistance\VtM Coteries of New York\Saves. Enjoy!

column8: Á≤â‰∏ùÂêëÔºåÂâßÊÉÖÊúâÁÇπÊÑèÊÄù

The game offers a very deep atmosphere. It is not an action-adventure, which gives more room to feel as a part of the World of Darkness. As with a book, one has to imagine the text based descriptions, which brings the atmosphere more personally to your head. ;)

After completing the game, I have to add some negatives:
It is over much too quickly and abruptly. When you get the feeling, the story is about to start - it ends. The (dialogue) options during the game give the impression of choice, but have no consequences in the end. And the one and only outcome the game does have is a real downer. These things angered me a lot back then.

That being said, it is worthwhile to suck in the atmosphere of the game.

Two things to keep in mind : This is a pure, straight-up visual novel. No resource management systems of any kind (The feeding mechanic is super lightly implemented). 

It's made for hardcore Vampire The Masquerade fans. Invested, long-term tabletop players.

It effectively conveys VtM's vibe and night-time atmosphere. It's not essential by any means, but your inner goth will be fascinated and role-play it to the end. If you owned a frilly silly shirt in high-school and stuck with it through all the bullying, you are going to have a grand ole time with Coteries.

column8: If you want a good game that presents the realities of kindred life very well and truly introduces you into the world of darkness than this game is probably for you. It is great and it shows the realities of being kindred from the first person point of view with a clarity that i, through years of consuming as much of the WoD as i could, have not found anywhere else. I would strongly recommend this to both people who are new to the WoD, as it provides you with a large amount of information in a fun and interesting way and will allow you to learn about kindred society alongside your character in game, and i would also recommend it to people like myself who are very well versed in the WoD. as it will serve as both a refresher to what kindred life is like from the eyes of a fledgeling with no sire and little access to information and because it will serve as a fresh take on kindred life and how modern kindred operate, so all in all i would highly recommend this game to anyone interested in VTM no matter at what stage you are interested in it.

column8: It's a good story and the artwork is great. Does a pretty good job at narrating certain clan weaknesses. It lacks in a variety of disciplines and different clans. Pretty much the only important decision you'll make in the entire game is what clan you'll start as: Brujah, Ventrue, or Toreador. Each have minor differences and some different dialogue throughout the game. I didn't like that there's only 1 ending. You can make any choice you want in any circumstance and you will be forced to go along with the very linear storyline. Some grammatical and spelling errors and moments where the wrong portrait may show up. Buy on sale.

column8:
A tense visual novel filled with atmosphere, corruption, violence, sex, sleaze and blood; exactly what you'd want out of something adapting the World of Darkness. Loved the music and the art, and the writing is solid aside from the occasional mishap where what should be a line of dialogue is accidentally delivered as narration and vice versa.

VERY MILD SPOILERS INCOMING: I found the ending a little vague. I understand the feel they were going for, but felt like there were more loose ends to tie up. It gave me more a sense of an "episode 1" than a closed book.

Overall, however, a very enjoyable experience. I'd recommend it to fans of Vampire: The Masquerade and also look forward to seeing more like it.
