column8:
Do yourself a favor and give this one a pass.

Synopsis:  The limited span of choice and even more limited and sometimes broken link to rational consequence makes this a very poor game with a tissue-thin story, poor cast of wooden characters, and a plot every bit as soulless and paint by numbers regurgitation of the setting material that you would be forgiven for thinking you were reading the 5th edition World of Wokeness tabletop rulebook verbatum at times right down to the character arcs.

Here‚Äôs the lineup of one-note hard left polemic expies projected into three fixed characters every bit as soulless and ugly as the modern leftist ideology they adhere to complete with the usual Baizuo/"white left" euphemisms:

1.  An SJW corporate executive drone turned Ventrue portrayed as a strong, independent woman who is all ‚Äústunning and brave‚Äù as she pours herself into her work to the point she didn‚Äôt really have much of a soul to lose to vampiric damnation.  Her one key character trait as evidenced in her internal monologue is misandry especially of the "white male patriarchy" and her contempt for anyone lesser than her on the corporate food-chain.  No family, no friends, no heart, no soul.  At least the writers went with what they knew when they wrote her.
  
This hatred of hers is graciously supported by the writers portraying every straight white male as either a cartoonishly boorish idiot, a slave worshipping smart, strong, independent women, or as some form of hateful white male who doesn‚Äôt want women to get ahead just because it threatens their male dominated world like this was still the 1960s USA instead of "the current year" in this poorly researched VN.

Ironically, the misandrist character is the most tolerable of the bunch if you can believe it since her dialogue ‚Äúchoices‚Äù aside from a few spots where evil white men appear does tend toward the subdued. Its a pretty businesslike tone with lots of internal corporate culture monologuing mixed in with a mouth full of sanitized corporate-safe slogans and veiled corporate double-speak.  Yes, that‚Äôs right; a soulless misandrist drone exercising her girl-power is literally the best of this very bad bunch of SJW half-wits and degenerate losers.  It only gets worse from here...

2.  An SJW half-white/half-something-else Antifa-style half-wit craptivist who is "Embraced" by his literally illegal alien Latina one-night-stand vampiress sire "on the strength of his [hard-core leftist] violent principles", she [a violent left-wing radical who gloats about attacking cops and glories in left-wing mob violence against the white man] uses him, "Embraces" him, and then abandons him like all the other "sires" do at the start of the VN.  Again, his ‚Äústrong‚Äù Starbuck Marxist "principles" and "her blood" are apparently "all he needs"  to be successful in the usual delusional victim hierarchical dialectic of cultural marxism with all the madness that failed ideology always has ever and will ever entail when it doesn‚Äôt get its way.

3.  A black uber-mensch gay artist whose ‚Äúinnate cool factor‚Äù and ‚Äúunwillingness to sell out‚Äù is mostly told to you by the company he keeps around ‚Äúhis work‚Äù. You are immediately introduced to a more or less blatant degree of homosexuality, which is literally thrown into your face right at the start. This one-note quality is way too enthusiastically treated in the story tethered to the usual brainwashed "tolerant‚Äù contempt for others not as pathologically awesome as he intrinsically is for his black skin tone and over the top gay liberal lifestyle as an artist ‚Äúheroically starving‚Äù for his ‚Äúart‚Äù. Yuck.

I hated this character the most for his pretentious ghetto edge-lord ‚Äústarving gay artiste‚Äù attitude and the unrealistic levels of degeneracy thrown around as it is sickening. So much so, that I couldn‚Äôt force myself to scan-read through all the prologue for this creep much beyond the bit with his sister and the gay ‚Äúsire‚Äù-man who ‚Äúembraced‚Äù him into a soulless leech in the character prologue written for this degenerate bag of gayness and innate black superiority for the color of his blackness alone that these shall I assume far left of center writers shoehorned in to make this trio of left-wing rejects complete.

The rest of the game, at least the parts I could stomach reading along through the Venture misandrist character is like conversing with characters who exist only as proxies to help introduce you to the world of wokeness that is the 5th edition WoD  setting. This game hits every smug little blue leftist checkmark you would expect from the Baizuo of modern nights only marginally muted for the sake of overlapping all of these characters together into the same text-based story blender in a way that leaves you with not much choice in the story variation aside from a few throw-away lines of dialogue here and there and a changed short scene here or there that shifts mostly depending on which of the three losers you can stomach best to follow.
   
If you are still interested in WoD, then I‚Äôm afraid I will have to recommend you stick with the much older but far better Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines with the ClanQuest mod installed. If you are interested in a saner vision of the WoD when it was still focused on creating a good story, plot, and decent characters clinging to their humanity, then give that one a try and this one a pass. At least, in the old world of darkness setting, the game still had a soul and a rhythm to it that made the final countdown toward Judgement Day interesting for all.

I suspect that taking out Gehenna, God, and the obviously evil and insane Sabbat sect has greatly diminished the contrast and depth you once had in the old WoD especially in your dealing with vampires from the Camarilla and Anarch factions since they could all agree the Sabbat were utterly evil, insane, and had to be culled by any means necessary.

After all, who were the Sabbot but the greater and dangerously chaotic free radical parasite brood of evil bloodsucking monsters. It made these two other groups look almost normal and sympathetic in comparison and gave you a reason for conflict and cooperation between the two groups as both factions at least try to cling to their humanity in spite of their blood-sucking monster status.

Now, after the Sabbot get themselves hosed deader than dead, this new setting is as soulless as its characters in its Sisyphean quest of a Rebel in search of a cause without anything to rebel against. This VN is a very poor CYOA game that reads like a poorly crafted setting lore tutorial kinetic visual novel every bit as static and lifeless as its cast of dramatis personae.

TL;DR?  This hard-left VN has got a tissue-thin story, with a thin amount of Telltale "choices" scrapped over too much bland ‚Äúanti-white‚Äù bread, which along with some bugs and even more obvious errors (pick one choice but the other character acts like you‚Äôve chosen something else kind of error mostly) is the least of this VN‚Äôs sins. More seriously, its dramatic personae cast is full of hard-coded NPC losers who each exemplify the typical modern Antifa identity political ideology and cultural Marxist political hackery that I‚Äôve come to expect of the Baizuo (Baizuo is our Communist Chinese corporate overlord's word for ‚Äúwhite left‚Äù; the more you know and all that).

Verdict: Do not buy this unless you are a leftist wanting to secure more virtue signaling points to add a sheen to your edgelord status by playing this and e-texting around on your Apple iPhones with your fellow left-wing lunatic Starbucks Marxist trust-fund buddies instead of filling that space between your ears with something marginally more productive like taking a walk to get away from your parent‚Äôs basement in the hopes of passively absorbing some of that Vitamin D into your skin in a vain effort to clear away some of that dope-induced brain fog levels of confusion suffocating whatever infantile excuse you have left for a hive-mind.
column9:
Do yourself a favor and give this one a pass.

Synopsis:  The limited span of choice and even more limited and sometimes broken link to rational consequence makes this a very poor game with a tissue-thin story, poor cast of wooden characters, and a plot every bit as soulless and paint by numbers regurgitation of the setting material that you would be forgiven for thinking you were reading the 5th edition World of Wokeness tabletop rulebook verbatum at times right down to the character arcs.

Here‚Äôs the lineup of one-note hard left polemic expies projected into three fixed characters every bit as soulless and ugly as the modern leftist ideology they adhere to complete with the usual Baizuo/"white left" euphemisms:

1.  An SJW corporate executive drone turned Ventrue portrayed as a strong, independent woman who is all ‚Äústunning and brave‚Äù as she pours herself into her work to the point she didn‚Äôt really have much of a soul to lose to vampiric damnation.  Her one key character trait as evidenced in her internal monologue is misandry especially of the "white male patriarchy" and her contempt for anyone lesser than her on the corporate food-chain.  No family, no friends, no heart, no soul.  At least the writers went with what they knew when they wrote her.
  
This hatred of hers is graciously supported by the writers portraying every straight white male as either a cartoonishly boorish idiot, a slave worshipping smart, strong, independent women, or as some form of hateful white male who doesn‚Äôt want women to get ahead just because it threatens their male dominated world like this was still the 1960s USA instead of "the current year" in this poorly researched VN.

Ironically, the misandrist character is the most tolerable of the bunch if you can believe it since her dialogue ‚Äúchoices‚Äù aside from a few spots where evil white men appear does tend toward the subdued. Its a pretty businesslike tone with lots of internal corporate culture monologuing mixed in with a mouth full of sanitized corporate-safe slogans and veiled corporate double-speak.  Yes, that‚Äôs right; a soulless misandrist drone exercising her girl-power is literally the best of this very bad bunch of SJW half-wits and degenerate losers.  It only gets worse from here...

2.  An SJW half-white/half-something-else Antifa-style half-wit craptivist who is "Embraced" by his literally illegal alien Latina one-night-stand vampiress sire "on the strength of his [hard-core leftist] violent principles", she [a violent left-wing radical who gloats about attacking cops and glories in left-wing mob violence against the white man] uses him, "Embraces" him, and then abandons him like all the other "sires" do at the start of the VN.  Again, his ‚Äústrong‚Äù Starbuck Marxist "principles" and "her blood" are apparently "all he needs"  to be successful in the usual delusional victim hierarchical dialectic of cultural marxism with all the madness that failed ideology always has ever and will ever entail when it doesn‚Äôt get its way.

3.  A black uber-mensch gay artist whose ‚Äúinnate cool factor‚Äù and ‚Äúunwillingness to sell out‚Äù is mostly told to you by the company he keeps around ‚Äúhis work‚Äù. You are immediately introduced to a more or less blatant degree of homosexuality, which is literally thrown into your face right at the start. This one-note quality is way too enthusiastically treated in the story tethered to the usual brainwashed "tolerant‚Äù contempt for others not as pathologically awesome as he intrinsically is for his black skin tone and over the top gay liberal lifestyle as an artist ‚Äúheroically starving‚Äù for his ‚Äúart‚Äù. Yuck.

I hated this character the most for his pretentious ghetto edge-lord ‚Äústarving gay artiste‚Äù attitude and the unrealistic levels of degeneracy thrown around as it is sickening. So much so, that I couldn‚Äôt force myself to scan-read through all the prologue for this creep much beyond the bit with his sister and the gay ‚Äúsire‚Äù-man who ‚Äúembraced‚Äù him into a soulless leech in the character prologue written for this degenerate bag of gayness and innate black superiority for the color of his blackness alone that these shall I assume far left of center writers shoehorned in to make this trio of left-wing rejects complete.

The rest of the game, at least the parts I could stomach reading along through the Venture misandrist character is like conversing with characters who exist only as proxies to help introduce you to the world of wokeness that is the 5th edition WoD  setting. This game hits every smug little blue leftist checkmark you would expect from the Baizuo of modern nights only marginally muted for the sake of overlapping all of these characters together into the same text-based story blender in a way that leaves you with not much choice in the story variation aside from a few throw-away lines of dialogue here and there and a changed short scene here or there that shifts mostly depending on which of the three losers you can stomach best to follow.
   
If you are still interested in WoD, then I‚Äôm afraid I will have to recommend you stick with the much older but far better Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines with the ClanQuest mod installed. If you are interested in a saner vision of the WoD when it was still focused on creating a good story, plot, and decent characters clinging to their humanity, then give that one a try and this one a pass. column8:
I loved the dialogue and characters in this game, they like full fledged people with depth. Draw Distance really did they're homework on the New York setting and cast in VtM and it shows. I only felt constrained towards the end.

It does have some drawbacks. My biggest complaint is not able to finish coterie member line in one playthrough. Normally I'd be ok with that, having to make choices that exclude other avenues but the game is so short I don't feel it's justified.  

The ending also felt forced and unsatisfying but not enough to keep me from starting again and finishing other storylines through.

It was difficult deciding to recommend this game, but enjoyed the ride more than enough to like it. Even with my complaints on the end and the time constraints.

column8:
There is maybe 5 hours of gameplay for each character.  Your characters are premades and you cannot change their appearance nor gender.  You literally get to change the character's default name and that is it.  There are 3 characters to choose from and their respective clans:  a female Venture, a male Toreador, and a male Brujah.  If you're unfamiliar to the lore don't worry!  There is an in-game dictionary that can be looked at pretty much any time and defines the various lore-related words.  The novel uses pretty much all the common English words, so you don't have to constantly go, "What does that word mean?".

I would recommend that you buy this game when it is on sale like some others have mentioned.  I got it for $17.99 (down only 10%), but I love the whole Vampire Masquerade lore and universe, so I would've paid full price anyway.

The only bad thing about the game is that your choices are locked in and you don't have any control over saving the game.  So, if you think you can just Alt+Tab and close the game.. well, don't worry!  It'll keep you at the same spot you closed the game, so your little trick to go around the "save game" didn't work.

column8:
This is not a game. It is a graphic novel you read on your computer.

It's not a long graphic novel. My one an only play through lasted 5 hours and yes... you are only a pawn.

Maybe it's the kind of game you need to play more than once?

I will give it a second run through on a different character and update.

UPDATE

It is the same game on a second play through. Not worth the money unless it is on sale and I mean a good sale.

column8:
Your in-game choices don't matter, your character is a meaningless pawn from the beginning to the end, and the entire way you feel like a captive audience to what feels like a crappy DM in a tabletop game flexing their OCs. I did not enjoy myself in the slightest, in spite of the initial wonder with the atmosphere and art style.
The cut corners with the in-game assets only stand out in face of the weak story experience: all characters have only one character sprite, no matter what is happening, what they're feeling, or what the narration says their facial expressions and body language are like. And of course, the small number of location backgrounds becomes noticeable. "Wait, why does this alleyway look EXACTLY like the alleyway I was at in the Bronx a few minutes ago?" Considering how short the game is, that kind of corner-cutting feels a bit lazy, especially when you consider that even less famous visual novels with a much smaller budget (I imagine) accomplish more than that in the visual variety department. Everybody's a statue with glowing eyes.
The feeding mechanic felt less like a tense ticking clock and more like a noose quickly tightening around my neck, with the game contriving limitations for feeding opportunities, and punishing you for trying to take one when you're literally on the brink of Frenzy. And OHOH, good luck playing a Ventrue and figuring out what kind of human you can safely feed on, because the game sure won't be consistent about it to help you.
I feel like this was a very frustrating and stressful waste of time, with a twist ending that felt like the writers just gave up trying to weave the different plot threads together and just pinned the authorship of EVERYTHING that transpired on one NPC. And who that NPC is will cause you to tear chunks of your hair out, I guarantee, it's that unsatisfying and out of left field.
Don't play this.

column8:
Should you buy Coteries of New York? 
First, remember this is a visual novel. It's not an action game and the RPG elements are limited. Decision-making on the player's part is scarce : you mainly go through the story, except for a couple of choices (that really have no impact on the story as a whole, I have to say).
Second, the story itself is a bit short and feels not quite finished. I do think this story needs a better ending, and it could have gone on for a bit.
I really liked my first playthrough, and I thought that the writing was good. The characters were interesting and the plot, if not original, grabbed my attention. The shoe dropped during the following playthroughs, when it appeared that your character and their choices didn't really matter, and that the story would unfold in the exact same way.
All in all, it took me 8 hours in total to get all the achievements (I'm a slow gamer). I have to admit that a 'skip' button would have been a nice addition, as continually clicking the "Continue" button felt a little boring after two playthroughs.
The visuals are nice, if a bit repetitive (the same visuals are used for different locations, which can be a little puzzling).
The music is nothing remarkable, except for the track at the end, that is eerily similar to some tracks one could find in V:tM: Bloodlines 1.

In conclusion, if you're a Vampire : The Masquerade fan, chances are you already got the game. If you are not a rabid V:tM fan, but still interested in the game or the lore, my two cents are you should wait for a sale. You will like it if you just take it for what it is, a low-budget visual novel set in the World of Darkness.

column8: Absolutely Captivating!!!

Alright i want to make clear that this is just my personal opinion....
i was really looking forward to this game, because i really enjoyed the old Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines...alas, its one of the largest disappointments i had in recent years. Why? Here the reasons:
1. There are only 3 of the clans available, and they are even gender and appearance locked
2. The story felt a bit inconsistent at times, especially near the end
3. it was short, like really short. not even 4 hours of gameplay.
this had so much potential, but what we finally got is a pretty sad example for a visual novel, even worse for such a well known lore. With the lack of character options it was really difficult to get immersed into the story and many of the choices given felt like any is a bad choice. All in all the story itself feels very rushed with the short timeframes and overall time is also much to short. The devs should have definetly taken more time to make this game, put in more variety, options and most important, a longer storyline.

column8: Les choix du personnage n'ont aucune influence sur l'histoire.

Its a good game that loses replay value.
If you love VTM you will enjoy the nuansces of this game but its held back by the shortness of the story and the fact that the game doesn't really expect you to make certain decions (like recruiting all coterie members) or feeding rarely so as to avoid attracting attention. But it was still a decent game and worth the reduced price.

column8:
A solid visual novel with about 5.5-6 hours of story if you main-line it. Several side quests and tight dialog choices hint at replayability to seek out all the secrets. I intend to jump back in soon, choosing a different clan and a different approach to the characters. 

I'd say it's a must if you're already into the World of Darkness/Vampire the Masquerade setting. It's probably going to have limited appeal otherwise.

column8:
Pros
-Good sound design
-Fitting art design for the setting
-Interesting characters
-Very well versed in the lore of VtR

Cons
-Lack of real character customization
-Context for your choices are severely lacking
-Story railroads very hard; normally I'm not picky about this, but it's egregious in a "choose your own adventure" game since that's the only real game play.

I really tried to like this game, but after failing every single story point for the first try it started to get on my nerves. There isn't enough context to the answers you're given. A lot of the time the game gives you 3 options for choices "Correct" at the top, "Incorrect" second choice, and "Wild-Card" on the third. Sometimes it'll throw a power use in the third slot. 

But the real problem isn't just lack of clarity, it's a lack of reward. Your responses don't typically carry any weight, and they won't be remembered either. You'll just get railroaded into the next act of a story unless you mess up bad enough to fail.  The best you can hope for in most cases is an "Attaboy" in the next response you get, and the worst kills you or fails a plot line bad enough that you restart the game from the beginning forcing you to click through 10 minutes of continue boxes.

The game unfortunately isn't a "Choose your own adventure", it's an unforgiving roulette of trial and error.

But the real problem isn't just lack of clarity, it's a lack of reward. Your responses don't typically carry any weight, and they won't be remembered either. You'll just get railroaded into the next act of a story unless you mess up bad enough to fail.  The best you can hope for in most cases is an "Attaboy" in the next response you get, and the worst kills you or fails a plot line bad enough that you restart the game from the beginning forcing you to click through 10 minutes of continue boxes.

The game unfortunately isn't a "Choose your own adventure", it's an unforgiving roulette of trial and error.

column8:
I am a HUGE fan of the "world of darkness"
There is some deep dialogue and an okay music, i personally loved the dynamic backgrounds
But! with all that in mind
the game is barely okay...
Its rushed, out of 13 clans you have in this world, you get to play the most boring of them.
(give me : Malk,Nosferatu or other not yet touched classes ) and choices just don't change much
its either u get the companion or not, that's all
Might be getting some background on V5 but just not enough to make me more excited about Bloodlines 2 
5/10 - gonna get all achievements anyway

column8:
While I enjoyed the game, I feel like it promised more than it delivered. It's a very short game (~3 hours), and the touted replayability seems superficial at best.

The good: 
Beautiful artwork
Very atmospheric
Well-written and engaging plot

The bad: 
I would have loved to see more vampire abilities being used. Most abilities only saw use once or twice, and the blood mechanic never really came into play for me.
Most choices you make seem to have very little impact.
It lacks an option to show text without delay, forcing me to double-click enter constantly, sometimes resulting in me picking an option by mistake. 
It doesn't have a "skip text" option, which is honestly mandatory in a visual novel that wants you to replay it.

Overall, I don't regret buying and playing it, but I wish there was a bit more of it. I can't recommend it unless you are already a fan of Vampire the Masquerade and/or you really like visual novels.

column8: A great introduction to VtM. Good characters, excellent mood - sadly its very, very short so you might want to wait for a discount.

To anyone who's exerienced world of darkness at the peak of it's writing, this is it. Tense, serene, sensueal this game is everything great about Vampire the Masquerade, I've been waiting years for VTMB2 but I wouldn't be suprised if I end up liking this more.

column8:
I received this game as a gift from a dear friend, and I'm thoroughly grateful to them for it.

Coteries of New York is a beautiful VN with an interesting story and compelling, unique characters. I had a lot of fun and don't regret my time playing it at all. Unfortunately, for a game that amounts to a slideshow (if an enjoyable and elegantly-crafted one), the lack of quality control is painfully present. It's a good game. You should buy it. You should play it. Despite some disappointments you'll probably enjoy it. Waiting for it to go on sale and paying less money for it is an appropriate and proportionate response to its unpolished release.

That's the short review. To get into the weeds about it...

Sometimes decision options appear as dialogue and the decision prompt is just skipped. Some decision options lack the appropriate bullet symbols. Narrative description (normally in italics) occasionally appears as dialogue and vice versa. Sometimes a character's portrait will appear when you're the one speaking. Worst of all, some rare typos completely shatter the immersion- in one especially egregious example, during the hostile branch of the Stalker quest, the hyperlinks to the dictionary aren't labeled correctly, so the text has square brackets with numbers indicating the dictionary indicies. In another, the word "blood" is replaced with simply "bl".

I'm not asking someone to test every map boundary surface in Dark Souls for out-of-bounds glitches here. I'm saying in a VN, it should not be unreasonable for one person (and maybe not even the same person) to read every single dialogue slide and make sure the formatting is correct, there are no typos or code glitches, and the portraits show up when they're supposed to. In the scope of the product, this is not a big ask.

As for the "twist" ending, I wouldn't go so far as to describe it as "insulting," as other reviewers have, so much as a borderline non-sequitor. It's on par with "The Dog Was The Villain" as far as tropes go. That your decisions make zero difference in the ending is disappointing, but I wasn't angry so much as confused. The game just dumps a bunch of plot and ends. You can experience nearly all of the game's content in six hours, which is not bad for a story, but brings me to one final complaint:

This is a visual novel. Fifteen years ago I played my first visual novel. It had a button to skip dialogue I had seen before on previous plays and to stop when new text was shown. Why do I have to mash the mouse button through literal pages of text that do not change in the slightest between play-throughs? The intro monologue and the ending are both the worst offenders, but by no means the only ones. When you are trying to find content that requires perfect execution (which in some cases can be impossible to do blind, necessitating multiple plays) it's an absolute drag to have to wade through text that doesn't change. 

That the "reward" is often the new content having no bearing on the plot is a separate, but lesser issue.

column8: An intriguing way to learn about lore of the vampire's side of world of darkness. Doesn't have any real mechanics outside visual novel stuff so I'm not certain why it references the 5e rulebook. Won't help with learning the tabletop game but has a very compelling story and guides you into a background understanding of the setting. Can see it taking up multiple playthroughs easily enough.

column8: A dark, rich and well written Vampire the Masquerade visual novel for those both old and new to the World of Darkness.  Welcome to the first night of the rest of your unlife fledgling...
column9: A dark, rich and well written Vampire the Masquerade visual novel for those both old and new to the World of Darkness.  Welcome to the first night of the rest of your unlife fledgling...

column8: Muy buen juego. Espero que en el futuro, pongan mas clanes jugables. La √∫nica pega que le pongo es su corta duraci√≥n, pero eso en parte se debe a que lo disfruto tanto que quiero m√°s. Personajes muy interesantes, y como no, los Malkavian nunca decepcionan.

Despite the fact that I enjoyed my time in this visual novel, I can't recommend it to others.  This short story set in the World of Darkness is meant to slake my thirst until Bloodlines 2 releases, and I can't help but feel a little disappointed with what I bit into here.  A couple things really detracted from my enjoyment of this product.

For starters, there are mistakes everywhere.  I don't think this thing made a single pass through any sort of quality assurance.  The plague of typos and the glaring errors in the branching story are a big problem when the major draw is the writing.  This is a pretty shallow dip into the setting, too.  I almost felt like I was playing a demo.  The whole thing feels abbreviated somehow.  It's almost as if there was meant to be something more but the project was aborted early on, or rushed out.

One playthrough is enough.  The additional clans really don't add much value here.  The music, the art, and the overall story are fine.  I do wish more care was taken with this property that I love so dearly.  Safely skip this offering.  Wait with fingers crossed for Bloodlines 2, or just buy the table top rpg.

column8:
After a long long time, this is the first Vampire the Masquerade game released the thumb up for this game supposed to be an automatic success. But now I am simply sorry that the game was not able to fulfill my expectations of a VTM game.
First I would like to state what I most liked about the game and it was music. The music of the game is terrific. It is both old and new, it reminds the good old bloodlines and at the same time it has a new feeling. Game music truly suits VTM universe. 
I am really happy to see some references to the current political events.
Text was mediocre, and although I don‚Äôt like deus-ex-machina type endings, last monologue was convincingly reasonable. 

There is a tendency that most content creators show when they return to an old gem. They want to reach a wider audience, well on the paper it is a favorable goal. But in reality this rarely works as intended, VTM has its unique features and its own community who love that features. When devs. are trying to connect with a new type of audience they usually seek to change the original artwork and try to meet in the middle with expectations of their old audience and projected new audience. Which usually results with the loss of uniqueness of the original artwork.
In Coteries of New York this tendency resulted two keywords Philosophical and Artistic
[b]Philosophical[/b]
There is a quotation from Irving Kristol I‚Äôd like to mention:
[i]"There are different kinds of truths for different kinds of people, there are truths appropriate for children; truths that are appropriate for students; truths that are appropriate for educated adults; and truths that are appropriate for highly educated adults, and the notion that there should be one set of truths available to everyone is a modern democratic fallacy.‚Äù[/i]
Well,[b] I am not supporting this idea[/b], on the contrary, other than a few exceptional cases,[b] I am mostly against this idea[/b]. I believe, as humankind, we are obliged to seek, find and reveal the truth in all matters. Even if the new revelations would deny and falsify the old ones, we should go on and on.I want to believe, the truth is out there. 
On the other hand Kristol‚Äôs idea mentioned above frankly summarizes how ‚Äúthe truth‚Äù presents in real world. We can observe this state throughout our whole lives from childhood to old age. As a kid we are educated in all important aspects of our civilization. We are educated in science, culture, religion, philosophy, history, politics etc. While growing up we start to discover that not all the things we have been thought before are true. Some of them are half-truths, some of them are just approximations, and some are totally fallacies. If we are dedicated and make lots of research, investigation, reading and thinking, it becomes clearer that most of ‚Äúthe truths‚Äù that are presented as ‚Äú‚Äúthe truths‚Äù are either deficient, misleading, altered, or manipulated. Especially the topics which affects masses such as politics, history and religion, are the ones where the most inaccurate information exist. This is not caused just by ignorance or technical impossibilities, most of the times this misdirection, this manipulation is carried out deliberately by other people who has an interest in it. This is the way how [b]hegemony[/b] is built up. 
I think this discussion about the truth deeply related with the VTM game system. It is a core element. In the vampire universe, players are risen in a new world where all their former knowledge of the world is wrong in some way. They are left in the frightening darkness alone and ignorant. They had to learn everything from the start in this savage world where they feel like small pawns under huge power structures and machinations. With time, somewhat experienced player realizes that, there is no ending of learning. There are secrets within secrets ..The machinations, goes back centuries even eons. Kristol‚Äôs words can be adapted to vampire universe such as[i] ‚Äú‚Ä¶There are different kinds of truths for kine and kindred, there are truths appropriate for fledglings, and there are truths appropriate for elders‚Ä¶‚Äù[/i]
I think, this logic, this element, this feeling is one of the most important and unique aspect of the Vampire setting. From this specific aspect, the analogy between the real world and vampire setting is so strong and relevant even though VTM is full of supernatural elements it is also the best setting which depicts the real world with all its ups and downs. After playing a Vampire game, after feeling this experience a player may gain a notion of skepticism about his own easily accepted truths. Like an eureka moment, Vampire game has a potential to sway the player into criticizing his own ideals, beliefs, ideologies.etc.But setting only has this ability as potential, which should be activated by the plot & story of the game.This is where [b]Coteries of New York[/b] fails. The text & plot of the game is mediocre at best. The plot topics should be related real worlds mature and intellectually complex problems.Sometimes game should hit a nerve of the player. Occasionally, it should force the player for leaving his intellectual comfort zone by confronting him unexplored topics and perspectives. The Coteries of New York did not supply me any new idea or perspective. It did not challenge me intellectually in any unique way. This is mostly because this game tries to play too safe and sound. It doesn‚Äôt want to scare the audience at all so it takes (nearly) no risks. I am not saying it never tries, there are a few references here and there, but neither politics, nor history, or religion is discussed in a detailed and bold way. 
I feel like the devs. think that making a VTM game alone is a risk enough so they doesn‚Äôt want make things worse, well guess what we already decided to play a VTM game and most of us familiar to the universe. So this is not enough. 

[b]Artistic[/b]
From the artistic point of view the game visuals Coteries of New York fails to create a proper VTM atmosphere and this is a big loss considering it is a visual novel game with no voice acting. Well although the visuals do not imply a totally different universe it is also obvious that they are missing a few key elements. The feeling that game creates is not just right. In this subject I put the blame on the style. And by [b]style[/b] I mean two parameters [b]form[/b] and [b]color[/b].
Let‚Äôs start with form, the drawing style, form of the lines in this game is not very similar to other drawings existing on the former VTM books. Well V5 has similar change in the art style I can‚Äôt say I am fond of that either. I think my taste is prone to gothic retro style. Apart from my personal preferences, this games character models are all ‚Äúbeautiful ‚Äú(nearly all).But all of them are same type of ‚Äúbeautiful ‚Äú. It seems like there is a defined pattern. Their eyes, their faces, their bodies strongly resembles each other‚Ä¶ as if only changing things are their hair, clothes, or complexion. Most characters do not have their uniqueness.They seem like shallow-flat characters instead of deep-well developed characters.  
Another thing is, there are lots of smoothly curved objects at the backgrounds‚Ä¶ well this is also adding with color pattern. The game has lots of blue color and lots of lightning.This game is too blue, too bright. I did not see a good dark night back ground throughout the whole game. This is a VTM game a [b]World of Darkness[/b] game literally no darkness in it. With those soft objects, blue heavy color palette and daylight bright HDR devs. are definitely  accomplished their intention which is creating an atmosphere of calmness and safety. Trough out the game I have never felt fear, anxiety or stress. It was one happy ride. This game is supposed to have horror elements. You can‚Äôt simply remove horror aspect from a VTM game it is one of the core elements. 

Well it was a long review, I only hope we have more VTM games, thank you for reading.

column8: The story is weak and short compared to VtMR and VtMB but we don't have a lot of games for this setting. So if you like visual novels and table RPG it is the game for you.
column9: The story is weak and short compared to VtMR and VtMB but we don't have a lot of games for this setting. So if you like visual novels and table RPG it is the game for you.

column8:
It's enjoyable if you're already a fan of the VTM universe, but probably won't hold up as a stand alone game.  It can be exposition heavy, and if you're not already aware of all the vampire terminology, get ready for a not of telling without the showing.

As other users have said, the choices you make have little impact on the main plot or ending.  I started playing with this mind, and surprisingly I wasn't as disappointed as I expected to be.  The choices I made still felt real, even if they all became meaningless in the end.  And the fact that I had no control over the story actually made sense narratively (in my opinion).  But to be fair, there's very little buildup for the main plot, and when it finally arrives it isn't that exciting.  The ending was abrupt, and I found that I didn't really care.

Thankfully, you'll spend far more time working on the side stories, and those are the actually enjoyable parts of the game.  You get to meet a lot of interesting characters, and you do have some control over how well they get along with you.
column9:

column8:
I'm a longtime player of the World of Darkness in all forms over the last 20-30 years and have witnessed the highs and lows that VtM brought.  This being said VtM: Coteries of NY is a perfect example of how to make an easy to understand intro to the world of Vampire.  If your a long time player that's familiar with the world and wants to dive head first into the deep end, this is not your thing. This game is what we call a single story with 5 or 6 chapters to it.  A few stories makes up a Chronicle.  This story is an obvious intro and setup for other projects to come that would be too overwhelming to people starting from scratch in VtM. This Novel is a great intro for new players and those wanting a cheaper appetizer before Bloodlines 2.

You will NEVER hit everything to do in a single run in the game...that's not what a choose your path novel is, which makes RP fun in the first place.  If anyone here posting negative  reviews has ever run a RP game that lasted more than 3 sessions before falling apart they would know this. 

Pros
+ Excellent Character design of NPC's, Unique and you feel for them in many ways and always makes you curious to know more.  You WANT to have more interaction with them be it peaceful or violent, this desire is crucial in storytelling.
+ Beautiful audio that pulls from music of Bloodlines, and eerie atmospheric tones that set a mood. I use this often for my tabletops and it immerses the player.
+ Graphics are stunning and the details in the work tease story hints in some places if you know what to look for, it helps with a feeling of paranoia
+ The writers NAILED the politics and trials of being Camarilla and Anarch and what it takes to survive
+ The story was well written and teases you with details to the big reveal which brings us to the cons.

Cons
- It is CRUCIAL that when storytelling you dont "railroad" your players to a story ending with only one outcome where you survive, where the other choices you made don't seem trivial.  This was not done.  I understand that the story could have ended other ways but from the playthroughs I've done it only ended with death.  A good storyteller will never kill players if they try for an outcome different than what was written.  More than one survival outcome should have been written.
- Should have made my actions feel more important by showcasing at the end how I changed the NY kindred society in some way.
- The ending was good first time through but abrupt. If this is one part in a greater Chronicle to come it would be nice to know that.  

This was an wonderful experience even for a WoD vet GM.  My newer players are all playing and laughing about how their playthroughs went and they have a better understanding of the Kindred world that will help me move our campaign faster now that I know they have the concepts down.  If you want perfection in a novel that would have taken 5 years to do this isnt it, go make your own damn chronicle and find some players.  I loved it for the $20 it was and recommend it for new players to WoD players. Look forward to Bloodlines 2 as well as well as Fall of London next week.  Chicago by Night is amazing and I've already claimed my first character death for multiple masquerade breaches!
column9:
I'm a longtime player of the World of Darkness in all forms over the last 20-30 years and have witnessed the highs and lows that VtM brought.  This being said VtM: Coteries of NY is a perfect example of how to make an easy to understand intro to the world of Vampire.  If your a long time player that's familiar with the world and wants to dive head first into the deep end, this is not your thing. This game is what we call a single story with 5 or 6 chapters to it.  A few stories makes up a Chronicle.  This story is an obvious intro and setup for other projects to come that would be too overwhelming to people starting from scratch in VtM. This Novel is a great intro for new players and those wanting a cheaper appetizer before Bloodlines 2.

You will NEVER hit everything to do in a single run in the game...that's not what a choose your path novel is, which makes RP fun in the first place.  If anyone here posting negative  reviews has ever run a RP game that lasted more than 3 sessions before falling apart they would know this.

column8:
It's good.... but too short.
For the price the fact you can play through the entire game in 3 hours is very disappointing.
It plays like the prologue to the game rather than a full game.

If it was available on patreon for $1 with the promise of frequent updates sure, but as a "finished" game with no future update, it's a bit of a joke.

column8:
When I first learned that a Vampire: The Masquerade visual novel would be releasing, I was very hopeful that the coming together of two things I love (visual novels and the Vampire universe) would add up to a special and grand experience. Unfortunately, while Coteries of New York hits several home runs in different areas, it fumbles enough in other areas to leave you with a dissatisfied feeling at the end of your run. 

First, let me say that the game does a lot of things right. I loved the art design in this game. The characters are well-designed and the backgrounds are beautiful and immersive. The art design sets a good mood that I believe does justice to the Vampire universe, but more importantly makes it easy to immerse yourself into as you play the game. 

The soundtrack in this game is enjoyable and doesn't get in the way. That being said, I did encounter what I assume are bug related issues wherein certain tracks would continue to play endlessly until I restarted the game. 

Technical issues aside, the game doesn't have a lot of QOL features you might hope to see from a visual novel. Most importantly to me, there is no manual saving in this game (It has autosave and save on exit only). 

The game has side quests, but it is not possible to complete all of them in one run which means multiple runs are mandatory if you want to see all the content the game has to offer. Pacing is an issue in this game as the relatively short main quest moves on at such a fast pace as to not allow you time to fully explore the different side quests. 

I thought the characters were decently written. Overall, I enjoyed the different personalities the game had to offer, even if some of the dialogue contained too many present day references (which immediately takes me out of the experience). All in all, the characters have unique and fun side quests (even if I wasn't able to finish all of them). 

This game is not a choices-matter type of game as you might expect or want. There are no branching paths, and no distinctly different endings. Rather, the "choices" simply reflect slight variations on dialogue and are for the most part largely insignificant to the overall plot. 

Regarding the main plot itself: My take is that the main story is too short, climaxes too quickly, and ends too abruptly. There was a point in the game where I believed things were picking up, only to learn the game was about to end. Personally, the ending is not my cup of tea. There is also no resolution to your companions (the ones whose questlines you were able to finish at least). 

Ultimately, while the game excels in several areas, the main story and pacing left me dissatisfied. I'm no stranger to cliffhanger endings, but in this case Coteries of New York did not leave me with a feeling of excitement or anticipation for what's next. Rather, it left me with a feeling of disappointment and confusion.

column8: I liked it. It held my interest. People are saying that the ending was tacked on but it played out as expected except the final boss was my second choice. Not much of anything to warn the reader. It is a mystery story not an action story but it does have some action.  The negative reviews are being overly severe in my opinion. Yes I saw one or two typo's but the game played smoothly with no problems.  A little more foreshadowing of the ending would be good. It would also be good if "mystery story" was mentioned in the advertisements so people would read it closely and not fly through like a straight forward action story. I would buy dlc for it and the art was great. Life is full of sad endings and bitter sweet endings so a writer will lose approval with anything but a happy ending (since newspapers are cheap and the nightly news is free and they are both sad.)

column8:
Working on my 2nd playthrough, probably gonna go a 3rd time just to play as each of the three potential protagonists. That being said, the main story and the ending seem to be the same for each character (with MINOR throwaway differences in details and the opening scenes.) You can experience almost all of the game's content in 2 playthroughs, despite there being 3 playable protags.

They nailed the worldbuilding and the brand to the point where i wanted more content. The storytelling is great, the characters are entertaining, but the ending felt sloppy and unclear. When i first beat the game, I was confused when the credits started to roll because it felt like the game ended in the middle of a scene. Was that a set up for a sequel? If not, there was no closure and too many questions were left unanswered; I understand this is the World of Darkness... but c'mon guys... It was too abrupt. I also feel that the main antagonist should have been built up more. They appeared once during the main story in my 1st play through and it was for all of two minutes; I didn't really know who they were and I had no feelings invested in them to give their involvement in the finale any weight. 

During my 2nd run, I made it a point to choose different things and responses, but it seems that your choices do not change much in the story besides some random details that the NPCs mention. I would have liked to have seen maybe 2 or 3 different endings, if not an extended cut of the actual ending...

Quality of life patches should be implemented, as many others have said, such as the ability to skip previously seen text, the ability to manual save and load at will, etc. It would be cool if your 'dictionary' didn't reset with each playthrough.

Despite how critical my review may sound, I want to be clear that I genuinely enjoyed playing this game. Although, I probably won't pick it up again once I've finished a run as each of the 3 protags, unless there is added content via DLC or a patch. The team gave us a great product, but I wanted just a little bit more out of it.

TL;DR it's a decent game for the price and genre, although it could stand for added content.

column8:
I've been involved with Vampire: The Masquerade since the 90s, played all the games video or otherwise, and Im glad to see a revival again. That being said, this was pretty lackluster. Don't get me wrong, my issue is not being a visual novel, which is absolutely is. 

No my issue stems from the lack of choices and options. From the lack of clan/character choice, to being unable to really shape the story nor the ending with your choices,  this is terrible for the World of Darkness which about those things. It does not even complete well with the other Vampire Visual Novels, VTM or otherwise available on steam. Even the content isnt so dark compared to other VTM media.  I'd reccomend Red Embrace or even the other VTM Visual Novel over this.

column8:
So I have played this game for about one and a half play throughs and I have to say as far as a great visual novel approach goes this game is not the best and is also missing a skip button which is the most basic of needs. I don't play VIs at all really and got this because I'm excited about blood lines 2 and wanted more back ground info into this world since I don't play the actual board game. I have to say this is a great learning experience to get you ready for blood lines 2 but if you already know everything about this world unlike me than this is a pass but if you don't then this is a pretty good and fun pick up to help you learn about it especially if you haven't played the first blood lines game. So I do recommend it and I think the devs are pretty chill and cool and made a game that was not 100% in the play house but made some awesome goddamn art work nonetheless. 

P.S. devs seriously add a skip button.

column8:
I wish I could recommend this game. I do. It's worth it if you're a huge VtM fan and want to read a slightly interactive book. 

It's not a game. It's a visual novel that railroads you through. 

There's no multiple endings. Not *really*. 

Reading and enjoying every bit of text...I finished all three character stories in under 10 hours. I've played each character multiple times now. I have all the achievements except for 2 hidden ones, which I didn't bother to explore because I'm pretty sure I know what/where they are and...I don't even care. I'll do it maybe at some point. Maybe. 

Because I played multiple quests already with each character, picking each choice...just to see if I could get a different railroaded result. Which...you sorta do? 

Example without spoilers. 

One quest chain ends with:
-X dies
-X dies
-Y dies but you don't know what happens to X except I guess they're alive

There's no good ending. And...while I get that's kinda the point, the constant jerk arounds are ultimately unsatisfying to the very sudden ending. 

Soundtrack is okay, but repetitive
Artwork is lovely, but reused to exhaustion AND some character art is unforgivably reused for other chars
You can play 1 of 3 premade chars with pic/gender/clan picked for you
SO MUCH DIALOGUE is poorly written to clearly be reused, using gender neutral pronouns/generalizations for laziness. 
There's no voice over acting. 

This is at best a $10 game.
This is in reality, a mobile game. 

It could've been so much more, but it is what it is. 

Did I like it? Yes, I enjoyed it...much the way I enjoy McDonalds. But when I thought I was at a higher end joint? I'm not pleased with paying higher prices for the MickeyDs. 

Get it on sale, if you're a fan.

column8:
[h1]Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York √© um jogo de estilo visual novel sobre vampiros[/h1]

No jogo ainda seguindo o mesmo ritmo de como come√ßar a hist√≥ria dos outros jogos da franquia, √© sempre sobre um humano que √© for√ßado contra sua vontade a se tornar um vampiro, mas definitivamente ap√≥s isso a hist√≥ria me surpreendeu bastante, apesar de ser um visual novel o que n√£o sou t√£o f√£, achei o jogo bem interessante tanto que fiquei bastante focado em ler e aprender tudo o que podia.
Ainda para facilitar o jogo cont√©m um mini dicionario das palavras, isso √© √∫til principalmente pra quem for novo na franquia, entender o que certas palavras nesse universo significam, al√©m tamb√©m de uma mini caixa de textos caso voc√™ tenha pulado ou queira revisar algum texto de dialogo anterior.

Achei bem interessante o desenrolar dos personagens por toda a hist√≥ria e principalmente o final, no entanto bem pro fim do jogo me deu a sensa√ß√£o de que foi um final um pouco apressado, tanto que h√° um plot-twist totalmente inesperado o que √© bom, mas tenho que confessar o final pecou um pouco, tanto que o que acontece no fim n√£o h√° nenhuma emo√ß√£o basicamente...

Pra estragar um pouco a experi√™ncia do final, voc√™ provavelmente vai querer jogar novamente e isso √© poss√≠vel, pois voc√™ tem 3 personagens diferentes para se jogar, acontece que logo ap√≥s voc√™ come√ßar a hist√≥ria de algum outro personagem vai perceber que ela quase toda √© a mesma coisa, mudando alguns detalhes de di√°logos e um personagem pr√≥ximo ao protagonista, fora isso mais nada pelo que pude observar, o que pode ser bastante decepcionante para muitos, tanto que as an√°lises neutras aqui est√£o citando muito isso, al√©m do final sem emo√ß√£o.

Agora sobre a rejogabilidade e conquistas Steam
Eu levei umas 7 ou 8 horas pra zerar com meu primeiro personagem, tecnicamente voc√™ precisa recome√ßar varias vezes com os tr√™s personagens e muita das vezes qualquer um deles para se pegar 100% de conquistas, por√©m o jogo decepciona muito no quesito da hist√≥ria na hora de rejogabilidade, como citei anteriormente n√£o vale muito a pena, exceto nesse caso se voc√™ quiser ir atr√°s das conquistas, basicamente todas s√£o muito simples de se pegar e voc√™ n√£o deve ter nenhuma dificuldade, exceto com as conquistas escondidas que meio que te desafia a voc√™ explorar todas as "grandes" op√ß√µes poss√≠veis para se pegar elas.
Nada muito dif√≠cil nesse quesito das conquistas, talvez s√≥ uma ali que n√£o ficou t√£o √≥bvio o que tinha que se fazer at√© eu chegar a conclus√£o do que s√≥ o podia ser e conseguir ela, ent√£o acabou que com os 100% de conquistas estendi minha jogatina de 8 horas, pra 13 horas j√° que eu j√° sabia a maioria dos di√°logos, eu economizei muito tempo ao pular todos eles super ulta fast e-e.

[b]Bom na minha opini√£o voc√™ S√ì deveria comprar esse jogo apenas se tiver interessado nesse universo do Vampiro: A M√°scara e principalmente se voc√™ for novo, √© prov√°vel que se voc√™ se interessar em ler todo o di√°logo, al√©m de ser necess√°rio manjar muito de ingl√™s, pois se trata de um visual novel totalmente 100% em ingl√™s com muito di√°logo, ent√£o voc√™ tem gostar pra ter paci√™ncia de ler tudo.[/b]

Ent√£o mesmo com algumas decep√ß√µes, eu definitivamente compraria outro jogo da franquia mesmo se fosse desse estilo de VN de novo, pois gostei muito da abordagem da hist√≥ria.

If you're a fan of VTM then this is a lot of fun! The animation art style is nice and the music is certainly on brand for WOD and keeps up the atmosphere. The ending is a bit abrupt but it seems like it has some re-playability. Overall I enjoyed it, took me about 6 hours casually!

column8:
This feels like a session, not a campaign.

There is a lot of stuff about this game that is good, and I will give it a thumbs up,
but there are waaaaay to many loose ends at the climax and I feel a lack of catharsis.
I don't even know if my choices had influenced the ending, I mean, could be or not, but I have played blatant quasi-choice presenting single story thread RPG's that made my character feel more dramatically involved than this game.
column9:
This feels like a session, not a campaign.

There is a lot of stuff about this game that is good, and I will give it a thumbs up,
but there are waaaaay to many loose ends at the climax and I feel a lack of catharsis.
I don't even know if my choices had influenced the ending, I mean, could be or not, but I have played blatant quasi-choice presenting single story thread RPG's that made my character feel more dramatically involved than this game.

column8:
Really good, not absolute perfection. Enjoyable. Worth the money. If there is a sequel or a DLC, I will buy it.

I read the reviews here a few times and was really close to just waiting for a big sale. They made it seem like it's going to be 17,99‚Ç¨ for a five hour playthrough. I bought it anyway and it took me about 12 hours to enjoy once. Thought I would easily finish it in one go but at seven in the morning I decided to rest.

I, too, spotted a few typos and grammatical errors here and there, approximately ten of them. The ambience soundtrack seemed buggy at times, you move to a new scene and the old one keeps playing. Going back to the main menu and loading seemed to fix this.

How would I improve this experience? I think there could be a little bit more art, more pictures of the scenery and the people.

I only went through it once so far, so I don't really have a comment on the replayability or how much the player can affect the story but at least the game created an illusion that your choices matter.

I liked the ending too, I think it is a matter of taste.

column8:
I'm right on the fence with thumbs up or down, but I'm going to go with down. Let me start by saying I absolutely love the setting, V:tM is my favorite of the WoD settings and one of my favorite things to play on tabletop period. This game does a good job of capturing the mood of Vampire, and in fact taking it in a good direction by distancing it from some of the over-the-top goth angst that was its hallmark back in the day. My love of Vampire is probably a major contributor to why my review is close to a 50/50, because anybody of a similar mind will probably have a similar experience. For people less vested in the setting, you will likely have a much more negative time for the reasons outlined below. 

My issues with the game are twofold, the first and foremost being technical. As other reviews have noted, there are a lot of small bugs, typos and grammatical errors scattered throughout the game. For a visual novel style game whose content is almost exclusively the written narrative you explore, you'd think basic spellchecking would be high on the To Do list. My second major gripe is in the narrative structure. I have only played through one character's story all the way to the end thus far, but from what I've read of other people's games there is only one ending that each character shares, assuming you make it to the very end and don't get killed beforehand. Again, for a Choose Your Own Adventure - style thing, I would expect at least some things to play out differently based on how you progressed through the story. That does not seem to be the case.

That said, I still enjoyed most of the playthrough. I felt pretty let down by the ending, it landed for me as feeling very abrupt, rushed and forced. I don't like being railroaded in roleplaying experiences, which is why I tend to favor sandbox RPGs. Still, I don't regret buying it and hopefully encouraging the continued development of V:tM video games. Maybe even some DLC for this game that adds additional depth to the gameplay, new clans and so on, I might be willing to revisit and change my review score. In its current state, though, I can't recommend for anyone except the most rabid fanboy of the setting.

column8:
EDIT: As of this edit, a skip text function has been added, though my thoughts on it are very mixed. Even though it was my biggest gripe with the game, it was added after an extremely long wait and many requests for a base function for the format. It seems the team wanted to focus more on getting their DLC out so they could make more money. Even though I love many things about the game, like its atmosphere and art direction, it fell short in a lot of places, including the team's willingness to communicate clearly with their customers. I still can't in good conscience recommend it, but if you're still interested in it after knowing its problems, it is still enjoyable on other levels.

I tried to keep my expectations from being too high for this game, knowing that it was going to be a small visual novel. The final product, however, was ultimately underwhelming even with the delayed release date.

The BIGGEST mistake made here was the lack of a skip text function. When creating a visual novel, a game form that inherently includes branching narratives and boasts replayability with the exploration of different plot lines, a skip text function is a necessary feature. No one wants to have to wade through the same flavor text and speeches they've already read to get to the quest lines they didn't get the chance to finish, or want to play through some other way.

The game also has a large number of typos and bugs involving flags. At certain points I found NPCs acknowledging certain flags, and then the scene would continue and they would repeat the same text as if I hadn't triggered a flag at all. In one instance, the hunger mechanic's flag even caused me to skip over an important main plot scene at the end of a night, leaving me starting the next night in confusion as to what had happened.

Not to mention that the ending of the game seems entirely rushed and static. It comes nearly out of left field, and seems to attempt to throw in plot twist after plot twist in an attempt to show the reader how they've truly been outplayed. Perhaps this is meant to come off as a commentary on the nature of Kindred, but it ultimately plays out rather heavy handed.

It's a shame this game seems to have been rushed so badly, even after being delayed, because the art and atmosphere are amazing. I simply can't in good conscience recommend it to someone with all the flaws it has at the moment.

column8:
Just got all the achievements.

Pros
*Vampire the Masquerade setting
*Malkavians

Cons
* Short game 4-6 hours long, with not much replayability 
*The intro is very long, before the game lets you "explore"
*Only three classes and there's not much difference between them.  About two extra scenes per class and a choice to use a power the other classes might not have.
*Powers are just flavor text, so you can still get the same results without using them.
*Choices don't matter, I can smash the enter key the whole game, be a jerk, or be friendly,  and all of them have the same ending.
*Side characters only have about three scenes each and then you can't visit them again.
*Dying and finishing the game deletes your save.
*The game forces you to end it very fast, without letting you explore everything.
*No change in the character art work, even if the scene describes a change. 
*Some plot problems that mention something happening but it didn't

column8:
I'm not gonna lie, this game isn't to everyone's taste as you can probably tell from most of the reviews.

However, I came to this game with an open mind that I was expecting a visual novel, and that's exactly what it is. I'm only a few hours into the storyline, so I can't comment on the endings or how well the choices effect the game, but I can comment that as someone pretty addicted to the World of Darkness 'world' lately - I am enjoying the playthrough. The atmosphere is good with the animated backgrounds and the music, the characters are unique, and the story does seem pretty well put together (so far.)

It's basically something to give you your Kindred fix before the release of Bloodlines 2. Enjoy it as that. :)

column8:
The choices are shallow and the game relies way too heavily on railroading you into decisions you might not otherwise make. It wouldn't be so bad if it was subtle but it literally forces your character to say and do things which feel completely out of character to suit the writer's narrative.

Speaking of which, the writing in general is adequate but not really strong enough to hold the game up on its own (there's no voice and very little ambient sound). Just to end off on a positive note, I'd like to add that the artwork and visuals are nice.

column8:
I'm not sure if I can recommend this to people unfamiliar with the World of Darkness, but if you are a VtM fan, there are no two ways about it. You... will... love it. And you must have it. You know the hunger in you is growing and the beast is getting stronger and stronger.

Only one thing can save you, now that you have arrived this far in reading my recommendation. Your inner desire shall not rest until all of it has been consumed. Do it. NOW. Soon enough, an even greater event will happen. But for now, this is an extraordinary gift that has been laid before you.

I have succumbed to it and do not regret a single minute, although I have yet to find a lot of what the Coteries of New York have to offer.

Good luck, Neonate.

column8:
A fully text-based adventure for lovers of narrative, interesting characters and vampire the masquerade. Very lore-appropriate and an enthralling trip into the world of darkness. I admit I didn't expect much out of this game earlier but it managed to grab my attention fully. 

However, bloodlines 2 it is not. Coteries is more of a "choose your own adventure" kind of thing. There is little gameplay other than choosing options out of a list, both dialogue and actions. I have noticed some people expect more this time and age, but I am perfectly happy with this.  The way the game is built you could easily play it in your smartphone while travelling in a bus. 

The one negative I have to point out: it is somewhat short. I finished the first playthrough at 7 hours. But it has three starting clans and probably non-trivial amount of replay value. I hope there is more to come from White Wolf. I am not disappointed that I bought this.

Thoroughly enjoyed my first playthrough of this visual novel.
A well told story in the World of Darkness universe and one that took more than a few twists and turns.

Update:  I updated this review to showcase the visual style of this game, which is lovely.

column8: This game keeps its promise. Beautiful art, very nice FX and immersive story. The universe of World of Darkness is respected here!

I really tried to like this game. As a fan of the Bloodlines the Masquerade game I really *wanted to like this game* but I just couldn't get into it. The prose rarely got to the point. It was wordy and some of the characteristic design choices were questionable. For example (although I've refunded it now) I recall a point where the Venture player says something along the lines of 'your boss is quoting shakespear to impress an attractive secretary' ..and later she would be meeting up with either a 'self-obsessed Musk-Wannable or a fat old pervert covered in cologne.' [an investor] Why would a Venture which "embodies wealth, sovereignty, and control" whose also "a top-level corporate exective" lack such a degree of social intelligence and be so irrationally jaded? It felt like I was reading someones perspective of a venture than a thinking and capable person. And while it's easy to glance over it, at no point did i feel like the game was interactive. I may as well have just been reading a book.. but I dunno man, this is just like my opionion of things.

column8:
I've just played through as toreador for the second time and this is what I think about the game.
Positive:
-pretty fun click n tell game. 
-Cool story all n all, 
-Interesting characters. 
Nice artwork and atmosphere

Negative: 
-kinda sad tho that you dont got time to do all the missions before the mainstoy forces you to play along. 
- Without spoiling to much, Your choices have little impact. Even tho I played my cards abit differently the second run, the outcome was the same. Would have been fun to get different endings depending on how you made your choices.

I give it a thumb up. Though I don't recommend to buy it without a good discount, or unless you're a fan of vampire games. If you played pen and paper RPG and know, what one shot is, this is what that game is. It does a very good job introducing you to the universe and makes you invested, but that's about it.

Overall, I've liked the story, and good story in the World of Darkness universe worth a lot. But aside from storytelling, there's not much to the game. Even the VN part... Good VN usually gives a story branching, different endings (good/bad/secret/etc), access to secret characters for additional effort. This game doesn't do that, all "questlines" are accessible at all times, the ending and how you get there are more or less the same. So, this game isn't a "good" VN. Character variety doesn't change much as well, though it allows you to see the story from "different perspective". When I've picked a Ventru clan in my second playthrough, I though "yes, here it is, a hard mode!", but then special quirk of that clan didn't kick in a single time past tutorial. What a bummer... Oh well. Anyway, this game is above of many other games that trying to sell the story, especially vampire based ones, so I still found this game worth of recommendation. Just probably not the full price.

column8: As a VTM-Fan I really liked it. Far better than the android-one from some years ago. Yes, it is short. Yes, your choices are limited. So what. The Story is good and that's all that matters to me.

As far as Visual Novels go this is a pretty bad one, it's feature-lite with no way to automatically advance dialogue or save the game at critical junctions to explore different choices. Though that's probably because there are no different choices, most of the time the choices seem to either kill you or offer some slightly different flavour to the scene without having any narrative impact at all.
Beyond that the game is a buggy mess, there are spelling and grammatical errors aplenty, some sets of choices net you the same passage of text no matter what you click, and at one point the game skipped an entire plot critical event where I was supposedly beaten and introduced to a critical NPC, leaving me to find out about the events via an NPC remarking about the trouble it would bring.

Regardless of all this, I'd still recommend the game if you like the world of darkness and can deal with reading for 4 hours straight with little in the way of interesting backdrops or music.

column8:
pros:
-it's VtM
-I enjoyed the artistic interpretation of Aisling Sturbridge.
cons:
-your companions are unlikeable and you're forced to deal with them to move the plot forward
-you're punished for actively roleplaying your character. the game forces you to make certain choices, which at times are completely concept-breaking for the character you're given.
-the ending was straight out of a M Night Shyamalan movie, complete with nonsensical "twist" designed to seem deep but coming up massively short.
-pricey for how little game there is. 5 bucks? yeah, it's worth that.

And none of your choices actually have an effect on the story, that's also pretty lame. So, yeah. Don't buy this. It wasn't worth my time and it's not worth yours.

column8:
Great Visual Novel set in the Vampire universe. Strong art, music, and tone with an interesting plot and characters. Some typos and grammatical errors. More moment-to-moment conversation choice/interaction than most VNs I've played, but does not tell a branching narrative like some VNs or like interactive fiction such as (for example) "80 Days". Mostly the choices appear to be flavor or to add replay value.

Roughly the length I would expect for a $20 VN. Story note (spoilers): [spoiler]tells a complete story that reads like the prologue of a bigger tale (think Shenmue I). This might ultimately be a negative if the developers don't intend to finish the larger narrative (or don't get the opportunity to do so)[/spoiler].

Lacks some basic features that are otherwise standard to VNs: no ability to fast forward/auto advance (generally or, in particular, to the next conversation choice); no chapter select; no ability to save to multiple slots. These are minor annoyances, but they did make a second playthrough more tedious than it needed to be.

In short - if you're a fan of Visual Novels and the Vampire universe, you should love this. If however you've never played a VN or you are expecting an RPG, you may be disappointed.

column8:
I rather enjoyed this game.  It is a fairly linear visual novel, so if that turns you off I entirely understand, but I found the game decently written, the story engaging, the characters interesting, and the atmosphere perfect.  It plays like an intro adventure to the VtM setting and certainly rekindled some of my old interest in the rpg. 

The game is short, about 5-7 hours in length, and the main story is very linear, but there are side missions and alternate decisions enough that I think it should be worth a second playthrough. 

I liked the ending, which felt very appropriate for the narrative and even managed to surprise me a little. 

It is a bit buggy upon release, however, so if you're on the fence I would recommend giving it a month and buying it after a couple patches. 

I hope to see some story dlc for the game and maybe an expansion or sequel down the line.

column8:
Welp, finished the game in...half an hour? I mean, credits rolled, so I "beat" it, right? By dying for no reason? Cool. But not really. Not sure if I think this game is trash or it just needs its "chance". Anyway... Possible spoilers ahead?

Pros
- Good art and atmospheric music.
- Interesting world building, albeit shortlived.

Cons
- I've read there's no save system or just a bad one, but...well, I wasn't able to save in my first playthrough before I died.
- Character logic makes 0 sense. You cooperate w/ NPCs, but they still say you were a pain to deal with. One NPC says she'll save you at X moment and she...doesn't. And you die. Game over. Start again. All over again.

Neutral
- Writing/dialog is solid for the most part. Pretty...generic or meathead-ish at other times. But I suppose that can still be realistic.

So, deciding to not refund this, tho it sort of deserves to be. Rather, I'll just try to "complete" it again. Maybe as Bloodlines 2 gets closer, I'll get more hyped. 

But...will the game just sort of "randomly" end at any point due to some unknown effect I had? And will there have been a save point hopefully close to that? Not sure I wanna risk it.

That's really about all I can say. As of now, it deserves a play if you're interested. I think that about any game, really. But also as of now, Draw Distance does NOT deserve anything but maybe $5 for this game due to some easy features (saves, better character logic, maybe prompts that the game will be over if you do/don't do X, etc) they avoided for some reason.
