column8:
I do not usually write reviews but I've decided to express my disappointment regarding VTM - Coteries of New York. Or rather the misleading approach on it's announcement and description regarding it's "high replayabilty" and non existent "choices matter".

Now before going into the bad criticism I would like to point out the good things about it: 

The scripting and narrative pace until the last night is truly enchanting. As a long time WoD (World of Darkness) player and DM I personally found so much potential in this game it squeezes NYC and 5e in a simple way for people who have never involved themselves in the pen & paper setting but it also makes for a fan to get immersed in the story.  

The characters that are presented are kind of lazy trope of each clan representation but the way that the narrative introduces them and the gimmicks added in each background makes each individual NPC an attractive asset. I've really appreciated the persona of the early 20th century Brujah, the non Dr Frankenstein/Arkham bat shit crazy Malk stereotype and the non wannabe a warlock Tremere. I can keep writing regarding this but to make it short. Great work on this. Kudos to the art and background music, great combination.

Now into the bad points regarding this. The misleading product selling. 

Personally I wasn't expecting a masterpiece for 10 bucks but there are limits on how different the product would be apart from it's description. About your options as a PC, pre-made ones are within the expectations and I personally kinda like them but three clans are not "several distinct Clans" this disappointment could have been easily be avoided. I won't nerd rage about the disciplines I mean yeah writers could have made an effort but that's fine.

Your coterie companions are just flavor, they do not matter in the story. If you are really into the game you might find that as your biggest turn off. For what is worth and as I mentioned before, the backgrounds are cool and the side stories are enjoyable to read through.

And speaking of things that don't matter, we have the dialog options on important plot choices. And this linear (and short) story does not offer replayability at all, you can enjoy three playthroughs if you want to do a run with each PC, four or five if you want to choose different side quests. Of course this doesn't matter in the end as the last night of the game is just an inevitable rush for the PC to learn about the mangled silly plot twist and the random antagonist. It really feels like the team didn't have time to finish the game properly. 

As a neonate you face lots of inevitable consequences, you are just a dirt spot or a chess piece (as implied) for the elder and for other factions in the World of Darkness, you are weak, ignorant and unimportant but if different variants of the ending mean just a change in dialog depending on which clan you selected at the start of the game, well I might have just preferred this as a book, not a VN.

I might experiment by trying to complete the achievement if I might change this review if the game surprises me but I've read many reviews for me to lose hope. It's really sad because this could have been a great short narrative if it weren't for the publishers that created big expectations for the fans. I will go to bed now and hope that the pushed back release of Bloodlines 2 is worth.

Welchen der drei vorgegeben Charaktere man spielt und welche optionalen Quests man erledigt, ver√§ndert den Spielablauf aber schon. Man kann vier Verb√ºndete rekrutieren und drei Nebenquests angehen. Allerdings nicht in einem Spielablauf da man nur begrenzt Raum f√ºr die optionalen Inhalte bekommt.

Die Geschichte endet allerdings offen, unbefriedigend und unver√§nderlich.

column8: I would absolutely love to give this a good review, but I can't.. It does the vampire the masquerade lore justice, it really does, but your playthroughs are all the same, regardless of choices, characters can die off and you can attempt to save them but never have the questline pop up again, it just disappears. The ending is through the amount of nights, not the progress you made and quickly is cut off and the replayability is just non-existent and this is from someone who wants all the achievements even the vampire powers you get are basically the same, if this was more than 4 hours per play through with much more meaningful choices and not a night system until the end, I'd adore it so much more but you don't even get more than one new changable scene of the characters you like, you get one close up on your sire, once and that's the only time you'll really get a good visable novel approach. I loved the references to the first game and the art style, if there was just a bit more content I'd happily recommend this but right now I just can't.

column8: This should have been a mobile game as it is literally just text.  It's basically original Zork, but vampires.  Well not really, but it is literally just a choose your own adventure book on the computer.  Zero reason this isn't primarily or only a mobile game.  In fact if I could play it on my phone I'd I will give it a thumbs up, but as a computer game for 19.99 or 17.99 it is a BAD investment.

column8:
"Coteries of New York" is a visual novel game set in the "World of Darkness" universe, more specifically "Vampire: The Masquerade". One of the things people like the most, whether in the original tabletop game or video games, is a special atmosphere that is hard to describe. In my opinion Draw Distance managed to create this atmosphere very well with a lot of awesome artwork for both the background and the character images, and a wonderful music. 
The storytelling is also very interesting and reflects the eternal struggle of the factions in the Kindred society as we know it.

However, who might expect a role playing game in any way, could be disappointed. You have three characters with a different embrace story to choose from. You have less time than you would need to get every Coterie member/finish every side quest you can do, so each time you will play you will have a different experience. But what happens in the story is very similar.

If you consider buying it, please take into account that this game is a visual novel, not an RPG of any kind! It is a wonderful one, but if you expect three different takes on the plot with multiple endings, this game is not for you. It is no "Bloodlines Light", it was never ment to be. It is something set in the same universe as the tabletop game and Bloodlines 1 and 2, but it is its own product, with its own story and gameplay.

There are also some bugs left, but the team is already working hard on fixing them. They already released a first patch a few hours after release.

tl;dr: If you are looking for a game that gives you the opportunity to enjoy the Vampire: The Masquerade atmosphere, this visual novel is perfect for you! If you are looking for an RPG experience, a lot of variations and big consequences of each action, you might want to look somewhere else, because this is just the wrong genre for that.

column8:
The game delivers on the Vampire the Masquerade style of story as told through the format of a visual novel. The game is dripping with atmosphere with well written descriptions of varying environments and characters. The entire time I played, things felt akin to a storyteller with a very specific vision for his campaign written, who would allow me to run from the Sheriff if I really chose to, but wouldn't let me succeed. No, his story depends on a level of respect for his vision as opposed to a world I can just mess about in. 

I do say *his* campaign with reason, as there is one issue I had with this game. It feels as though there were only men involved in the writing process. A good few moments felt tainted by the ever present male gaze, such as women acting in ways I imagine only a man would imagine them to act. Apart from that breaking my sense of truth (in a game about blood sucking monsters which apparently don't) this game does have my recommendation.

column8:
Major disappointment! I played bloodlines and loved it. This is a poor 27th to it. 

If you are a glutton for punishment, then at least wait for a 75% off sale.

1) WTH is the with the save system or should I say, lack there of. You get only one save that is overwritten automatically while you play. I have played a number of "Visual novels" and they all had multiple saves. But Draw Distance thought is was a good idea to grief their customers by limiting the saves to only one per bloodline/PC. 
We at Draw Distance feel that decisions should have consequences. So we are being (Colorful Metaphors) and making you start the game from the very beginning if something goes differently then you want or expect. Oh and we will make sure it does, cause yeah we're (Colorful Metaphors). Feel free to insert your own colorful metaphor in the above, whatever you feel fits the statement.

2) The text presented to pick from does not coincide with what is said. So you have to guess what will be said. If you are not happy with what was said, you can just reload the save, NOPE, already overwritten, so start all over again! Keep mashing the Continue button... (Colorful Metaphor!)

I truly feel like I have been griefed by the devs playing this game. They couldn't even set mile stone saves that would alow you to go back to a major decision and start over from there.

column8:
I was nervous when they announced a week's delay five days before launch, and unfortunately, my fears were justified. I really wanted to give this a thumbs up since I've been a VtM fan since the late 90's and it's been so long since we got a Vampire video game, but alas, it is not meant to be.

The game nails the feel of Vampire. It looks good for a visual novel. The soundtrack  is pretty decent.  That's about all the good things I can say, though.

Things start off well enough and I was hyped for the first hour, then the bugs started tearing their ugly head.  Typos and glitches like placeholder code for your character's name being in the text instead of your actual name. Being able to use disciplines you don't have. Scenes not triggering. For them wanting to take an extra week to fix things, I don't even want to think about what this would be like without that extra time.

You also get the illusion of being in charge of the narrative, and then you get rammed into the ending sequence with the power of a freight train. And while the ending itself is very on brand with VtM, the way the devs go about it is clumsy and just very poorly written.

6.5/10

column8:
As someone whose all-time favourite table-top RPG is Vampire: the Masquerade, I didn't know what to expect from this game, beyond that might it be visual novel-esque.

I've played through to the end as one of the three available characters, and I enjoyed the game quite a bit.
The story and characters are very well written. Deep, complex and mature. Even side characters who only appear briefly during scenes were interesting and had me wanting to know more about them, hoping to see them recur later on.

The developer has really captured the mood and atmosphere of how I think a V:tM game should feel. The soundtrack is quite good and had me reminiscing about V:tM Bloodlines - one of my top 5 games of all time.

I like how dialogue choices impact the story progression. This was well done, though there were some situations where it felt the story was presented a bit forced, in order to accommodate all three playable characters without coming up with separate narratives. For example, at one point, the narration referred to plot elements from a scene in a limo with an NPC, things that didn't actually happen/weren't revealed while I was playing that scene. Thankfully, I can only count instances of that happening through the game on one hand.

From a setting, theme, mood, etc. feel, throughout play I kept thinking to myself "This would make an excellent introduction for people who may be interested to learn what the tabletop game is all about."

Re-playability is high as well, as there are definitely situations I want to replay to see how different dialogue options will affect the story. Not to mention I want to play through the game with the other two characters well.

Hope you put more V:tM games out in a similar style! A Sabbat chronicle in this style would be AMAZING
column9:
As someone whose all-time favourite table-top RPG is Vampire: the Masquerade, I didn't know what to expect from this game, beyond that might it be visual novel-esque.

I've played through to the end as one of the three available characters, and I enjoyed the game quite a bit.
The story and characters are very well written. Deep, complex and mature. Even side characters who only appear briefly during scenes were interesting and had me wanting to know more about them, hoping to see them recur later on.

The developer has really captured the mood and atmosphere of how I think a V:tM game should feel. The soundtrack is quite good and had me reminiscing about V:tM Bloodlines - one of my top 5 games of all time.

I like how dialogue choices impact the story progression. This was well done, though there were some situations where it felt the story was presented a bit forced, in order to accommodate all three playable characters without coming up with separate narratives. For example, at one point, the narration referred to plot elements from a scene in a limo with an NPC, things that didn't actually happen/weren't revealed while I was playing that scene. Thankfully, I can only count instances of that happening through the game on one hand.

From a setting, theme, mood, etc. feel, throughout play I kept thinking to myself "This would make an excellent introduction for people who may be interested to learn what the tabletop game is all about."

Re-playability is high as well, as there are definitely situations I want to replay to see how different dialogue options will affect the story. Not to mention I want to play through the game with the other two characters well.

Hope you put more V:tM games out in a similar style! A Sabbat chronicle in this style would be AMAZING

column8:
Great "old fashioned" storytelling text game, but with great music and visuals. 

Two complaints: 1) As a Ventrue, they explore my disadvantage to needing a particular type of blood, but after that allow me to receive the benefits from anyone I drink from. This is a major flaw of the clan that shouldn't be ignored. 

2) There should be more clans to choose from at the start. Will these be added later?

column8: Bought because of the VtM title. The game has about 6-7 hours of content. If you play through once it's a good experience (true to lore), but once you play through a second time you realise how limited the game is. No matter what character you choose or what dialogue options you choose the story is the same. Going by the 1$/hr rule this game is worth about $7, only get if on sale.

column8:
It's always good to see more World of Darkness content out there as a fan of the Tabletop games.
That said, Coteries of New York is a bit of a mixed bag for me. I enjoyed it though. An enjoyable mixed bag.
At the time of writing I've completed 1 run of the game, and done some research on the other paths I could have taken.

Pros:
-Great Writing
-Most Realistic Portrayal of Kindred Society I've seen in a while (Though Anarchs existing in New York instead of Sabbat is frustrating. Ditch the V5 Metaplot you cowards I want to smooch a Tzimisce.)
-Creative usage of powers within a VN.
-Wonderful art, both Characters & Backgrounds.

Cons:
-Only one choice matters, and you make it really early on, rendering the rest of the game near pointless.
-Too few Nights. Even if the main story was more sporadically spread out, I would have preferred that over only being able to reliably recruit 2 characters and just maybe tackle a sidequest. The game never explains its time limit. 
-Big Twist at the end feels cheap.

That's about all I can say for Cotories atm, I'd reccomend it if it's still on sale or if you've got a hankering for Vampires. I'll end this review with a note. Why not try the Tabletop games? Not V5, but Vampire 20th, Mage 20th, and Changeling 20th are all great Tabletop RPG's!

column8:
I'm really sorry to have to thumb this game down.

I started as the ventrue character and I really enjoyed the writing but the longer I played the more I would notice the flaws.

-There are quite a few of spelling mistakes
-Sometimes characters respond to you in ways that contradict the choices you've made
-During the anarch questline the scene where Callihan's goons threaten you to not meet Torque did not trigger for me, suddenly this character appears and the game acts as though I already know this character
-At one time a scene suddenly ended, while doing the agathon questline, he gets hurt and I selected the option to use celerity to chase after his attackers and suddenly the scene stopped, back to the map screen

For a visual novel game this is just unacceptable, which is a shame because the writing is very good.
This needed more time in the oven.  I also get the feeling your choices don't have a lot of influence on the overall narrative.

column8:
I wanted to love this game. I really, truly did.

Pros: 
+ Lovely, atmospheric artwork
+ Solid VtM lore with a clear, decent in-game glossary to guide those unfamiliar with the setting
+ Entertaining & unique coterie characters

Cons:
+ Typos and bugs are... ubiquitous. Way too many to ignore, though I tried. In a game based entirely on reading, the poor grammar and spelling are frankly unreasonable. Bug Examples: Your character having access to powers that do not belong to their clan. Certain achievements not popping. Characters responding as if you have picked entirely other options, thereby impacting how they treat you, even though you definitely chose the opposite response. To the developer's credit, they are currently trying to address the bugs, but I have little faith the grammar and spelling will be resolved.

+ Bizarrely inconsistent writing. In one sentence, they'll refer to someone as 'he', then refer to the same character as 'they' in the next line. There also seem to be scenes missing, somehow?  In one notable instance with a Stalker storyline, I went from having never met a character before to instantly knowing their name, behaving as if I'd met them previously, AND being berated by my patron for spending time with them, as if I had spoken to my patron about having a stalker at all AND had been warned (spoiler alert: neither was the case.)

+ Absolutely no character customization of any kind. This would be acceptable if the storylines were unique and tailored to each clan, but... honestly, they aren't. The main storyline concludes the same way no matter what you do. So why can't I pick my avatar? My gender? My clan? Because it really, truly does not matter whether I'm a Brujah, Ventrue, or Toreador aside from the very tiny slivers of their origin stories. Even in those origin stories, gender is irrelevant.

+ Unfriendly game design. Sure, kill off characters, discourage save-scumming; it's a dangerous world, that's fine. But then they DELETE the save upon character death, wasting perhaps hours of investment. Also there is no autosave, so if your game crashes, you are also out of luck. When you combine bugged dialogue options with a terrible save system that actively deletes your progress, that's pretty bad. When you ALSO do not include a "Fast Forward" option to skip past dialogue you've seen multiple times due to your save being erased, that's frankly awful and inexcusable in this day and age.

On the whole, I'm disappointed. They clearly "get" the vibe of World of Darkness and know the setting well enough to make this feel right. I am also, as previously stated, incredibly fond of the artwork. If there had been more effort included in refining the writing as well as giving us *either* unique, branching storylines OR the ability to customize a character, I really think this game could have been great.

column8:
If there was a horizontal thumb I would have used that. Just finished my first playthrough, and I must say I am a bit disappointed. The story had potential and I was looking forward to getting more in-depth with my coterie members and the other characters of the story. Anyway, before I even knew it, the story skipped right to the ending, and I barely even got to know why and what exactly was going on. This must have been due to the choices I made and which tasks I prioritized to handle first, but I thought I would have time to go through them all before they just shut down the whole story on me before it has even begun. This just seems like poor game design to me.

Maybe it will be better the second time around ... but I know how its gonna end, eventhough I have only the vaguest understanding why at this point.

I played as the Brujah btw.

Second playthrough:

Played as Brujah again, chose some different options. Yet again, the game seems determined to rush you towards an ending which just leaves you ... frustated. You wanted to explore that questline? - to bad, no time. Game says no. Time to end the story now. Also, you would expect those questlines to form a bigger picture and the dots to connect in an ending that made some kind of sense? Except they dont, they are just left there, flapping in the wind. And you are left there feeling "whats the rush?", "that made no sense at all". It's like being halfway through a novel, only to have someone come by and rip out the rest of the pages except the very ending.

Sorry guys, changed my mind, it's gonna be a "no" now. You have made a lot of little stories which in and by themselves are pretty cool and interesting, but you have failed to  make them fit into a bigger picture which leaves the player satisfied.

column8: I had not heard a lot about this game, but the setting was enough to draw my interest. I am glad to say that this game exceeded my expectations. The atmosphere, story, characters all draw you in. My one gripe is that you could not do all the coterie/side quests before the final night.

column8: I love VTM i fell in love with the Orginal game back 2004. Nothing has made me happier than seeing renewed interest in it with the release of this game and then Bloodlines 2. So first of all despite the fact that I love this game and the authors are clearly well versed in the lore, I also love VN's . Not everyone does however if you do like VN you will more than likely like this game as it is a very good VN among the best I have seen since Steins Gate in terms of graphics. I feel that the ending was kinda abrupt but not really bad it was properly foreshadowed at least in my mind. However I dont like that it was over in 4.6 hours, the ending could use some work as in it ended before it should have. But all in all I enjoyed the narrative as it was very well written, I just wish there was more of it.

column8:
The game resembles the playbooks of the 80's, like Lone Wolf, and the likes. You pick a predetermined character, and then make choices as you go along. both dialogue and actions. Due to having 3 different characters to pick and limited actions per night, there's a lot of replayability.

The bad is that you get disciplines not belonging to the clan you pick, which makes me think, after my first play through, that clan picking is just a pointless gimmick. I will edit this review after my second play through. First took aprox 4 hours.

I'd recommend this game as it relaxes, and lets you be drawn into kindred politics. it's a simple, but charming game.

column8:
I've only gotten a short way into the story, but I am already in love with this game. As a longtime fan of the VtM tabletop RPG, I'm finding this to be not only a wonderful entry point into the series (the game provides a dictionary to quickly get accustomed to the vocabulary of the game) as well as a great story that fits the melancholy, twisted setting of the World of Darkness.

The only downside so far is that the occasional typo will break immersion, but for this price, it's very easy to overlook this. If you like vampires and a good story, get this game!

column8: I really enjoyed the game! The characters seem very well fleshed-out, it's great that they actually use the powers and the Hunger mechanic, it makes the gameplay more engaging. Your coterie is people you can actually bond with, they're very compelling characters. Unfortunately, the overarching plot isn't something you have any real influence over, and as of now there are only three playable clans that are also gender-specific, I'd like to see them expand on that.

column8:
Quick disclaimer - this game is a lot of fun from a 'getting the atmosphere of V:TM right' perspective. There's a much heavier focus on talking, building relationships, lies and deceit, grand schemes, etc...

The first time around, anyway. No matter what character you play or choices you make, it always plays out the same way, so if you're hoping for unique scenarios with various clans or quest choices, you're going to be disappointed after the first run through.

column8:
It's fun and immersive, a great introduction to Vampire: The Masquerade for those that are not very familiar with the game or with more recent developments in the lore with 5th edition of the tabel top rpg. I played 9 hours straight with just a break to sleep until I finished my first playthrough: it's the kind of game that will hook you up and I'm itching to dive right back in.

Backgrounds are pretty, characters are interesting (malkavians do not disappoint) plot is... Jesus. It's what you'd expect from a VtM Game and then more. I definitely recommend it if you like reading and have any interest in Vampire: the Masquerade, even if (specially if) you are not particularly familiar with the franchise yet.

I got my first achievement, and haven't done anything other than click the continue button and read a story. Bloodlines 2, this ain't. I'm not even sure it's a video game. I still want to see what happens though... almost as if I'm under some sort of vampire spell.

column8:
So ill start by saying I am a big fan of the whole Vampire: The Masquerade world and lore, however this game is very bland to say the least.
This is a novel and its simply all it is, there is no real effect to your actions, no real point in choosing which words you say or what course of action you take.
I barley had any time to let the story sink when I was spiraled into a chain of events that did catch my interest more than the "game" so far but just at that point the devs decided to end it there, barley 4 hours and its over.
I cannot recommend this even though I love the genre.

[h1]üéÆ [u]Vampire: The Masquerade - Coteries of New York[/u] üéÆ [/h1] 

Diese Visual Novel von [url=https://store.steampowered.com/publisher/DRAWDISTANCE]Draw Distance[/url] entf√ºhrt uns in den Big Apple, New York, und gibt Einblick in die Welt von Vampire: The Masquerade. Doch f√ºr wen ist das Spiel? Vorab: Definitiv nichts f√ºr Leute mit schlechten Englischkenntnissen!

[b]Gameplay[/b] 

Zu Beginn w√§hlen wir einen von drei Charakteren, der auch einem entsprechenden Haus/Clan (Brujah, Ventrue, Toreador) zugeordnet werden kann. Danach erhalten wir eine kurze Erkl√§rung zu unserer gew√§hlten Person, bevor wir uns schon mittendrin im Erz√§hlstrang befinden. Nach 20 Minuten war mein erster Durchgang dann auch schon vorbei, denn erfreulicherweise war eine falsche Entscheidung zeitgleich auch das Ende. 

Zweiter Versuch und anderer Charakter. Hier zeigt sich dann auch, dass sich die Erz√§hlungen zun√§chst signifikant unterscheiden, wobei sie sich gen Ende hin dann doch wieder ann√§hern. Ansonsten ist die Entscheidungsfreiheit, wie so oft, mehr oder minder illusorischer Natur. Auch die hauseigenen F√§higkeiten hatten meiner Beobachtung nach keinen oder wenn √ºberhaupt nur marginalen Einfluss auf den Verlauf. Doch was ist das Ziel? Nat√ºrlich mehr Macht zu erhalten, zu √ºberleben und sein eigenes Coterie aufzubauen.

Ansonsten bieten Questreihen eine gewisse Abwechslung, denn ohne die richtigen Antworten zu geben, wird man keine Hilfe erhalten und schon gar nicht die dazugeh√∂rige Errungenschaft freischalten. Diese sind es im √úbrigen auch, neben den drei Anfangscharakteren und ihren Eigenheiten, die den wesentlichen Wiederspielwert ausmachen. Denn man will halt letztlich doch, dass Charakter X oder Y einem hilft und Person A bzw. B sich einem anschlie√üt. 

[b]Grafik & Sound[/b] 

Grafisch sehen die Hintergrundbilder sehr gut aus, jedoch erschienen sie mir nach einer Weile schon recht monoton (Stichwort: Auto mit wechselndem Fahrer oder ver√§ndernde Gem√ºtszust√§nde). Dar√ºber hinaus sind die Artworks aber allesamt gut anzusehen und der Soundtrack mit seiner instrumentalen Musik, beispielsweise einer Melodie mit Kontrabass und Harfe (so mich meine Ohren nicht t√§uschten), lie√üen eine sch√∂ne Welt entstehen. Auch die Ger√§usche, wie das Klopfen oder Klingeln an einer T√ºr oder das Fallen von Regentropfen sind sehr hervorzuheben!

Apropos Tropfen: Ein Wermutstropfen ist jedoch die fehlende deutsche Sprachausgabe des Spiels, denn man muss schon wirklich sehr gute Fremdsprachenkenntnisse vorweisen k√∂nnen, damit man das Geschriebene ohne √úbersetzungshilfe versteht. [b]Nachtrag[/b]: Mittlerweile gibt es auch eine deutsche Sprachausgabe und die √úbersetzung ist unerwarteter weise doch sehr gut. Wiederum positiv ist jedoch das eigene Dictionary mit Erkl√§rungen zu Begriffen aus der Welt von Vampire: The Masquerade, die auch jederzeit wieder nachgelesen werden k√∂nnen. So wird die Welt an sich auch immersiver. 

Hinzu kommen die wirklich langen Textpassagen. Normal m√∂gen die Einen sagen, Angesichts des Umfangs behaupte ich jedoch, dass das schon herausragend ist wie viel M√ºhe man sich hier machte. 

[b]Fazit[/b] 

F√ºr wen also ist das Spiel? F√ºr Liebhaber von Visual Novel-Titeln definitiv, denn die investierte Energie in das Gestalten der Welt und die Dialoge sucht schon seines Gleichen. F√ºr Lesefaule ist das Spiel daher definitiv nichts. Ansonsten kann ich das Spiel jedem empfehlen, der sich mit der Welt von Vampire: The Masquerade intensiver besch√§ftigen m√∂chte, eventuell auch, weil er die Titel [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2600/Vampire_The_Masquerade__Bloodlines/?curator_clanid=32139821]Bloodlines[/url] und [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/532790/Vampire_The_Masquerade__Bloodlines_2/?curator_clanid=32139821]Bloodlines 2[/url] in Betracht zieht zu spielen. Mit 30% zum Start ist der Preis auch mehr als fair, wobei ich auch den Vollpreis f√ºr in Ordnung halte. Der Spieleumfang d√ºrfte zwischen 15 und 20 Stunden liegen, das Dictionary und der √ºberragende Soundtrack k√∂nnen jedoch jederzeit abgerufen werden.

Honestly as someone whos extremely familiar with the World of Darkness and Vampire in particular this may be one the best Video Games of the Table to every come out. 
For Starters it is faithful to the lore and source material, something that cannot be said about 99% of almost anything based video games. 
This is how World of Darkness and any game based off another source should be handled. 
The art style is fantastic and i cannot give it high enough praise.
The atmosphere and music is amazing. 
The writing is top notch and the Canon characters such as Qadir, Panhard and High Regent herself are all portrayed accuratly and faithfully with exceptional writing. 
On a level of immersion and recreating what it is to play a game of the Table Top this game did a great job, not perfect but better then any predecessor thus far, i would highly recommend this game. 
My only complaints would be some minor bugs ( which are currently already in the process of being patched. ) And the ending which felt like it came abit to soon, on the ending however, it was infact good, abit to soon but very good. The World of Darkness pulls no punches and this game didnt either, secondly as someone who has played and run the source material for years its good to see in clear situations where you would die for being dumb or a smartass the game is faithful.
So outside of an ending that came to soon and bugs? No, treat yourself, buy this game and replay it, i am currently on my second playthrough as we speak. 
Also on a final note, Cudos to the Developers for not being afraid to tackle the sleeping Giant that is the Setting of New York, i hope to see another World of Darkness game out of you soon.

column8: Good game, if you are into the World of Darkness. The story is interesting enough, but not mind-blowing. The visuals are just great. The plot is midiocre tho.  There are some false choices, but i personaly liked it for the atmosphere.Rather than the actual gameplay. If you are into  The Masquerade i suggest buying it, because it brought back my old-scool role-playing memories, just like Bloodline. But don't expect too much from it. If it had a voice acting i would have been much happier, but still not a bad buy.

column8:
[b]FULL DISCLOSURE:[/b] I received a 10% discount on this game for buying it on launch week.

>Finished a mostly self-insert Brujah run the night of release: found it very enjoyable. Game is a bit short, but choices are interesting and often tense. I hope to see similar games with the same license or an expansion pack from this developer.

>If you or a friend haven't yet gotten into Vampire the Masquerade (VtM) or have never played a visual novel, I'd recommend waiting for a sale. It's kind of like an old-school text adventure.

>If you're into VtM, absolutely buy this with no hesitation. Draw_Distance did a great job at capturing the essence of the franchise in an easily digestible format. You have full license to yell at me in the comments if you love the franchise but somehow hate this game.

>Please note, a day-one patch may have fixed many of the bugs other users encountered. I found a few minor typographical errors and one abnormality with the powers in exactly one scene during my playthrough.

>SPOILER (you have been warned, I really recommend you avoid any spoilers whatsoever with this sort of game) 

[spoiler]My only problem with this visual novel is how abrupt the ending was. Really, it felt more like a potential sequel or DLC hook rather than a proper conclusion to the story. The loose ends are largely wrapped up by the time it hits (and it's not a long time), but there's clearly another story to follow. Who tells that story? Maybe you do in your next chronicle, but I think it's more likely Draw_Distance has another story arc on the way. Usually I hate this sort of thing, but I tolerate in this case because their work here was really good.[/spoiler]

Edits: Added a spoiler section which was originally left out because I [b]HIGHLY[/b] advise avoiding spoilers as much as possible with visual novels. Addressed the release of a patch.

column8:
Pros:
The art is beautiful. The soundtrack does its job perfectly fine. The moment to moment writing works. All of the characters so far are enjoyable, except for maybe Hope playing it too close to Malkavian stereotype for my liking.

Cons:
Bugs. Every once in a while you'll lose out on actions as the game moves you immediately to rest after the first scene of the night.
Pacing issues. The game is weirdly lacking in the central hook department. So far it's kind of been slice of unlife vampire stuff. Sophie told me to build a coterie, so I guess that's what I'm doing. A stronger character motivation to do stuff than just "it's a living!" would have gone a long way I think.
Unclear game mechanics. Am I hungry? Should I feed? Would using this discipline action affect my hunger? All of this is completely obfuscated. After I did the first event with the companion vampires - are we pals now? Are we a coterie? The achievement says so, but the text certainly didn't deliver this vibe.
Lack of PC personality. Past the prologue, my character became a cardboard cutout who communicates entirely in exposition prompts.
The titular "coteries" are basically non-existent. The coterie you assemble doesn't matter, its members interact with each other exactly once, and none of your coterie-mates assist you with any of your missions.
The ending is extremely rough.

All in all, this is a very rough game. The art and the moment to moment writing are enough to stick around for at least one playthrough. A 5/10 by visual novel standards, pick it up when it's on sale.

column8:
So Let's not be confused by what this it.  1st and foremost, it's a visual novel.  If that isn't your genre and you're a VtM fan, that may not be enough to get you into it.

The game doesn't hold your hand either.  You won't know if the choices you're making are the "correct" ones or not.  The game will not let you make multiple saves either, so that might frustrate some gamers looking to minimize their playthroughs.

Once you come to the end of your story that save is deleted, so you have to start over.  What this does, very effectively though, is force you to consider your choices and make note of what tried before and try different options.

The one complaint I do have is because of this, you do have to go through the intro every single time.  That becomes tedious and because of that, it does invoke the feeling of not this again, which can sour the experience.

Overall if you're into VtM for story element and not the combat of VtM:BL you might want to hold off until VtM:BL2 launches next year.  If you're looking for a cheap tide over to get into the mood of VtM (the game is only $20 full price) the I'd recommend this as the game nails the vibe.  Especially if you look at it from playing a visual table top with a strict game master whose focus is on playing the social Masquerade elements and not a combat campaign.

*Edit after playing every clan*

This is a $4.99 dollar game not a $20.00 VN.  Unfortunately, the story path is the same for all 3 playable clans.  There is very little difference between the characters except for the intro and a forced middle section.  After seeing the same intro over and over I pulled out an auto-clicker to plow through the dialogue that I've already seen.  By the time I got to the 3rd clan, which for me was Ventrue, I had seen everything but the intro and the middle section, which isn't a spoiler, the part where you meet the person from your past.

Nothing changes in this game.  All the conversation choices stay the same, the ending is always the same, nothing changes.  Which is just sad because the 1st play through of the showed just how much potential they had here.

The Dev team should have postponed this for a couple more months and really focused on the branching trees and explored the clans more.

column8:
This is my first review and it can contain spoilers.

Pros.: - atmosphere
          - music
          - Some characters like D'Angelo, and the Sheriff are fun.
          - Story could be interesting, but:

Cons.: - obvious political preaching on the SJW side. Basically half of the story can be summarized by: "Hurr durr status quo herp derp ruling elites, disrespecting whamen- this comes from Agathon near in the end game,  positions of power, and other buzzwords. You didn't see this coming(?) obious old white guy is the BBEG."
           -The BBEG is racist and sexist because why wouldn't he be. Although I would think that someone who existed more than a decade as an undead wouldn't give a f@ck about gender or race.
 - Inconsistencies and contreadictions for example:
 - Vampire society survived a Second Inquisition, and needs to be in secret to survive now more than ever, BUT there is a Caitiff(!) Primogen who lives with his family. (Why isn't he resting in pieces with his family exactly?), And a Tremere who keeps meeting with his grandmother (Why aren't they dead again?) 
 - Red hook murders: if you come to the conclusion that the killer is a Malk, D'Angelo says something along the lines: " Nah, it can't be a a Malkavian. They can be tricky but there is a method to their madness." - Are you f.cking kidding me. 
  - you can choose only from 3 Clans, but your Clan won't matter. Doesn't add to the story.
  - you can use Disciplines what normally wouldn't be available for you.  Brujah can Dominate, Ventrue can use Potence....

Conclusion: This is a VtM fanfic spiced with IRL political screeching, preaching. With less IRL politics, and more internal logic, and with some talent this could be a great graphic novel. But sadly it's not.

I'd give the game full marks for the great atmosphere and descent writing, but the game is extremely short and ends just when it seems to pick up. Honestly, the game feels more like a prologue chapter than an actual game.  Additionally, the game is somewhat buggy, and it seems as if your choices don't really matter.  With that said, it's a great introduction to a World of Darkness, so if you want to get to know the world a bit more before playing the next Vampire game, you can pick this up during same sale.

Okay, well, I was wrong about this game. So, so wrong! And for that, I want to apologize to everyone who thought this game might hold some promise of being a good purchase.

The bugs and spelling errors could have easily been forgiven, with just a few patches meant to help correct things. But the ham fisted political ideology the game tries to sell you can not.

Coteries of New York is not a game that offers players the freedom of choice. The developers flat out lied to you. They lied, and they feel absolutely no shame about it. They did not set out to provide you with a fun role playing experience, or a compelling story set in the world of darkness. They set out to push their political agendas upon everyone they tricked into buying this game, and they did so in the most insultingly sloppy fashion imaginable.


The game itself is very heavy on the rail roading, often with your choices seeming to have no impact on the story. The game, or story teller, or whatever you want to call it is constantly seizing the reigns and robbing the player of their agency. They have a very specific story that they want to relay to you, and if you go off the rails and try to deviate from their pre-determined story, the ST will not hesitate to usurp control of your character. 

Worse than that, they will take it upon themselves to lecture you, the player, as if you were a naive child, that your behavior was wrong and you should feel bad about the way you acted. I am dead, fucking serious about that!

This game is written by people who can not seperate reality from fantasy. It treats your in game decisions as if they were something you as a player would condone in real life. So it actively punishes you for behaving like a vampire, and not in a fun, or creative way.

In my previous version of the review, I said I might change my stance on this game not being recommended in the future. But now I have decided that this stance will be permanent. Fans of the World of Darkness, I emplore you: Do not buy this game. Do not support this kind of game design.

Do not allow 5th edition to do to World of Darkness what Kathleen Kenedy has done to Star Wars. Previous editions of the game might have been offensive to some people, but at least they had some god damn integrity. It realized the purpose of the game was to tell us a fun and interactive story, not to try and beat us over the head with the iron rod of politics!

column8: Swietna, klimatyczna gra, nie tylko dla fan√≥w wampir√≥w.

As much as I want to like this game - I have long awaited for its release -, I think it lacks the depth it would like to have. 
Don't get me wrong, the atmosphere is really great, and VTM fans will probably enjoy it a lot. I was completely into the game pretty quickly, despite being first disappointed by the lack of freedom regarding character choices (only three choices with fixed genders). I really felt I was going for a treat.
But then, after two hours problems start to be hard to ignore. There are little connections between side stories and the main plot - for example I completed the entire storyline with Benoit but the character just disappears after that and never makes it back into the story. The game moves very quickly so you don't really have the time to complete all side-quests - I actually only finished the story with D'Angelo and met Hope once before the ending started. It seems somehow my Brujah had access to all disciplines and not only three - for example I could Dominate one character. Hunger really has no influence on the game, to the point that I had the feeling I could ignore most feeding opportunities without consequences.
But the real issue is that the story railroads you very quickly and I believe there is very little replayability as it did not seem that any choices really mattered - actually hardly any choices seem to have big implications later on. 
The final twist is underwhelming because things just go too quickly for you to deeply care about what is going on. There was no building of mystery, no feeling of impending revelation. 
Also, I would have expected the last sentence/image to fade away much slower if it is really how the game is supposed to end, to at least create some sense of suspension. 
Apart from all this, again, the atmosphere is great, the dialogues are well-written, the sceneries and characters are beautiful (if not many in number). Buy it if you like this kind of story, but on sale.

column8:
https://niveloculto.com/analisis-coteries-of-new-york/

Casi siempre hay dos constantes en los vampiros: son inmortales y necesitan sangre para seguir existiendo. La inmortalidad puede tomar distintas formas o tener grados de dificultad a la hora de matarlos, pero lo m√°s claro es que el vampiro no perecer√° por viejo. Y lo de la sangre, si var√≠a, lo hace en la cantidad que pueda necesitar y en el destino de sus v√≠ctimas; ya sea que se alcen tambi√©n ellas como vampiros o simplemente que vayan enfermando por la exanguinaci√≥n. Luego pueden encontrarse decenas de variaciones sobre el mito, pero esas dos caracter√≠sticas son ininmutables y son, tambi√©n, las dos que yo busco cuando me pongo frente a una obra que incluya vampiros. Vampire the Masquerade: Coteries of New York es la √∫ltima a la que me enfrento, y quisiera fijarme bien en esas dos caracter√≠sticas, aparte del resto de su funcionamiento como videojuego.

Patreon Nivel OcultoComo saben, el t√≠tulo de Draw Distance se basa en la quinta edici√≥n de Vampiro: La Mascarada, el longev√≠simo juego de rol al que tambi√©n debemos adaptaciones como Bloodlines o el m√°s reciente We Eat Blood And All Our Friends Are Dead. El juego est√° viviendo una segunda no-vida tras la adquisici√≥n por parte de Paradox Interactive, que no s√≥lo est√° cediendo su licencia para videojuegos sino que lo ha vuelto a publicar. Lo interesante de esto es que Coteries of New York est√° pensado especialmente para el ne√≥fito, como casi siempre pasa con estas adaptaciones. Por eso nos va a poner en los pies de un vampiro reci√©n Abrazado (transformado) y nos va a zarandear por Nueva York un rato mientras nos ense√±a lo b√°sico de la sociedad secreta que ellos mismos constituyen y evita que sean descubiertos. Va a tomarse su tiempo y a intentar que entendamos bien todo lo que rodea a la existencia vamp√≠rica, pero a veces es tan exhaustivo y tan dirigido en sus primeras noches que cuando nos pongamos a rejugarlo puede hacerse algo pesado. Es el precio a pagar cuando quiere llegarse a todo el mundo, pero no estar√≠a de m√°s poder saltarse ese tutorial.

La estructura va a ser siempre la de una novela visual. Como he dicho, muy dirigida al principio, pero ya abri√©ndose cuando hayamos recibido la suficiente informaci√≥n sobre c√≥mo ser un vampiro y no liarla por el camino. A partir de ah√≠ se nos abre el mapa de la ciudad y tendremos que ir eligiendo personajes a los que visitar para atender a las distintas tramas. Me parece un acierto querer hacer del juego algo m√°s coral y que cada l√≠nea de misiones tenga una relaci√≥n clara con otro personaje: la existencia inmortal es solitaria, pero ya nos explican en el propio juego que acabaremos buscando la compa√±√≠a y hasta el antagonismo con otros para evitar el hast√≠o.

As√≠ que empezamos a jugar de verdad, y ser√° en estos compases cuando m√°s apreciaremos Coteries of New York. Sus creadores han tenido muy claro que en las novelas visuales es en la narraci√≥n cuando m√°s te la juegas, y han trabajado mucho en la escritura. En dos sentidos: por un lado lo que cuentan est√° bien contado y tratan de huir de los clich√©s con cierto √©xito; y por el otro saben darle a los conocedores del juego original el suficiente extra para que se sientan tan cuidados como el novato. Aqu√≠ hay apuestas arriesgadas y tipos de personaje que en mesa suelen salir muy mal, resueltos con bastante solvencia y sin torcer demasiado las reglas del juego. Tambi√©n hay tem√°ticas para todos, desde el politiqueo m√°s manipulador hasta la fe, la redenci√≥n o la rebeli√≥n.

Como adaptaci√≥n del juego de mesa tambi√©n se esmera en respetar tanto la trama del mismo con respecto a Nueva York como con cumplir con sus mec√°nicas. Al principio nos deja elegir entre tres clanes (‚Äúfamilias‚Äù vamp√≠ricas con una debilidad y una serie de poderes en com√∫n) y sabe hacer que la elecci√≥n sea significativa; ya sea variando la narraci√≥n como introduciendo los distintos poderes o notando m√°s dificultades para alimentarnos en el caso de uno de los clanes. Se echa de menos algo m√°s de hincapi√© en otros sistemas, pero en general cumple con mucho acierto con lo que un jugador de Vampiro: La Mascarada puede esperar.

Y, sin embargo, si vamos a las dos caracter√≠sticas de las que hablaba al principio, echo algo en falta. Est√° claro que la longitud del t√≠tulo influye, pero a veces se siente algo apresurado, como si no tuvieras toda la eternidad para maquinar y tramar. A la vez que se gestiona con elegancia que s√≥lo tengas las noches para actuar, limit√°ndote mucho las acciones, la sensaci√≥n de urgencia choca con el propio vampirismo. Pasa lo mismo con la sangre: quitando al clan Ventrue, que tiene restricciones de alimentaci√≥n (muy bien narradas), no es dif√≠cil en absoluto alimentarse. Es una pena que no tengamos la opci√≥n de, simplemente, dedicar unas horas a cazar. Tendremos que buscar v√≠ctimas en medio de las misiones, lo que rompe un poco el potencial de las mismas. Pienso que quiz√° ser√≠a m√°s aburrido dedicar toda una noche a cazar, pero que mostrar√≠a mucho mejor el cambio que se sufre de humano a vampiro; y de paso eso romper√≠a con las prisas y la necesidad de ir acometiendo misiones sin parar.

Dicho esto, creo que hay poco que reprochar a Coteries of New York. Es un videojuego peque√±o y contenido, pero tambi√©n rejugable y verdaderamente respetuoso con nuestras elecciones. Visualmente es una pasada y consigue meterte de lleno en esa sociedad de no-muertos ego√≠stas y asesinos; y como introducci√≥n al juego de rol puede funcionar a la perfecci√≥n y abrirle el apetito a m√°s de uno. Tiene cositas mejorables, pero son eso, cositas. Y a la vez ha entendido a la perfecci√≥n el material en el que se basa, ha cuidado mucho no contradecirlo ni enfrentarse a sus propias l√≥gicas, a la vez que ha huido de los clich√©s m√°s manidos del juego.

√âse es su mayor m√©rito: es una muy buena adaptaci√≥n de Vampiro: La Mascarada, pero tambi√©n ha tenido la osad√≠a de experimentar, de variar y de probar sin tener que transgredir el material original. Ah, y sus Malkavian no son una mierda.

column8: I love VTM the writing was good and the plot believable, but I prefer to have more agency in my games.  There aren't really that many outcomes like most visual novels.  I'm keeping the game as a collector of VTM stuff, but Bloodlines was 1000 percent better for the illusion of choice.

column8:
VAMPIRE: THE MASQUERADE: COTERIES OF NEW YORK is a video game set in the World of Darkness and developed by Polish company Draw Distance. More precisely, it is Visual Novel which consists of a "Choose Your Own Adventure"-esque text adventure. Your character is Embraced as a vampire one evening and have a limited amount of time to make a number of allies to help you against both the Second Inquisition as well as your fellow undead.

If you've played either those or [i]Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines[/i] you have a basic idea of how the game world goes: there are vampires, they live among us, they have a complicated royal court, and there's those vampires who rebel against them. The setting has been updated for the 5th Edition of the tabletop game with vampire hunters actively scouring the city for the undead (albeit under the cover of secrecy like their prey) and any slip ups potentially alerting them.

The game is moody and atmospheric with excellent writing. From the moment you begin the game, you are under the thumb of the Camarilla and they're ready to kill you for the slightest infraction. In my first playthrough, I got myself killed in the first ten minutes because I played the stereotypical rowdy Anarch. I played much more cautiously afterward and it proved to an interesting experience that reminded me of my own [i]Vampire: The Masquerade[/i] tabletop gaming sessions. 

I didn't know quite what to expect from the game but I got a solid three hour experience out of the game and immediately replayed it because I only got roughly half the content of the game before the "timer" ran out with events reaching their final conclusion. So, really, you need to play the game at least twice to experience all of the content as well as meet all of the game's characters.

You have three choices of Clan in the game with a male Asian American Brujah, a female Ventrue businesswoman, and a black gay male Toreador. This is good diversity to choose from but some fans will be annoyed that there's no opportunities to play Malkavians or Nosferatu. The lack of customization is a mild annoyance as I really liked the designs and dialogue is mostly the same between them (with the exception of one incredibly racist Anarch Baron).

There's no voice acting in the game but a enjoyable soundtrack, ambient noise, and lots of well-drawn art pieces to add to the text. This was a game definitely made on a budget but it is a perfectly functional visual novel experience. The price was worth it at twenty US dollars but buyers expecting something remotely similar to Bloodlines will be disappointed. They'll have to wait for the sequel coming out in 2020.

Gameplay-wise, 99% of the game consists of you talking to various characters and making decisions based on your actions. Do you trust this person? Do you act snarky or respectful? Do you kill someone or not? Sometimes you'll get options to use your Disciplines and they aren't always the ones your player character should possess. One interesting game mechanic is your character needs to regularly hunt and feed or they will become a savage wild animal who can't interact with other characters effectively. I thought that was very clever and was a far better use of the Beast and Hunger than Bloodlines.

The writing for the characters was very well done and I was especially fond of Hope, D'Angelo, and Sophie. Hope, in particular, is a internet streaming riot grrrl and Malkavian that is just my kind of Gothic Punk heroine. D'Angelo, despite looking too good for a Nosferatu, is a character that I love for being "Miami Vice Noir" in his attitude. Sophie is a typical Toreador elder with smiles and claws in equal measure. The supporting cast is all vividly realized and a lot of nods to the 2001 New York By Night supplement that I and a handful of other gamers remember.

I felt the plot was very well done with a complicated double, triple, and quadruple-cross-filled web of undead intrigue. I was disappointed that the games ending seems to be somewhat predestined to have one result but I still had a lot of fun. It really manages to capture the paranoia and lies that were central to the game. I would have appreciated more opportunities to work with the Anarchs but that's a mild disappointment.

In conclusion, I recommend [i]Coteries of New York[/i]. It is not going to be something that breaks the mold for horror gaming everywhere but it might lead to the creation of more of these set in the World of Darkness. It was short, sweet, and a familiar setting that I loved in the 90s (and love now). Keep your expectations moderate, though, as it's more like being at a tabletop session than anything else.

Has some fun moments and characters, but for the most part - is filled with baffling non-sequitors and illusory choices. The game treats you like a big part of the story, but in reality you never do anything that nobody else couldn't have done. Things just sort of... happen to you - you never feel like you are in the driver's seat. Not to mention that the few times the game gives you a choice, it will do its best to misremember what you did the next time it comes up - whether by design or because of a bug, I cannot say. Many of the plotlines feel unresolved by the end. Additionally, almost nothing is properly set up so that it feels like it's earned. If you are looking for an introduction to the World of Darkness you're better off playing VtM: Bloodlines. If you have played it and want to see how the world has changed in 20 years - you can give this game a shot. Either way, play at your own risk.

column8:
Should someone tell them this is not how you write an ending?

Gameplay issues:
- no instant text speed option;
- no skip function (yet, apparently);
- no manual saving;
- no quicksaving;
- you die - your save is wiped.

Story:
One playthrough - about 5 hours. 
Good-but-could-be-better in the process, and then it's SUDDENLY - THE END, ROLL CREDITS. Little replayability. Choices don't really matter, and there is only one ending. 
Really it feels like the bootleg VtMB novel by Argent Games did way better at being a good cohesive story than this official game.

Won't be mentioning technical issues since the game just launched. We'll see if it gets better with patches.

Thumbs up for being enjoyable*, at least. That and the really nice soundtrack.

* - only on the 1st playthrough. Going for more than one is sadly disappointing. The amount of content for the price is very underwhelming. 

My advice is to only buy on sale.

column8:
TLDR: Too short, decent writing, uninspired plot.

5.5 out of 10

Honestly if you read fast enough you can probably get a refund after finishing this novel. I might run another play through to see how different it is but I doubt it's very much. Less than four hours for twenty dollars? What is this, Call of Duty?

I mean I get why these games are expensive. The artwork and the music cost all of the money. Still, $5+ an hour for written non-voiced work is a bit much.

To be honest the game comes up short. The twist at the end was unoriginal and uninspired. The characters barely develop before the story ends. It's like watching a pilot for a show they never funded. Now if they had decided to make a series of several of these at like $8 a pop? I'd drop cash on that every month.

The writing is decent, however. If you're a fan of Vampire you'll probably enjoy it. For me, however, it's not worth the pricetag.

column8: No voice-acting, boring drawings, stupid dialog, poor writing skills. Also it is obvious that the choices you have make have no impact on the story. Pick up a good book, E.A. Poe or R.L. Stevenson - you have far more fun with those texts!

column9: I¬¥ve finished the first story,if you like the world of darkness you¬¥ll love this game

column8: Very interesting stories, good narration, overwhelming ambiance and music... If you're into narrative stuffs, especially into Vampire the Masquerade, this is such a great opportunity to enjoy yourself!

The game does justice to the VTM brand with the atmosphere and the lore adequacy, and the plot is interesting and intriguing on a first playthrough; you feel like you're doing a juggling act with your choices, and it's intense.

On a second playthrough, I noticed that everything happened pretty much in the same way, even though I made different "choices" and spent my time in different ways. The ending was EXACTLY THE SAME, and it gives me the feeling that this is the case no matter what you do. The hunger and power mechanics are flavorful but ultimately not impactful. A lot of characters are interesting but cannot be explored in any fashion. The unavoidable twist ending is narratively interesting but insulting from a game perspective, and kind of kills your desire to replay after realizing its inevitability.

Overall, I enjoyed the experience as a Vampire the Masquerade fan. I suppose it was like watching a movie or short series. I could have just read about it or watched some gameplay on YouTube, though. Maybe you'll want to do the same.

column8: Highly satisfying addition to the World of Darkness. Incredibly well written and paced with a ton of replay value. This visual novel is amazing. The setting, the world, the characters, the soundtrack - it really is incredible. My only wish was that there were both male & female options for each clan, and maybe additional clans to play as (physical gender would be a small detail that wouldn't have too much of an effect on the story). Great. I am anticipating Bloodlines 2 even more now.

column8:
Edit Dec 16th, 2019: This review was written before the developers clarified some of the previously grand statements made in the game's description. Though the nature of my review remains unchanged, I appreciate that future customers will have an easier time making the decision to buy or not buy. Kudos.

At time of writing I've finished my first playthrough and am...underwhelmed. The Steam tags should really allow you to emphasize one over the others, because this one would have a great big VISUAL NOVEL with not much else from the other tags.

What do I mean? Your ability to affect the story is INCREDIBLY limited, and I have a suspicious you literally cannot affect it at all. All answers seem to lead to the same results, and on at least one occasion I responded to a character and they answered as if I had chosen a completely different line. Characters call you unco-operative even if you weren't, and this feels much less like a story the player can affect and much more like a story the player just reads through. The Adelaide story in particular IMMEDIATELY railroads the player once they make nearly any choice, and is incredibly frustrating.

There is also very little feedback about the use of your characters Disciplines, and you frequently seem able to make use of Disciplines that aren't even normally available to your Clan of choice. At least once I attempted to Dominate someone and the game behaved as though nothing had happened, and one several occasions I was able to use Auspex (My Clan has Fortitude, Dominate and Presence).

All of this leads me to believe the game is pretending to be deeper than it really is. It's not bad, and if you enjoy the visual novel games I suspect this will be right up your alley. But it is much, much shallower than advertised, leading to moments of genuine fun surrounded by frustration and railroading.

And the non-ending was insulting.

column9: Solid tone and atmosphere for VtM. If you're a fan of the setting it's worth checking out

column8: Great art, solid writing, very well-developed characters. Absolutely a good value, especially for the price. No, it may not be the most polished game on the market, but a lot of love went into its development and that is plainly obvious when you give the game a chance. Recommended for fans of the source material and fans of a well-constructed narrative game.

column8:
The game feels... Unfinished. The ending seems to come out of the blue, and I'm pretty sure the actual "resolution" is currently bugged. Plenty of inconsistencies in the game's reaction to player choices (EG, if you're cordial and polite with someone, they'll complain that you were insulting them later.) Out of the 3 allies I've recruited (not sure if this is a bug), only 2 showed up in the end and honestly basically did nothing in the narrative short of a cameo. Like their feels like could have been done by Generic No-name Silhoute NPC. Beyond that the game feels fairly short, less than 4 hours for a single play through. Which compared to other VNs in this price range is a pretty bad deal. 

Which is a shame because game seems to have a lot of good ideas, it just never follows through on anything. It teases the idea of having ghouls work for you, but doesn't permit it. It teases a bunch of interesting characters, that are just completely forgotten about. It teases the idea of a reactive world with interesting companions, but then just sweeps them all under the rug once their story is done with. It teases the idea of deep political vampire intrigue, except you neither get to participate in it, nor make any coherent sense of it.

If you've got plenty of disposable cash and a few hours in the evening, feel free to give this a go, but the "game" just as a whole feels like a teaser for VtM: Bloodlines 2, rather than a game to stand on its own merits. Which I guess if that's what it wanted to do it succeeded, because I'm honestly just left with a thirst for more.

column8:
My only disappointment is that the story is so short.

The cost is not too terrible for what it is, as it would not be too bad for a novel of approximately the same length.  However, I am saying this after one play through and do not know if other choices would offer other endings.  All in all for the price it is acceptable.

The story does a good job of bringing you into the subtlety of the Vampire milieu and describing the details in a visceral and engaging manner.  Altogether an excellent introduction to the World of Darkness or a reminder of the rules of engagement for this particular brand.

Definitely suggested for a good read, but do not expect more than an introduction to a world, and not a immersion into it.

column8:
Likes: Good story, great art, great music. Excellent intro into the setting of V5.

Dislikes: Tons of typos. Some logic loops. Can finish the game accidentally and then be left with unfinished missions and storylines you can't go back to.

Major Dislike: I was playing along, doing the missions, when all of a sudden I'm on the mission that leads to the ending... NPCs are referencing scenes I haven't done, I'm completely confused, the finale comes and then the game is over. I can't tell if it was a bug, or if I somehow skipped a major scene (if so, I shouldn't have been able to progress).

column8:
I originally gave this a positive review (with stipulations) after finishing the game but after giving it a lot of thought I decided I can't recommend this. It's just too short and the story is too lacking. The game ends abruptly and it feels like my decisions had little to no impact whatsoever. Many of the major characters had nothing to do with the ending, and the only choices that do matter are simply survive or die. 

Despite the extreme lack of any character customization the clan I belong to was never once mentioned. It never had any impact on the story, and I was able to use bloodlines powers that would normally not even belong to my clan. It's the same with gender, there wasn't any reason that my character being male effected the story, there aren't any paths that lead to romance anyway other than I had an ex-girlfriend. Overall it's really disappointing.

column8: Story is short and your choices don't seem to have any impact on it. End comes suddenly and the story feels incomplete. No character customization and your coterie doesn't really have any purpose in the story. You just spend a week running errands before the inevitable ending comes. That said, the feeling is very VtM. So maybe buy when on sale, 20‚Ç¨ is like 15‚Ç¨ too much.

I was disappointed for all of ten minutes.  The game plays more like one of those choose-your-destiny-novels where you pick the action and get the part of the story that generates.  I wasn't happy that there was only three characters that are pre-made that I needed to choose from.  One might think this would be a deal breaker.  It's not.  

*Edit on 12/19/19 - The game description has been updated from its original.  Now we are forewarned that there are only three personalities you can choose from that are gender locked.*  

The story is well developed.  I only spotted two grammar problems, but they are easy to miss in editing.  'You' instead of 'You're' because a mere spell checker wouldn't know it's an improperly placed word.  

There's a ton of reading, of course, but the characters you get to meet and associate with are not shallow.  Choices can get you or the people in your new social circle killed.  

If you love Vampire games and adore the genre, this isn't too bad.  You can enjoy the story and make the choices that have some interesting consequences.  

If the Vampire genre isn't a special interest for you, take a pass on this one.  It's more like a Flash game than anything else, and the deep story on Vampire lore and the such may bore you.

Update on 12/19/19 - I did another play through as the female Ventrue.  Unlike the Brujah vampire I originally played, she can't hold down the blood and pukes it up unless it's premium 'clean' blood from a well educated human.  That is in line from the lore.  However, all of the major characters in the story do not change.  Your mentor and how you are assigned so far remains the same.  The only way to enjoy another play through without repeating dialog is to choose options you didn't select before.  Not all of those different options are healthy.  Enjoy!

column8:
Just finished my 3rd playthrough (although first one lasted less than 5 mins before i final death'd myself - a Ventrue's gotta do what a Ventrue's gotta do). I absolutely love WoD and this game was danse macabre at it's best - political scheming and sincere feeling of dread and paranoia in vampire society.

+ atmosphere
+ art and music
+ story and NPCs
+ lore

- choices don't actually matter that much, only one possible ending
- you cannot finish all quest lines in one playthrough (i recommend focusing 2 coterie quest lines and all other side quests, you cannot finish all coterie quests anyway even if you start them)
- very little variation between different protagonists story-wise

All in all, this is a great visual novel and i absolutely recommend it.

column8:
It's a pretty decent introduction game to Vampire The masquerade, with a lot of the common things you should know explained by the game in a handy dictionary if you're new.

The game itself is pretty fun, the story is pretty good, the ending however feels a little abrupt and all just happens in a rapid pace with no real closure, it almost feels like you just finished the first chapter of a multi chapter game?

There isn't a lot of replayability, you could do some quests slightly different with the different clan abilities but aside of doing quests you couldn't finish on time in your first playthrough. The ending seems pretty set in stone aside from maybe a few dialog lines.

Finished my first playthrough in roughly 4 hours, considering the quests I still had to do before the forced ending I'm guessing you can finish the content in about 8-12 hours if you want to try all 3 clans you can play. not too shabby for 20 euros but it really depends if you like the whole setting enough to sit through the mandatory story bits.

column8:
OLD REVIEW
So far I'll give it a "No". Played it for 2.5 hours. It felt somewhat good. The art is great. The writing is fine, but too much time is spend on explaining stuff. "Kindred", "Camarilla", "Clans", "Hunger", "Blood", "Primogen", "Prince", "Sheriff". Grew a bit bored with it, I don't really need a tutorial to VtM.

Then when I finally got to do something seemingly on my own and got a list of characters to recruit the game shut down. Then everything shut down because Windows decided that it's time for an update without asking. When it was over and I launched the game again I noticed that my save is "Night 1" and upon opening it, that it's the very very beginning of the game. Basically 2.5 hours of my time gone. I don't feel like replaying it again right now just to get to the part that I haven't seen. I may do it at some point with just clicking and not reading any stuff but... I'm tired of this night.

EDIT:
It's 1.5 year later today. Let me tell you what happened next

I replayed it. Got pretty far, up to Night 14. Then while transitioning from one scene to the other the game broke. The new scene didn't load and I couldn't do anything. The game has only one save that's overwritten constantly as you play, so I was unable to load game. The only way to get through it was to start over yet again. There was no "Skip" in the game, so replaying it yet again would take me another few hours. I even wrote to devs and they had no fix to what was a known and not that uncommon bug. I abandoned the game.

Yet I bought Shadows of New York, the standalone expansion/sequel. I had it in my library for some time until I decided to play it. I enjoyed it so much, that I decided to try Coteries yet again. The bug at Night 14 was supposedly fixed and they added the "Skip" option. 

It made the game so much better. I could just skip the boring intro and got to the actual story, or stories, because most plots are not connected. This visual novel feels more like visual short story collection. But those stories are pretty good. They are dark yet colorful. It's an amazing introduction to Vampire the Masquerade. Add to it gorgeus music and stunning art.

You might hear or read that the ending is bad and that your choices doesn't matter. Kinda on the latter and not on the former statement.  The ending is pretty bleak, yet open. It is the World of Darkness, Vampire the Masquerade, you are always a pawn. However I could see myself storytelling an actual VtM game with characters our protagonist and members of our coterie. 

I'm kinda rambling at this point... 

TL;DR
The game was bad on release, now it's fine. I recommend.
column9:
OLD REVIEW
So far I'll give it a "No". Played it for 2.5 hours. It felt somewhat good. The art is great. The writing is fine, but too much time is spend on explaining stuff. "Kindred", "Camarilla", "Clans", "Hunger", "Blood", "Primogen", "Prince", "Sheriff". Grew a bit bored with it, I don't really need a tutorial to VtM.

Then when I finally got to do something seemingly on my own and got a list of characters to recruit the game shut down. Then everything shut down because Windows decided that it's time for an update without asking. When it was over and I launched the game again I noticed that my save is "Night 1" and upon opening it, that it's the very very beginning of the game. Basically 2.5 hours of my time gone. I don't feel like replaying it again right now just to get to the part that I haven't seen. I may do it at some point with just clicking and not reading any stuff but... I'm tired of this night.

Top notch writing. I know it looks like a budget mobile text adventure game but the art is surprisingly good and the writing is fantastic. Definitely good if you don't mind or like text RPGs and especially if you like V:TM.

There are a few gameplay mechanics but this is primarily a visual novel. I'll let you all discover the rest, but it's worth $20.

Nach dem ersten durchspielen kann ich einfach nur sagen ich h√§tte gerne mehr gehabt...  allerdings passiert einem das wohl auch bei den meisten Pen & Paper Vampire Storys... die grobe Geschichte endet halt Irgendwann in diesem falle nach 7.7Std. laut Steam.

Hier die Gr√∂√üten Mankos:
Die fehlende Sprachausgabe und √úbersetzung in andere Sprachen sind leider ein Dicker Minuspunkt.
Desweiteren waren die eingebauten F√§higkeiten nat√ºrlich sehr Unspektakul√§r, die Eigenen, als auch die der anderen Charaktere. 
Kaum etwas wird √ºberhaupt ordentlich Dargestellt man findet sich oft 5-10min vor dem selben bild und man muss sich wirklich alles vorstellen was der Charakter dort wohl sehen mag. 
Ein Tatort? eine Ausgesaugte Leiche? ... Bisspuren?! ... kein Blut.... nichts davon werdet Ihr sehen. 
Coole K√§mpfe?! klar aber nur in eurem Kopf. 

Fazit:
Das spiel h√§tte an allen Fronten mehr gekonnt, allerdings kommt es daf√ºr auch zu einem angemessenem Preis.
Hier h√§tten die Entwickler mit ausreichend Budget und einem Gr√∂√üeren Verkaufspreis auch viel mehr leisten k√∂nnen.
So darf man das ganze als Pilot Projekt sehen. 
Und verdammt ja ich m√∂chte mehr gute World of Darkness Spiele, seien es auch Visual Novels. 
Jede Menge Potential f√ºr Interessante und Tolle Geschichten stecken hinter der Lizenz. 

Wenn man Visual Novels mag, ne Vampire Story erleben will, mit Entscheidungsm√∂glichkeiten und etwas Wiederspielwert greift zu. Aber erwartet keinen Meilenstein, mein Weg durchs spiel war Unterhaltend aber irgendwie auch 08/15.
